Les éventuels points obscurs sont maintenant peut-être éclaircis et la méthode développée dans ce livre devient plus claire. Gardez votre enthousiasme mais restez serein car la route est encore longue. Vous êtes maintenant familiarisé avec les index, et si ce n'est pas le cas, prenez quelques instants pour les feuilleter, car vous devrez parfois vous y reporter.  Chapitre treize Voyage  SI VOUS avez suivi pas à pas, peut-être sentez-vous croître votre impatience de lire 2223 histoires jusqu'à la fin du livre, mais il faudra rester vigilant et toujours rester maître de la situation. À chaque fois, vous devez former une image vive, afin que le caractère concerné ne s'efface pas de votre mémoire au fur et à mesure. Tous les détails ne sont pas toujours précisés mais vous devrez faire le même travail que celui mené jusqu'à présent. Pour chaque kanji possédant plusieurs significations sans relation apparente, nous les préciserons et offrirons un moyen simple de mémorisation. Voici un groupe de caractères ayant trait au voyage, et les composants qui les accompagnent : une route, une paire de jambes qui marchent et une voiture.

column11: The key word carries both the sense of a road for transit and a way or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the neck of a road. Think of a crowded road-way where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a "bottleneck."  -    -  When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that´s why I take the train! ).  -  Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel´s neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it´s precious contents into the dust?
column12: Ce kanji représente une voie par laquelle transitent des choses diverses : des véhicules, des connaissances : le sens de ce kanji ne diffère guère de celui du mot clé français. On le dit cou…route. Pensez à une chaussée sur laquelle un ralentissement provoqué par un « goulet d’étranglement » nous contrat à rouler ou pas.  --

column11: When we accept someone's guidance, we permit ourselves to be glued to a certain road or way of doing something, and try to "stick" to it.  -    -  For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.  -  Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.
column12: En acceptant les directives d’un autre, on accepte la voie proposée, en y adhérant coûte que coûte.  --

column11: Take the first two strokes in the sense we gave them back in frame 10, as the pictograph of a cross, and set it on a road to create a "crossing."  -    -  Cross-road.  -  This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a cross by the road, at a busy crossing, marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby´s death.
column12: Prenez les deux premiers traits dans le sens que nous avions utilisés aux cadres 16, comme étant la représentation d’une croix, et placez-les sur la chaussée pour obtenir l’image de passages zébrés japonais, traçant les deux diagonales sur le carrefour.  --

column11: Here we see a crossing in the form of a barbed fishhook, suggesting a swifter alternate not only to the roundabouts used in Europe but also to the "cloverleaf" design used on superhighways in the United States.  -    -  The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.  -  In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero ´froggy´ forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.
column12: Ici se trouve un carrefour surmonté du hameçon. Imaginez une grue géante placée au-dessus du carrefour, et saisissant les voitures qui ne seraient pas assez vives au démarrage lorsque le feu passe au bleu.  --

column11: Think of creating as making something out of nothing. Then recall how the way of revelation laid out in the Bible begins with the story of how God created the world out of a dark and chaotic nothingness.  -    -  A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.  -  CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you´re feeling artsy) :).
column12: Penser aux créateurs, capable de créer quelque chose à partir de « rien », ou plus exactement à partir d’une idée qui lui a été soufflé par la « voie de la révélation ».  --

column11: To urge someone to do something, you make the way as appealing as possible, perhaps even whitewashing it a bit.  -    -  When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it´s time to hit the road.  -  When you start down the road of cocaine, you´re sure to feel some pretty bad URGEs soon.
column12: Harceler quelqu’un consiste à le « chauffer à blanc », pour qu’il se lance sur sa route.  --

column11: When escaping from something or someone, one always feels as if one is not going fast enough, like a turtle on an expressway. (Since the turtle is on the road and not on the left, it can keep its full kanji shape as given in frame 250.)  -    -  I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!  -  A turtle version of frogger dodging cars to escape to the other side of the road...　　　RTK2:　トウ　逃走　とうそう(escape)...　　　　　　　MIXED GROUP:　桃236　(ﾁｮｳ): 兆235　眺237　挑658　跳1284.
column12: Quand on s’évade, on a l’impression de ne pas aller assez vite, comme une carapace de tortue sur l’autoroute. Notons aussi que s’évader et une façon de s’écarter. Comme la carapace de tortue est ici placée sur la route, et non à gauche du caractère, elle garde la forme complète vue au cadre 250.  --

column11: To keep the environs clean and safe, you could cement daggers in the road, blades pointed upwards, so that no polluting traffic could pass by. You could, if you were an ecologically-minded terrorist.  -    -  Caution: this kanji doesn´t mean environment; it means "environs; boundary; border; vicinity". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.  -  To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords.
column12: Pour que les environs restent propres et sûrs, vous pourriez planter des poignards sur la route, pointés vers le haut, pour que aucun véhicule polluant ne puisse y passer : vous le feriez cibles et une sorte de terroriste à tendance écologiste.  --

column11: A virtual flood of motorcycle police washing down a road is this kanji's image for a patrol.  -    -  The cops don´t PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.  -  The Venice cops patrol on river roads.
column12: Un déluge de motocyclistes balayant la chaussée et l’image que suggère le kanji patrouille.  --

column6: cart, vehicle; carry in a cart; Kangxi radical 159
column11: You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, car, provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.  -  * Car, cart, wagon, and vehicle may all be used as primitive meanings.  -  My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.  -  Rather than hobbling along with a walking stick to cross through a span, it´s much better to use a car. (Imagine an old man with a walking stick creeping along a span of road, and you, in a car, whizzing right by him. It´s funny ´cause it´s true.) Also, it´s important to include the word "through," so you know the walking stick goes right THROUGH the span.
column12: Ce kanji est le caractère générique de véhicule, du vélo à la voiture de chemin de fer en passant par le fer de lance de l’économie japonaise dont on s’amusera voir un pictogramme : remarquer les essieux avant et arrière, les quatre sièges et l’arbre de transmission.  --  * De même qu'une voiture japonaise se trouve en temps normal à gauche, ce com- posant se trouvera en temps normal à gauche au sein des kanjis où il apparaît.

column10: Emmener, rame, se mettre en rang, s'unir, série
column11: What you are meant to take along in this kanji are not things but people. The image of the car on the road should ground your image for picking up your friends to take them along to wherever you are going.  -    -  When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don´t confuse with carry (#303).  -  This kanji also means "linked" or "series" so I´ve changed the kanji meaning to "GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)." Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the "Union" in Soviet Union and the "United" of United Nations (the countries that "go along with each other" at least some of the time).
column12: Comme en français, la distinction est faite en japonais entre emporter (quelque chose) et emmener (quelqu’un). Cependant si en français de l’idée de emmener suggère « de se prendre par la main », il ne peut en être de même en japonais, car cela supposerait alors un contact physique avec le prochain, choses presque impossible au Japon en temps normal. Le caractère de emmener nous montre donc un véhicule sur une route : le véhicule dans lequel vous emmenez vos amis ou bon vous semble.  --  Si vous pouvez imaginer ce véhicule sous la forme d’une rame de métro, ce sera encore mieux. Car ce caractère signifie aussi se mettre en rang, s’unir, comme le font les wagons de la rame, ou encore série, dans son sens plus général.

column11: Combine the primary and secondary meanings of this keyword to form your story. Begin with the car whose tires get caught in a rut and spin without going anywhere. Then go onto the baseball team who can't win a game because it has fallen into a rut of losing.  -    -  My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.  -  I got my car stuck in a rut ! I´m gonna have to call 999 !
column12: Véhicule…neuf : Vous avez décidé d'étrenner votre voiture neuve. C'est dimanche, tout le monde a pris place dans la voiture et vous voilà partis vers la forêt pour tester votre acquisition. Sur l'autoroute le véhicule neuf roule comme sur des rails (sens associé) ; puis vient la forêt et bientôt, vous louvoyez entre les ornières creusées la veille par les tracteurs forestiers.  --

column11: On the left we see a vehicle used for transport. On the right, we see a new tangle of elements that need sorting out. The first three strokes, you will remember, are the primitive for meeting. Below it we see the elements for flesh and saber, which combine to create a compound element for a butcher and his trade. Together they give us the image of a "trucker's convoy."  -    -  The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher´s meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.  -  The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.
column12: A gauche trône autre véhicule, et à droite un ensemble qui mérite analyse. Vous aurez reconnu le composant assemblée dans les trois premiers traits. Puis apparaissent la chair et le sabre, qui nous permettent de voir dans cet ensemble l’étale d’un boucher. Il ne reste alors qu’à imaginer les grands quartiers de et les gros coutelas dans le camion de transport du boucher.  --

column11: We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the butcher hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's horns placed in front of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for before (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book.  -    -  When I get horny my flesh sword sticks out in front of me.  -  If you stand in front of a bull´s horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).
column12: Nous avons attendu jusqu'ici pour présenter ce kanji, bien que ses composants soient connus depuis longtemps, car il permet de consolider l'image précédente. Voyez le boucher trancher une grosse pièce de viande, les deux cornes de l'animal placées devant de lui.  --

column11: "Suum cuique" goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see someone walking with his/her mouth between his/her walking legs, giving us an image of "To each his/her own."  -  * The sense of the proverb should help when using this kanji as a primitive; otherwise, reduce it to its original elements. But do not associate it in any way with the word "every," which we shall meet later in another context.  -  Son, I´ve never told you this but each woman has a second mouth between their fiiiiiine walking legs.  -  Each and every one of us walks and talks differently.
column12: Chacun a sa façon de marcher, et sa façon de parler. C’est ce que nous rappelle ce kanji, qui s’est ingénié à se faire le plus petit possible, à la façon de nos proverbes, quitte a placé la bouche entre les jambes qui marchent.  --  Veiller à ne pas associer cet élément à l’idée de « tous les » (chaque), évoque la répétition de choses semblables et que nous verrons cadre 511.

column11: If you can imagine trees as status symbols (as they might well be for those living in Japan's congested cities, where greenery has become something of a luxury item), then each might be aiming to have his/her own tree, just to keep up with the Suzukis.  -    -  Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree. "Errr, Each tree sir?" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. "That´s Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!".  -  A man measures his own status by the size of his woody...and compares it to each one he sees.
column12: Si l’on conçoit l’arbre comme symbole du rang auquel on appartient (et dans les cités congestionnées du Japon, cela pourrait bien être le cas), alors chacun pourrait être tenté d’avoir son propre arbre, pour tenir la dragée haute aux voisins.  --

column11: Each field has its own abbreviations (chemistry, philosophy, sports, etc.). Needless to say, the "stronger" primitive - thatis to say, the simpler and more often used one - takes the dominant position on the left, even though the story would read them off the other way around.  -    -  There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.  -  A very anal farmer wants to catologue each grain of rice in his rice field. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain.
column12: Chaque champ ou domaine a ses propres abions . Il va sans dire que le composant le plus « fort » va prendre la place clé, à gauche, bien que l’histoire tende à nous les faire écrire dans l’autre sens.  --

column11: When you are a guest in a courteous town, each household has its own way of welcoming you, and each house becomes your home.  -    -  Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.  -  In my house I welcome each guest.
column12: Si vous êtes l’hôte d’une ville accueillante, chaque maisonnée aura sa propre façon de vous recevoir, et chaque maison deviendra un peu votre maison.  --

column11: As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect, one does not look straight into the eyes of one's guests, but focus on the top button of their collar. Here, however, you are told to look above the eyes to the forehead of your guest.  -    -  Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).  -  In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together.
column12: Plein de respect, vous ne regardez pas votre hôte droit dans les yeux, mais sur la place de sa tête située juste au-dessus, le front.  --  Sans raison valable, ce kanji signifie également montant d’argent.

column11: In the summer, fatigued by the heat, your head hangs down nearly as far as your walking legs, or rather, your "dragging legs." Note how the walking legs (instead of "animal legs") are the only thing that distinguishes this character from that for page (Frame 64).  -    -  In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.  -  I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.
column12: En été, fatigué par la chaleur, votre tête prend à la hauteur de vous jambes qui marchent en râclant le sol. Notez comment les pattes de que l’on utilise pour écrire tête ont été remplacés par les jambes qui marchent au cours du processus.  --

column11: Both the stretching out of the walking legs and the little bit of wind tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or dispose of it.  -    -  The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.  -  To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.
column12: Voilà présentée une façon toute simple de traiter une affaire. Les jambes qui marchent s'allongent jusqu'à la table, où l'on apporte les affaires à traiter. Cette situation nous convient bien, car le même kanji porte aussi le sens de lieu. En pratique, il s'agit sans doute du lieu où nous traitons cette affaire.  --

column11: Geppetto made walking legs for his little Pinocchio from two twigs of a tree, giving him a set of "twiggy" shanks.  -    -  Pinocchio's Walking Legs (which resemble Twigs) are Articles made out of Wood. Using this story you can remember both meanings for this kanji: article and twig.  -  (Doesn't mean TWIG!!! Actually means "Article".) I once read an ARTICLE about a guy whose walking legs were made from tree twigs.
column12: Pour faire les jambes qui marchent à son Pinocchio, Gepetto avait utilisé deux brindilles taillées dans un arbre.  --  De brindilles, le sens de ce caractère a dérivé de façon générale à diverses choses longues et fines comme des brindilles. Vous découvrirez les détails au cours de vous lectures, mais il est bon de ne pas se limiter strictement au sens de brindille.

column11: When water falls, it splats and splashes; when flower petals fall, they float gently in the breeze. To each thing its own way of falling.  -    -  Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.  -  [It´s been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also dilute (#227), clan (#1912), seaweed (#2035). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down.
column12: Quand l’eau tombe, cela éclabousse. Quand les végétaux tombent, elles glissent doucement dans l’air. A chacun sa façon de tomber.  --  NOUS allons faire un petit pas dans le processus de sevrage, cette fois en ce qui concerne l'ordre des tracé des kanjis, en indiquant désormais l'ordre d'écriture composant par composant. En cas de doute, vous devrez donc consulter l'index pour y chercheer le composant qui vous embarrasse. Toutefois, les composants nouveaux ou les écritures exceptionnelles seront précisées comme auparavant. En tout cas, il serait bon de compter par vous-même l'ordre des traits, et d'en vérifier la concordance avec le nombre indiqué. Reprenons notre chemin, pour aborder cette fois une zone où il est écrit : couronnes et chapeaux.

column11: Picture a weather vane beneath a regal crown, spinning round and round. It is not only superfluous but makes a perfect ass out of the one who wears it.  -    -  The king´s crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it´s just a superfluous symbol.".  -  The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King´s court. This kanji is read as "JOU" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-employee (#56).
column12: Imaginer une couronne royale au sommet d’une girouette (retourner voir le 575 vent au besoin). Quoi de plus superflu ?  --

column11: The crowned vehicle depicted here is a "chariot," symbol of an army.  -  * Used as a primitive this kanji means only chariot.  -  British army cars are at the service of the crown.  -  Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.
column12: Voici un véhicule avec une couronne, soit un char militaire et sa tourelle, symbole de toutes les armées.  --  On utilisera aussi le sens de char militaire en composant.

column11: Take advantage of the first syllable of the key word to think of the ray of light to the left. Now add the glittering chariot that is emitting those rays and you have radiance.  -    -  Rays of light emitted from Apollo´s chariot = radiance. Don´t put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!  -  Radiance is an army of rays.
column12: Le mot-clé est à prendre tant au sens propre qu’au sens figuré. Voyez d’abord les rayons puis le char « rayonnant » qui les envoie.  --

column11: A long string of "sweet" chariots "swinging low" to our roads is a sure sign that the Lord is "comin' for to carry" someone home.  -    -  Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).  -  Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).
column12: Le char est ici placé sur la route est là pour transporter diverses choses. Le kanji porte le sens secondaire de chance, un peu à la manière du français transporter qui évoque aussi l’enthousiasme.  --

column11: By having the crown pass from one age to the next, a people keeps itself glued to its beginnings.  -    -  Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".  -  A crown, from the beginning of the new king´s life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.
column12: La couronne, transmise de génération en génération, permet un peuple de garder la mémoire de ses origines, ce qui est montré ici graphiquement avec les éléments commencement…collé.  --

column11: To have a dream after going to bed is really the crown to a perfect evening. The flower petals over the eyes (instead of the "sand" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirms the image of a pleasant dream suggested by the rest of this rather complex kanji.  -    -  Last night´s date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.  -  In the movie American Beauty, Kevin Spacey liked to DREAM about his daughter´s friend and have a rose petal fall onto his eye from the ceiling. He did this lying in his bed each evening. You can almost see him lying in his bed in this kanji.
column12: Le rêve permet peut-être d'adoucir notre quotidien, comme parfois les plantes permettent de le faire. Lors du rêve, le cerveau rassemble les principaux événements de notre journée dans une sorte de filet et nous en fait une sorte de projection privée, pour bien couronner notre soirée.  --

column11: A whirlwind begins to dig its way into the soil like a drill until it makes a deep pit.  -    -  A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.  -  Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.
column12: Le poltergiest a creusé la terre au point d’y former une fosse.  --

column6: high, tall; lofty, elevated; Kangxi radical 189
column11: Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the mouth under the extraterrestrial's glass hood, and then the mouth under the top hat of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much taller than everyone else.  -  * As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of tall and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated to the first 5 strokes.  -  Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.  -  Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).
column12: Rappelant l'image vue en 193, voyez votre ami sous sa coiffe, qui vous crie quelque chose, et derrière lui une autre bouche, plus un chapeau : un autre ami sans doute, plus grand que lui puisqu'il dépasse un peu.   --  En composant, cet élément sera abrégé en sa partie supérieure : .

column11: Tall children receive more attention. Tall children grow up to make better wide receivers. Take your pick, depending on whether you prefer child psychology or American football. At any rate, be sure you have some particular tall child in mind, someone who really was outstanding and always attracting attention, because he or she will come in handy in the next two frames.  -    -  In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.  -  Tall children receive all the attention. They also make great receivers in football... this kanji also means ´catch´ (therefore a football receiver is a great image).
column12: Les grands enfants jouissent de plus d’attention que les petits, et ils grandissent encore.  --

column11: Cram schools are after-hours educational institutions where kids can do concentrated preparing for their coming entrance examinations or drill what they missed during regular class hours. The exception are the tall children who are out on the school grounds practicing sports, and the fat ones who are out there burning off calories. So this character depicts those who do NOT go to the cram schools, rather than those who do.  -    -  Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.  -  You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school says the advertisement. "Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!".
column12: Ces écoles de bachotage sont de véritables institutions au Japon. Le kanji montre les exceptions, les grands enfants qui sont aussi ronds doivent aller sur le terrain de sport brûler les calories en trop.  --

column11: The tall and fat children from the last frame are here cast into a cauldron over an oven flame until they have sufficiently mellowed that they can return to the normal life of a student.  -    -  Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.  -  The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the tall and fat ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they mellow. (Note that here the keyword ´mellow´ only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of ´chill out´).
column12: Ses enfants grands et gras, dispensés de cours du soir, sont ici jetés dans un chaudron jusqu’à ce qu’ils soient bien mûrs et puissent reprendre leur vie d’écolier.  --

column11: Think of all the pavilions at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering tall crowned nail (the crown being a revolving restaurant) - that architectural monstrosity that has become a symbol of science and technology at such events.  -    -  The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.  -  The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.
column12: Penser à une exposition universelle, que vous auriez visitée ou vue dans l’immédiat, et bientôt voir apparaître le pavillon-clou de l’exposition, haut clou couronné d’un restaurant, monstruosité architecturale devenue le symbole de la science et de la technique modernes.  --

column11: When we think of a capital city today we think of tall skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of little folk scurrying here and there about their business.  -    -  Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).  -  The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done.
column12: Parmi toutes les villes d’un pays, la capitale est en principe la plus grande, et en tous les cas celle où l’on prend le plus conscience de sa propre petitesse. Fait ce que nous content tous les éléments grand et petit.  --  Je ne sais trop pourquoi, mais ce kanji est également la puissance quatrième de myriade. Il est capital que vous calculiez vous même ce plus grand nombre, et vous conclurez que vous ne risquez pas de le voir utilisé bien souvent, comme c’est le cas.

column11: Since few things are as refreshing on a warm day as a cool shower (the water), here we picture an entire capital city treating itself to one, and in full view of everyone.  -    -  When you´re a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.  -  The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!
column12: Parmi toutes les villes d’un pays, la capitale est sans doute celle qui a le plus besoin d’une bonne douche rafraîchissante pour se rafraîchir de l’activité intense qui y règne jour et nuit.  --

column11: Scenery is depicted as a sun rising over a capital city, which is a bit of natural scenery the city dwellers themselves rarely get to see!  -    -  Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.  -  Anyone who´s been to Kyoto doesn´t need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there´s no better scenery.
column12: Parmi toutes les villes d'un pays, la capitale est sans doute celle qui porte les visiteurs à fixer le soleil rougeoyant au-dessus des immeubles et illuminations, pour donner l'image mémorable d'un échantillon de paysage.   --

column11: The whale swallows a whole school of fish, who turn their new abode into a proper little fish-capital.  -    -  If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.  -  When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!
column12: Sans doute ce kanji est-il eut une énormité, qui place la baleine dans la catégorie des poissons, mais cela nous donne l’occasion de penser que le mot clé poisson que nous avions alors attribuées est peut-être trop précis. Néanmoins, le kanji baleine résume bien l’intérêt capital que l’on a porté de tous temps au plus grand des mammifères, et qui suscite encore beaucoup d’intérêt auprès des pêcheries japonaises.  --

column11: A lidded crock with an umbrella overhead gives us a mixture of the modern and the nostalgic in this design for a cottage.  -    -  The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth.  -  My vacation cottage is nothing but a hole in the ground covered by an umbrella.
column12: Un parapluie et une poterie à couvercle donnent un mélange de modernité et de nostalgie dans ce dessin d’une chaumière, dont le sens a dérivé à celui de logements.  --

column11: Look more closely at your lidded crock and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the circumference of your motorcycle helmet: just begin at a fixed point and turn the lidded crock around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the helmet, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your lidded crock made, you now know the circumference.  -  * As a primitive, this character can take the added significance of a lap.  -  If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.  -  You´re at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.
column12: Regardez votre poterie à couvercle de plus près, et vous verrez de petite graduation sur son bord inférieur. Grâce à ces graduations, vous pouvez mesurer la circonférence de la cloche de verre qui l’entoure : partant d’un point donné, vous faites rouler la poterie dans la cloche, jusqu’à revenir au point de départ. Il ne vous reste plus qu’à compter le nombre de tours qu’aura fait la poterie durant l’opération délicate qu’est la mesure de la circonférence.  --  Nous assignerons à ce composant les sésames suivants : révolution, tour, ou cycle.

column11: Picture a circular road with 7 markers on it, one for each day of the week. When you have walked one complete lap on this road, you shall have completed one week.  -    -  Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.  -  Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. circumference (#317) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.
column12: Imaginer une route circulaire comportant sept étapes. Quand vous aurez parcouru les sept étapes, et aurez ainsi fait le tour complet, une semaine se sera écoulée.  --

column11: The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for soil by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's gentlemen.  -  * The primitive meaning reverts to the more colorful image of the samurai, Japan's warrior class.  -  What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He´s like a modern samurai!  -  A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn´t soil himself.
column12: La forme de ce kanji, différente de celle de sol en vertu du trait final tracé plus court, nous révèle un guerrier aux larges épaules, posté en observation. Le sens actuel du caractère s’apparente à guerrier, spécialiste des arts martiaux ou d’une technique particulière, mais aussi érudit, tous grands connaisseurs de leur sujet.  --

column11: Here we see a samurai standing on a street with an open mouth, which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for good luck.  -  * As a primitive, we shall take this shape to mean an aerosol can, from the mouth and the very tightly-fitting lid (note how it differs here from the lidded crock).  -  The samurai´s wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for good luck.  -  A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, "Good luck" to his opponents before a match.
column12: Notre vieux professeur à maintenant la bouche grande ouverte, car il nous souhaite « bonne chance » pour le chemin qu’il nous reste à faire. Le sésame sera bombe aérosol, compte tenu de l'ouverture et du couvercle bien serré qui la ferme. Remarquez comment cette forme diffère de la poterie à couvercle.  --

column6: big, large; robust; name of tribe
column11: Robust is seen as a turtle turned samurai.  -    -  Half of a turtle shell as a shield makes a samurai more robust.  -  The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are robust gentlemen aren´t they?
column12: Robuste nous est donnée par l’image du vieux professeur protégé par de forts madriers de chêne placés devant lui.  --

column11: The villa pictured here is filled with exotic flowers at every turn, and has a pair of turtle-samurai standing before its gates.  -    -  A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.  -  The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don´t get suspicious.
column12: Cette superbe villa est ornée de plantes à ses fenêtres. Eh non, vous ne rêvez pas : c'est bien la résidence de notre vieux professeur, protégé par une barrière de forts madriers de chêne.  --

column11: A samurai, out of a job, is going door-to-door selling little windup crowns with human legs that run around on the floor looking like headless monarchs.  -    -  The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me?  -  A "samurai" will never sell his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!
column12: Le vieux professeur, retiré de la vie active, vend ses possesions. Il a tout placé dans un grand filet sur le trottoir et harangue les chalands. Rappelons bien q ue, comme nous avons vu avant 328,  est un filet, une sorte d'ampliation de . Le filet est un objet essentiel pour le commerce.  --  Chapitre quinze Étude  NOTRE chemin nous mène en face d'une grosse maison où il est écrit : école. Pénétrons dans la bâtisse, et assurons-nous d'accorder aux histoires assez de temps pour qu'elles s'installent confortablement en notre esprit.

column11: The child in the little red schoolhouse is there for one reason only: to study. Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that study is one thing and learning quite another again. In the kanji, too, the character for learning (Frame 616) has nothing to do with the schoolhouse.  -    -  In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字).  -  Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!
column12: L'enfant dans l'école n'y est que pour une seule raison : étudier. Quiconque a suivi le cursus scolaire sait que apprendre est une chose, et étudier en est une autre. Il en est de même dans les kanjis, qui nous présenteront le kanji « apprendre » sans aucun lien avec l'école.  --

column6: to wake up from sleep; conscious
column11: The idea of memorizing things is easily related to the schoolhouse; and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that memorizing involves seeing things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together.  -    -  In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it.  -  You´ll never memorize all the kanji by seeing them in a school house. You need Heisig and RtK!
column12: L’idée de mémoriser est aisément reliée à l’école. Comme nous l’avons fait depuis le début de ce livre, le fait que mémoriser implique de voir des choses qui ne sont pas réellement présentes devraient nous aider à mémoriser, ou à nous rappeler ce kanji.  --  Ce caractère contient aussi la notion de perception, ou sens. On peut le comprendre en considérant que la mémoire peut être perçue comme un sixième sens : celui de voir les choses qui ne sont pas. Corollairement, la notion de réveil, le moment où nos sens reprennent connaissance, y est aussi incluse.

column11: The botanical connotations of the word flourish (to bud and burst into bloom, much as a tree does) are part of the ideal of the schoolhouse as well.  -    -  The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there´s no room for the students any more.  -  Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.
column12: Ce kanji correspond à l’ancien verbe florir, dont ne subsiste que le participe présent florissant. Ce kanji montrant un arbre à l’école n’est utilisé en effet que dans le sens de prospérité.  --

column11: The sage talks rapidly with his tongue wagging in his mouth, while the brush of the scribe runs apace to write down the master 'swords.  -    -  Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.  -  The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her brush to write, she would stick out her tongue, just slightly.
column12: Le sage parle rapidement, et sa langue s'agite dans sa bouche, tandis que le scribe, armé de son pinceau, écrit les mots du maître.  --  RÈGLE 7 : Un trait vertical coupant plusieurs horizontaux se trace en dernier.

column11: Seeing the tiny boats of poor mortals tossed about in a stormy sea like so many corks, the All-Merciful took its brush and drew little inlets of water where the hapless creatures might seek shelter. And so it is that we have havens.  -    -  A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.  -  The haven for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!
column12: Voyant les bateaux des pauvres mortels en perdition dans une mer agitée, le tout puissant pris sa plus belle plume, pour tracer au milieu de l’eau de petits havres dans lesquels les créatures à la merci des éléments purent trouver refuge.  --

column11: When it is time to breed new cattle, the bull is usually willing but the cow is often not. Thus the taskmaster to the right forces the cow into a compromising position, so to speak, so that she and her mate can breed.  -    -  Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start breeding, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.  -  Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don´t differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.
column12: À l’heure de la tétée, le veau est en général bien disposé, mais la vache est quelquefois récalcitrante. Le chef de corvée est ici installé à sa place-clé, à droite, forçant l’animal à prendre la position requise. Une autre façon de comprendre le caractère consiste à énoncer qu’il « faut beaucoup d’énergie pour l’élevage des vaches ».  --

column11: The special craft of successful taskmasters is their ability to remain constantly on the aggressive, never allowing their underlings a moment to ponder a counter-aggression of their own.  -    -  Aggression is the craft of a good dominatrix.  -  AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.
column12: La qualité particulière du bon chef de corvée, dont le travail est res­pecté, est d’être suffisamment agressif, respectant en cela l’adage selon lequel l’agression est la meilleure des défenses.  --

column11: The taskmaster is acknowledging the failure of a clam to make the grade in some marine school or other.  -    -  If you end up in failure, you give money to the taskmaster to train you.  -  The shell who was defeated before (defeat (#63)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.
column12: Le chef de corvée prend les huîtres et les ouvre une par une. Une fois son travail terminé, elles sont toutes vaincues et le festin peut commencer.  --

column6: stalk of shrub, trunk of tree
column10: Feuille de, compteur des objects plats
column11: English counts thin, flat objects, like bed linen and paper, in sheets. The kanji does this with a taskmaster whipping a tree into producing sheets against its will.  -    -  The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers.  -  This taskmaster is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many sheets of toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed.
column12: Voici le compteur des objets plats, que l’on appelle des feuilles en français ; et il faut beaucoup d’énergie pour découper un arbre en feuilles.   --

column11: Call it fate or providence or plain old Lady Luck, happenstance is the oldest taskmaster we know. It nearly always has its way.  -    -  An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.  -  Need to disambiguate from enemy (#443) as it´s easy to mix up antique and old here. Let´s think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .
column12: Qu’on l’appelle providence ou destinée, le destin est notre plus vieux chef de corvée. En quelque sorte, il symbolise l’énergie qui peu à peu nous conduit à vieillir.   --

column11: Standing in awe of someone, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in flowery phrases out of veneration or fear. The taskmaster at the right is drilling you in the practice of your "honorifics."  -    -  The flowery phrases of the schoolmaster held the students in awe.  -  敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don´t talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.
column12: Quand on est plein de respect pour quelqu’un, on tente de lui parler en phrases belles comme des belles plantes, et cela demande de la bonne volonté, de l’énergie.   --

column6: words, speech; speak, say; Kangxi radical 149
column11: Of all the things we can do with our mouths, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for say has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.  -  * This kanji, which appears often as a primitive, can mean saying, speech, or words, depending on which is most useful.  -  A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.  -  This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.
column12: Parmi tout ce que faisons avec la bouche, la parole est sans doute la chose la plus complexe, qui exige le plus de clarté. C’est ce que semble nous souffler le kanji dire, qui porte quatre petites « ondes » au-dessus de la bouche. Mais lisons Alfred Tomatis, qui exprime si bien cette idée : « Lorsque vous parlez, le son s’écoule de votre bouche comme le flot qui déborde d’un bassin trop plein. Il inonde tout votre corps sur lequel il s’étale. Chaque onde syllabique se déverse et déferle sur vous d’une manière inconsciente mais certaine². » ² Alfred Tomatis l'Oreille et le langage (1991) éd. du Seuil, p.11  --  Lorsqu'il apparaît en composant, ce kanji sera rendu par les sésames dire, mot, discours, selon la nécessité et en accord avec l'usage qu'en font les Japonais. Notez aussi que le tracé à la main diffère légèrement de la forme imprimée.

column11: Words and a meter's needle combine to form the sense of plot: to talk over plans and to calculate a course of action.  -    -  A plot is a summary of a book that can be given in ten words.  -  Say-ten´s (satan´s) evil plot.
column12: Les mots et l'aiguille - branche (d'un compas) symbolisent les outils de l'architecte, et se combinent pour former l'idée de calculer ou planifier.   --

column11: Here you have a perfect example of how an apparently impossible snarl of strokes becomes a snap to learn once you know its elements. The idea of being admonished for something already sets up a superior-inferior relationship between you and the person you are supposed to stand in awe of. While you are restricted to answering in honorifics, the superior can use straightforward and ordinary words.  -    -  To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.  -  Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you´ve never heard her use before.
column12: Respect...mots. Voici l’exemple intéressant d’un caractère à peu près impossible à retenir pour qui n’en connaîtrait pas les composants et qui devient fort simple dès qu’ils sont connus. Avertir revient à savoir trouver les mots suffisamment pleins de respect pour que l’interlocuteur les comprenne, et respecte l’avertissement.  --

column11: Although we did not make note of it at the time, the kanji for dog is also a low-grade term for a spy. And later (Frame 1517) we will meet another association of criminals with dogs. The prison here depicts a pack of wild dogs (the long-timers and hardened criminals) into which the poor little chihuahua (first offender) has been cast. The only thing he has to protect himself against the pack are his shrill and frightened words.  -    -  The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.  -  The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being ´initiated´ by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.
column12: Bien que nous n’en ayons pas fait état, le kanji chien est aussi une sorte de synonyme d’espion. Nous verrons plus tard une autre association entre chien et criminel. La prison décrite ici nous montre un petit chien (le voleur à son premier larcin) au milieu d’une meute de chiens sauvages (les bandits de longue date), et les seuls moyens dont il dispose pour se protéger de ses compagnons de chambrée sont les mots terribles qu’il peut prononcer, et qui le séparent des autres.  --

column11: After completing the first draft, you revise it by nailing down your words and "hammering" them into shape.  -    -  Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.  -  Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?
column12: Après avoir rédigé le brouillon, on le révise, et pour cela on cloue bien chaque mot à sa place.  --

column6: to discuss; ask for, beg; demand; dun; marry
column11: Words spoken to chastise us stick to us like glue in a way no other words can.  -    -  I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!  -  In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the "A" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity.
column12: Au cours du débat, on se lance des mots à la figure. Le meilleur « débat­teur » est celui qui sait choisir les mots les plus collants, desquels ses opposants auront le plus de mal à se défaire.  --

column11: The personalism connoted by the word instruction, as opposed to "teaching" or "discipline," suits the picture here of words guiding one's progress like the gentle flowing of a stream. Even the etymology of the word instruction suggests the sense of "pouring into".  -    -  The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.  -  Listen carefully to the words of instruction before you try swimming in the river.
column12: À la différence de l’enseignement ou de la discipline, l’instruction corres­pond bien à l’image des mots qui nous ordonnent de suivre le courant du fleuve.  --  Ce caractère définit également la prononciation « japonaise » affixée aux kanjis.

column11: The imperial edict, spoken with the force of unquestionable law, is made up of words intended to seduce the masses - be it through fear or respect - to follow obediently.  -    -  The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.  -  The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.
column12: Prononcé avec la force des lois divines, l'édit est fait de mots destinés à faire venir les masses à l’opinion de l’empereur.  --

column11: A piece of writing that is pregnant with meaning and needs to be reread several times to be understood we refer to colloquially as "packed." The character sees the words as sealed tightly inside an aerosol can.  -    -  WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.  -  Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!
column12: Ce mot-clé fait référence à diverses sortes de congestions, allant des foules compressées au nez engorgé. Une image semblable est rendue par le kanji, qui nous présente ces mots entassés dans la bombe aérosol.   --

column11: That the words of the tongue should come to mean a tale is clear from the etymology: a tale is something "talked," not something read from a book.  -    -  Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.  -  Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.
column12: Mots...langue. Dire des mots avec la langue est une façon de parler, mais aussi de raconter des histoires.   --

column11: Listening to the words of poets reciting their poetry is like being transported for a moment into eternity where the rules of everyday life have been suspended.  -    -  Listening to the words in a recitation of Vogon poetry is worse than spending an eternity in hell. [Note: I assume those 2 reports are to warn against possible confusion with poem (#346) but how can you confuse Vogon poetry with an actual poem? Anyway, it´s the next frame, so it should be easy to keep them straight... Or maybe there´s a kanji for Vogon in RTK3?].  -  If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity.
column12: En versifiant, nous pouvons imaginer que nos mots nous survivent et nous transportent dans l’éternité.   --

column11: Since silence is treasured so highly at a Buddhist temple the words spoken there must be well-chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like poems. Before going on, back up a frame and make sure you have kept poem and recitation distinct in your mind.  -    -  A poem is a temple of words.  -  WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That´s why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.
column12: La poésie est appréciée au sein du temple bouddhique, dans le calme duquel les mots nous touchent au plus profond.  --

column11: Whereas the character for say focused on the actual talking, that for words stresses the fact that although it is I who say them, the words of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between I and words just by looking at the kanji.  -    -  The simplest word to say is I.  -  May I say a word about that?
column12: Dire...soi. Alors que le kanji de dire est centré sur le fait de parler, celui qui définit les langues précise que les mots que l’on dit soi-même sont ceux de notre propre langue.   --  Les notions de mot, langue et raconter sont toutes comprises dans ce caractère.

column11: In the age of advertising, most words we read are out to sell some product or point of view.  -    -  Read the WORDS used to SELL things.  -  People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don´t believe everything you read (読).
column12: En cette ère essentiellement commerciale, les mots qui nous sont donnés à lire sont la plupart du temps destinés à vendre un produit ou un point de vue.  --

column11: A complete tune is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one lap of the words that go with it.  -    -  To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what´s being said.  -  words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can´t get it out of your mind.
column12: Lorsqu’on enquête sur quelque chose, ici un crime, l’état d’un mécanisme ou la santé d’une personne, on cherche à comprendre comment « répond » la chose, ce qu’elle dit, jusqu’à en « faire le tour ».  --  En bonne logique, ce kanji contient aussi la notion de état des choses. Un autre sens est mélodie, vue comme un ensemble de mots musicaux, dont certains reviennent au cours de cycles, comme des refrains.

column11: In almost every attempt to discuss an issue, the fervor of one's convictions comes to the surface and creates an inflammation of words (if you will, the "cuss" in discuss).  -    -  Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone´s words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.  -  Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!
column12: Dans une discussion, la ferveur de chacun provoque une véritable inflammation des mots.   --

column11: The words of the young do not have legal validity unless backed up by "parental consent."  -    -  The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.  -  Delores might say, "Yes!", but she´s way too young give any legal consent.
column12: Les mots du jeune n’ont de valeur que s’ils sont validés par le consentement parental.  --

column11: The stern tone of a rebuke is seen here in the image of words spoken at a meeting of butchers (See frame 307) waving their choppers at one another and "cutting one another down" as only butchers can.  -    -  A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.  -  I imagine Socrates gate-crashing a meeting of butchers and REBUKING them: ´You´ve been killing things again; you have, haven´t you?´ while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.
column12: Nous retrouvons l'équipe de bouchers du cadre 310. Ils s’étripent ici d’une belle façon et croyez-moi, les mots qu’ils emploient sont du plus parfait louchebem. Alors, pour calmer le jeu avant qu’il ne soit trop tard, vous allez vers eux et les conseillez doucement.  --

column11: Take style in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element arrow and craft stand for the well-known style of shirts known as "Arrow shirts" because of the little arrow sewn on each one.  -    -  Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..  -  The latest style is shirts crafted out of arrows.
column12: Au moment d’acheter une flèche chez le marchand de flèches, vous précisez le type dont vous avez besoin, en lui disant la manière dont elle doit être faite.   --  La notion de type implique celle de processus défini, et selon un phénomène comparable, ce kanji signifie aussi protocole, ou cérémonie.

column11: When a manufacturer produces a new style for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a test on consumers, asking them to speak their opinions frankly about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the kanji was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember.  -    -  In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style.  -  The Japanese oral exam was a test of my speaking style.
column12: Lorsqu’un fabricant lance un produit d’un nouveau type, il fait un test auprès des consommateurs et leur demande de dire ce qu’ils en pensent.  --

column11: We use the Roman numeral II here to stress that this kanji is an older form of the kanji for two. Think of two arrows in a quiver, standing up like the numeral II.  -    -  II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).  -  Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!
column12: Le sens du caractère II est exactement le même de celui présenté au début du livre, à ceci près qu’il est employé dans certains actes officiels, pour éviter les contrefaçons. Il serait autrement facile de contrefaire un deux normal en un trois. Pensez à deux flèches dans un carquois.   --

column11: Let the drop in the upper right-hand corner of this character close the right angle off to make an arrowhead. Whenever we find the needle with that drop in an element that has no other special meaning, we will take advantage of this primitive meaning. At the bottom, we see the grains of rice, the vertical line doubling up for the two elements. Do not confuse with petition (Frame 143).  -    -  Enemy: "Any final requests?" // MacGyver: "Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice." (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.).  -  Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.
column12: Le kanji réclamer associe la flèchette et l’eau d’irrigation, comme si chacun peignait de grosses flèchettes sur son terrain pour s’assurer d’être le mieux servi par le système d’irrigation.   --

column11: Ball . . . request.  -    -  Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls!  -  The KING REQUESTS your presence at the ball ... game.
column12: Balle...réclamer. « Eh, fais une passe ! » crient les gamins jouant au ballon, pour réclamer la balle.  --

column11: Request . . . taskmaster.  -    -  Like in the biblical sense, someone looks skyward and makes a request for salvation from this horrible taskmaster...  -  For salvation you have to request forgiveness from God (the ultimate taskmaster).
column12: Pour être réussi, un sauvetage exige que chacun donne le meilleur de lui-même, et cela réclame la plus grande énergie.  --

column11: From its original meaning of a defined area or zone, a range has also come to mean a grazing land where cowboys roam and do whatever it is they do with cows. When the herds have all been driven to market, there is a great homecoming fiesta like that pictured here. As soon as the cowboys come home, home on the range, the first thing they do is kiss the ground (the mouth on the floor), and then get on with the fiesta.  -    -  An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.  -  Instead of Heisig´s "Fiesta" I use "Spear". Why? A spear is just a DROP extra on an Arrow. 域, range actually means range as in limits/boundary/border sort of range(In a box it was the old meaning for Country國 (581). Ok way too much etymology here, but back to story. With your SPEAR standing in a HOLE on the FLOOR with SOIL to its left9as you dug some out), you can see the RANGE of the spear in attacking a possible enemy (re Diablo and other RPGs, spear´s have range).
column12: Le terme de zone ici défini est général, puisque le kanji définit aussi bien le champ d’action que l’étendue vocale. Le kanji nous montre donc un certain terrain, qui représente l'étendue de la région qui nous intéresse.  --

column6: to cultivate, plant; to care for plants
column11: On a fruit plantation it is the trees that one is particularly grateful for at the time of Thanksgiving. Imagine yourself inviting a few representative trees from the fields and orchards to join you around the table to give thanks.  -    -  The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.  -  During Thanksgiving, all the trees on the plantation celebrate the harvest. It´s a good time for them, too.
column12: Dans une plantation, ce qui importe le plus c'est la taille du terrain et la hallebarde pour procéder aux récoltes. Tout cela entoure les objets plantés, une belle collection d'arbres fruitiers.  --  Si vous le désirez, vous pouvez associer  à une hallebarde et un plan de travail, ce qui convoie l'idée de couper de façon industrielle, ou parfois blesser.

column11: One loads bales on a wagon or cart in preparation for the great Hay Ride that follows the Thanksgiving dinner each year.  -    -  After eating a big Thanksgiving dinner, you have to be careful in the car ride home not to drop a load in your pants.  -  After ´Thanksgiving´ dinner, my girlfriend gave me a BJ on the drive back home. I blew my ´load´ and ´soiled´ the ´car´. But it was LOADS of fun! Please report this story if this makes you feel uncomfortable :).
column12: Dans notre plantation, au moment de la récolte les arbres font place à un grand véhicule sur lequel on charge l'ensemble de la récolte.  --

column11: The sense of the key word overgrown is of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess - in this case a whole parade of weeds (outcast flowers). By way of exception, the flowers take their normal place over the enclosure.  -    -  The gay parade looks astonishing, as if overgrown with flowers.  -  When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it´s like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!
column12: Ces végétaux qui croissent hors du cadre de la parade, mais cependant en leur position normale de couronne, ont justement débordé du cadre de cette parade pour mieux rendre l’idée de pousser dru.   --

column11: Let the phrase "turn into" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the parade marching down main street turns into a dagger-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change.  -    -  It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.  -  The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.
column12: Que cette expression se changer en vous laisse imaginer une transformation magique ! de fait, la parade qui descendait tranquillement la rue principale s’est changée en une armée de poignards, par l’ajout d’un simple trait.  --

column11: In this frame, we see a mound of dirt that is being turned into a castle (the way you may have done as a child playing on the beach).  -    -  The sand castle is just the soil (#150) that turns into a castle.  -  Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE, the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.
column12: Un monticule de terre se change en château dans ce caractère, comme savent si bien le faire les enfants, prêts à monter la garde autour de leur merveille de sable pour la protéger des pieds aveugles des adultes.  --

column11: The sure sign of sincerity is that one's mere words are turned into deeds.  -    -  Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.  -  Sincerity is turning your words into actions.
column12: Une garantie de sincérité est que nos propres mots se changent en actes.  --

column11: Here we see a march of women demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, something extremely intimidating to the male chauvinist population.  -    -  The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!  -  Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of "dignity" and "threaten." I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men.
column12: Ces femmes se font accompagner de leur horde de chiens afin de manifester pour l'égalité des sexes, intimidant les mâles qui voudraient résister.  --

column11: Picture a march of flames demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to destroy, but being doused with water by the police riot squads.  -    -  Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.  -  Use a water cannon to destroy a line of marching fire monsters. I keep mixing this one up with disaster (#167) and demolition (#400). Remember, you DESTROY monsters (think of the Godzilla movie "Destroy All Monsters!"). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot´s balrog story).
column12: La horde de chiens s'est armée de flambeaux et manifeste contre le corps des sapeurs pompiers. Ceux-ci, armés de leurs puissants jets d'eau, parviennent à les anéantir.  --

column11: A group of unquenchable mouths sets out on a march across the country, drinking water wherever they find it until the water supply has dwindled to a trickle, triggering a national disaster.  -    -  When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE.  -  When water supplies dwindled, the population became a horde of dry mouths, marching to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.
column12: La horde de chiens est assoiffée, on ne voit plus que leurs gueules béantes buvant toute l'eau disponible, et qui diminue à vue d'oeil.  --

column6: a crosspiece, cleat, frame, door bolt; shelf
column11: Prior to the use of metal, trees were once cut down and bound together for use as scaffolding material. In the case of this kanji, what is being constructed is not a skyscraper but a simple float.  -    -  Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).  -  You need a SCAFFOLD made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.
column12: Cet échafaudage est fait d'un assemblage de planchettes bien fines taillées dans un arbre.   --

column11: Those special gold-colored tokens minted each year for the Mardi Gras and thrown into the crowds from people on the floats give us the kanji for coins.  -    -  Political hopefuls in Rome threw gold COINS from floats when they were campaigning for office.  -  Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.
column12: Les piécettes métalliques sont faites à partir de tôle mince de métal. Imaginez une machine produisant ces piécettes à partir d'une bande de tôle métallique qu'elle avale sans faiblir.  --  Le sens précis est une ancienne unité monétaire valant un centime de yen, encore utilisée de nos jours dans les opérations financières.

column11: An entourage of floats going from one town to the next must always seek a shallow place to cross the water. Try to picture what happens if they don't.  -    -  The water can´t be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.  -  The water isn´t shallow enough to ford (#372). We´ll have to cross by float!
column12: La rivière est peu profonde, si peu profonde qu'on peut en mesurer la profondeur de l'eau avec notre fine planchette.  --

column11: The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint: the first 3 strokes represent the front of the foot and the last the heel. The big toe (stroke 2 sticking out to the right) on the right indicates that this is a left foot.  -  * Although the meaning of stop will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of footprint.  -  If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it´s some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.  -  If you don´t remember this one from the 10,000,000 STOP signs on roads all over Japan, you´re beyyond help!
column12: Comme la plupart des éléments de base qui forment le squelette du vocabulaire graphique que nous construisons pas à pas, ceci est un pictogramme : celui d'une trace de pas. Certes, on conçoit mal comment représenter la trace d'un pied comportant cinq orteils en quatre traits, mais c'est ainsi. Le sens réel du caractère, arrêter (ou s'arrêter, ou cesser) est naturellement dérivé de ce pictogramme.  --  Nous utiliserons quelquefois le sens de trace de pas en composant.

column11: Footprints that follow one another a few at a time indicate walking.  -    -  When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.  -  When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.
column12: Des traces de pas qui se succèdent, peu à peu, indiquent la marche.   --

column11: To ford a body of water means to walk across it.  -    -  The new Ford Jesus. It can do everything except WALK on WATER.  -  A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.
column12: Le gué est l’endroit de l'eau qui est si peu profond qu’on peu littéralement y marcher.   --  Si l’on peut traverser si aisément la rivière, on peut aller interférer dans les affaires des gens qui vivent en face ; ce kanji possède aussi le sens exact de interférence, dans tous les sens du terme.

column11: The image of something occurring repeatedly, over and over again, is of having one's head walked on.  -    -  I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.  -  Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who repeatedly walked back and forth forcibly over all the pages of her boss´ most important letters. When confronted she just says "Well you said they needed to be stamped before they´re mailed.".
column12: Quand quelqu’un n’a de cesse de nous demander quelque chose, nous avons bientôt l’impression qu’on nous marche sur la tête.   --

column11: Seeing footprints on someone's flesh indicates a rather brutal way of having secured that person's agreement.  -    -  A secret agreement between a covert gov´t agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.  -  NASA and Armstrong made an agreement: They´d never tell anyone that no-one actually stepped foot on the moon.
column12: Voir des traces de pas sur la chair de quelqu’un indique qu’un tiers a obtenu son accord quant à leur différend.  --

column6: plan a project; stand on tiptoe
column11: To undertake a project is to take some idea floating in the air and stop it so that it can be brought down to earth and become a reality. Here we see some undertaking made to stop under a beach umbrella.  -    -  Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children´s misbehaving.  -  The Undertaker is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an umbrella until he stopped moving.
column12: Entreprendre quelque chose consiste à arrêter des idées qui sont dans l’air, puis à les prendre sous sa coupe, sous son parapluie.   --

column11: That same grove of trees we met in frame 226 shows up here in the character for curriculum (in the sense of a record of one's life or academic achievements, the curriculum vitae). Instead of the grove making its way slowly through the surface of the cliff as before, here we see it stopped, much the same as a curriculum vitae calls a halt to the calendar and talks only about the past.  -    -  A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.  -  A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time.
column12: Le bois que nous avons vu croître du bas au haut de la falaise au cadre 225 a ici cessé de croître, et contemple le chemin qu’il a su faire jusqu’à ce jour, ne prenant en compte que le passé, comme on le fait lorsqu’on dresse l’historique d’une série d’événements.  --

column11: With a quiver of arrows set on one's back, the goal of the warrior depicted here is not to attack but merely to stop the attack of others: the oldest excuse in history!  -    -  ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior.  -  A great warrior can stop any 0pponent with one arrow.
column12: Muni de son carquois, le but du guerrier n’est pas de passer à l’attaque, mais bien d’arrêter les éventuelles agressions ennemies. Cette vieille excuse encore valable permet aux guerriers des temps modernes d’obtenir les fonds nécessaires à leur besogne.  --

column11: A certain portion of shells (money) is collected by the warrior from the local villages as he passes through to defray the costs of keeping the land safe, and this is called a levy.  -    -  A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.  -  Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you´ll die. Pay up the clams or you´ll die....
column12: Le guerrier perçoit une certaine quantité de monnaie auprès des villageois pour assurer leur sécurité, et cela s’appelle un prélèvement.   --

column11: "A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step," says the Chinese proverb. Here we see one footprint, complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made correctly, the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in correcting their students, and parents in correcting their children.  -    -  If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.  -  The correct way of learning Japanese? First, stop everything you´re doing. Then, go pick up a copy of Heisig´s book and work from there.
column12: Un voyage de mille ris (le kanji vu en 182) commence par un simple pas, nous dit un célèbre proverbe chinois. Ce kanji nous montre ce premier pas, et précise que s'il n'est pas fait correctement, c'est le voyage entier qui risque d'être compromis.  --  Pour les matheux : un nombre positif est un nombre correct. Les nombres négatifs, quant à eux, sont les nombres « chargés », vus en 64.

column11: Words that testify to the correctness of some fact are classified as evidence. (Here we see a good example of how the more common primitive element takes the "strong" position to the left, even though it has more strokes.)  -    -  Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.  -  If what you say is indeed correct, we could use use your testimony as evidence.
column12: Les mots qui attestent de l’exactitude d’un chose constituent une preuve. Une fois de plus, l’importance relative des deux éléments peut vous aider à retenir l’ordre d’écriture.  --

column11: To the many definitions for politics that already exist, this character offers yet another: correct taskmastering. Think about what the primitives tell us. On the one hand, we see the pessimistic wisdom that politics has to do with taskmastering, maneuvering people with or without their will. And on the other, we see the campaign assurances that this duty can be performed correctly if only the right candidate is given a chance.  -    -  Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.  -  Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.
column12: Aux nombreuses définitions que possède le mot politique, ce kanji en ajoute une autre : le chef de corvée correct est un bon politicien, « politiquement correct », et cela lui demande beaucoup d’énergie.   --  Voyez ici que, comme il en fut pour l’enfant et pour la vache, le dernier trait de correct est tracé légèrement en remontant.
