column11: Determination, in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to mending one's house.  -    -  In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher´s HOUSE in various ways.  -  People who decide to renovate (ooh, that´s a fancy word, let´s say "mend") their houses must be very determined DIYers. (Using DIY helps me remember this story when I see DEtermine).
column12: Déterminé est à comprendre comme « décider à l’avance une action », ou « fixer quelque chose à l’avance ». Vous comprendrez bien les implications très terre-à-terre que ce concept peut avoir dans la vie japonaise, le jour où vous tenterez, probablement sans succès, d’obtenir un « gâteau + jus d’orange » dans un restaurant japonais déterminé à servir l’ensemble « gâteau + café ». Pour en revenir à notre kanji, on s’imaginera, d’une façon tout aussi terre-à- terre, raccommodant diverses choses, et pour ce faire, déterminé à rester à la maison tant que le travail n’est pas terminé.  --

column11: Metal of itself doesn't lock. It needs to be so determined by a locksmith. Now make a concrete image of that.  -    -  Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.  -  The best stories for this kanji tend to have a thief in them, which always makes me confuse them with the kanji for burglar (357). So, let´s try this one: My girlfriend wears a metal chastity belt with a lock but I am determined to open it! I must get inside!
column12: Pour que le métal constitue une serrure, il est nécessaire que le serrurier intervienne, et le détermine ainsi. Un sens associé est pilule, petite pastille qui contient quelque métal en infime quantité (un oligo-élément) que le médecin a déterminé et nous prescrit.  --

column6: walk, go on foot; run; leave; Kangxi radical 156
column11: Running, we are told here, mends the soil. Observe in the following frames how this kanji can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for road does; and how, in order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened.  -    -  Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!  -  The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.
column12: Courir raccommode le sol, nous raconte ce kanji qui semble réécrire la théorie de la relativité. Regardez dans les kanjis suivants comment ce caractère hébergera d'autres éléments, comme le fait l'élément route vu plus haut, et pour ce faire, comment il s'allongera un petit peu.   --  La forme ancienne, , de l'élément route vu page 93, et que l'on trouve dans des ouvrages de référence ainsi que dans les index de ce livre, montre qu'il a même origine que le présent kanji.

column11: When one is running after something, the goal that seduces one is said to transcend the seeker.  -    -  A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.  -  To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and....
column12: Lorsqu’on cherche à courir très vite, en vue de dépasser tout le monde, il faudrait trouver un truc pour faire venir à soi le bout de la piste, alors que les autres concurrents en seraient réduits à faire aller leurs jambes.  --

column11: In proceeding to a new city or a new job, something in you runs ahead with excitement, and something else holds you back, like a divining rod built into your psyche warning you to check things out carefully before rushing in too wildly.  -    -  Don´t run into trouble, Dumbledore tells Harry. "Proceed with caution with your wand out.".  -  While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed.
column12: Lorsqu’on se rend en un lieu inconnu, on est certes tenté de courir, mais aussi quelque chose nous dicte de rester prudent, et de garder à portée de main la rassurante baguette magique.   --

column11: Here we see two parades in competition, each trying to surpass the other by running at high speed from one town to the next. Note the little "hook" at the end of the first stroke of the element for parade. This is the ONLY time it appears like this in the kanji treated in this book.  -    -  The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...).  -  The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).
column12: Ici se trouvent deux parades en compétition, chacune cherchant à doubler l’autre, en courant très vite d’un village à l’autre. Regardez le petit crochet à la fin de l’élément parade : c’est la seule fois que nous le verrons dans ce livre.  --

column11: Stop . . . march . . . little. Be sure not to forget that final dot in the element for march.  -    -  Santa had to put his foot down to stop a march of little guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every year-end when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.  -  At the year-end, everything seems to come to a stop. However, there's still enough time for a little march to celebrate.
column12: Arrêt...horde de chiens...défilé. Historiquement, les Japonais gagnent un an tous le même jour, au moment de la nouvelle année. C'est dans une belle union que tous s'arrêtent un petit moment puis repartent à l'unisson pour une nouvelle année, unis comme dans une horde de chiens. Incidemment, un enfant né un 31 décembre a donc deux ans le lendemain, selon ce comptage traditionnel japonais.  --

column6: indeed, yes, right; to be; demonstrative pronoun, this, that
column11: In this kanji we are shown someone spending an entire day at mending one stocking, because they want the job done "just so." Be sure to make a clear image of a finicky old fusspot to make the abstract idea as concrete as possible.  -    -  ´Sun´ ´Mend´ - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.  -  My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all day obsessively mending the code so this page looks just so....
column12: C’est cette fois la couturière qui passe la journée entière à raccommoder, car de guerre lasse vous lui avez confié votre ouvrage, lui précisant que ce devait être fait comme il faut.   --

column11: In many kinds of research, one can find information on a given topic only if the headings are prepared just so.  -    -  The "TOPIC" of the day´s newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.  -  You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!
column12: Bien connaître son sujet revient à dire qu’on l’a bien dans la tête, comme il faut.   --

column11: A dike is a successful bit of engineering only if the amount of earth piled up is measured just so for the height and pressure of the water it is meant to contain.  -    -  Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so....  -  The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the dike, and that´s the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in just so - there, I think it´s good enough. Pull it out -----yes! Success!
column12: Une digue ne sera une réussite que si la terre dont elle est faite a été mesurée comme il faut.   --

column11: To construct a building, you first draw a set of plans (the writing brush) and then s-t-r-e-t-c-h your drawing out to scale in reality.  -    -  Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it´s just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.  -  A construction worker´s classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build.
column12: Pour construire une maison, on trace d'abord le plan, avec le pinceau, puis on étire l'ensemble en vraie grandeur lors de la construction.   --

column11: This character is a kind of pictographic image of how prolonging is a clever way of stopping things by trying to stretch them out a little bit at a time (the extra drop at the top of stop). Be sure to get a concrete image of this process, by imagining yourself prolonging something you can really, physically, stretch.  -    -  Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...  -  Here´s a great mnemonic: "stop, drop, and stretch (!?)." Now let´s associate it with ´prolong´: if you´re ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it´ll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!
column12: Ce pictogramme montre comment prolonger est une façon intelligente d'arrêter les choses pour les étendre un tout petit peu (la goutte en haut). Assurez-vous d’obtenir une image concrète, en prolongeant quelque chose que vous puissiez physiquement allonger.  --

column6: to bear children, give birth; birth
column11: The key word of course calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the nativity we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history: it represents the prolongation of the eternal Word in time and space.  -    -  Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!  -  When you are being born ( nativity ), your mother´s WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!).
column12: À chaque fois que nous fêtons l'anniversaire de notre naissance, les amis se réunissent autour du gâteau et nous souhaitent, par des mots agréables, que tout se prolonge pour un an encore.  --

column11: This character depicts a cornerstone as a stone set at the end of a wildlife preserve (the "zoo in the grove").  -    -  Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.  -  A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.).
column12: Ce kanji décrit la première pierre comme celle placée au coin d’une réserve naturelle, le zoo dans le bois. Il vous reste à décréter réserve naturelle votre jardin et d’aller y poser la première pierre. Mais plus simplement, vous verrez apparaître ce kanji gravé au pied de nombreux édifices dans de nombreux endroits au Japon.  --  Le sens figuré de base existe aussi.

column11: What makes a man a bridegroom is obviously a woman and her dowry, here presented as a small zoo (animals were often used for this purpose in earlier societies) and a month away from it all (the "honeymoon").  -    -  The virgin bridegroom tries to understand the new, mysterious part of his woman´s body - but with little success. It´s a zoo down there! (primitives placement: the part of the body is ´down there´ - the woman is ´left´ unsatisfied).  -  The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they´re about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon.
column12: Ce qui transforme un jeune homme en gendre est, nous apprend-on ici, la femme et sa dot, représentée ici par un zoo (les animaux étaient souvent utilisés dans ce but dans les sociétés anciennes), ainsi qu’un mois de liberté, la lune de miel.  --  Chapitre dix-huit Vêtements et intempéries  PROCURONS-NOUS des vêtements, quelque peu multiformes. Nous pourrons ensuite nous frotter aux intempéries.

column6: clothes, clothing; cover, skin; Kangxi radical 145
column11: At the top we see the top hat, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a garment. If you break the "4-fold" fold into 2 sets of 2 strokes, you will find it easier to remember.  -  * Used as a primitive, the additional meanings of cloak or scarf will come in handy. What has to be noted particularly are the changes in shape the kanji can undergo when it becomes an element in other kanji. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the kanji we shall treat, and for that reason deserves special attention here. When it appears to the left, it looks like a hiragana ne (ネ) with an extra drop on the right, and we shall take it to mean cloak. At the bottom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, which we shall take to mean a scarf. On rare occasions, the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first 2 strokes appearing at the top and the last 4 at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitive, in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf. And finally, of course, it can keep its original kanji shape, along with its original meaning of garment in general. Note that when any of the above forms have something beneath them (as in frame 429), the third from final stroke is "unhooked."  -  The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.  -  The garments most commonly associated with the craft of a magician are the top hat and the magic wand. (It´s a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.).
column12: En haut est placé le chapeau haut de forme, et en bas sont représentés les deux pans d'un vêtement.  --  * En composant, ce caractère subira diverses modifications, comme suit :  - Placé à gauche, il deviendra  et nous lui donnerons le sens de manteau.  - En position inférieure, et fixé au trait qui le surmonte, ses deux premiers traits vont disparaître, et nous lui donnerons le sens de écharpe : .  - Il pourra également être divisé en deux, faisant voir le chapeau haut de forme en haut, et l'écharpe en bas : . Nous y verrons donc un chapeau haut de forme et une écharpe.  - Il lui arrivera enfin d'apparaître sous sa forme normale, et en pareil cas le sens général de vêtement sera adopté.  - Des exemples précis de ces différents cas vont apparaître dans les kanjis suivants.

column11: You might think here of garment that have been specially tailored for Thanksgiving celebrations to look like traditional Pilgrim garb.  -    -  The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving.  -  The tailor worked hard after thanksgiving to alter garments so they´d fit people who´d eaten too much at their thanksgiving dinners.
column12: Sur une grande surface plane, directement sur le sol, le tailleur armé de sa hallebarde se prépare à découper le patron à la taille du vêtement souhaité.  --  Ce caractère possède aussi le sens de tribunaux, monde dans lequel en un sens, on « taille des vestes ». Notons que c'est ici la seconde fois qu'un kanji signifie à la fois découper et décider ; et cela se reproduira.

column11: The character for attire can be remembered as a picture of what we may call a "turtle-samurai" sweater. At the top we see the turtle-samurai and at the bottom the element for garment.  -    -  The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others.  -  The ninja turtles tried to go eat at a fancy restaurant, but they were told to come back after their were dressed in proper attire. However, it´s too difficult for them to find proper garments because they bodies are so robust! (sannomiya + drwarrior12).
column12: Pour se revêtir, notre robuste vieux professeur protégé par sa tortue saisit son grand pardessus, mais comme il est bien maladroit, son « pardessus » se retrouve « par-dessous » !  --

column11: An innocent looking top hat and scarf lying there in front of you, turned over, reveal a hidden computer sewn into the back of each - obviously the tools of a master spy. Such experiences teach one always to have a look at the back side of things.  -    -  The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It was n´t until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.  -  Can computers be gay? I´m not sure, but mine always wears a top hat and scarf, and for some reason its back door port is always open...
column12: Un chapeau haut de forme et une écharpe parfaitement innocents, en face de vous, révèlent un ordinateur caché sur la face arrière. Sans doute les outils d’un maître espion, ou d’un marchand d’horoscope informatisé.  --

column11: The right half of this character shows a garment woven so fine that it can pass through the eye of a needle, fittingly draped around the slithering, ethereal form of a poltergeist. In this frame, our eerie visitor brushes its robes against a nearby block of apartments and completely demolishes them, razing them to the ground.  -    -  If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.  -  Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.
column12: La partie droite de ce kanji nous montre un vêtement très fin, fait d'un simple châle surmonté d'une broche, drapé autour de la forme éthérée d'un fantôme. Se frottant aux immeubles avoisinants, il les démolit entièrement, et les voilà qui s'écrasent lourdement sur le sol.  --

column11: A drunken sod in a tattered top hat and soiled silk scarf with a giant mouth guzzling something or other gives us a pathetic character role in which W. C. Fields might find himself right at home.  -    -  One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can´t see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it´s cool. I think it´s pathetic.  -  A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun "pathos." The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.
column12: Un vieil alcoolique vêtu d’un chapeau haut de forme et d’une écharpe entre lesquels une bouche bée nous donne une image pitoyable et un moyen radical pour retenir ce kanji.  --

column11: A distant figure on the road is such a blur it looks like a lidded crock wearing a silk scarf.  -    -  Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.  -  When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?
column12: Un personnage vient vers vous, mais il est encore si loin sur la route que vous ne discernez qu’une poterie à couvercle en guise de tête, et une sorte d’écharpe au-dessous.  --

column11: This clever little monkey has captured an entire pack of wild dogs, locked them inside a lidded crock, and wrapped the whole thing up in a silk scarf to present to the dogcatcher.  -    -  The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.  -  To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf.
column12: Ce petit singe malin est parvenu à attraper une meute entière de chiens féroces, qu’il a enfermés dans une poterie à couvercle et emballés dans une écharpe de soie, pour en faire présent au chasseur de chiens !  --

column11: The primitives here take care of themselves: cloak and dagger .What I leave to you is to decide on an appropriate connotation for "first time" to take advantage of them.  -    -  This is the first time we´ve been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo! Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.  -  On his FIRST TIME, he cloaked his dagger with a Trojan.
column12: La première fois que vous portez votre manteau, vous rendez visite à votre tailleur pour qu’il en ajuste la longueur. Or, surprise, alors que vous pensiez le voir saisir une banale paire de ciseaux pour mener à bien sa tâche, le voilà qui s’empare d’un long poignard qui traîne là, et prend un bon élan…  --

column11: The maid, towels by her side, distributes the linen.  -    -  A matador holding his red linen by his side.  -  The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker´s Guide to the Universe is "DON´T PANIC!" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort.
column12: La serviette sur le côté, la servante répartit le linge.   --  Répartir et linge sont les deux significations de ce caractère.

column11: A sail made of a towel makes a mediocre vessel.  -    -  When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.  -  A towel makes a mediocre sail.
column12: Une voile qui serait faite d’une serviette caractériserait un bien médiocre vaisseau.  --

column11: A towel owned by the wealthiest tycoon in the world is made into a hanging scroll after his death and auctioned off to the highest bidder.  -    -  In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don´t have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!  -  The towels of the wealthy: hanging scrolls.
column12: Une serviette qui donne l’impression d’opulence, plus encore que d’être longue, se doit d’être large, pour que l’on puisse s’y draper à loisir, comme dans une tenture murale (voyez « kakémono » dans votre dictionnaire français).  --

column11: Because of the risk involved (of getting the sun in one's eyes),one puts together a makeshift cap out of a dirty old towel.  -    -  If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.  -  Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.
column12: Pour éviter tout risque (d’avoir le soleil dans les yeux), on se fabrique une casquette de fortune, avec une simple serviette.  --

column11: A dirty towel draped over the entrance to the old graveyard is painted to look like the curtain of death that leads to the otherworld.  -    -  There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep.  -  When you´re dead in the graveyard, "it´s curtains for you.".
column12: Sur cette grande serviette de tissu, nous dessinons l'esquisse d'une décoration afin de créer un rideau qui égaye l'atmosphère.  --

column11: A large towel stretched overhead with only a few of the sun's rays breaking through represents a canopy over one's bed.  -    -  A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.  -  From the Hitch-Hiker´s Guide to the Universe: A towel is useful, among other things, as a canopy to keep out the sun´s rays from your face while napping.
column12: La toile que l’on place au-dessus de soi pour se protéger des rayons qui descendent du soleil s’appelle une capote.   --

column11: A strip of white towel and some scraps of metal have the makings of a primitive kind of brocade.  -    -  Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.  -  Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It´s embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it´d be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.
column12: Une bande de toile blanche où sont fixés quelques morceaux de métal nous donne un type un peu primitif de brocart.   --

column11: Dressed in nothing but a bath towel and top hat, one sets off to the marketplace in search of a bargain or two.  -    -  My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I´m wearing only a top hat...and a towel.  -  At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.
column12: Vêtu d’un chapeau haut de forme et d’une serviette, on va au marché pour dénicher la bonne affaire.  --  Par association, ce kanji signifie aussi ville.

column11: Of all the women of the family, it is the elder sister who has the duty to go to market to do the shopping.  -    -  Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!  -  She´s old enough to be allowed to go to the market.
column12: Parmi toutes les femmes de la maison, la sœur aînée est celle à qui incombe le rôle d’aller au marché faire les emplettes.  --

column11: One is surprised, strolling through the market, to find among the meats hung out for sale a slab marked: lungs.  -    -  LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.  -  The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice "IRASSHAIMASEEE" to attract customers.
column12: On est surpris, arpentant les allées du marché, de trouver parmi tous les quartiers de viande, un étal où il est écrit : poumons.   --

column11: The part of the apron where one finds the buckle (represented pictorially by the first 5 strokes) is on the sash.  -    -  First, note that the top half of the kanji consists of one and mountain. Of course, the "number 1" mountain in Japan is Mt. Fuji. The bottom half, under Mt. Fuji, consists of crown and towel. Now for the story. Archaeologists digging under Mt. Fuji (Japan´s #1 mountain) in an ancient royal tomb (they know it´s royal because of the crown) discover what looks like a towel, but after they clean it up, they see it is actually a splendid royal sash for the king´s kimono.  -  Beautiful "Miss Housewife Japan" is on posters everywhere, cooking right before Mt. Fuji (the number one mountain) while wearing nothing but her crown, and an apron tied with a sash. (hodgepodge of mspertus, zwarte_kat, et al, with a jot of hadaka apron to focus the image.).
column12: Le lieu du tablier où se trouve la boucle, ici représentée pictographiquement par les cinq premiers traits, est la ceinture.   --

column11: People that have been "sashed" to something (whether their mother's apron strings or a particular job) for too long become like water that has stopped moving: they start to stagnate.  -    -  History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one´s karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren´t their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????  -  A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.
column12: Les gens qui ont été « ceinturés » à quelque-chose (que ce soit au tablier de leur mère ou à un travail quelconque), deviennent comme l’eau qui a cessé de bouger : ils stagnent.   --

column11: Thorns grow on a bush here that has wrapped itself around a tree like a belt, cutting into the poor tree like little sabers.  -    -  A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.  -  The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.
column12: Un arbre sur lequel poussent de redoutables piquants nous contraint, pour nous frayer un chemin au travers de la jungle dans laquelle il pousse, de l'entourer d’une courroie, puis de tailler dans le vif.  --  Le sens de tailler est aussi inclus, ainsi que celui de coudre (piquer à la machine).

column11: This kanji show a unique system for leading cows to the slaughterer's saber: one ties a belt about their waist and fixes that belt to an overhead cable, pulling the cow up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it.  -    -  The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.  -  Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn´t have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he´s part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, "Moo!".
column12: Ce kanji nous propose un système pour amener la vache à l'abattoir : on lui enveloppe la panse d'une gigantesque courroie fixée à un palan puis on soulève l'animal sans défense vers le sabre du tueur.   --

column11: A label indicating that a garment was made in U.S.A. or Taiwan or Japan is itself a symbol for the systematization of the garment industry.  -    -  Made in china - a system of exploitation . making garments for nothing.  -  A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have MADE IN on the label.
column12: Une étiquette attestant qu’un produit est « Fabriqué en France », ou « Fabriqué au Japon » est le meilleur symbole de la systématisation de l’industrie de l’habillement.   --

column11: As the wheels of the car revolve, they kick up small rising clouds of dust and debris behind them.  -    -  The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.  -  Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku´s pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus [ http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg ]. The katakana-ization of this is {ニム}バス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.
column12: Quand la voiture  roule, ses roues soulèvent un nuage de poussière et de débris divers.  --

column6: rue, herb used to keep insects away; to cut grass or weeds; art, talent, ability, craft, technique, performance, acting, trick, stunt
column11: The secret technique of making a rising cloud of smoke turn into a bouquet of flowers is shown here.  -    -  Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: "Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!" smash pow crack!! .  -  One technique to smoke weed is to vaporize it and inhale those rising clouds to create a stronger effect.
column12: L’art secret qui permet de transformer un nuage de poussière en un magnifique bouquet de végétaux est décrit dans ce kanji.  --

column11: This kanji, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next 3 strokes a pair of clouds, and the final 4 dots the rain collected there and waiting to fall.  -  * As a primitive it can mean either rain or weather in general. Because it takes so much space, it usually has to be contracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown.  -  From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.  -  Towel hung out on a line to ....oops, it´s rain.
column12: Ce kanji est l’un des exemples les plus clairs que l’on puisse trouver d’un pictogramme complexe. La ligne supérieure est le ciel, les trois traits suivants veulent représenter une paire de nuages, et les quatre traits qui s’y trouvent symbolisent la pluie, prête à tomber.  --  En composant, cet élément symbolisera la pluie, mais aussi l'ensemble des phénomènes météorologiques. Comme il est volumineux, il sera souvent aplati, pour devenir un élément couronne, et on l'écrira : .

column11: Here is the full character for cloud from which the primitive for a rising cloud derives. Clouds begin with vapors rising up in small clouds from the surface of the earth, and then gathering to make clouds that eventually dump their rain back on the earth.  -    -  Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).  -  Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.
column12: Voici le caractère complet d'où provient le nuage qui s'élève. Les nuages de vapeur issus du sol se concentrent dans l'atmosphère et forment les nuages qui finalement engendrent la pluie.  --

column11: We refer to days when the sun is covered by the clouds as cloudy weather.  -    -  Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).  -  In cloudy weather, the sun is still there even if obscured by the clouds...　RTK2:　ドン　曇天　どんてん(cloudy skies).
column12: Le temps est nuageux lorsque le soleil est au-dessus des nuages.   --

column11: The full rumble and roar and terror of thunder is best felt not with your head tucked under your pillow safe in bed, but out in an open rice field where you can get the real feel of the weather.  -    -  If it´s raining and you´re standing in the middle of a rice field, you´re sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.  -  Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you´ve got time to get out of the field before it starts raining.
column12: Plus que la tête enfouie sous l’oreiller, c’est au milieu des champs que l’on ressentira le mieux le bruit terrifiant du tonnerre.   --

column11: Think of frost as a cooperative venture, an inter-action of the malevolent forces of weather that sit around a conference table and finally decide to allow a very light amount of moisture to fall just before a short and sudden freeze.  -    -  FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.  -  The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It´s RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.
column12: Imaginez le givre comme une réalisation faite en interaction par les divers éléments qui gouvernent le temps, assis autour d’une table de conférence, pour finalement décider qu’on va faire tomber juste ce qu’il faut d’humidité avant un froid vif et soudain.  --

column11: Walking legs slipping on the ice are a sure sign of winter.  -    -  Don´t slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.  -  In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.
column12: Les jambes qui marchent en glissant sur la glace sont un signe certain que l’hiver est là.  --

column11: This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the Heavens. (You may, of course, use the elements ceiling and St. Bernard instead.)  -  * The primitive can mean either the heaven of eternal bliss or the general term for sky, the heavens. Pay special attention to the fact that in its primitive form the first stroke is written right to left, rather like the first stroke of thousand (Frame 40), rather than left to right. From the next character, we shall give it the primitive meaning of a witch.  -  If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.  -  The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.
column12: Ce kanji est supposé être le pictogramme d’un homme très grand, repré­sentant le Tout-Puissant. Mais vous pouvez bien entendu faire une image à partir des éléments plafond et saint-bernard si vous le désirez.  --

column11: The bridge shown here is made of trees in their natural form, except that the trunks have been carved into the forms of angels, a sort of "Ponte degli Angeli."  -    -  The nicest bridge is not in Hollywood or Los Angeles, but in San Francisco.  -  A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don´t worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I´m trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels.".
column12: Le pont décrit ici est fait de troncs d’arbres sous leur forme naturelle, mais ils ont été courbés en forme d’anges, nous donnant une sorte de « pont Saint-Anges ».  --

column11: Associating a particularly attractive woman you know with an angel should be no problem.  -    -  The most attractive woman in the world is obviously Angelina Jolie.  -  The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive.
column12: Associer une femme attirante de votre entourage à l’idée d’un ange doit être chose aisée.  --

column11: This picture of a vase standing up has its meaning extended to represent the general posture of anything standing up.  -  * Used as a primitive, it can also mean vase. Using its kanji meaning, think of something standing up that is normally lying down, or something standing up in an unusual way.  -  A vase that can´t stand up won´t be a vase for long.  -  He was a stand up guy: he´d lend you the top hat he wears everyday if you asked, and he will turn everything upside down to help you find your tools.
column12: Cette image d’un vase debout verra son sens élargi à la représentation de quoi que ce soit se trouvant en position debout, au sens propre et figuré.  --  * Les sésames seront vase et debout, mais nous tenterons de mettre debout quelque chose qui habituellement ne l'est pas, ou qui l'est en une position peu usuelle. En tout état de cause, notez que ce vase a un volume d'un litre.

column11: One cries and cries until one is standing up knee-deep in water (or until one has a vase-full of water).  -    -  Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying.  -  She stood up to leave the room when her eyes started to water...
column12: Regardez cette façon étrange qu’ont les enfants de pleurer, restant debout sans savoir pourquoi, à l’endroit précis où ils se sont rendus-compte que rien n’allait plus. Et les chaudes larmes d’inonder le parquet.  --

column11: Try to imagine a club badge pinned to your lapel in the form of a mammoth sunflower protruding from a wee little vase.  -    -  In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention.  -  Ash Ketchum stood up early in the morning, and said, "Pikachu, let´s go get us another badge!".
column12: Voici le badge du club. Vous arrivez tôt ce matin pour la réunion du club, mais le préposé vous attend, debout, prêt à vous donner votre badge.  --  La principale raison d'être de votre badge est d'être clairement visible. Alors notez ce second sens au passage. Imaginez enfin que les têtes de chapitres d'un livre sont comme autant de badges, bien visibles sur chaque page.

column11: Two teenagers are seen here standing up to one another, vying for the attention of their peers.  -    -  TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!  -  Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.
column12: Deux adolescents debout face à face se dévisagent, chacun vantant ses capacités, pour attirer l’attention.  --

column11: An uncommon, but not altogether unlikely picture of a reigning sovereign has him standing up in his apron, presumably at the behest of HIS sovereign (she who is to be obeyed), who needs help with washing the dishes.  -    -  The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That´s why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.  -  This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown "winglets" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She´s standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign´s servants have the day off.
column12: Une image peu habituelle, mais après tout pas impossible, d’un souverain, nous le montre debout, en tablier de cuisine : sa gouvernante vient de lui annoncer qu’elle ne touchera plus la vaisselle !  --

column11: This frame shows up the image of a juvenile hacker standing on top of a computer, or rather jumping up and down on it, because it refused to come up with the right answer.  -    -  The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.  -  The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...).
column12: Le sens général de jeune enfant, est contenu dans ce caractère. Voyez ici un jeune impétueux bondir sur les ordinateurs, ou sauter dessus d’énervement.  --

column11: Begin with the double meaning of the key word pupil: "student" and the "the apple of one's eye." Now all you have to do is dwell on the phrase "juvenile of one's eye" (the meaning here) until it provides you with an image.  -    -  In Japanese comics, the eye´s of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils.  -  WARNING: This kanji only means the pupil of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it.
column12: Le jeune est entre autre celui à qui l’on tient comme « à la pupille de ses yeux ».  --

column11: This bell is made of cheap metal, and so badly made that when you ring it, it lets out a noise like the "bellowing" of juveniles who aren't getting their own way.  -    -  The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class.  -  The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to COMPUTER class.
column12: Une cloche est faite de métal, et c’est elle qui rappelle à l’ordre les jeunes à la fin de la récré.  --

column11: See the peddlar standing atop his motorcycle helmet as if it were a soapbox, hawking his wares to passersby. The legs and mouth represent the tools of the trade of making a deal any way you can.  -    -  I use what I think is the real etymology for this kanji which is so shocking it sticks. The STANDING member at the top is a certain part of the body that all men have and it is approaching the HOLE between TWO LEGS (the HOOD) with extra marks to show they are FLESHY - ie a womans legs. So this shows the oldest DEAL of all time - prostitution.  -  Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he´s trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, "hey, we can still make a deal.".
column12: Voyez un colporteur debout à côté de sa cloche de verre contenant ses plus précieuses marchandises : la bouche pour vanter sa pacotille, et les jambes, pour les prendre à son cou quand arrivent les inspecteurs.  --

column6: legal wife, child of legal wife
column11: The phrase legitimate wife would have no meaning if there were not such things as "illegitimate wives," taken because one's legal woman has turned into an antique. The very offense of the idea should help you remember the kanji.  -    -  Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.  -  Your legitimate wife is like an antique bong. Its not your favorite but you still hit it sometimes...
column12: L’idée de femme  légitime n’existerait pas s’il n’y en avait d’illégitimes la relégant au rang des antiquités.   --

column11: Can you imagine anything less suitable to do with one's precious antiques than to display them in the middle of a crowded road-way?  -    -  Think of the term from televison "suitable for all audiences" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the "antiques road(show)".  -  That old thing in your attic might be suitable to be shown on the Antiques Roadshow.
column12: L'antiquité placée sur la route est un vieux tacot, ou votre voiture qui refuse de passer l’infâme « shaken », mais qui est pourtant tout à fait appropriée pour rendre les menus services que vous lui demandez.  --

column11: Picture water dripping on what you thought were precious antiques, only to find that the artificial aging painted on them is running!  -    -  DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.  -  You must never let water drip onto antiques.
column12: Imaginez des gouttes d’eau tomber sur ce que vous pensiez être une authentique antiquité, le tout pour constater que les traces de vieillissement artificiel s’effacent à mesure que les gouttes glissent sur le bois.  --

column11: Picture your most precious antique (it doesn't matter how old it really is, so long as it is the oldest thing YOU own) being knocked over by your most unlikeable taskmaster, and you have a good picture of how people make themselves enemies for life.  -    -  The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife´s ashes.  -  Indiana Jones is an enemy of taskmasters in search of antique artifacts. RTK2: 　テキ　敵地　てきち(enemy territory)...　　　　　　　　　　　Pure Group:　嫡440　適441　滴442 　摘657.
column12: Imaginez votre pire chef de corvée renverser votre plus précieuse antiquité, et vous aurez une idée satisfaisante de « comment se faire des ennemis pour la vie ».  --

column11: This character, a pictograph of a spoon, is easy enough to remember, provided you keep it distinct from that for seven, where the first stroke is written left to right (the opposite of here) and cuts noticeably across the second.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji can take on the additional meaning of someone sitting on the ground, of which it can also be considered a pictograph. In general, the second stroke does not cut through the first - or if it does in some fonts, only slightly.  -  To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.  -  Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both ´spoon´ and ´seven´, the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in ´seven´ it is a strong line from left to right.
column12: Ce kanji, pictogramme d’une cuiller, sera aisément retenu si vous le distinguez du sept. La différence est que le premier trait est tracé à l’envers, et ne sectionne presque pas le second.  --  En composant, ce kanji représentera aussi selon les besoins un individu assis sur le sol, ce dont il est aussi un pictogramme.

column6: this, these; in this case, then
column11: -    -  "I'm not going to use 'this here' as a primitive because it's too vague. But 'stop and sit down', usually tied to a tour guide explaining scenery works for me.//Stop and sit down to have a look at this here."  -  "A wildlife explorer, let's call him Steve Irwin, the sadly passed away wildlife expert, is tracking down an animal in a forest. He finds a footprint, and gets out a spoon to taste it. He scrapes the spoon over the floor and tries it. ""Now, this here is a crocodile footprint"" he announces."
column12: Un personnage s’est arrêté, et s’est assis : il est ici.  --  Le sésame pourra être un petit laser de poche, celui duquel on montre le lieu dont on parle, et que toujours on nomme « ici ».

column6: a moment; a measure of area equal to 100 mu or 6.7 hectares; to lean
column11: When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking spoons on his head, you know it is about that time to come up with a reason to excuse yourself.  -    -  An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.  -  After spooning for hours it's about that time he got some head. Dayum woman.
column12: Pour saisir la notion d'époque, songez un instant à l’époque de votre enfance, où l’on vous nourrissait à la cuiller : cuiller...tête.  --

column11: The cold air from the north is so strong that we see two people sitting on the ground back to back, their arms interlocked so they don't blow away. (Pay special attention to the drawing of the first 3 strokes.)  -    -  Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!  -  In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.
column12: Le vent froid du nord est si violent que l’on voit ici deux personnes, dos à dos, les bras croisés pour ne pas risquer de s’envoler.  --  Peut-être aurez-vous du mal à reconnaître le symétrique de la seconde partie dans la première, mais la façon dont les kanjis doivent être tracés dicte cette forme.

column11: One's stature is measured according to the "northern-most" part of the body.  -    -  While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!  -  Up in the Great White North, we eat a lot of meat - thus giving us great STATURE. Mmmm.... baby seals.
column12: On mesure la stature de quelqu’un à partir de la partie la plus au nord de son corps, qui est aussi le dos, second sens du caractère.  --

column6: to compare, liken; comparison; than; hexagram ䷇
column11: With two spoons, one in each hand, you are comparing your mother's cooking with your mother-in-law's.  -    -  A gay couple about to turn around to compare which role is better...  -  Compare the two spoons... the one on the left is funny-looking.
column12: Une cuiller dans chaque main, vous comparez la cuisine de votre mère et celle de votre belle-mère.  --

column11: By comparing apes with anthropoids, we not only discover the latter have descended from those progenitors educated in the higher branches, but that the very idea of seeing everything descended from everything else, one way or another, means that there is "nothing new UNDER the sun."  -    -  Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS.  -  Japanese people have compared themselves as being descendants of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = descendants.
column12: Soleil... deux individus. Rappellons que 匕 peut représenter un individu. Ici, deux de ces individus sont côte à côte ; ils représentent l'humanité, tout ce que nous voyons ici sous le soleil. Ainsi naît le sens de descendant puis de frère aîné et l'histoire montre naturellement la position relative des éléments dans le kanji. Mais ce kanji se rapporte aussi au monde des insectes, que l'on pensait procéder directement de la lumière du soleil dans une perception chinoise de la génération spontanée.  --

column11: Think of the housewives in TV commercials "comparing the whiteness" of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as All. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases "all-purpose detergent" or "all-temperature detergent.")  -    -  If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others.  -  Sometimes, Dr. Heisig´s keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn´t mean all, it means everyone!! Picture two ku klux klansmen comparing whose skin is whiter...finally, they agree that everyone there is white.
column12: Il aurait été surprenant de ne pas utiliser au moins une fois au cours de ce livre, les légendaires publicités des lessives. Celle qui est présentée ici « nettoie tout ». Cela signifie que tout va devenir incomparablement blanc.   --

column6: to mix, blend, mingle; to bumble along
column11: Mixed marriages, this character suggests, water down the quality of one's descendants - the oldest racial nonsense in the world!  -    -  People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.  -  Give plants the right mix of water and sun. Then compare the results...　RTK2:　コン　混乱　こんらん(disorder).
column12: L'ancienne question du mélange des races est ici posée en filigrane : ce mélange va « diluer » la qualité de nos descendants.   --

column11: As you pass by the muchacho taking the siesta, he cries out that he is thirsty and asks for something to drink. So you turn the water hose on him.  -    -  You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water.  -  The muchacho taking his SIESTA cries out that he is THIRSTY. So you pull out a bottle of WATER and pretend you´re going to give it to him...but then you dump it all on the ground before his eyes. HAHA, sucked in muchacho!!
column12: Alors que vous passez près du dormeur, il vous crie qu’il a soif, et vous braquez le tuyau d’arrosage vers lui.  --

column11: Imagine an audience with the emperor or the pope in which all those in attendance are sitting down, leaning against the wall, sleeping like our muchacho on siesta as the honorable host delivers his speech.  -    -  The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.  -  The man talking during his siesta (in his sleep) is saying strange things and drawing an audience.
column12: Imaginez le pape ou l’empereur donnant audience, et tous les assistants assis, semblables à notre dormeur pendant sa sieste, alors que l’honorable délivre son discours.   --

column11: The color of the serape or cloak of our muchacho on siesta is a dull brown, the color this kanji indicates.  -    -  Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you?  -  Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.
column12: La couleur du manteau de notre dormeur est de couleur brune.  --

column11: When the muchacho on siesta looks up at you and opens his mouth to talk, his voice is so hoarse that you cannot understand him.  -    -  If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice.  -  After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is hoarse (after all you ARE thirsty remember).
column12: Lorsque le dormeur s’adresse à vous, il ne fait que gronder de sa voix rauque et vous ne comprenez pas ce qu’il dit.  --

column11: You will have to imagine "capturing" a favorite aroma by having it gagged and bound up in a spoon.  -    -  The muchacho sits down bound up to enjoy his own aroma.  -  If you bind up a person and let him sit for several days, an unpleasant aroma will result.
column12: Lorsque la nuit tombe et que le soleil disparaît, vous ne pouvez plus voir votre dormeur, mais vous savez quand même qu’il est là...  --

column11: Something is so downright delicious that one spends the entire day with a spoon in hand gobbling it up.  -    -  Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..  -  It´s sooo delicious I could spoon it in all day.
column12: C’est si délicieux qu’on passerait la journée entière, la cuiller à la main, pour le déguster.  --  Dans l’usage, ce caractère comporte aussi la notion de très bien, ce qui n’est qu’un élargissement de sens du caractère. Une autre association conduit à quintessence, contenu.

column11: This kanji tells us that if you feed the flesh with too many delicious things, it soon picks up a thick layer of fat.  -    -  Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious.  -  Fat is the most delicious part of the flesh. (Note this refers to physical fat, not the concept of obesity obese (#494)).
column12: Si l’on nourrit la chair avec trop de choses délicieuses, la graisse ne va pas tarder à s'accumuler.  --

column11: The Roman numeral I - like that for II we met earlier in frame 379 - is only rarely used now. In the midst of all the samurai, we notice one in particular sitting on the ground with a crown on his head, indicating that he is "number I" in the current rankings.  -    -  I am ´the one´ , says the samurai with the crown around his waist and a spoon up his a***.  -  The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.
column12: De même que deux vu au cadre 382, le kanji I est utilisé principalement dans les actes officiels. Il montre notre vieux professeur, assis et couronné, vêtu d’un dossard portant le numéro un.   --

column11: "Behind every successful person lies a woman...," who usually turns out to be one's mama!  -    -  Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.  -  Who does every person want to lie down with? Yo´ MAMA!
column12: Toutes les personnes de ce monde sont nées d’une femme : la mère, protectrice durant 10 mois et dix jours2, avant qu’elles ne se retrouvent couchées sur le ventre (comme un nouveau-né).  --  En composant, vous pourrez associer le sens de lieu sombre, si le besoin s'en ressent. l'association découle directement de la mise en scène qui précède.

column11: Behind every successful taskmaster, the cleverness of a fox to outwit his charges.  -    -  Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness.  -  Cleverness is something every taskmaster must have. Every taskmaster has cleverness.
column12: Cet adjectif caractérise une personne vive d'esprit. Derrière tous les chefs de corvée du monde, on trouve la promptitude qui leur a donné l’avantage.  --

column11: Behind every Jack Horner's pie maker, a tree full of plums.  -    -  Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn´t know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree´s genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums.  -  EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my PLUMS fresh from the TREE.
column12: On trouve partout au Japon des prunes conservées en saumure. On les dit bonnes pour la santé et les Japonais recommandent d’en manger une tous les jours, le matin. Cela peut se comprendre si l’on sait que par exemple en Slovénie, la prune traitée au sel a une excellente réputation contre les excès de la veille. Mais créons une image un peu plus plus bucolique, en nous imaginant sortant tous les jours au jardin pour aller cueillir un fruit sur l’arbre aux prunes.   --

column11: Behind every drop of water, a sea from which it originated.  -    -  Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.  -  As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with ocean (#549).
column12: Dans toutes les gouttes d’eau, on trouve une mer de laquelle toute l’eau est venue, et à laquelle elle retourne.  --

column11: See someone lying down in a public place with a hook in place of a hand, begging a morsel of rice or a few pence.  -    -  Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.  -  Men beg lying down. Women beg as hookers.
column12: Quelqu’un est couché sur la place publique, le doigt tordu en forme d'hameçon, à mendier un bout de pain, une bouteille...  --

column6: dry; warming principle of the sun, penetrating and fertilizing, heavenly generative principle (male); trigram ☰; hexagram ䷀
column11: In times of drought anything at all will do. Here we see the victims begging for just a little mist for relief.  -    -  During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.  -  Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.
column12: En temps de sécheresse, rien ne va plus, On voit ici les victimes, mendier juste un petit peu de rosée, pour que le soleil ne brûle pas entièrement le sol.  --

column11: -    -  Beg in the road until you get what you want.  -  """I'm going to sit here by the side of the road, in front of the government building and beg until they give me a pension"", the war veteran said."
column12: Un mendiant croise votre route, et vous demande de quoi tenir jusqu’à demain, ou jusqu’à la prochaine ville.  --  Ce caractère, ainsi que divers autres portant la même clé de la route, peuvent voir varier d'une unité leur nombre de traits car il arrive que la route porte une goutte supplémentaire.

column11: If you double back (fold over) most animals - or people, for that matter - in the middle, the part of the body where the crease comes is the abdomen.  -    -  The only body part that doubles over.  -  Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful.
column12: Si vous pliez un animal en deux, ça cassera probablement au niveau de l’abdomen.   --

column11: In its original and etymologically transparent sense, to duplicate something means to double it back with a fold, like the fold of a cloak.  -    -  My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) cloak at a party, so she doubled back to change!  -  In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a "time-turner" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione´s time-turner with Harry´s invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates.
column12: Dupliquer revient à appliquer deux fois, donc à replier un pan, comme le pan d’un manteau. Et si l'on tente de replier encore, plus encore que dupliqué, cela deviendra compliqué, second sens du caractère.  --

column6: owe, lack, be deficient; Kangxi radical 76
column11: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.  -  * As a primitive, it can mean either yawn or lack.  -  To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.  -  When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.
column12: Le pictogramme caché dans ce kanji montre un individu en train de bâiller. Le premier trait représente la tête de notre personnage, le second le bras qui tente de recouvrir la bouche, et le reste le corps et les jambes. Comme le bâillement est dû à un manque quelconque (d’intérêt, de sommeil, psychologique), la relation d’un sens à l’autre est naturelle.  --  En composant, cet élément signifiera bâiller ou manquer, et parfois une bouche ouverte sans pour autant qu'elle soit en train de bâiller.

column11: To blow is really no more than a deliberate effort to make one's mouth lack all the air that is in it.  -    -  This is clearly a BLOWJOB, we can see the MOUTH and the LACK OF condom. (I am sorry for the image, but it sticks forever in your mind).  -  I keep confusing this with suck (#689). Consider someone blowing bubbles using their chewing gum because they´re lacking attention in class.
column12: Souffler n’est rien de plus qu’un effort délibéré pour faire en sorte que l’air en vienne à manquer dans notre bouche.   --

column11: Better to picture what happens when you do not pay attention to your work in the kitchen. Here we see a blazing fire and an inattentive, yawning cook who let things get out of control.  -    -  Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.  -  This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning.
column12: Mieux vaut imaginer ce qui se produit quand on ne fait pas attention à ce qui se passe à la cuisine. On voit en effet ici un chef en train de bâiller en face de ses fourneaux, alors que le feu ronfle et brûle la nourriture. Pensez en particulier à cuire le riz, car d’autres kanjis concernant d’autres modes de cuisson sont à venir.  --

column11: The song in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of can-can girls. Why it should be eliciting nothing but yawning from the audience, I leave to you to decide.  -    -  Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance.  -  Can-can dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a song, so audience of men is yawning in boredom.
column12: On verra ici un idéogramme fidèle de ce que les Japonais apprécient le plus au monde dans le domaine de la chanson : le karaoké (orchestre vide). Pour fonctionner, cette invention du diable (les géants de l’électronique japonais) demande la présence de l’appareil à karaoké, deux micros, et deux interprètes-clients du bar, faisant vraiment ce qu’ils peuvent. Honnêtement, le résultat est triste à pleurer, et cela me fait réellement baîller².  --  ² Luís Fróis ne dit rien d'autre : « Chez nous la musique chorale est sonore et douce ; celle du Japon, comme tous s'égosillent d'une seule voix, est la plus horrible que l'on puisse entendre. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)

column11: If the cushions of one's car are too soft, one may begin yawning at the wheel.  -    -  Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness.  -  If your car has really soft seats, you may start yawning and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge soft beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember).
column12: Si les sièges et suspensions de la voiture sont trop mous, nous commençons rapidement à bâiller.   --

column11: This key word connotes the "next in line" of a succession of people or things. Let there be a lack of ice on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out "Next!"  -  * As a primitive, this character can either retain its key word meaning of next or the related meaning of second.  -  Is this store lacking ice? Let´s try the next one, then.  -  A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next...
column12: Supposons que la glace vienne à manquer par une chaude journée d’été. Tout le monde attend en ligne, bâillant et trépignant d’impatience, que le distributeur de glace crie enfin : « au suivant ! ».  --

column11: Earlier we made mention of the story of Briar Rose (or "Sleeping Beauty," as we called her in frame 165) and drew attention to the briar hedge that grew up all about her castle. But in the second part of the story, these briars blossomed into flowers. Hence her name, Briar Rose. Be careful not to confuse this character with that for thorn (Frame 446).  -    -  To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.  -  The briar patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be flowers next, and it will be beautiful.
column12: Ce kanji est une exhort(icul)ation à prendre quelques précautions quand on cueille des roses (le végétal en haut), car la suivante pourrait bien être une redoutable épine, et l’on aurait tôt fait de se blesser.  --

column11: The first shells (money) you earn, you use to pay your debts. From then on, the next shells you accumulate become your assets.  -    -  Assets are the next best thing to money.  -  The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your ASSETS, you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!).
column12: Les premières coquilles - monnaies que l’on gagne servent en général à rembourser les dettes contractées auparavant. Cela fait, donc le mois suivant, on commence à amasser le capital.   --  Les sens de essentiel ou important sont associés.

column11: This kanji depicts a woman's figure as a sort of second self.  -    -  Whenever I am next to a woman, I can´t help but take notice of her figure.  -  The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you´ll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!
column12: Ce kanji signifie figure au sens le plus large, allant jusqu’à aspect des choses. Pour retenir son écriture, on y verra simplement la figure de la « femme suivante », celle qui relègue la légitime au rang des antiquités.  --

column11: To seek the words of a second mouth is to consult with someone about something.  -    -  Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.  -  Consulting with is having words with the next mouth.
column12: Chercher les mots d’une « seconde » bouche revient à consulter quelqu’un au sujet de quelque chose.  --  Chapitre dix-neuf Une muselière  Nous nous procurerons au cours de ce chapitre une muselière, les confins, le Diable et un porteur, tous bâtis à partir de formes connues. Après ce chapitre, il vous sera utile de revoir l'ensemble des kanjis vus depuis le chapitre 13. Ainsi, et même si vous n'avez rien noté, vous pourrez faire le point et procéder aux nécessaires éclaircissements, le cas échéant. Nous avons déjà dépassé notre premier demi-millier de caractères, mais plus important encore que ce nombre symbolique est le fait que vous soyez parvenu ici avec assurance, sans trop trébucher. Continuez ainsi et très bientôt nous passerons une nouvelle borne. Bravo !

column11: Picture a clam used as a muzzle to quiet the complaints of a fisherman's widow asking compensation for her husband lost at sea.  -    -  Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).  -  Compensation is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that muzzles.
column12: Une huître joue ici le rôle d'une muselière, pour faire taire les complaintes de la veuve du pêcheur demandant des dédommagements pour la perte de son mari disparu au large.  --

column11: The barrel hoops used by many Japanese farmers to stretch clear plastic over row of vegetables in a garden patch in the hopes of cultivating bigger and bigger vegetables is a way of muzzling the soil.  -    -  To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it´s unruly, chaotic nature.  -  The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).
column12: Les tunnels de plastique que les agriculteurs japonais utilisent abondamment ressemblent à de gigantesques muselières sur le sol.  --

column11: To "divide and conquer" you use a saber and a muzzle.  -    -  When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That´s why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.  -  Divide and conquer - first you cut them up (saber) , then you shut them up (muzzle).
column12: Protégé par la muselière, on dissèque avec le sabre.   --

column6: sound, tone, pitch, pronunciation; Kangxi radical 180
column11: The kanji for sound depicts something standing in the air over a tongue wagging in a mouth, much the same as a sound does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.  -  * The primitive from this kanji also means simply a sound.  -  If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you´d be making sound.  -  The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.
column12: Le kanji son décrit quelque chose debout dans l’air au-dessus de la bouche avec la langue qui s’agite, comme le fait le son pendant quelques instants avant de s’étouffer.  --

column11: When "darkness covered the earth" at the beginning of time, there was neither sun nor sound.  -    -  Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.  -  In places of complete darkness, such as caves where the sun can´t reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by sound rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming "Marco!" and "Polo!" all the time.
column12: Dans le monde sombre originel, il n’y avait ni Soleil ni son.  --

column11: Poetry restricted to verses that rhyme often finds it has to abandon clarity of thought in order to make the rhyme of the words work. In this kanji's picture, one becomes a kind of "sound-employee."  -    -  What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.  -  Dr Seuss´s employee finally rebels against him: "I´m tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!".
column12: Une poésie dont le seul but serait de parfaitement rimer pourrait montrer quelque manque de clarté. La rime est perçue ici comme un employé du son ou comme une entité sonore (revoyez au besoin le cadre 57). Pensez, pour retenir l’ordre des éléments, que le son est ici l’élément important.  --

column11: A person of discriminating intellect can tell the difference between mere kazoo-buzzing and words spoken wisely.  -    -  Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.  -  I have discriminating taste. I´d rather listen to the words of a lecture than attend a kazoo concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).
column12: Un individu ayant de grandes connaissances est capable de discerner les mots correctement prononcés parmi le tintamarre ou, pour remettre cela dans un vocabulaire moderne, les informations pertinentes parmi tous les gibits disponibles sur la toile.  --

column11: After lakes but before glass, polished metal was used for mirrors. These metal mirrors are recalled in this character for a mirror.  -    -  Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.  -  metal + stand up + sun + legs remember the legend of Amaterasu who retired in a cave. the other Gods brought a MIRROR made of polished METAL at the entrance of the cave. Amaterasu who was STANDING UP saw her image of the SUN and began to dance with her LEGS.
column12: Métal...confins. Quand le rayon lumineux parvient à un miroir, il ne peut aller au delà, il doit rebrousser chemin, il est arrivé aux confins de son monde. Après les lacs, c'est maintenant le métal qui est employé pour façonner les miroirs, et le kanji nous le rappelle.  --

column11: Imagine the boundary of a plot of land marked with gigantic mirrors enabling the landowner to keep trespassers in sight at all times.  -    -  In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.  -  This is an old trick to keep out migrants. You put a bunch of dirty mirrors on the boundary of your land and theirs. When they approach the boundary, what they see in the mirror is their own land and someone that looks like themselves, only dirtier, so they figure your country isn´t any better than their own and they head back home.
column12: Aux confins de notre terrain se trouve la ligne de la frontière, qui représente aussi la limite de notre environnement.  --

column11: A top hat hanging on a hook in the front hall, right where the deceased left it the day he died, reminds us of him and his kanji.  -  * In addition to deceased, the primitive meaning of to perish will also be used for this character.  -  The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.  -  The recently DECEASED are said to hang their hats on a hook by the door to the afterlife.
column12: Un chapeau haut de forme pendu au crochet, là où précisément l’avait laissé la veille de sa disparition, nous rappelle à lui et à son kanji.  --  * Le sens de périr sera également employé en composant.

column11: If one's eyes perish before death, one remains blind for the rest of life.  -    -  Deceased eyes! Easy ;).  -  A person with deceased eyes is blind.
column12: Si nos yeux périssent avant la mort, nous demeurons aveugles pour le restant de nos jours.  --

column11: The "ideal woman" one daydreams about is no more than a delusion. Hence, perish the thought of her.  -    -  I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here´s my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.  -  If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.
column12: Ce caractère défini divers concepts confinant au mensonge ou à l’absurdité. La « femme idéale », à laquelle on rêve chaque jour, n’est jamais qu’une obsession insensée : que périsse l’idée que nous en avons.  --

column11: The flowers that perish in the flood are taken here as symbols of an area that has been laid waste.  -    -  After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.  -  Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it´s flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use "waste" to avoid destroy (#365) demolition (#400).
column12: La notion de brutalité est rendue par l’image de végétaux périssant, emportées par des flots tumultueux.  --

column6: to look at, look forward; to hope, expect
column11: The story of ambition talks of a king walking under the perishing (or "waning") moon dreaming great dreams about his kingdom. (The roots of ambition are from the same word as "ambulate," meaning to walk about.)  -    -  You´re dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.  -  The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.
column12: L’histoire d'ambition nous présente un roi  contemplant la lune décrois­sante - mourante, et ambitionnant de grandes choses pour son royaume.  --  Repensez à tous les kanjis comprenant l'élément lune, partie du corps. Remarquez qu'à chaque fois qu'il apparaît à droite, c'est avec le sens de lune et que lorsqu'il apparaît à gauche, c'est avec celui de chair ou partie du corps. Puis retournez au kanji précédent fort de cette précieuse information, sans laquelle il est presque impossible de retenir l'ordre d'écriture des deux premiers éléments. Notez enfin que le kanji lac pourrait être une exception qui confirmerait cette règle.

column6: a square, rectangle; a region; local
