column11: Spinning a dagger about on its hilt on the top of a top hat - waiting to see in which direction it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.  -  * As a primitive, this character will take the sense of a compass, the instrument used to determine direction.  -  Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare ten thousand (#64). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.  -  I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won´t lose them.
column12: Quelque chose est emballé sous ce chapeau haut de forme. C'est sans doute un pigeon-voyageur, qui va prendre son envol, puis partir dans la direction de son colombier d'attache. Prenez garde en écrivant ce caractère, et revoyez 65  au besoin.  --  Le sésame sera une boussole, l'instrument à l'aide duquel le pigeon-voyageur détermine la direction de son pigeonnier d'attache. Ce caractère représente également une façon polie de dire moi, vous, il... Il faut comprendre que les Japonais aiment à parler à demi-mots, et qu'il est considéré comme trop « brutal » d'utiliser les pronoms en question, qui pourtant existent. Cette direction-là comprend-elle ce que cette direction-ci vient d'écrire ?

column11: Imagine a compass that is disturbed every time a woman passes by, sending the needle spinning madly round and round.  -    -  Capt. Jack Sparrow´s compass gets disturbed every time a beautiful woman walks by him (just picture Keira Knightley in her sexy asian outfit as Elizabeth and the image will be fixed forever).  -  One way to Disturb a woman is to give her directions while she is in the middle of driving -- she just can´t take that kind of stress.
column12: Imaginez une boussole dont le mouvement est entravé à chaque fois qu’une femme passe à portée, faisant tourner son aiguille dans tous les sens.  --

column6: neighborhood, urban subdivision; (J) priest's residence; (Buddhist) priest; boy
column11: The character for a boy shows us a Boy Scout cleaning the dirt out of his compass - the more dirt, the better.  -    -  Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.  -  Boys thoughts often head in dirty directions.
column12: Le kanji garçon montre un jeune garçon avec sa boussole pleine de terre. Plus sale ce sera, mieux ce sera.  --

column11: Here we see a special compass used to pick out those flowers most suited for making good perfumes.  -    -  She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers.  -  People always seem to overdo it with their perfume. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap flowery perfume. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that floweriness as a compass - it tells me which direction they´re in.
column12: Nous voyons ici une boussole spéciale, utilisée en vue de choisir les meilleurs végétaux pour faire un bon parfum.   --

column11: If you eat too much, you may need a compass to find your way around the obese mass of flesh that piles up in the midsection. Compare this with your stories for round (Frame 44) and fat (Frame 494), similar in meaning but distinct in imagery.  -    -  Flesh in all directions = obese.  -  Yo momma so obese, she changed the direction of the moon.
column12: Si l'on devient trop gras, on a bientôt besoin d’une boussole pour se repérer à travers la masse de graisse.  --

column11: When making a courtesy call on a dignitary, one has to gauge one's words with great care. Hence the need for a compass.  -    -  When you call on someone, you point your words in their direction.  -  When calling on a girl, you´d better what what sweet words will turn her fancy in your direction. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).
column12: Quand on rend une visite de courtoisie, on mesure les mots dans la bonne direction, grâce à la boussole, pour ne pas froisser l'interlocuteur.  --

column11: The taskmaster sets an unruly servant free, giving him no more than a quick glance at the compass and a boot from behind.  -    -  Go in any direction away from your taskmaster when you are set free.  -  When slaves were set free from their masters, they set off in all directions… RTK2:　ホウ　放射　ほうしゃ(radiation)… Pure group: 倣979.
column12: Lorsqu’on est libéré, on attrape en sortant la boussole du chef de corvée pour s'y retrouver dans le dédale de la vie active retrouvée.  --

column11: -    -  "Image: An Arctic explorer frozen within ice, within his hands are an umbrella and a compass."  -  Within minutes the weather changed and ice blew in from all directions making my umbrella useless…
column12: On emploie ce caractère pour définir un lieu, un instant ou un concept, avec le souci d’en décrire les relations avec l’entourage. Pour ce faire, on emploie la boussole, puis on « gèle » l’ensemble en le plaçant sous notre coupe, sous le parapluie, comme nous avons fait au cadre 410. Puis on explique ce qui se produit dans l’objet de notre étude.  --

column11: Some cosmic taskmaster hovering overhead whips up the waves to make them dash violently against the shore. In the white foam that covers the water we see a broken compass floating, all that remains of a shipwreck.  -    -  When the taskmaster found his favorite white compas damaged by water, he became the most violent taskmaster there ever was.  -  Overnight the slave got Violent and was Set Free. Overnight....Set Free.
column12: Un chef de corvée cosmique a levé une violente tempête, qui provoque de terribles vagues. Sous la masse blanche qui couvre l'eau, une boussole surnage, seul reste du naufrage.  --

column11: To undress is to expose the flesh and tempt the devil in the eyes of one's onlookers. Ignore the moral if you want, but not the devil.  -    -  HORNY TEENAGERS love to UNDRESS FLESH.  -  Before you undress I should warn you -- the sight of flesh brings out the devil in me.
column12: Se déshabiller revient à tenter le diable chez son compagnon ou sa compagne. Ignorez la morale au besoin, mais pas le diable.  --  Le caractère possède aussi le sens de s’enfuir. La première préoccupation du prisonnier qui s’enfuit étant de se déshabiller, afin de quitter les vêtements qui auraient tôt fait de le dénoncer...

column11: Not inappropriately, this character likens an explanation to the devil's own words.  -    -  The words of a horny teenager typically fall into one of two categories: either rumors or explanations.  -  The words of the devil incite rumours and false explanations.
column12: Dès que quelqu’un avance une thèse en une quelconque matière, rapidement apparaissent des critiques laissant passer les arguments qu’elle avance pour les propres mots du diable.   --

column11: Metal that has been pointed (as an awl, a pick, a nail, or a knife) tends to serve the devil's purposes as well as civilization's: our tools are also our weapons.  -    -  Pointed is the devil's metal pitchfork.  -  The Horny teenager who worked part time at a gold smelting plant always had uncontrollable errections that pointed out all the time, this is not a good thing to have when you work in a gold smelting plant, surely he will one day end up with a Goldmember!
column12: Le métal est taillé en pointe pour servir les intérêts du diable.   --

column11: This primitive (named for its associations with the kanji of the following frame) is composed of a pair of horns growing out of a brain with a tongue wagging in the mouth beneath. Think of "former" in connection with administrators or heads of state who have just left office but continue to make a nuisance of themselves by advertising their opinions on public policy.  -  * The primitive meaning, increase, comes from the next frame. Always think of something multiplying wildly as you watch.  -  The Artist formerly Known as Prince has the horniest brain around, and I think you can imagine what his wagging tongue is doing...  -  Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day. Nowadays it's done by machine.
column12: Ce caractère est formé d’une paire de cornes croissant sur un cerveau, au-dessus d’une bouche et de sa langue qui s’agite. Pensez à anciennement en imaginant les anciens administrateurs ou politiciens, qui ont quitté leurs fonctions, mais continuent à faire du bruit en exprimant leur opinion sur la nouvelle politique suivie.  --  Le sens du sésame dérive du caractère suivant ; voyez quelque chose se multipliant à vue d'œil.

column11: This kanji depicts an increase of soil, multiplying so fast that it literally buries everything in its path.  -    -  Prices always INCREASE for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.  -  Farmers work the land so they can INCREASE their formerly puny crop supply.
column12: Ce kanji décrit l'augmentation de sol résultant de l'accumulation des anciennes couches de terre dont l'épaisseur augmente graduellement au cours du temps.  --

column11: The presents offered here are money that increases each time you give it away. Do not confuse with the temporal word "present" (Frame 275).  -    -  Presents represent money that was formerly yours.  -  Imagine if the number of presents you get increases with each birthday. So on your first birthday, you receive just one shell as a present, but the next year it increases to two shells as presents, and so on, increasing and increasing so by the time you´re elderly, the number of shells you´ll get as presents will have increased to an awful lot of presents. GOT IT YET? PRESENTS = SHELLS + INCREASE.
column12: Les cadeaux, que l’on fait en permanence au Japon, sont ici constitués par de la monnaie dont la valeur augmente à chaque fois qu’on l’offre.  --

column11: As a "Western" language, English identifies the east with the rising sun. In more fanciful terms, we see the sun piercing through a tree as it rises in the east.  -  * Both the direction east and the part of the world called "the East" are primitive meanings of this character.  -  Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.  -  The sun pierces through the trees as it rises in the east…　　　　　　RTK2:　トウ　東北　とうほく (the northeast)　東京　とうきょう(Tokyo)… MIXED GROUP　凍506　(ﾁﾝ):陳1301　(ﾚﾝ): 練1343　錬2030.
column12: En tant que langue occidentale, le français identifie l’est et le soleil levant. On verra ici une image un peu plus poétique, montrant le soleil au travers d’un arbre, à mesure qu’il se lève, vers l’est.   --  *  En composant, on utilisera les sens d'Orient, Asie, et Japon.

column6: the main beams supporting a house
column11: If the piece of wood in the roof known as the ridgepole points east, the sunrise will be visible from the front door.  -    -  Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.  -  Ok just a note to the ´ridgepole facing east story´ im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a ´sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is´, back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).
column12: Si le tronc d’arbre qui sert de poutre faîtière est tourné vers l'orient, on pourra voir le soleil se lever depuis la porte d’entrée.  --  Par association, ce caractère signifie aussi corps de bâtiment.

column11: The whole secret to breaking the ice with the East is to peek behind those mysteriously "frozen smiles."  -    -  Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!  -  The ice will stay frozen until the sun is visible through the trees.
column12: Pour pouvoir « casser la glace avec les orientaux », il faut savoir forcer ces mystérieux sourires gelés.   --

column11: A woman who is in her pregnancy is a bit like a porter, bearing her new companion wherever she goes.  -    -  A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.  -  The gentleman gave the woman a bit of sperm...BAM PREGNANCY!
column12: Une femme  enceinte est une sorte de porteur, emportant son jeune compagnon avec elle, partout où elle va.  --

column11: Those who rule the courts, the porters of justice and order, are often found to stretch the law to suit their own purposes. Recall the kanji for prolong from frame 419 and keep it distinct.  -    -  A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.  -  The gentleman stretched the truth a bit in court.
column12: Ceux qui hantent les tribunaux, ceux qui sont « chargés » d’une affaire, trouvent leur notoriété dans la capacité qu’ils ont d’allonger les lois pour les adapter à leurs besoins.  --

column11: Soil and a scorpion (an "earth animal"). This is, of course, the full character from which the primitive for ground derives.  -    -  Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying ´no trespassing, scorpion mines´ if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.  -  The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the ground.
column12: Sol et scorpion : l’animal terrien. Ce caractère est celui duquel nous avions tiré le composant sol.   --

column11: Water . . . scorpion. It would be easy to slip into a "lazy image" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a scorpion near the water. But if you picture rather a scorpion letting its venom out drop by drop until it has made a whole pond of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed.  -    -  Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.  -  Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.
column12: Eau...scorpion. Le scorpion est un signe d'eau en astrologie occidentale. Cet animal des déserts vient ici se soulager de la chaleur au bord d'un étang...  --

column11: Work with the pictograph as you wish.  -  * As a primitive, this insect will refer to the whole insect kingdom; it can be further specified for each kanji that contains it.  -  I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.  -  Insect in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.
column12: Milieu...couché. L’insecte vient piquer en plein milieu l’individu couché sur le dos, qui semblait pourtant si bien se reposer.  --  Dans les kanjis, la classe des insectes regroupe aussi reptiles et batraciens. Soyez donc indulgent vis à vis de certaines associations.

column11: Schoolhouse . . . insect.  -    -  Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become lightning bugs. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become lightning bugs.  -  Q: Who´s the smartest insect in school? A: The lightning-bug. Because he´s so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).
column12: Le luciole est un insecte qui va à l’école, sans doute pour y apprendre à luire !  --

column11: Insect . . . house . . . spoon.  -    -  Solid Snake crawled like a bug, infiltrated my house, and took out everyone with a spoon.  -  A snake eats insects and he does that outside, while we eat another snake in the house and preferably with a spoon.
column12: L’image d’un serpent dévorant des insectes, armé d’une cuiller en sa maison doit être suffisamment insolite.  --  * En composant, seule la partie de droite est employée (cette précision est inutile dans le cadre de ce livre mais vous servira plus tard).

column11: Insect . . . craft.  -    -  Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.  -  Rainbow is of course created by billions of colored insects (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the insect primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: rainbow is an Insect-Craft. Mnemonic: I.C. Rainbow (I see rainbow).
column12: Les gros scarabées irisées qui foisonnent au Japon sont réellement capables de fabriquer toutes les couleurs de l’arc-en-ciel.   --

column11: Insect . . . generation . . . tree.  -    -  A butterfly is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.  -  Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).
column12: Sans arbres, les insectes que sont les papillons ne pourraient fabriquer le cocon qui donnera la génération suivante.  --

column11: Think of this key word in connection with bachelorhood. The elements: wild dogs . . . insect.  -    -  The bachelor´s apartment looked like it had been attacked by a pack of wild dogs. There were even insects in the kitchen. No wonder he´s single!  -  A SINGLE guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.
column12: Voyez un célibataire endurci, entouré de sa meute de chiens, et se livrant à son passe-temps favori : la collecte des insectes.   --  Pour des raisons d’homonymie, ce kanji symbolise l’Allemagne. Nous verrons de loin en loin les noms de divers pays, auquels furent affixés des kanjis dont la prononciation, pour une oreille japonaise tout au moins, ressemble au nom du pays concerné.

column11: Heavens . . . insect. Be sure to do something about the position of the two elements.  -    -  There are no insects in heaven - well, that is, except for silkworms. What, do you expect Jesus to import his fancy robes from China?  -  In China it was believed that the silkworms were insects sent from heaven because of the beautiful material they produced.
column12: Le ver à soie est présenté un peu comme un « don du Ciel », ce que montre graphiquement le kanji, qui place l’insecte exactement sous les cieux.   --

column6: wind; air; manners, atmosphere; Kangxi radical 182
column11: Windy . . . drops of . . . insects. Hint: think of the last two primitives as representing a swarm of gnats, those tiny drops of pesky insects.  -    -  They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.  -  The WIND usually carries things around in it - drops of rain or snow, and lots of insects.
column12: Voici posé le gros problème de l’« effet papillon » : un papillon (une goutte d’insecte) volant aux antipodes pourrait-il avoir un effet sur la vitesse du vent enregistrée en notre vieille capitale ?  --  La notion de style, particulier à une culture, est aussi comprise dans ce kanji. Pensons alors aux marchandises exotiques que nous apportent les vents du large.

column6: self, oneself; personal, private; 6th heavenly stem
column11: The kanji carries the abstract sense of the self, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a snake - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, oneself (frame 36) and I (frame 17).  -  * As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the snake - of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the snake has in myth and fable.  -  This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".  -  When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.
column12: Ce kanji contient le sens abstrait de soi, c’est à dire la structure interne de la personne humaine (le « cerveau reptilien »), que la mythologie a souvent décrite sous la forme d’un serpent, dont on verra ici un pictogramme.  --  Le sésame sera parfois un serpent, en accord avec ce qui précède.

column6: rise, stand up; go up; begin
column11: Run . . . snake.  -    -  Be careful when you´re RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you´ll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!  -  Nothing will rouse you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you´ve never run before!
column12: Courir...soi. Ce kanji décrit ce qui donne lieu au commencement d'une action. Il montre comment la personne se met soudain en marche, ou plus exactement si nous suivons les composants, comment le soi se met en course.  --

column11: Woman . . . snake.  -    -  Cleopatra.  -  Be careful you don´t pick up a drag queen at a club - they might look like women, but they have a snake down there!
column12: Femme...serpent. Par l’influence qu’elle a sur le roi, la reine tient presque plus d’importance que ce dernier sur la conduite des affaires du royaume. De là à l’associer à quelque empoisonnement (le serpent) pour favoriser un cousin ou descendant, comme cela s’est produit parfois, il n’y a qu’un pas.  --

column11: Pluralizing the snake and focusing on a single taskmaster may help recommend the image of Ireland's most famous reformer, St. Patrick, who, legend has it, drove away the snakes from the land.  -    -  The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.  -  This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).
column12: Soi...chef de corvée. Lorsqu’on tente de réformer les choses, c’est en principe pour les améliorer, et l’on se fait quelquefois violence. Le kanji nous propose ici d’être notre propre chef de corvée.   --

column11: Words . . . snake.  -    -  A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).  -  Snakes have no hands. So, when a snake needs to write down something, it has to call in a SCRIBE, who will write down all the sayings of the snake.
column12: Imaginez-vous remplissant un formulaire. Et devant la complexité de la chose, votre crayon va de haut en bas, de bas en haut, en zigzag, serpentant à travers la page, pour y inscrire quelques mots.   --

column11: Bind up . . . snake.  -  * The primitive meaning of wrap should always be used with the snake in mind to avoid confusion with similar terms. Just let "wrap" mean "with a snake coiled about it."  -  The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.  -  Imagine Jessie sending in her Ekans (snake pokemon), and telling it to use bind attack to wrap up pikachu.
column12: Emballage..serpent. Si vous vous imaginez dans la gueule du boa con­strictor, vous ne devriez pas avoir de problème particulier avec ce kanji.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . wrap.  -    -  Imagine a newborn baby, fresh out of the womb, being entirely wrapped by the long piece of flesh, called a placenta, that once fed him.  -  Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.
column12: Partie du corps...emballer. Où l’on constate que bien souvent les kanjis appellent un chat un chat. Le sens premier, cellule, est aussi fort bien rendu par la juxtaposition des deux sésames employés.  --

column11: Stones . . . wrap.  -    -  Primitive cannons fired stones wrapped with poisonous snakes.  -  Cannon = stone projectile wrapped by a barrel.
column12: Pierre...emballer. Si cela pouvait être vrai.  --

column11: Water . . . wrap.  -    -  When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.  -  To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the bubbles with water.
column12: Eau...emballer. Soufflez dans l’eau !  --

column11: This is not a turtle (See frame 250) but a tortoise, however you wish to picture the difference. Let the "bound up" at the top refer to the head, and the two suns, with a long tail running through it, to the shell.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji is abbreviated to its bottom half, ⻲, and comes to mean eel. (If it is any help, this kanji in its full form can also be remembered through its abbreviation's primitive meaning.)  -  It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.  -  A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.
column12: Certes, cela n’a pas grand-chose à voir avec une tortue. On pourrait reconnaître la tête dans « emballé » situé en haut, et voir dans le reste, formé de deux soleils et de l'hameçon, la carapace et les pattes.  --  Nous avions vu en 250 que les anciens Chinois décryptaient les carapaces fissurées de tortues. De fait, le sens de fissure est également compris dans le présent caractère. À titre de jeu, vous pouvez aussi construire une saynète à partir de l'ancienne forme du kanji tortue : 龜.

column11: Rain/weather . . . eel.  -    -  Think of a two natural sources of electricity: electrical storms (a form of weather) and electrical eels. 電話 でんわ phone, call.  -  This kanji was invented by the first Chinaman to discover electricity. He was so unfortunate, he stepped on an electric eel and got struck by lighting at the same time.
column12: Tonnerre...hameçon. Le hameçon recueille l’électricité fournie par les éclairs du tonnerre.  --  * En composant, seule la partie inférieure sera utilisée : .

column11: Vase . . . eel. In order not to confuse this kanji with the zodiacal sign of the dragon, which we will meet later (Frame 2164) and use as a primitive, you might think here of a paper parade dragon.  -    -  Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.  -  If the poor villagers don´t provide him with a vase full of eels each day, the dragon will lay waste to the village.
column12: Le dragon est un animal terrifiant, qui se dresse ici devant vous, crachant un feu électrique.   --

column6: onomatopoeic for the sound of falling rain; an ancient name for Wu Shui; a place in Guangdong
column11: Water . . . vase . . . eels. To avoid the confusion mentioned in the previous frame, the character learned there for dragon should not be used as a primitive.  -    -  The Water Dragon dwells in the waterfall.  -  Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?
column12: Eau...dragon. Le plus simple sera de voir cette cascade comme une gargouille à tête de dragon crachant l'eau depuis le bord du toit de la cathédrale.  --

column6: small pig, suckling pig; shuffle one's feet
column11: Flesh . . . sow.  -    -  Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.  -  One possible pictograph for "sow" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow´s legs.
column12: Chair...truie. La truie étant réservée à la reproduction, c’est le porc dont la chair nous intéresse le plus.  --

column11: Sows . . . road.  -    -  In association with consummate (#579), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.  -  The pig is on the road in the pursue of the turtle who is trying to escape (#283). (See story on escape (#301) & consummate (#579)).
column12: Truies...route. Sans doute avez-vous un souvenir d’enfance de quelques jours de vacances à la campagne pour établir une relation simple entre les éléments et le kanji.  --

column11: The horns atop the sow suggest a boar at work in the background. Add the element for a road. Now create a story whose meaning is: consummate.  -    -  This is still Miss Piggy only she´s gotten horny (as she often does) and now she´s pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.  -  In association with pursue (#578), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they´ve consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.
column12: Dans le sens de « mission réussie ». Les deux cornes suggèrent un verrat au travail... Ajoutez-y l’élément poursuivre pour créer une histoire dont la chute serait « mission réussie ».   --

column11: This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. To help a little, this kanji recalls the times when the "domestic" animals were, as the word itself suggests, really kept in the house. Hence: house . . . sow.  -    -  Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.  -  Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.
column12: Maison...truie. Voici le kanji d’où fut tiré le composant de même nom. Il relate le temps où hommes et animaux vivaient sous le même toit.  --

column6: to marry, give a daughter in marriage
column11: The kanji in this frame demonstrates the traditional Japanese approach to marriage: it is the woman who leaves her family for another household, thus marrying into a man's family.  -    -  Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she´s married into the house than into a relationship.  -  Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband´s families.
column12: Une femme devient une bru quand elle quitte le toit familial pour aller dans une autre maison. Comme pour les verbes donner et recevoir, il existe en japonais plusieurs verbes signifiant « se marier », variant selon la personne. Ce kanji signifie donc aussi prendre mari.  --

column11: Tall . . . crowned . . . sow.  -    -  In Orwell´s ´Animal Farm´ the pigs overpowered every other animals. They crownded themselves as ruler of the farm and walked tall on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.  -  Ganon, the tall crowned pig, has been overpowering ther land of Hyrule for decades.
column12: Dans le sens de « victoire écrasante ». Le kanji met en scène le plus grand lutteur sumo, celui qui porte la couronne, après sa victoire écrasante sur l’adversaire.  --  Ce caractère symbolise également l’Australie, bien qu’il n’y ait pas de corres­pondance sonore...Cependant la présence d'un monolithe d’une masse écrasante au centre du désert australien suggère une correspondance.

column11: Flesh . . . piggy bank.  -    -  Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.  -  Taking things too literally, you used a real piglet as a piggy bank. Now when you smash it open to get your coins out, you have to dig out your coins from its intestines. ew.
column12: S'il est une partie du corps où nous aimons bien ressentir la chaleur bienfaisante de la lumière solaire matinale, c'est peut-être bien le ventre, là où se trouvent nos intestins.  --

column11: Soil . . . piggy bank.  -    -  You´re looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that´s easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to remember like this kanji.  -  Don´t confuse with place (#1208). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You´ve buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can´t remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.
column12: Le sens de ce kanji est « lieu d’une certaine surface dans lequel on pratique une activité quelconque ». Nous imaginerons une grande surface au centre d'un village, une aire où ont lieu diverses activités. C'est donc un terrain au grand jour, éclairé par la lumière solaire.  --  Ce kanji définit aussi la notion de champ, bien connue du physicien ou du mathématicien : à chaque endroit de l’espace (terrain) est associée une grandeur, vectorielle ou scalaire. Ici, nous pourrions mesurer en tout point l'énergie reçue de la lumière solaire, celle du champ électromagnétique solaire, cela va sans dire.

column11: Water . . . piggy bank.  -    -  Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!  -  Hot water is a phrase that can mean "getting into trouble." This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it´s water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!
column12: En présence de lumière solaire, l'eau devient de l'eau chaude. Pourquoi faire plus compliqué ?  --

column11: This pictograph shows the animal horns at the top attached to the head (3rd stroke), the front and back legs (strokes 4 and 5) and body (final stroke).  -  * The primitive meaning of sheep can add the further connotations given in the following frame. As we saw with the cow, the "tail" is cut off when it is set immediately over another element: ⺷. Note the change in stroke order, as exemplified in the following frame.  -  Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.  -  Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.
column12: Deux cornes...une tête...quatre pattes...une queue. Ceci pourrait bien être un mouton.  --  * Nous utiliserons l'image des moutons de Panurge. La queue du mouton sera coupée comme celle de la vache quand un autre élément vient au-dessous.

column11: Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of beauty with a large sheep.  -    -  I guess this kanji proves it´s not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.  -  A Sheep on top of a dog is NOT a beautiful thing.
column12: Tentez d’imaginer où en étaient les anciens sages chinois quand ils ont décidé d’associer l’idée de beauté à celle de grand mouton.   --  La queue du mouton subit le même sort que celle de la vache quand un autre élément vient au-dessous.

column11: Water . . . sheep. Be sure to keep the stories and key word of this kanji distinct from those for sea. (Frame 500).  -    -  This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.  -  Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.
column12: L’océan est une vaste étendue d’eau parcourue par les crêtes blanches des vagues ; on dit alors que l'océan moutonne.  --

column11: The abbreviation Esq. will help associate this character with the honorific form of address to which it belongs. Its elements are: tree . . . sheep . . . grains of rice. Note that the final vertical stroke in the element for sheep is extended to form the first stroke for grains of rice.  -    -  Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice.  -  This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you´d definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.
column12: Au sens de apparence s’ajoute une forme honorifique de Monsieur, Madame, selon un phénomène d’assimilation semblable à celui vu en 544. Pour avoir l’apparence d’un monsieur, il nous faut posséder un arbre, un mouton, et un bon système d’irrigation  !   --

column11: Words/speaking . . . sheep.  -    -  Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".  -  Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?
column12: Sur la place du marché, avant de vendre un mouton, on en vante les qualités de façon détaillée, pour en tirer le meilleur prix.  --

column11: Fish . . . sheep.  -    -  The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are "counting sheep." (If you´ve ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).  -  This one´s easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, "SH", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.
column12: Plus encore que les fruits et légumes, la viande marine ou terrestre doit être fraîche.   --

column11: The key word is meant to connote someone "skilled" at something. On the road we find soil OVER a sheep. You may have to work with this one a while longer.  -    -  Dolly (the first cloned sheep ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an ACCOMPLISHED escapist, as she managed to dig a road under the soil. /Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.  -  The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had accomplished many things.
column12: Dans le sens de « quelqu’un doué pour quelque chose ». Ce mouton accompli s’est déguisé en se mettant une motte de terre sur la tête, pour que le berger ne le remarque pas sur la route.   --  De façon corollaire, ce kanji est une marque de « pluriel respectueux ». Plus tard viendra un pluriel « peu respectueux » !

column11: Sheep . . . water . . . yawn/lack. Although this character looks rather simple, special care should be taken in learning it because of the proximity of the final two elements to the character for next, which we learned in frame 510. Note, too, that the water comes UNDER the sheep, rather than on its own to the left.  -    -  A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.  -  Envious of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the sheep looks down in disgust at his own dry grass lacking water.
column12: Revenons à nos moutons : on voit ici le strict idéogramme du second mouton de Panurge; il vient de constater qu’il lui manque l'eau, et est subitement devenu envieux du premier.  --  La chose présentée ainsi vous évitera d’écrire l’élément de suivant en partie supérieure, ou de placer l’eau en face des deux autres éléments.

column6: to differ; different, wrong; nearly, almost; an officer
column11: Wool . . . craft.  -    -  This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many distinctions playing WoolCraft (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).  -  Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it´s the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!
column12: La différence présentée ici est celle qui sépare le mouton avec la laine du mouton après la tonte, sans laine, une différence très courte dans le temps et énorme dans l'apparence. C'est le métier qui fait toute la différence.  --

column11: I cannot resist doing this one for you, since it clearly describes donning (putting on) one's clothes as "pulling the wool over one's eyes."  -    -  A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.  -  Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.
column12: Ce kanji décrit le fait de placer un vêtement sur la moitié supérieure du corps, et c'est bien ce que racontent les éléments : laine...yeux.   --  De même que le kanji vu au cadre 553 contenait l’idée d’évasion, celui-ci contient celle d’arrivée. Du reste, quand le train arrive à destination, on enfile son pull­over ou sa veste ! Nous verrons plus loin une explication plus convaincante, mais pour le moment si celle-ci vous convient, tenez-vous y !

column11: Mouth . . . turkey.  -    -  The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.  -  Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.
column12: Bouche...dindon. Le dindon est l'unique animal à savoir pousser le cri qu’il sait pousser.  --

column11: Words . . . turkey.  -    -  Do you remember that song where they say "Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?  -  [who; someone; somebody] You´re alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone speaking. "Who´s there?", you say, but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a turkey gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).
column12: Dire...dindon. Périodiquement réapparaissent des programmes de radio ou télévision au cours desquels l’animateur est chargé de deviner quelle célébrité se chache derrière une voix dont le timbre est brouillé par un artifice électronique, à tel point que la voix devient comparable au cri du dindon. L’une de ces émissions, animée par José Artur, s’appelait à juste titre « à qui ai-je l’honneur ». Titre au demeurant remarquablement choisi, puisqu’aujourd’hui, il nous permet de comprendre comment dire-mots et dindon s’associent pour signifier qui.   --

column11: Turkey . . . oven fire.  -    -  When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I´m not a very good cook.  -  Char could be any meat over oven fire. So why is it a turkey in this kanji? Because charred turkey is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.
column12: Dinde...four. L’image légendaire de la dinde de Noël, et de l’excita­tion qui règne habituellement à cette époque de l'année nous mènent tout naturellement à la laisser carboniser.   --  Foyer optique est une signification associée.

column11: Rocks . . . char.  -    -  Coral reefs are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like charred stone. For a picture illustrating this, see http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg.  -  Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or "rock that has been charred".
column12: Les légendes de marins nous fourniront une image du récif, dangereux amas de pierres sur lequel les navires échouent et se carbonisent.  --

column11: Turkeys . . . atop a tree.  -    -  Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!  -  Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...
column12: Voici le rassemblement dynamique évoqué au cadre 272. Dans la dinde unique perchée sur cet arbre, il faudrait imaginer un rassemblement d’oi­seaux avant le grand départ pour les migrations. La forme ancienne de ce kanji montrait d’ailleurs trois dindes, soit des dindes partout, partout !  --

column11: Ice . . . turkey.  -    -  Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn´t actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!  -  An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.
column12: Glace...dinde. Ceci est donc notre dinde, encore congelée. C’est à dire quasi carbonisée, puisque bientôt elle va aller au four en passant par la case 615.  --  Ce caractère est une abréviation du kanji 準 (cadre 622, ci-dessous) mais comme il sert notamment à transcrire le mot « ratification » (批准(ひじゅん)) on l’a maintenu dans la liste des kanjis d’usage courant.

column11: Turkey . . . road.  -    -  Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.  -  [re: raulir] Animals on the road: Turtles escape (#283) and Pigs pursue (#539), while the Turkeys advance (looking very formidable indeed).
column12: Alors que l’image obtenue plus haut avec les truies page 156 était assez effrayante, on verra ici simplement un troupeau de dindes, progresser lentement mais sûrement sur la route.   --

column11: Baseball . . . trees . . . turkey.  -    -  Newscast: "Among today´s miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!".  -  On the left we have baseball and wood, which obviously means a baseball bat. Instead of balls, there are miscellaneous other objects you may hit with it. While beating people may be one favorite use, in this case we see it used for making turkey mash.
column12: Notre dindon s'alimente des graines les plus diverses, provenant de neuf arbres différents. Cette courte scène est sans doute la façon la plus simple de retenir le tracé de ce caractère qui résulte probablement de la simplification d'une construction plus complexe.  --

column11: This character for female forms a pair with that for male, which we will learn later (Frame 804). The elements: footprint . . . spoon . . . turkey.  -    -  Stop | spooning | turkeys. Spoon females.  -  To become feminine you must stop using a spoon to eat turkey and use a knife and fork like a proper lady.
column12: Ici...dinde. Ce terme concerne les animaux. Nous verrons son corres­pondant par la suite.  --

column11: Think of this in terms of the semifinals of some sports competition. Water . . . turkeys . . . needle.  -    -   Boiling a turkey in water for 10 minutes will only make it semi-cooked.  -  The anhinga, or water turkey, has a needle-like nose, so really it´s only a semi-turkey http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anhinga.
column12: Pensez à la demi-finale d’une compétition sportive. L’eau et la dinde du haut suggèrent une collation. En bas, l’aiguille.  --

column11: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . rice field/brains.  -    -  The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?  -  Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The St. Bernard stirred up a crowd of turkeys and caught one. It bit the head, brains spilling onto the rice field.
column12: Grand homme...dinde...rizière. Cette fois notre grand homme avec la dinde traverse la rizière à grandes enjambées car il s'est fait remarquer. Tout cela suggère une grande excitation.  --

column11: Whereas burglary (Frame 381) implies clandestine appropriation of another's property, robbery refers to taking by force. The primitive elements: St. Bernard dog . . . turkey . . . glue.  -    -  Remember the scene in A Christmas Story where the big dogs robbed the family of their Christmas turkey? Well, the following year Ralphie´s mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.  -  Don´t let the neighbor´s St.Bernard rob tonight´s turkey....glue it to the table if you must.
column12: Grand homme...dinde...colle. L’idée de dérober est bien de s'emparer par la force du bien d'autrui. On verra dans ce grand homme un voleur de poules qui se colle une dinde sur le dos pour la dérober.  --

column11: On the left you see the rock, which is familiar enough. But pay attention to the right. Taking careful note of the unusual stroke order that has the "chimney" on the house doubled up with the first stroke of the turkey, we may see the right side as a turkey house (or "coop"). We shall see this pattern only on one other occasion (Frame 2093), but even for these two characters it is well worth the trouble to single it out as a primitive.  -    -  To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!  -  You´ve heard the expression "killing two birds with one stone." (一石二鳥 is-seki-ni-chou). We´ll, there´s another one that roughly translates as "killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. " That´s the method that hunters use when they want absolute assurance of taking home a bird.
column12: A gauche, le caillou ; à droite, prenez garde au trait peu habituel, commun à la cheminée de la maison et la tête de la dinde. Cette image de « poulailler » est rare mais utile. Alors, assurez-vous avec certitude que la dinde ne sorte pas de son poulailler, en plaçant une grosse pierre devant la porte.  --

column10: Midi, signe du cheval dans le zodiaque chinois
column11: With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftwards in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of noon. Note how this kanji primitive differs from that for cow (Frame 260).  -  * As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a horse. Any horse image will do, except that of a team of horses, which will come later (Frame 2132) and get its own primitive.  -  Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).  -  Noon is the hour of the horse.
column12: En forçant un peu vous pourrez voir la tête d’un cheval inclinée vers la gauche dans ce caractère. Cela nous donne le signe du cheval dans le zodiaque chinois, le septième signe, correspondant à l’heure de midi. Le zodiaque chinois partage les 24 heures de la journée en douze périodes de 2 heures, mais dans la pratique, seule la période du cheval ici décrite est encore couramment employée². En composant, nous utiliserons le sens de cheval. N'importe quelle idée de cheval conviendra, à condition que ce ne soit pas un troupeau de chevaux, dont le galop est encore lointain, mais qui approche...  --  ² Autrefois la mesure du temps répondait à des règles surprenantes : « Nous comptons les heures de 1, 2, 3, jusqu'à 12 ; les Japonais les comptent de cette manière : 6, 5, 4, 9, 8, 7, 6, etc. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)

column11: Words . . . horse.  -    -  If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.  -  Mr Ed ( a famous talking horse ) was finally at a loss for words when told he would need a permit for public speaking.
column12: Comme le cheval possède un statut spécial parmi les animaux de bouche­rie. il ne suffit pas, comme pour le mouton, de bien le détailler pour le vendre : une autorisation officielle est nécessaire.  --

column11: Again I cannot resist sharing my own associations. If you've ever seen Disney's animated interpretation of classical music, "Fantasia," you will recall what was done there with Beethoven's "Pastoral Symphony" (the 6th), and the flying horses that figured in it. The mares are bathing in the stream and the stallions begin to gather. As dusk sets in, the flying horses all start yawning and pair off for the night: a perfectly delightful portrait of delight.  -    -  Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.  -  I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.
column12: Pégase...bâiller. Lorsque Pégase se prend à bâiller, on peut entendre un gazouillement superbe, quelque chose d’extrêmement ravissant.   --

column11: Tree . . . Pegasus.  -    -  I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.  -  No one has the authority to tie up a pegasus to a tree!
column12: Arbre...Pégase. Pégase a le pouvoir secret de déraciner les arbres sur lesquels il vient à se poser.  --

column11: Pegasus . . . see.  -    -  Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can´t see: they both crash all the time.  -  I used to hate birds.They´re loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.
column12: Pégase...voir. Imaginons la perspective que voit Bellérophon juché sur le dos de Pégase.   --

column11: From the pictograph of two bird-wings, we get feathers.  -  * The related image of wings can be added as a primitive meaning. It can also take the form ョョ when used as a primitive, as we shall see in frames 618 and 619.  -  Pictograph. Easy enough.  -  These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.
column12: La plume naît du pictogramme de deux ailes d’oiseau.   --

column11: Feathers . . . white bird.  -    -  Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...  -  Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you´ll receive when you have learned the kanji!
column12: Plumes...oiseau blanc. Repensez un instant au merveilleux voyage de Nils Holgersson, écrit par Selma Lagerlof. Le petit Nils avait eu la chance de voir sa taille réduite considérablement, et il était parti apprendre le Monde sur le dos d’une oie sauvage.  --  Il est amusant de savoir que ce livre avait été écrit à la commande du ministère suédois de l’éducation, afin d’apprendre aux jeunes Suédois à connaître leur pays.

column6: bright; daybreak, dawn; the next day
column11: Feathers . . . vase. Be sure to contrast the connotation of this keyword with that for next (Frame 510).  -    -  The following segment is sponsored by...Swiffer - who make excellent feather dusters for cleaning your vases.  -  Your feathers would also stand up if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: "The following!".
column12: Un vase à plumes fournit l’image d’un pigeon d’argile. Et vous attendez que la machine vous lance celui d’après sans plus tarder.  --

column6: glorious, as sun; daylight, sunlight; one of the seven planets of pre-modern astronomy (the sun, the moon, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn)
column11: Day . . . feathers . . . turkey.  -    -  Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , laundry (#577), leap (#1285), outstanding (#2272), twinkle (#2534), shimmering (#2880). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.  -  The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.
column12: À gauche, le jour ; à droite, une dinde dont les plumes s’en vont. Dans votre atelier imaginaire, faites-vous un calendrier hebdomadaire découpé en forme de dinde, à sept feuillets sur chacun desquels vous écrivez les noms de chacun des jours : Soleil, Lune, feu, eau, arbre, or, Terre. Et sur chaque feuillet, vous écrivez aussi le caractère présent pour obtenir jour du Soleil, jour de la Lune, Jour du feu, etc. qui suivent les noms du Soleil, de la Lune et des planètes. Puis vous effeuillez votre semainier, en regardant la dinde perdre ses plumes chaque jour de la semaine.   --

column11: Water . . . feathers . . . turkey  -    -  At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.  -  When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don´t have clothes).
column12: On rince à la buanderie. Mais cette pièce est aussi le lieu où l’on trouve l'eau en quantité, et où l’on plume les animaux de basse-cour. Donc la dinde y perd ses plumes.   --  Chapitre vingt et un Déformations  Peut-être pouvons-nous faire une autre pause pour observer comment les composants se déforment lorsqu'ils entrent au sein d'un kanji, toujours inscriptible dans un carré de taille fixe. Nous avons déjà fait çà et là des allusion à ces déformations, mais maintenant votre aptitude à écrire les kanjis a crû et vous commencez à mieux tenir votre crayon. Voici succintement les principales déformations rencontrées jusqu'à présent : - À gauche, un composant sera souvent comprimé horizontalement, et sa partie droite se déformera parfois, pour mieux se fondre avec l'élément placé à sa droite. Par exemple, or 金 devient  et arbre 木 est équarri en . - De longs traits formant crochet, et qui en temps normal s'allongent, comme allant vers le caractère suivant dans la logique de l'écriture, se trouvent resserrés en des formes angulaires s'ils sont placés en composant sur la gauche. On repensera à lumière 光, qui devient  dans rayonner 輝. - De façon semblable, les éléments placés au bas d'un kanji sont aplatis. C'est pas exemple le cas de femme 女 qui devient  dans banquet 宴. - Le long trait vertical qui coupe une série de traits horizontaux est souvent coupé sous le dernier de ces traits lorsqu'un autre élément vient au-dessous. C'est ce que nous avons remarqué pour vache 牛 , mouton 羊  ou pinceau . - Ainsi mentionné au second paragraphe, le long trait s'étendant vers la droite, par exemple dans le kanji feu, 火, est raccourci considérablement et tendra à aller vers le bas quand un autre élément se trouvera sur sa droite, comme dans lampe 灯. - À plusieurs reprises, nous avons remarqué que certains traits faisaient double emploi. Ce fut par exemple le cas dans commerce 商. - Enfin, il existe des substitutions complètes, au cours desquelles un caractère est transformé en un composant dont la forme n'a rien à voir avec celle du kanji original. C'est notamment le cas pour eau ou feu. En pareil cas, et compte tenu fait les formes complètes de ces mêmes caractères interviennent aussi en tant que composant, nous avons assigné aux formes « dégénérées » une signification supplémentaire, pour nous assurer que les histoires commandent d'écrire le kanji  L'ensemble de ces réflexions sur l'écriture des kanjis pourra être complété et précisé par vous-même à mesure de votre progression et de votre aptitude à bien écrire. Tentez, si vous ne l'avez pas encore fait, en traçant le kanji sur votre fiche, de l'écrire lentement, en portant attention à tous ces détails graphiques. Comme l'ordre des traits n'est maintenant plus votre principal souci, vous pouvez être plus attentif à l'allure générale du caractère. Veillez à écrire lentement les caractères, afin de bien en maîtriser le tracé.  Comme vous savez maintenant tracer de vous-même la plupart des kanjis qui vont apparaître, nous nous dispenserons d'en indiquer l'ordre de tracé. Le nombre de traits sera indiqué en petits caractères, à gauche de chaque kanji, mais en cas de doute possible ou à chaque nouvel élément présenté, le tracé et le nombre de traits seront indiqués comme d'habitude.

column11: Pent in . . . one. The key word refers to famous sayings of famous people, and is the origin for the primitive meaning of a tongue wagging in the mouth that we learned in frame 12. The size of this kanji, a relatively rare one, is what distinguishes it from day.  -    -  Sayeth?! Who the hell says "sayeth"? Doesn´t seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like "day" but doesn´t seem "quite right.".  -  When pent up alone, one sayeth little.
column12: Enceinte...un. Ce kanji est employé pour citer des personnalités. Il est à l’origine de l’élément langue qui s’agite dans la bouche, introduit au début de ce livre. La différence entre ce kanji et celui de soleil réside dans la taille du rectangle et dans le fait que le trait intérieur ne touche pas le bord droit.  --

column6: to surround, besiege; to be surrounded; difficult; hexagram ䷮
column11: Pent in . . . trees.  -    -  I´m supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won´t be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!  -  You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a quandary -- should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?
column12: Enceinte...arbre. On voit parfois, sous des cieux cléments, des maisons dont le propriétaire ne s'embarrasse pas de la présence d'un arbre enceint dans la maison. Le toit est partiellement découpé pour que l'arbre croisse normalement.  --

column11: Old . . . pent in. Leave the people out of your story to avoid complications later when we add the element for person to form a new kanji (Frame 1047).  -    -  Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.  -  Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..
column12: Au sens de corps solide. Enceinte...vieux. Un fromage laissé dans sa boîte pendant quelques semaines ou une momie dans un sarcophage pendant quelques siècles nous mènent droit à la notion de solide.   --

column11: Jewels . . . pent in.  -    -  In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).  -  Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.
column12: Bijoux...enceinte. Avant l’établissement des constitutions dans la plupart des pays, l'unité des pays était symbolisée par l’ensemble des bijoux constituants la couronne. C'est en tout cas l'image que nous propose ce kanji.  --

column11: Glued . . . pent in.  -    -  When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you´re well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.  -  A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or "glued together.".
column12: Collé...enceinte. Nul n’ignore l’importance que joue le groupe dans la société japonaise, et les éléments composant ce kanji ne semblent pas renier cette impression.  --

column11: St. Bernard dog . . . pent in.  -    -  We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he´d cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.  -  Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.
column12: Grand homme...enceinte. Comme un éléphant dans un magasin de porcelaine, un grand homme confiné dans une enceinte est susceptible de réagir et de causer bien des déboires.  --

column11: Woman . . . cause. Think here of the "state of matrimony" and you will not confuse it with other characters involving marriage, one of which we have already met (Frame 581).  -    -  Matrimony is the state in which the woman has got you pent in like a dog so that you cannot go after other bitches.  -  When the woman gets angry, she treats her man like a pent in dog (i.e., puts him in the doghouse). It´s a perfect metaphor for the state of matrimony.
column12: Femme...cause. Par sa fertilité, la femme est en quelque sorte la cause du fait conjugal.  --

column11: Pent in . . . lidded crock . . . scarf.  -    -  A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).  -  There was a homeless man living in a box at the park so I gave him a lidded crock filled with hot curry tied with a scarf...
column12: Enceinte...poterie à couvercle...écharpe. Pour nous balader dans l'enceinte que constitue ce parc, nous emportons un en-cas dans notre poterie à couvercle et nous mettons une petite écharpe pour nous protéger de la fraîcheur qui vient. 猿 et 遠 ont en commun un élément.  --

column11: The suffix "-times" refers to a number of repetitions. Its elements: a mouth . . . pent in. Hint: you may find it more helpful to forget the primitives and think of one circle revovling inside of another.  -    -  Write mouth two -times.  -  Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).
column12: Le mieux sera de voir dans ce pictogramme un cercle tournant à l’intérieur d’un autre. Faites-le tourner un certain nombre de fois, en retenant son second sens : fois.   --

column11: Soil/ground . . . top hat . . . -times . . . nightbreak. With kanji as difficult as this one, it generally pays to toy with the various connotations of its primitives before settling on one image. Aim for as much simplicity as you can.  -    -  A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.  -  Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.
column12: Terre...chapeau haut de forme...fois...point du jour. Ce podium est celui de la fête que l’on donne sur l’aire en terre battue du village. Un magicien en chapeau haut de forme va s’y produire un certain nombre de fois, et ce jusqu’au point du jour, est-il précisé. Le commun des mortels n’est pas autorisé à monter sur ce podium, réservé à la société des notables, du village ou d’une confrérie quelconque.  --  Le commun des mortels n'est pas autorisé à monter sur ce podium, réservé à la société des notables, du village ou d'une confrérie quelconque.

column11: Cave . . . fortune-telling.  -    -  Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.  -  The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.
column12: Appentis...occuper. Ce magasin occupe entièrement l’espace disponible à l’intérieur de l'appentis.   --

column11: Cave . . . car.  -    -  I think of the Batcave. It´s a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.  -  Have you ever worked in a warehouse? It´s like a giant metal cave. Watch out for that forklift!
column12: Appentis...voiture. Un appentis assez grand pour y ranger la voiture devient un entrepôt.   --

column11: Cave . . . courts.  -    -  When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard.  -  Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.
column12: Appentis...tribunaux. Au tribunal, on a installé dans les jardins un appentis où ranger les outils du jardinier.  --

column11: Cave . . . a spike.  -    -  Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave.  -  In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a "government office", it´s actually a dungeon where they´re dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall.
column12: Dans le passé, de nombreux objets étaient nécessaires à l’intérieur du bureau du gouverneur. De nos jours, avec l’évolution des techniques, cette pièce s’est vidée de la majorité de son mobilier. Il en est de même dans les kanjis : alors que l’ancienne forme du caractère 廳 est d’une insondable la nouvelle se réduit aux éléments appentis...clou : le clou pour accrocher le portrait du Président de la République, ou de l’Empereur.  --

column11: Cave . . . tree.  -    -  The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.  -  (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.
column12: Appentis...arbre. Dans l'appentis, le plancher est en bois.   --

column6: hemp, jute, flax; sesame; Kangxi radical 200
column11: Cave . . . grove. If it helps, this is the hemp marijuana comes from.  -    -  (Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin´ a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove).  -  Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!
column12: Appentis...bois. On pourra faire une image à partir du chanvre indien dont la culture interdite nous contraint à le cultiver en cachette, au fond d’un appentis. Le sens secondaire confine à la racine grecque narco-. Notre sésame sera une grosse corde de chanvre.  --

column6: grind; polish; rub; wear out; a millstone
column11: Hemp . . . stone.  -    -  If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.  -  You must GRIND the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.
column12: Lorsque la grosse corde de chanvre frotte sur la pierre, celle-ci subit graduellement un phénomène d'abrasion.   --

column6: heart; mind, intelligence; soul; 5th lunar mansion, determinative star α Scorpii (Antares)
column11: This character, a pictographic representation of the heart, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.  -  * As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings. In its kanji-form, it appears BENEATH or to the RIGHT of its relative primitive and means th physical organ of the heart.  To the LEFT, it is abbreviated to three strokes, ⺖,  and means a wildly emotional state of mind. And finally, at the very BOTTOM, it can take the form ⺗, in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine.  -  The four chambers in the heart. In the West, we point to our head when asked about the mind. In the East, they point to the heart. So then, the radical for "state of mind"…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　シン　安心　あんしん(peace of mind).  -  Heart needs three drops of blood to work.
column12: Cette représentation pictographique du coeur compte parmi les composants les plus employés. C'est peut-être aussi l'un des plus difficiles à bien écrire.  --  * En composant, il apparaîtra sous trois formes différentes, auxquelles, comme nous avons déjà fait pour d'autres composants, nous attribuerons trois significations différentes.  - Sous la forme du kanji, il signifiera l'organe cœur, ou portera la notion de sentiments.  - À gauche, il sera abrégé en  , et signifiera état d'esprit.  - Enfin, il apparaîtra quelquefois au bas sous une autre forme, , et nous lui assignerons le sens de amoureux.

column11: Perish . . . heart.  -    -  You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.  -  To forget means that something perishes from your heart.
column12: Périr...sentiments. Lorsque périssent nos sentiments, nous oublions.  --

column11: Blade . . . heart. Endure here means long-suffering patience.  -    -  A ninja must be able to endure the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the blade of his sword into the hearts of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.  -  Someone with a razor blade stuck in their heart has to endure the pain wherever they go and can tell no one about it.
column12: Lame...cœur. Si l’on dit en français d’une chose difficile à supporter qu’elle « fend le cœur », c’est sans doute parce qu’une sorte de lame est placée au-dessus du cœur, comme une épée de Damoclès.  --

column11: Words . . . endure.  -    -  You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge.  -  I never read the "acknowledgements" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring words that i must endure reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :).
column12: Mots...supporter. Lorsqu’on reconnaît avoir tort, ou qu’on reconnaît le droit à la parole à un interlocuteur, on est contraint de prononcer quelques mots pourtant difficiles à supporter.   --

column11: Snake . . . heart.  -    -  Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.  -  You are mourning the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. -- "mourning feels like snake-bitten heart".
column12: Serpent...cœur. Certains films d’horreur pourront aider.  --

column11: Samurai . . . heart.  -    -  A samurai´s intentions always come from the heart.  -  Gentleman always have hearts full of good intentions.
column12: Lisez le dessein du vieux professeur : ce qu’il a sur le cœur.   --

column11: Words . . . intention.  -    -  A will is an important document that contains your final word on how you intend to distribute your assets.  -  This is quite simple: a document is a set of words describing your intentions.
column12: Tout document contient des mots cachant un dessein entre les lignes.  --

column11: In the middle of a . . . heart.  -    -  Their true loyalty exists in the middle of their hearts.  -  Your loyalty is to what´s in your heart.
column12: Sentiments...milieu. Il s’agit de faire trouver le juste milieu à nos sentiments.   --

column11: This pictograph of two pieces of meat on a skewer, a shish kebab, will help us in the next frame.  -    -  Naka naka , "who´s there?" shish kebab .... "shish kebab who?".  -  This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.
column12: Ce pictogramme d’une brochette est évident.  --

column11: Shish kebab . . . heart.  -    -  A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.  -  If you are afflicted with severe heartburn, eating a spicy shish kebab will feel only slightly less painful than having it jammed straight into your heart.
column12: Ce kanji dont un sens associé est patient peut se voir de la manière suivante : Une brochette de sentiments divers pèse sur la conscience, et l’on commence à se faire des soucis. Puis on se fait tellement de soucis que l’on finit par être atteint de quelque mal.  --

column11: Brains . . . heart.  -    -  Think with your brain NOT your heart.  -  To think is to use your brain over your heart.
column12: Penser est vu comme une association entre le cerveau et les sentiments, qui distingue le rationnel et l’instinctif, le cerveau droit et le cerveau gauche.  --

column11: Take grace in its sense of a favor freely bestowed, not in its meaning of charming manners or fluid movement. The primitives: cause . . . heart.  -    -  Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!  -  This kanji tells us that wherever heart is the cause, grace is the consequence. Think of “grace” as a graceful act: something benevolent that comes from the heart.
column12: Cette faveur que vous fait votre prochain (la faveur divine viendra dans quelques cadres) est causée par les sentiments.   --

column11: Cave . . . heart. The sense of the key word here is of something appropriate that fills a particular need, and hence "applies."  -    -  In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will APPLY magic to fill his HEART containers.  -  [bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say "Those who don´t make it to the heart of the cave need not apply.".
column12: Ce kanji défini ce qui comble un besoin particulier ou apporte la réponse adéquate à un problème. L'appentis est devenu la cage thoracique où le cœur  comble adéquatement l’espace corres­pondant.  --

column11: Sound . . . heart.  -    -  When you get a good IDEA you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it´s pounding so hard.  -  Picture someone who´s just had a great idea, but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a heart thumping with great noise. Imagine the greater the idea, the louder the sound of the beating heart.
column12: Une idée est le bruit  du cœur.  --

column11: To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the "con-" in the word "concept." Its elements are: inter- . . . heart.  -    -  The concept of love is basically two hearts inter-acting as one.  -  ´´Inter-heart´´ is a new therapy CONCEPT that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.
column12: Pour distinguer ce kanji du précédent, sans doute trouverez-vous avantage à vous concentrer sur le con- de concept : inter...sentiments.  --

column6: rest, put stop to, end, cease
column11: Nose . . . heart.  -    -  Your breath brings oxygen in through your nose which is then pumped around your body by your heart.  -  I think I´ve met my dream girl, but there´s a problem. her breath is horrible! So, do I listen to my nose or my heart?
column12: On s’intéresse avant tout au nez et au cœur pour savoir s’il subsiste le souffle de la vie chez un accidenté. Le fils est un enfant qui respire, et l’argent que l’on fait fructifier, lui aussi, respire.  --

column11: Tongue . . . nose . . . heart. The sense of breath from the last frame should not be used; it could lead you to put only the nose over the heart and leave the tongue off to one side.  -    -  Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!  -  Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.
column12: Langue...nez...cœur. Vous ne pouvez pas utiliser le sens de respirer du cadre précédent, car cela aurait tendance à vous faire écrire le cœur uniquement sous le nez, ce qui serait faux. On exprimera la notion de détente par le fait que la langue cesse de s’activer au profit du nez qui prend le frais durant la pause lors d’une conférence. Le cœur, lui continue de battre.  --

column11: Ten . . . fields (or: needle . . . brains) . . . heart.  -    -  Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three FAVORS: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?  -  Do yourself a favor and take ten minutes to think about your decison...　RTK2:　エ　知恵　ちえ(wisdom)　　　ゴ　互恵　ごけい(reciprocal).
column12: Cet individu bénéficie d'un cœur et de dix cerveaux. Voilà la faveur divine dont nous parlions en 669.  --

column11: Craft . . . mediocre . . . heart.  -    -  If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to fear. ("Oops, I think I left my scissors in there").  -  My deep dark fear at the bottom of my heart is that I am mediocre at my craft.
column12: ...du travail mal fait : travail...médiocre...sentiments.   --

column11: -    -  "Aru starts with a. To most Japanese, the differance between ""a"" and ""the"" is confusing. It wasn't ""the"" mouth of someone important on the floor at the fiesta, it was just a mouth of a common drunk."  -  "A is an indefinate article alright. At this fiesta, the band wern't the genuine article either. So the patrons threw them off the stage (""Aaaaaa!"") and pressed their mouthes against the floor. ""Sing no more you talentless hacks!!'."
