column12: On a coutume de dire « un certain » lorsque précisément, on n'est pas du tout certain de ce dont on parle, de sorte que ce kanji est une sorte d'article indéfini, comme « un ». Ici, nous nous trouvons au coeur, d'une région pleine de logements tous identiques, chacun possédant une porte ouvrant sur le plancher du dessous, chacun possédant aussi une hallebarde. Parmi tous ces terrains, il en un qui est le nôtre et il nous faut le trouver.  --

column11: The first three elements, fiesta . . . mouth . . . floor, appeared together once already in frame 380. Beneath them, once again, the heart.  -    -  She was beguiled/mislead by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the mouth, they did it on the floor and thus he stole her heart. Poor girl!  -  The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to beguile women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts.
column12: Un certain sentiment nous emplit l'esprit, une perplexité causée par le mal que nous avons à retrouver notre bien.  --

column11: Mouths . . . marching . . . heart.  -    -  Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.  -  Strong EMOTIONS don´t stay hidden. They march right out of one´s heart (below) and out one´s mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!).
column12: L’émotion ici décrite est le sentiment commun des chiens de la horde de chiens qui avancent en jappant de concert, ce que montrent les bouches : hordes de chiens...bouche...sentiment.  --

column11: Head . . . crown . . . heart . . . walking legs. Two things merit mention here. First, the doubling-up of the last stroke of head with the top of the crown serves to make the whole more aesthetically beautiful. It happens so rarely that the exceptions are easily learned. Second, try to make a single image out of the four elements. (Religious statuary of melancholy figures should offer plenty of suggestions.)  -    -  Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so ´emo´. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.  -  This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!
column12: Tête...couronne...cœur...jambes qui marchent.  Malgré sa complexité, ce kanji offre une description plausible de la mélancolie. La tête tente de prendre le dessus pour couronner le cœur et ses sentiments, mais las, celui-ci continue à marcher à son gré. Notez le doublement du trait inférieur de tête et de celui de couronne, qui fait disparaître les pattes de la tête. Ce type de complication est très rare, et ne mérite pas d’analyse plus approfondie. Nous verrons plus loin une autre occurrence de ce phénomène.  --

column11: State of mind . . . perish.  -    -  Busy (as in "occupied") means a state of mind where all other thoughts are perished.  -  ^^^Make the "state of mind" primitive Data (from Star Trek) instead right now and save yourself the headache; ´state of mind´ is too vague! (Data can stay so busy as not to sleep without dying. He´s a robot).
column12: Lorsqu’on est occupé, on l’est tellement que l'état d’esprit  lui-même est absent, a péri.   --  RÈGLE 9 : Dans état d'esprit , on trace en premier les deux petits traits latéraux, puis ensuite le grand trant central. Voir aussi 慕  en 700.

column11: State of mind . . . devil.  -    -  ECSTASY alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.  -  The state of mind that horny teenagers are looking for.
column12: État d’esprit...diable. Il s'agit d'un plaisir orienté vers soi-même, typiquement marqué d'un état d'esprit diabolique.  --

column11: State of mind . . . span.  -    -  Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).  -  Data is the epitome of constancy. As a robot, his consistency spans the entire day.
column12: État d’esprit...temps qui passe. La constance caractérise cet état d’esprit qui ne change pas, au fil des jours.   --

column11: To keep this character distinct from others of similar connotation, one need only think of the Prophet Jeremiah whose poetry gave an eminence to the state of mind we call lamentation.  -    -  When the world´s most eminent magician died, everyone´s state of mind became that of lamentation. He was buried with his famous sun-flower wand in his hand.  -  Data laments that he could never see his eminent father, his creator, ever again. He paints a picture of his father, that looks like a sunflower in the shape of a magic wand.
column12: Etat d’esprit...table. Cet état d'esprit nous laisse désemparés, prompts à tout déplorer, étalant sur la table la situation telle qu'elle nous apparaît.  --

column11: I know of an Indian religious sect which teaches that enlightenment is to be had by covering the eyes with one's index fingers, the ears with the thumbs, and the mouth with the little fingers. While these differ a bit from the five holes that we used to represent the "I" (frame 17), the idea of achieving a special state of mind by covering those five places can help you learn this kanji. You might try the position out while you are learning this character.  -    -  Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.  -  Data finds enlightenment when he discovers the answer to the question, "Who am I?". (Image: Data meditating in a sitting lotus position).
column12: Il existe en Inde une secte enseignant que l’initiation peut être atteinte en couvrant les yeux des index, les oreilles des pouces, et la bouche des auriculaires. Bien que cela diffère des cinq trous mentionnés au cadre 17, l’idée d’arriver à un certain état d’esprit en couvrant ces cinq endroits pourra vous aider à retenir le kanji. Essayez la posture en l’apprenant.  --

column11: State of mind . . . linen.  -    -  Someone in a dreadful state of mind has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (linens).  -  Being an android, Data is white as a sheet. Doctor Crusher always has to remind herself that this is perfectly normal. From a doctor´s perspective, he really does look dreadful.
column12: (État d’)esprit...linge. Associer ces éléments à l’image d’un fantôme et l’effroi qu’il suscite nous aidera.  --

column11: State of mind . . . laid waste.  -    -  (re: wazzab) The state of mind of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city´s concert hall laid waste can best described as disconcerted.  -  Data walks in and sees Picard weeping. "What is the matter, Captain?" Picard looks up, and replies that his entire home planet has been laid to waste. Data, the master of tact, offers up this consolation: "Ah. I can see how that would be DISCONCERTing". It turns out that the flow of tears was really just because Picard had lost his chance at getting at some rare (and thus valuable) flowers on his home planet.
column12: Lorsque l’état d’esprit montre quelque brutalité, c’est peut-être parce qu’il agité.   --

column11: State of mind . . . every (See frame 497).  -    -  For all have sinned... so everyone´s state of mind should be to repent.  -  When you repent, you heal your state of mind by going over every thing you regret doing.
column12: Derrière tout péché, un état d’esprit : le regret.   --

column11: State of mind . . . increase.  -    -  Like the saying goes, Hate just begets Hate. A state of mind that just increases and increases until it explodes.  -  Data´s one true emotion is hate for Prince´s music. (Image: Data hunched over hands to his ears and screaming while Picard bobs to Purple Rain).
column12: Voici un kanji peu optimiste : état d’esprit...augmenter.   --

column11: State of mind . . . pierce.  -    -  It took him awhile, but Data finally got ACCUSTOMED to his nipple/breast piercings. They were constantly rubbing up against his shirt and his heart-shaped locket. Picture Data, shirtless, squeezing his nipples in front of Picard and saying "Yes, at first they were a bit shelly, but I´ve grown quite ACCUSTOMED to them". That last bit should do it for you.  -  Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.
column12: Il n'y a que le premier pas qui coûte. L'habitude est cette capacité à supporter une certaine contrainte sans que cela ne coûte plus. En un sens, cela revient à percer de nouveau au même endroit, c'est absolument indolore pour notre état d'esprit.  --

column11: State of mind . . . butchers (See frame 307).  -    -  At the meeting of butchers, in their narrow state of mind, they throw lame jokes around like, ´Oh hello, it´s a pleasure to meat you´, and find this rather pleasing.  -  Image : Data attending a meeting of the butchers union. As a joke to begin his speech he says, ´Its a pleasure to MEAT you all.´ (thanx to Shibo & nestOr).
column12: Le plaisir est l’état d’esprit qui anime notre assemblée des bouchers (revoyez 310), nous apprend-on ici.  --

column11: State of mind . . . left (i.e. "sinister") . . . flesh.  -    -  When I am in a LAZY state of mind I use my left hand to play with my meat...it feels like someone else is doing it, which is good cause I´m to lazy to get a date.  -  When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.
column12: Etat d’esprit...gauche...chair. Lorsque la chair est gauche, c’est que l’esprit est paresseux.   --

column11: State of mind . . . truth.  -    -  Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu´s).  -  Humility is a state of mind when you consider yourself in accordance with the truth (you neither boast nor demean yourself).
column12: État d’esprit...vrai. Il est vrai qu'au Japon, une grande qualité est l'humilité. Nous verrons d'ailleurs par la suite plusieurs caractères concernant cet état d'esprit.  --

column11: State of mind . . . emotion. Hint: the etymology of "remorse" indicates a memory that returns again and again to "bite at" one's conscience and disturb one's peace of mind.  -    -  Remorse is the state of mind where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and emotional!  -  Tip: If you are confusing this keyword, remorse, with repent (#672) and regret/resentment (#1570), then note that rEMOrse contains EMOtion.
column12: Etat d’esprit...émotion. L’étymologie de remords suggère une émotion qui revient et nous « remord » la conscience.  --

column11: State of mind . . . idea.  -    -  Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.  -  Data´s recollection powers are unparalled. He never loses a single idea.
column12: En se replaçant dans l’état d’esprit où l’on était à l’époque dont on recherche le souvenir, on fait renaître petit à petit l’ensemble de nos idées en l’état où elles étaient, et le souvenir prend forme. C’est ce que nous faisons depuis le début de ce livre pour chacun des kanjis dont nous cherchons à nous souvenir.   --

column11: Graveyard . . . valentine. Note carefully the stroke order of the valentine primitive.  -    -  Pining, yearn for... etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the graveyard, placing an old valentine card amonst all the existing tributes.  -  Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their Valentine´s Day at the graveyard, pining for each other´s affection.
column12: Esquisse...amoureux. Voyons dans cette esquisse d'amour le début de la passion amoureuse, cette période durant laquelle tout confine à l'adoration de l'être aimé.  --

column11: Water . . . heavens . . . valentine.  -    -  You shed tears (water) as your departed valentine is annexed to the heavens.  -  Tip 1: 天 and 夭 (heavens and sapling) are different, but RTK confuses them. Sapling appears in numbers 添 (#684), 笑 (#1008), 妖 (#458), 沃 (#459), 呑 (#2225), and all characters containing angel 喬 (橋 (#460), 嬌 (#461), 矯 (#1306), 喬, 僑 (#2253), 蕎 (#2454)). Tip 2: The kanji 添 means "something added/attached", so think of it as a building annex. Story: While in the Annex watering saplings, you find a valentine card amongst them – addressed to you! [cred: Katsuo].
column12: Adjoindre associe la fertilité de 472 et les sentiments ; et cette adjonction va permettre d'améliorer la marche du monde.  --

column11: First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the heart, even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph "dividing" the heart in half, then one has one of those invariably true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each heart is divided into two halves.  -    -  You swear you´ll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.  -  For this kanji I invariably got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost heart, but decided to stick (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I invariably get it right.
column12: Notez en premier lieu l’ordre des traits de ce caractère. Puis comprenez-le comme une vérité physiologique absolue : le fait que le cœur est nécessaire­ment divisé en deux moitiés, comme le fait le trait central ici.  --

column11: Water . . . the invariably divided heart.  -    -  Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.  -  When you pierce a heart with a stake, it invariably oozes blood.
column12: Eau...nécessairement. Voici transposée à l’eau l’expression « il n’y a pas de fumée sans feu » : il faut nécessairement un liquide pour que cela suinte !   --  Chapitre vingt-deux  La main  CE long chapitre va nous mener bien au delà du premier tiers de notre chemin. Il rassemble essentiellement des kanjis comportant deux éléments qui reviendront fréquemment : la main et le doigt. Ces kanjis définissent en général des actions, et c'est donc une mine de verbes que nous allons aborder. Efforcez-vous, comme aupa- ravant, de former des images claires et suggestives, pour éviter de ne conjuguer ensuite ces verbes qu'au « passé décomposé ».

column11: Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a hand in this character. But that it is, and so you must.  -  * Keep to the etymology when using this kanji as a primitive: a single hand all by itself.  -  This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.  -  A hand is useful for 千一(1001) things.
column12: De quelque façon que l’on compte, il y a ici soit trop, soit pas assez de traits pour voir le pictogramme fidèle d’une main. Mais c’est ainsi !  --  Le sens de ce kanji ne se limite pas strictement à celui de main. On peut parfois y associer l’être humain tout entier ; le sens associé de opérateur permet de rendre ce second sens.

column11: Hand . . . eyes.  -    -  It´s a hot day of summer with a clear sky, you´re sitting outside a cafe (or maybe on a reclining chair in the garden), and you watch over the kids with a hand covering your eyes from the sunlight (next time, don´t forget the sunglasses).  -  Think of the monster from Pan´s Labrynth, that watched over the poor girl with eyes in the palm of his hands.
column12: Main...œil. Le kanji dépeint avec une bonne précision l’action de scruter, la main formant abat-jour au-dessus des yeux. Faites-le une fois.  --

column11: Hemp . . . hand.  -    -  If you grind the hemp without a stone but use your hand instead it will chafe. (Image: "Robin, why are your hands all chafed?" ´Uh... (I´ve been grinding hemp all day)´).  -  When the feds came to bust your little hemp grove, you jumped out the back side of the cave and tried to repel down with a hemp rope. Unfortunately, the rope chafed your hands and you fell .. ouch!
column12: Chanvre...main. Ce kanji vous rappellera le temps des concours de grimper à la corde de l’école primaire dont le but était de redescendre très vites et à la fin desquels les mains étaient bien souvent irritées par le frottement de la grosse corde de chanvre.   --

column6: our, us, i, me, my, we
column11: Hand . . . fiesta. Note how the second stroke of the hand is stretched across to double up as the first stroke of the tasseled arrow we use for fiesta. Compare to frames 17, 36, and 564.  -    -  Someone with a huge EGO is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal "hand fiestas" with himself every night.  -  Did you hear about the guy who had such a big EGO that he threw a fiesta for his left hand?
column12: Main...hallebarde. On imaginera un soldat, tenant une hallebarde dans l'ensemble de ses doigts, le torse bombé, fier de lui-même et de sa patrie. Ce kanji est un des caractères employés pour qualifier la première personne, souvent au masculin singulier.  --

column11: Sheep . . . ego.  -    -  Righteous Christians are sheep with egos (reworked from raulir, fixes word order to match radical order).  -  On the other hand, Woman tend to have too much self-righteousness to allow any man to touch their wooly black sheep this results in similar hand fiestas.
column12: Le kanji rigueur nous montre le second mouton de Panurge, que nous avons déjà rencontré, et dont l'ego a décidé de faire rigoureusement la même chose que le premier. On trouve en corollaire le sens de définition : ce qui décrit avec rigueur le sens d’un mot.  --

column11: Words . . . righteousness.  -    -  Careful deliberation produces words of righteousness.  -  At the worst of times, a jury´s deliberation descends into a war of words between competing self-righteous, power-tripping bastards.
column12: Mots...rigueur. La délibération se termine par un communiqué final, ensemble de mots relatant rigoureusement ce qui a été décidé.  --

column11: Cow . . . righteousness. Do NOT use the image of an animal sacrifice here, as that will have it own character later on.  -    -  A cow that is righteous sacrifices her milk for the human race.  -  Cows are truly righteous animals. They SACRIFICE their milk so that we can have some. And if they don´t have any left, they give a sheep a hand fiesta (good lord this is going too far) and give us that instead. What righteous cows.
column12: Vache...rigueur. Tentez de ne pas imaginer un sacrifice animal, car ce terme possède son propre caractère que nous verrons plus tard. Afin de respecter rigoureusement le droit à la vie d’un ruminant traversant la route, vous donnez un fort coup de volant et... sacrifiez votre voiture dans le platane.  --

column11: Fingers . . . extremity.  -    -  I like to RUB my FINGERS over my EXTREMITIES ....like my extremity-ly long, umm, hair.... This has been edited in response to being reported ...you can change "hair" to whatever extremity-ly long body part you like.  -  When you´re cold, your RUB your FINGERS over your EXTREMITIES vigorously to warm up a bit. I´d still rather go in for a warm fire and some hot cocoa, though.
column12: Doigt...extrémité. Placez l’extrémité de votre doigt sur la table. Que faites-vous ensuite ?  --

column11: Fingers . . . wrap.  -    -  When embracing someone, wrap your fingers around her butt for added effect. You may think of "bound with snakes" as a description of the fingers slithering around the buttocks, if you want a particularly graphic image.  -  Here, I´m picturing that scene from ET (the extra terrestrial), where ET hugs Elliot before leaving. You see that EMBRACE is ET´s long FINGERS that WRAP around Elliot.
column12: Doigt...emballage. Lors d'une embrassade, on commence par tenir les doigts de notre partenaire pour une courte poignée de mains, puis on procède à l'accolade, l'embrassade durant laquelle on l'emballe littérallement.   --

column6: join together, attach to; add to
column11: The key word refers to boarding vessels for travel. Its elements are: finger . . . flowers . . . fit together (See frame 270).  -    -  Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for pagoda (#254). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: "Now boarding the pagoda ride. Please keep your fingers inside at all times...".  -  When you board the ship on the way out from Hawaii a beautiful crewmember takes her fingers and fits a lei around you ....a lei is flowers fitted together with your fingers.
column12: Lorsqu’on embarque pour un long voyage, du bout des doigts, on lance quelques végétaux à nos correspondants restés à quai. Revoyez le cadre 274.  --

column11: Fingers . . . a few.  -    -  The mafia want to extract information from you. You don’t say a word, so out comes the knife. They cut off your fingers until you only have a few left and then you speak.  -  You can extract her juices by inserting a few fingers.
column12: Du doigt qui tient votre stylo, vous recopiez l'extrait qui vous intéresse : le peu qu'il vous faut. Remarquons que le second sens du kanji, fabriquer du papier, est en fait identique au premier : On extrait le papier feuille à feuille, comme on peut encore le voir dans certains moulins à papier.  --

column11: Fingers . . . a whirlwind.  -    -  Gandalf confronts the evil beast, shouting "you shall not pass!". He holds up a single finger and sends forth a whirlwind.  -  Imagine a thumb war. A confrontation of fingers in a whirlwind.
column12: Ce doigt d'une forte résistance est parvenu à opposer sa force au poltergeist.  --

column11: Finger . . . compare.  -    -  Think of the two most famous critics, Ebert and Roeper. On their show, they compare thumbs (which are technically fingers) with each other before dispensing criticism.  -  My criticism earned me the FINGER when I COMPARED her cooking to my mother´s.
column12: Doigt...comparer. Après avoir comparé la cuisine de votre mère et de votre belle-mère, vous passez à la critique, et du doigt, vous montrez ce qui va et ce qui ne va pas.  --

column11: Finger . . . seduce.  -    -  A Geisha beckons you with her index finger, and as you approach she runs her fingers all over her body in an attempt to seduce you. Keyword meaning : “invite”.  -  I bet you all know the Maneki Neko, or beckoning cat, who with its raised fingers tries to seduce all good things (success, happiness and harmony) to its owner.
column12: Voici une façon peu cavalière d’inviter quelqu’un : on le fait venir à soi, en le tirant avec le doigt.   --

column6: expand; open up; support or push
column11: Fingers . . . rocks.  -    -  A huge index finger coming down from the sky is kicking boulders of rock, clearing the land. Maybe it´s the finger of God preparing a place for his little people to live.  -  I imagine clearing the land in order to set up your tent after a long day of backpacking. Using your fingers, you pick up all of the rocks and get them out of the way so that you can get a comfortable night sleep. If you don´t clear the land you can just picture the rock sticking into your back as you toss and turn all night long.
column12: Pour gagner de nouvelles terres, on procède en enlevant jusqu’au moindre caillou, et c’est avec le doigt qu’on le fait.  --

column6: clap, tap, beat; beat or rhythm
column11: Fingers . . . white.  -    -  (Image: the most snooty prim and proper English Lord with white gloves clapping only with his fingers. "Oh bravo old chap. Bravo...").  -  I clapped so hard, my fingers became white.
column12: Applaudir trop fort nous chauffe les doigts à blanc.   --

column11: Finger . . . spike.  -    -  You´re using a hammer to drive a nail into a plank, but you miss and strike your fingers, ouch ! PS: the character does not mean "to go on strike", it will be very helpful in the long run to create images that convey the proper sense of the character!  -  My teacher used to strike my fingers with a street sign.
column12: Doigt...clou. Le jeu consiste ici à enfoncer du doigt un gros clou, en tapant de toutes nos forces. Faites-le une douzaine de fois pour retenir ce second sens.  --

column11: Fingers . . . phrase.  -    -  You approach the thief from behind, stick your finger at his back to fake a gun, and say the phrase "You´re under arrest".  -  Giving the police the finger and a colorful phrase is a surefire way to get arrested.
column12: Lors de l'arrestation, le représentant de la force publique tend le doigt vers le prévenu et prononce une phrase rituelle lui signifiant son état d'arrestation.  --

column6: discard, give up willingly; give alms
column11: Fingers . . . cottage.  -    -  Someone stuck their fingers in my cottage cheese! I´m going to have to discard the lot!  -  The wicked witch from Hansel and Gretel only likes the meaty parts of kids. Outside her candy cottage, you can see a pile of discarded fingers.
column12: Dans la chaumière, on choisit délicatement, avec le doigt, les objets que l’on va jeter.   --

column11: Finger . . . mouth . . . dagger.  -    -  Wrap your FINGERS around someone´s MOUTH to keep them quiet, then put the KNIFE to their throat to ensure their cooperation. This is the best way to KIDNAP someone.  -  After you beckon (#650) someone by seducing them, you kidnap them and hang them upside down (the reversed positions of seduce).
column12: Regardez bien ce kanji, et voyez comment une simple inversion de deux éléments (la bouche et le poignard) en bouleverse le sens. C’est avec le doigt que l’on a fait signe au futur kidnappé de suivre, et le malheureux se retrouve le couteau à la gorge, sous la bouche.   --

column11: Finger . . . antique.  -    -  My grandma always pinched me with her fingers when i was playing with her antiques. Imagine her fingers, also quite antique, thin, bony and hard, pinching at your hand. "Keep your fingers away from my antiques!!".  -  >_< Don´t you hate when your aunt (who is an antique) PINCHES your cheeks with her antique fingers?
column12: Doigt...antiquité. Cette antiquité est très fragile, il faut donc la saisir « avec des pincettes », du bout des doigts.   --

column6: a load carried on the shoulders; to carry
column11: Fingers . . . portent.  -    -  Here comes a new challenge, try to kill Bowser, the giant Turtle using jut on finger.  -  You are sure to take a challenge because your victory was portended. So you stand self-confident before your foe, point a finger at him and say "I will prevail, as was long portended!".
column12: Ce petit doigt intrépide défie les mauvaises augures.   --

column11: Finger . . . delicious.  -    -  Finger lickin´ delicious.  -  I remember this not as finger which has too many uses elsewhere but as "fingering" then its easy: fingering some delicious...
column12: Doigt...délicieux. Le sens de chocolat n’est pas inclus, mais par contre celui de désigner y est.  --

column11: Fingers . . . Buddhist temple.  -    -  At the BUDDHIST TEMPLE you´ll see wonderous things, such as the priest that can HOLD himself upside down with just a FINGER.  -  In Kyaiktiyo, there is rocking stone which sits on the edge of a cliff, and there is a Buddhist temple built on the top of it. You can rock the stone by pushing it with your finger, but it still holds in place. It´s true, see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyaiktiyo.
column12: Lorsqu’on va au temple bouddhique au Japon, on tient entre les doigts quelques pièces que l’on jette dans l’énorme tronc, et en repartant, on tient un petit papier sur lequel le prêtre aura écrit quelques caractères, preuve de notre passage en ce lieu. Ce verbe tenir porte aussi le sens d'avoir, un peu comme l'espagnol « tener ».  --

column11: Finger . . . tongue.  -    -  Teacher was always telling us to fasten our lips by pulling a zipper shut with our fingers. It always frightened me because I imagined getting my tongue stuck in the zipper.  -  On the plane, you refuse to FASTEN your seatbelt and even go so far as to give the stewardess the finger and stick out your tongue at her. The crew comes and pins you down and forces you to FASTEN it.
column12: Pour lier, il faut de la ficelle, mais c’est si évident qu’elle n’est pas représentée. Mais si vous imaginez le moment crucial où vous auriez besoin d’une troisième main, tenant le premier nœud alors que les deux autres font le second, vous constaterez que c’est finalement la langue qui vient au secours de vos doigts défaillants.  --

column11: Finger . . . chariot.  -    -  A military leader in his chariot is brandishing his finger at the enemy, crying "chaaaaaaaaarrrgggeeee!".  -  Think of the movie Gladiator but instead Maximus is brandishing a giant foam brand name (nike, rebok, adidas, whatever) finger like you see at a baseball game. He´s riding in a chariot using the foam finger to kill his enemy.
column12: Plutôt que de brandir une épée d’une main, ce caractère présomptueux nous propose de brandir une armée entière d’un seul doigt. Alors regardons les soldats s’éparpiller au coup de sifflet, et notons le second sens du caractère.  --

column11: Fingers . . . turkey.  -    -  In mathematics, a conjecture is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the Finger-Turkey conjecture ? It states that if turkeys had fingers, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.  -  In the midst of conjecture on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her fingers in the turkey to check.
column12: Ce caractère qui ne présente pas la relative simplicité des précédents nous oblige à imaginer une histoire suffisamment frappante. Nous ressortirons pour l’occasion la dinde carbonisée apparue au cadre 615 et nous imaginerons les invités narquois, montrant l’objet du bout des doigts : « nous présumons que ceci est la fameuse dinde... ».  --

column11: Fingers . . . piggy bank.  -    -  My piggy bank is so heavy that I cannot HOIST it using just my fingers.  -  Picture a major robbery where some dudes are breaking into a bank to steal their money. They get their man in the vault through the ceiling - now he´s hanging from a rope a few feet from the ground (like in the movies, dodging laser beams). He reports back that he has found the loot, and its all in a large piggy bank in the center of the vault. The alarm sounds and he´s got to think fast. He jams the four fingers of his right hand in the piggy bank slot and tells his team to hoist him up, he´s got the loot!
column12: Doigt...lumière matinale solaire. Lorsque vient la lumière matinale, on hisse les couleurs dans un grand élan patriotique.  --

column6: hold in hand; lift in hand
column11: Fingers . . . just so.  -    -  When a man PROPOSES to a lady, he takes her FINGER and places the ring on it JUST SO, and the moment sweeps her away.  -  I tried to propose to my girlfriend, but the ring was too small to fit her finger. Instead of saying yes, she just uttered an annoyed sigh. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally just so. Her eyes lit up and she said yes.
column12: Doigts...comme il faut. Avant de faire une proposition, il faut lever le doigt, comme il faut.   --

column11: Finger . . . employee.  -    -  Boss yells, "Who damaged the Xerox machine?!" fingers of employees point at one another.  -  If you finger your employee, you risk incurring many damages from a possible sexual harassment lawsuit.
column12: Peut-être cela pourra-t-il nuire à l’employé s’il se manifeste un peu trop, ne serait-ce qu’en bougeant le petit doigt.  --

column6: pick up, collect, tidy up; accounting form of the numeral ten
column11: Fingers . . . fit together. Compare frame 698.  -    -  I tried to PICK UP the bowling ball...but my FINGERS didn´t FIT in the holes.  -  Try PICKING UP a girl by trying to FIT your FINGER in you know what... let me know how that works.
column12: Doigts...correspondre. Rien de plus simple : pour ramasser un objet tombé au sol, il suffit de se pencher, et d’y faire correspondre les doigts. Notez aussi qu'en faisant correspondre les cinq doigts d'une main avec les cinq autres, on obtient le total de dix, qui est le second sens du caractère.  --

column11: The key word of this frame refers to shouldering a burden of some sort. Its elements are: fingers . . . nightbreak.  -    -  One of the classic stories of shouldering a heavy burden is that of the kid who had to stick his finger on a dam until nightbreak to prevent it from breaking down.  -  One of Hercules´ labors was to hold the world in his fingers for Atlas and not move until nightbreak, shouldering the considerable burden.
column12: Les sens propre et figuré du mot-clé sont compris dans ce kanji mettant en scène le doigt, qui s’est chargé (de ce que vous déciderez vous même) depuis le point du jour.   --

column6: to occupy, take possession of; a base, position
column11: Fingers . . . dispose.  -    -   When rockclimbing, when your weight disposes of the valuble foothold, all that's left is your fingers keeping you from death. Meanwhile, your walking legs are left dangling in the wind.  -  Once you have a good foothold, you can dispose of your fingerhold.
column12: Ce point d'appui est le lieu où nous appuyons notre doigt pour prendre un élan et repartir de plus belle.  --

column11: Fingers . . . seedling.  -    -  A sketch is a seedling (#234) of things to come. Before the assault, the sergeant draws a sketch of the attack with his fingers in the sand.  -  I´m bad at drawing, so when I try to sketch the kanji for cat, you can sort of recognize it, but I don´t get the curve of the "wild dogs" just right.
column12: Doigts...pousse. De même que la pousse devient une plante, les traits que l'on fait du doigt deviendront un joli dessin.  --

column11: Fingers . . . goods . . . tree.  -    -  Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it´s worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (#215) , maneuver (FRAME 671), winding (#1369), seaweed (#2035). Story: Using just a finger you are trying to maneuver your furniture round your room.  -  Luke skywalker points his fingers and uses the force to maneuver the goods through the tree branches and up over the tree.
column12: Doigts...pantin. Le doigt donne vie au pantin, en le manœuvrant. Il est bon de ne pas se laisser « manoeuvre » outre mesure, car ce kanji signifie aussi fidélité.  --  Il faut toutefois savoir qu’il est bon de ne pas se laisser « manœuvrer » outre mesure, car ce kanji signifie aussi fidélité.

column11: Fingers . . . vase . . . woman.  -    -  A pervert meets a woman. The pervert tries to touch the women with his lustful fingers. The woman takes a vase, lifts it over her head and smashes it on the pervert´s head...  -  CHIKAN!! These are the perverts who use their fingers to touch standing women on crowded trains.
column12: Je vous laisse pour ce kanji travailler de votre propre chef, tout en vous précisant que la partie de droite de ce kanji (  dresser...femme) est aussi un kanji, signifiant : maîtresse. Cela étant retenu, vous ajoutez un doigt à l’histoire pour obtenir joindre.   --

column6: to set (a table); to install, equip; to lay (a foundation)
column11: Fingers . . . siesta.  -    -  A muchacho puts up a notice that says “NO FINGER SNAPPING ALLOWED. MUCHACHOS ON SIESTA”. The muchachos are sleeping soundly, completely oblivious to the sound of dogs barking, guitar playing and even gun shots. Now imagine one tourist passing by and snapping his fingers and waking up all the muchachos at once.  -  Just as I was finished putting up a "no siestas" notice on my property, a muchacho gave me the finger, sat down, and promptly fell asleep.
column12: Doigt...sieste. Peut-être vous est-il arrivé de coller des affiches pour quelque cause. Sans doute avez-vous alors remarqué que le meilleur moment est celui de la sieste en début d'après-midi, quand tout est calme et les rues désertes.  --

column11: Fingers . . . ivy . . . magic wand.  -    -  Think RPG. The wizard points his finger to the guard and the ivy he has just animated with his magic wand climbs down the wall to hang the poor guy, opening the way for the adventurers into the dungeon.  -  3 ways you could hang something: 1) the normal way, with your finger putting something on a hook or whatever, 2) hanging from a vine the natural way, or 3) by means of the magic of the wand.
column12: Doigt...joyau...baguette magique. Pour attacher au doigt ce magnifique joyau posé sur le présentoir du bijoutier, il ne manque qu’un petit coup de baguette magique  ! Ce kanji est un verbe d'usage très courant, qui peut facilement se traduire par mettre, dans son sens le plus général.  --

column11: Stone . . . two hands.  -    -  My stones are so huge that it takes two hands to polish them!  -  You use two hands to polish a stone: one to hold it and the other to rub it.
column12: Pierre...deux mains. Les premiers caractères chinois datent du troisième millénaire avant notre ère, mais la notion contenue dans ce kanji était connue dès l’âge de la pierre  polie.   --

column11: Two hands . . . fiesta.  -    -  Two hands, fiesta.....when moses received the ten commandments with two hands, he went back down the mountain and threw a fiesta with the jews, celebrating the arrival of the commandments.  -  When Moses returned with the commandments in his hands he saw that his people were throwing a fiesta. At first he was excited. Then he looked around and got pissed. "Awww, c´mon guys. Golden idols? Really?".
column12: Deux mains...hallebarde. Tenir la hallebarde à deux mains laisse songeur quant à la taille de l'instrument, et on n'ose imaginer le châtiment.   --

column11: Tree . . . commandment.  -    -  The ten commandments were heavy. So to help carry them, Moses made a wooden contraption; the ark of the covenant.  -  Think of a complex wooden contraption capable of giving you a two-handed fiesta.
column12: Arbre...châtiment. Cet instrument était à l'origine une sorte de gibet dont le sens, découlant des éléments bois et châtiment, a évolué à instrument en général.  --

column11: Let me share a rather grotesque image to help with this kanji. Imagine taking your two hands and reaching up into someone's nostrils. Once inside you grab hold of the brain and yank it out. At the end, you would have a picture something like that of this character, the full kanji for nose.  -    -  An Egyptian embalmer reaching both hands into the dead pharaoh´s nose and yanking out handfuls of brain.  -  I sneezed so hard that through my NOSE I blew out my BRAINS into BOTH HANDS.
column12: Nez...cerveau...deux mains. On explique ici une partie du procédé que les anciens Égyptiens utilisaient pour momifier les pharaons. Il leur fallait retirer le cerveau du défunt, et le faisaient en utilisant un orifice naturel : le nez. Le kanji montre ici l’outil employé lors de l’extraction : les deux mains²  !  --  ² Le commentaire que fait Luís Fróis au sujet de l'introduction des corps étrangers dans le nez est surprenant : « Nous nous nettoyons les narines avec le pouce ou l'index ; eux, qui les ont très petites, le font avec le petit doigt. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)

column11: Two hands . . . saber.  -    -  This kanji is for severe punishment. A man has his shackled hands placed on a wood block and they´re chopped off with a saber. No more stealing bread in the Middle East...  -  In Arab countries they punish theives by cutting off BOTH HANDS with a SABRE.
column12: À voir les éléments deux mains et sabre, vous comprendrez que ce kanji fait référence à la peine de prison, et non au chagrin.  --

column11: Punish . . . soil. In cases like this, you might find it easier to break the character up into its more basic elements, like this: two hands . . . saber . . . soil.  -    -  A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area.  -  As a PUNISHMENT they made me lay face down in the DIRT leaving a nice imprinted MOULD of my whole BODY.
column12: Si courir raccommode le sol, mouler la terre revient à la punir. Dérivé de ce sens de base, on trouve naturellement celui de modèle.   --

column11: Whatever one is particularly adept at - one's special "genius" - one can do very easily, "with one finger" as the phrase goes. This kanji is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its distinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the element for fingers backwards.  -  * The primitive meaning, genie, derives from the roots of the word genius. Use the genie out in the open when the primitive appears to the right of or below its relative primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered, and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle.  -  Spinal tap: "Every other band´s amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven.".  -  A TEN year old had a STROKE of GENIUS and wrote this joke: 何歳ですか？　　　。。。天才です！.
column12: Si quelqu’un est très doué pour quelque chose, s’il en a le génie, il peut le faire aisément, d’un seul doigt. Le kanji génie montre un pictogramme du doigt en question. Notez comment sa forme particulière est créée, en traçant à l’envers le troisième trait de l’élément doigt.   --  En composant, cet élément verra sa forme altérée lorsqu'il apparaîtra à gauche, devenant : . En pareil cas, nous emploierons le sens de génie de la lampe (d'Aladin, Mille et une Nuits).

column11: Clam . . . genie.  -    -  If you´re a money genius, you can afford a lot of property.  -  The keyword refers to property in the sense of money or funds rather than of buildings or real estate. Keep this one distinct from frame 193 (“wealth”) and frame 473 (“assets”). Here we have a genie, gulping down oysters. Someone tries to grab an oyster and the genie puts his big arms around his oysters and states his “right of ownership” : “They´re mines, my property!”.
column12: Les huîtres sont la propriété du génie qui a appris à les cultiver.  --

column11: Tree . . . genie.  -    -     It doesn't take a genius to know that lumber comes from trees.  -   A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh.
column12: Bois...génie. Lorsqu’on sait la vitesse édifiante à laquelle les Japonais construisent leurs maisons de bois, on conçoit qu’ils sont quelque peu redevables au génie de ce matériau de construction².  ² Cette façon de faire n'est pas récente : « En Europe, nous mettons le bois d'oeuvre à l'atelier, au fur et à mesure des besoins ; au Japon, on travaille d'abord tout le bois nécessaire, puis très rapidement on édifie la maison. »  (Traité de Luís Fróis)  --

column11: Genie in the bottle . . . a child. Hint: focus on the key word's connotation of "make believe".  -    -  How do you suppose they manage to cram a genie inside a bottle? Well, I suppose they put him in there while he´s still a little child...  -  Villagers on a little remote island one day find a bottle washed out by the sea onto the beach. After wiping the bottle and taking a closer look, they are amazed to see a (very small) child in it. The villagers suppose that the child is a genie in a bottle.
column12: Génie de la lampe...enfant. L’histoire d’Aladin et la lampe merveilleuse tombe à point nommé pour ce kanji. Chaque enfant  suppose en effet que ce génie existe vraiment. On pourra noter que génie entoure enfant dans le kanji, comme le protégeant.  --

column6: be at, in, on; consist in, rest
column11: Genie in the bottle . . . soil.  -    -  Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one.  -  You wipe the soil from the bottle, only to have a genie float out above you, saying: ´I am the genie in a bottle, what is your wish?´ So now you know that they do exist.
column12: Le don particulier qu’avait le génie de la lampe était de faire apparaître n’importe quel endroit ou château merveilleux aux yeux d’Aladin, donc de faire exister n’importe quel endroit de la terre.   --

column6: then; really, indeed; as it turned out, after all; namely
column11: This pictograph of a clenched fist is another of the "hand primitives." Take note of its rather peculiar drawing. Try to think of drawing a fist (the primitive meaning) "from" this character to give yourself a connotation for the otherwise abstract key word.  -  * The primitive meaning is taken from the pictograph: a fist.  -  FROM a pictograph of a thumbs up. That´s how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist.  -  Think Charlton Heston: "From my cold, dead fists". Speech given to the National Boxing Association, in response to stricter control on boxing gloves.
column12: Ce pictogramme d’un poing fermé est l’un des nombreux composants ayant rapport à la main. Notez bien la façon dont on l’écrit, et pensez, ce faisant, à dessiner une forme de poing (sésame) à partir de ce dernier, pour établir une liaison entre sens composant et mot-clé.  --  Cela ne paraît pas très logique, mais ce caractère s'écrit effectivement en deux traits seulement.

column6: lead by hand, take with; carry
column11: Fingers . . . turkey . . . fist.  -    -  This is the portable TURKEY phone. You hold it by making a FIST and sticking your thumb up its ass, and operate it with the FINGERS of the other hand.  -  Because they have no fingers, turkeys must use their fists when dialing on a portable phone.
column12: Doigt...dinde...poing. Prenez soin à bien incorporer les doigts dans votre histoire. De façon logique, et de sorte à tracer les éléments dans l’ordre, placez le poing sous la dinde (tenez-lui les pattes !), et le doigt sur le côté, pour lui conserver l’équilibre. Moyennant quoi votre dinde devient portative.   --

column6: extend; reach; come up to; and
column11: The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched fist into the kanji for reaching out, much as a stroke of kindness can often turn anger into acceptance.  -  * As a primitive, this shall stand for outstretched hands. Only take care not to confuse it with that for beg (Frame 501)  -  I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.  -  Reach out and fist someone (Do you see the person primitive?).
column12: Le trait final ajouté transforme le kanji poing fermé en s’étendre. Si vous avez du mal à retenir cette forme, imaginez dans le dernier trait un ressort forçant le poing à s’ouvrir, donc à s’étendre.   --  En composant, on utilisera aussi le sens de mains ouvertes, en accord avec cette histoire, ainsi que celui d'atteindre.

column11: Mouth . . . outstretched hands. Hint: use the image of a nursing baby.  -    -  Imagine a baby reaching out and holding mom´s breast as if it were bottle, and sucking on it to get some milk.  -  An open mouth and reaching hands : a baby wants to suck at his mother´s breast.
column12: Bouche...mains ouvertes. L’image d’un bébé à la tétée pourra être utile.  --

column11: Finger . . . outstretched hands.  -    -  See suck (#689): if it´s too big to handle, just use your fingers instead...  -  One of the first thing a baby can do with his hand is to reach out and grab your finger as if it was a little handle.
column12: Doigt...atteindre. Pour que votre doigt puisse manipuler un objet, il faut qu’il puisse l'atteindre.   --

column6: unit of length equal 3.3 meters; gentleman, man, husband
column11: The length whose measure this kanji depicts extends from the tip of one hand to the tip of the other with arms at full length. Notice the final stroke, which cuts across the vertical second stroke to distinguish it from large (Frame 112).  -    -  Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.  -  This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn´t show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.
column12: Un...bras. Cette longueur semble donc être celle d’un bras, mais elle vaut en fait un peu plus : exactement 10 shakus, soit 3,0303 m, environ une de nos anciennes brassées.   --

column11: A mouth . . . tucked under the arm.  -    -  I sleep in history class with my mouth tucked under my arm.  -  History students usually going to school with a history book tucked under their arm. But now instead of a book, you have a small talking mouth that tell you about history. "When I was young, I used to walk 5 miles everyday.....".
column12: « Un jour, mon fils, tout cela sera à toi ». L'Histoire bégaye mais le kanji subsiste et montre la bouche et le bras du paternel s'adressant à son héritier.  --

column11: One . . . mouth . . . tucked under the arm.  -    -  One officer can change the course of history.  -  One officer, namely Napoleon, changed the course of history. (Thanks, ayoung24). Napoleon is also my primitive meaning.
column12: On verra un préposé qui pourrait se charger d’accueillir des clients. On lui a assigné un lieu unique, et ses seuls outils sont sa bouche pour expliquer, et son bras pour indiquer le chemin à suivre. Def: personne qui accomplit une fonction déterminée (généralement subalterne).  --

column6: more, still further, much more; to change, alter
column11: The implication behind the meaning of grow late is that things are changing in the same way that the day turns into night. The elements: ceiling . . . sun . . . tucked under the arm.  -    -  At nightbreak (#30) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm.  -  It´s starting to GROW LATE, so God will take the SUN, and TUCK IT UNDER HIS ARM, and walk away. In the morning, he´ll bring it back, so don´t worry.
column12: Le kanji concerne l'approfondissement de certaines circonstances, y compris temporelles, car il qualifie aussi le fait de veiller. Lorsque le soleil à disparu sous l'horizon, on cherche à tendre le bras pour avoir encore plus de sa lumière.  --

column11: Rocks . . . grow late.  -    -   In the TV show Gargoyles, they would turn to stone and become stiff until the day grew late.  -  A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day...
column12: Pierre...encore plus. Ce kanji nous propose de faire une petite expérience afin de vérifier la dureté de la pierre après une éruption volcanique. Il faudrait s'approcher au plus près et toucher la pierre pour s'assurer qu'elle est encore plus dure.  --

column11: Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate "and" (+, &, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of or again.  -  * As a primitive, it will mean crotch, as in the crotch of the arm. Or whatever.  -  After her boyfriend´s crotch has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, "Or again, we could fool around . . . ".  -  This keyword should really be "again" not "or again" Here is some context: think of the phrase "Jya mata" "じゃ又" which is a farewell similar to "then again". Also "Mata ne" "又ね" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) "又明日"。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out "mata" except for in the last example: 又明日.
column12: De même qu’il existe en français plusieurs caractères pour écrire « et » (-h, &, etc.), ce kanji simple est employé avec le sens similaire d'ou encore.   --  Ce composant apparaîtra assez souvent, et comme la notion d'ou encore, etc. n'est guère évocatrice, nous utiliserons aussi le sens de main droite, car ce kanji en est, dit-on, un pictogramme. On le trouve aussi parfois avec le sens de cuisse, sans doute pour des raisons d'homonymie.

column6: set of two, pair, couple; both
column11: The crotch reduplicated gives us a pair.  -    -  Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . .  -  The animals boarding Noah´s Ark all came in pairs – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each pair to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.
column12: Une main droite plus une main droite font la paire. Imaginez une « paire anormale », telle une paire de jumeaux pas exemple, qui vous montrera jus­tement deux mains droites.   --

column11: Crotches, crotches everywhere . . . tree. Hint: think of a group of children playing an original version of "Here We Go 'Round the Mulberry Bush."  -    -  Children going around the mulberry tree singing "This is the way we wash our crotch, wash our crotch, wash our crotch...".  -  Imagine kids all over the top of a mulberry tree, sitting astride limbs so that their weight is on their crotches. (Mulberry trees have big sprawling limbs that run horizontally or at shallow angles making them easy to climb and sit in. I have an old mulberry in my yard, and my kids are in it constantly).
column12: Dans cet arbre se trouvent des mains droites partout, partout. Ces mains droites sont bien entendu les mains adroites, promptes à cueillir les feuilles pour les donner en pâture aux vers à soie.  --

column6: single, one of pair, lone; measure word
column10: Vaisseaux, compteur des bateaux, anormalement unique
column11: The key word indicates the Japanese generic term for counting ships. Its elements: turkey . . . crotch.  -    -  On Vessels that travel long distances, sailors often get quite lonely. They keep TURKEYS on the VESSELS, but not for use as food. The lonely sailors take turns enjoying the turkey´s CROTCH.  -  Donald Duck is a big bird that does not wear pants. It´s good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count vessels.
column12: Ce kanji est le compteur des bateaux. On y lit les éléments dinde...etc. Remplaçons la dinde par un autre oiseau, qui soit également un bateau : la frégate, et nous obtenons de quoi compter les frégates, etc. La complexité de l’histoire est tout compte fait à notre avantage, car ce kanji sert aussi parfois à compter les oiseaux ! Enfin, il possède un autre sens qui en principe n’a rien à voir, mais que nous allons maîtriser de suite : anormalement unique. Ce sens est en quelque sorte le contraire de celui du cadre 768, car il servira par exemple à créer le mot « borgne ». Il suffit d’imaginer un capitaine de frégate borgne vous regardant de son œil anormalement unique pour établir la relation.  --

column11: Words . . . flowers . . . vessels.  -    -  Think of the flower-vessels as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big flower painted on the hull (this will come back in seize (#701) and harvest (#908)). Think of “flower-power” and of the “peace” in “Greenpeace” and it will make some sense hopefully. -- In this kanji, we see an inauguration speech being given before the Greenpeace vessel is set afloat and sent to safeguard our planet.  -  (With sarcasm) A Bush speech telling how all the US vessels are always welcomed, covered with flowers and words of gratitude for safeguarding democracy from the evil doers.
column12: En guise de sauvegarde, nous employons un ensemble de mots avec lesquels nous cherchons à attraper l'argumentaire des contradicteurs.  --

column11: A pack of wild dogs . . . flowers . . . vessels. Do not confuse this with the character for arrest (Frame 706).  -    -  A pack of genetically-modified wild dogs is seized by a group of Greenpeace activists and taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (the flower vessel, see safeguard (#700)).  -  Customs just seized a crate of poppies (flowers) detected by trained wild dogs who inspected the vessel.
column12: Pour assurer la meilleure prise à la chasse, nous partons avec notre meute de chiens, en vue d'attraper les plus belles proies.  --

column11: Woman . . . crotch.  -    -  That GUY stole my WOMAN so I kicked him in the CROTCH. (This story helps keep the word "GUY" as someone you hold in contempt).  -  Guys only care about 2 things: women and their crotch (preferably at the same time).
column12: Je choisis ce mot-clé car ce caractère s’applique aussi bien aux choses qu’aux êtres humains, avec une connotation souvent péjorative. Les compo­sants femme...main droite suggèrent un énergumène potentiellement violent.  --

column11: Guy . . . heart.  -    -  This woman is angry because of the guys in the previous frame who pay more attention to her crotch than her heart. I prefer to decompose the kanji in three elements here because it is easier to read like a mnemonic.  -  WOMEN get very ANGRY over the thought that GUYS are more interested in her CROTCH than her HEART.
column12: Alors que ce que le vieux professeur, cf. 343, avait sur le cœur était son dessein, cf. 662, ce que machin a sur le cœur est la colère.  --

column11: By one's side . . . crotch.  -    -  A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other´s crotches in a joking manner. It´s still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor´s crotch is a great way to express friendship.  -  Think of a sex friend (a fuck buddy if you will). The benefit of such a relationship is that there will always be a crotch by your side. (the Japanese refer to such a friend as セフレ, just as we do).
column12: Remettons une pendule à l’heure à l’occasion de ce kanji. Le compo­sant sur le côté ici présent possède aussi le sens de main gauche. Mais comme jusqu’à présent il n’était guère utile de le savoir, nous n’en avions pas fait état. Avec votre ami, vous êtes en toute confiance, vous lui confiez le bien et le mal, la droite et la gauche... Ce kanji simple recèle donc semble-t-il un sens assez profond.  --

column11: Fingers . . . friend.  -    -  Don´t let good friends slip out between your fingers.  -  Imagine a cliché Hollywood situation: one person is lying on the edge of the abyss and another (presumably his friend) is hanging, only thing holding him is the grip of their hands. Then fingers slip out of the grip and he falls in said abyss.
column12: Comme souvent cela se produit, ce kanji a un sens tout à fait général, allant de la chute des cheveux à la mue du serpent, l’extraction d’une écharde ou le fait de s’échapper du bureau. Nous jouerons avec ce dernier sens : l’ami faisant signe du doigt pour nous aider à nous « arracher » !   --

column11: Fingers . . . missile.  -    -  Well, you usually use your fingers to throw objects used as missile weapons. Easy. By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it´s a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers...  -  If you use the primitive "semen" (flying in the wind from your crotch) instead of missile then all kanjis with this primitive will hilariously create a perfect story.
column12: Doigt...frapper fort. Le doigt frappe fort un projectile afin de le lancer.  --

column6: not, have not, none; drown, sink
column11: Water . . . missile.  -    -  (Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/sink (#1888) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it´s target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns!  -  The submarine´s hull was breached after being struck by a torpedo ("water missile"), causing the entire crew to drown.
column12: Eau...frapper fort. Un objet mal identifié vient frapper fort sur le flanc d'un navire et celui-ci sombre sans tarder.  --

column6: build; establish; display; particle of hypothesis, supposing
column11: Words . . . missile.  -    -  When you attack the establishment with words, it fights back with missiles.  -  Establishment can be attacked by words or by missiles. Writers will use words, whereas militars will use missiles.
column12: Mots...frapper fort. Lorsqu’on établit une réforme ou une nouvelle entreprise, on cherche les mots qui frappent suffisamment fort les esprits afin d'être le plus convaincant.  --

column11: Car . . . missile . . . hand.  -    -  Your car has missles?! That beats mine, hands down.  -  Think 3 methods of attack all combined into 1 kanji: 1. Vehicle to transport troops 2. Once troops have disembarked they have their missiles 3. If they run out of missiles they resort to hand to hand combat to beat the enemy.
column12: Voiture...frapper fort...main. Un quidam vient de donner un gros coup de poing en frappant fort sur votre capot. Vous êtes à quelques mètres, la main prête à réagir.  --

column11: Samurai . . . superfluous . . . missile.  -    -  Samurai´s husk/shell/armour is superflous to missile attacks 甲殻　卵殻　貝殻.  -  husk or shell. Japan´s recent history in a nutshell: first the samurai became superfluous and then the Americans started to throw missiles and bombs during WWII.
column12: Le kanji coquille va de la coquille d'œuf à l'écorce terrestre en passant par la balle de céréales. Le vieux professeur a posé sa couronne sur la table ; il commence à frapper si fort que la croûte terrestre cède sous ses pieds.  --  On voit parfois ce kanji avec un trait en plus : . Les deux écritures sont des derivations du même caractère originel.

column11: Needle . . . crotch.  -    -  Picture sliding down the branch of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with needles) and getting a bunch of needles stuck in your crotch--ouch!!  -  A special branch of the military called the Needle Crotch Unit. Their only weapon is the needle embedded in their crotches, and they´re quite adept at using them.
column12: Dix mains droites fournissent un bon soutien pour retenir le kanji du même nom.  --  Notre sésame sera une branche, ce qui soutient les feuilles et les fruits.

column11: Fingers . . . branch.  -    -  (Adapted from darg_sama´s) Balancing a branch on your finger is the prototypical example of a skill that is nothing more than a skill (i.e., it is completely useless).  -  I think of a guy balancing a branch on his finger, which definitely takes some minimal amount of skill.
column12: Doigts...soutien. Ce kanji fait pendant à l’expression « être habile de ses doigts » et précise que les doigts sont le soutien de l’habileté.   --

column11: Tree . . . branch. Take a moment to focus on the differences between a bough, a branch, and a twig (Frame 319).  -    -  The tree´s primary branch is known as the bough.  -  Differentiate between BOUGH and branch (#711): ´branch´ is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store (支店), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a BOUGH is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large boughs, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical.
column12: Arbre...soutien - branche. L'arbre et les branches soutiennent le rameau.   --

column11: Part of the body . . . branch.  -    -  The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are "flesh branches".  -  Limbs are body parts that branch off.
column12: Partie du corps...branche. Les membres sont des branches plantées sur le tronc.  --

column11: Flower . . . spool.  -    -  Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Just get a flower and carefully wrap some toilet paper around its stalk. Spool also appears in suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), diameter (#882), sutra (#1360).  -  PRIMITIVE: soiled crotch = soiled underwear. To precent anyone from picking the beautiful flower, the gardner hung soiled underwear on the stalk.
column12: Quand on cueille un végétal, on en casse la tige, et à ce moment précis, la main droite est entre la terre et le végétal.   --

column11: State of mind . . . spool.  -    -  When you´re suspicious, your state of mind twists round and round like a spool of thread.  -  Imagine a loud farting sound on The Enterprise (sorry). Everyone looks around trying to find who did it. The one looking most suspicious is Data. His soiled crotch gives him away.
column12: Nous sommes méfiants à la vue de cette toupie tournant sur elle-même sans tomber, car son équilibre est régi par des principes qui nous échappent.  --

column11: Car . . . spool.  -    -  Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street.  -  I want to tread lightly on the environment.... That´s why I CAR-SPOOL to work everyday.... I know, lame.
column12: Imaginons léger comme ce qui devrait définir le « véhicule idéal », aussi léger qu’une modeste toupie.   --

column11: Above . . . little . . . crotch.  -    -  Oh come on people - say what we´ve all been thinking: the uncle is that creepy guy towering above a little one´s crotch.  -  Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team). You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column12: Au-dessus...petit...main droite. L'oncle est celui qui un beau jour a levé la main droite, en jurant de porter assistance aux petits en cas de difficulté. Cet oncle est le cadet d'un parent. Un autre kanji est employé pour l'aîné.   --

column11: Uncle . . . eye.  -    -  Creepy uncle volunteers as gymnastics coach so he can eye the team from below.  -  Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when COACHing...
column12: L'oncle est ici responsable d'une « équipe de jeunes », et en tant que superviseur, il doit avoir l'œil à tout.  --

column11: House . . . uncle.  -    -  The unmarried uncle´s house is the picture of lonlieness.  -  Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column12: Maison...oncle. On a tous plus ou moins une sorte d’oncle solitaire, vieux garçon endurci vivant dans une maison isolée.  --

column11: Water . . . uncle.  -    -  Uncle (the one who is lonely and coaches kids in his spare time) is actually a graceful guy once he hits the water, as he used to be part of the swimming team in his youth.  -  Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let´s make one story: Your UNCLE was full of loneliness (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally graceful (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as coach (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your uncle (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column12: On précise ici que cet oncle serait plus gracieux s’il mettait un peu d'eau dans son vin.  --

column11: If you think of a parade of particularly disagreeable relatives, it should not be hard to imagine them as large bodies with little pea-brains above.  -    -  Your half-uncle is leading a parade of your relatives. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of "uncle" 叔, so I´ve called it "half-uncle".).  -  Your uncle organizes a parade of all your relatives, which he himself is only half in because he´s busy taking pictures of it.
column12: Ici parade une sorte d'abréviation du composant oncle, venu représenter les cousins et petits-neveux, toute la parentèle.  --

column11: Cliff . . . crotch.  -    -  I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain´s back is turned).  -  Many cultures are so anti-sex you´d think they just want people to throw their crotches over a cliff.
column12: La main droite placée sous la falaise est vue ici comme un dispositif anti­ chute de la falaise.   --

column11: Ground . . . anti-.  -    -  As the villain (pushed off by the anti-hero) is tumbling down the slope, he activates gadget skis to escape, spraying soil everywhere as he flies down the slope.  -  This kanji depicts a classic enviornmental problem: erosion. Erosion occurs when all of the soil washes of the side of the cliff, eventually causing the cliff to disappear, leaving a slope (an anti- cliff if you will) in its place.
column12: Lorsqu’on gravit une pente, on s’éloigne lentement de la Terre, et c’est le sens que révèlent les éléments terre...anti.   --

column6: plank, board; iron or tin plate
column11: Tree . . . anti-.  -    -  Of course, trees are anti-plank. Wouldn´t you be if you were a tree?  -  Trees are naturally opposed to, or anti, the making of planks.
column12: Fabriquer des planches revient à faire des anti-arbres.   --

column11: Anti- . . . road.  -    -  Pretty obvious: to return is to turn back on the road you´re on and go the opposite way.  -  In "The Return of the anti-hero", Clint Eastwood kicks the villain in the crotch, pushes them off the cliff and onto a busy highway. A tiring movie franchise to say the least....
column12: On rend un objet en lui faisant parcourir l’« anti...route » de celle suivie lors de l'emprunt.  --

column11: Shells/money . . . anti-.  -    -  The goal of marketing is to get people who are naturally anti-buying to spend their shells (money).  -  『MARKETING: MONEY, ANTI』 The wide presence of MARKETING in our society has led people to become ANTI-MONEY.
column12: Pour le consommateur, la commercialisation d’un objet se solde par l’apparition d’« anti-monnaie » dans son porte-monnaie.  --

column11: This character is a pictograph of a bird's claw, and from there comes to mean animal claws in general (including human fingernails).  -  * As a primitive, we shall use the graphic image of a vulture, a bird known for its powerful claws. It generally appears above another primitive, in which case it gets squeezed into the form ⺥.  -  A pictograph of Wolverine´s adamantium claws.  -  Pictograph, see book. * I prefer the primitive meaning of an eagle rather than vulture. Somehow vulture makes me think more about meat and dead corpses than claws. An eagle however immediately brings to my mind the image of an eagle plunging into a stream catching fish in his claws, or that of the great eagles rescuing Bilbo and his party in Jrr Tolkien´s novel “Bilbo the Hobbit”.
column12: Créé à partir du pictogramme d’une serre d’oiseau, voici le kanji ongle.   --  * Le sésame sera vautour, en relation avec l'origine du kanji, et la forme deviendra souvent .

column11: Vulture . . . woman.  -    -  Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic!  -  An eagle must be extra gentle to pick up a dainty woman in its sharp claws.
column12: La « femme-vautour » présentée ici est peut-être votre féroce propriétaire, qui vous appelle dès le plus petit retard dans le paiement du loyer. Alors vous tentez d'arranger les choses à l'amiable.  --

column11: Fledglings . . . hook.  -    -  A fledgling is being nursed at a zoo, it is fed milk through a small tube that is bent in the shape of a hook (so that it fits inside its beak). The fledgling soon becomes addicted to milk, giving us this very catchy mnemonic: “fledgling hooked on milk”.  -  Drinking milk not only reduces cavity (#96)´s but also strengthens nails (claws) thanks astgtciv.
column12: Les oisillons ouvrent leur bec en forme de crochet, en quête de lait.   --

column6: to float, drift, waft; to exceed; superfluous
column11: Water . . . fledglings.  -    -  Floating rubber ducky!!!  -  A nest of fledglings somehow fell into the water (maybe it was perched on a tree bending over the river), but they are safe for now as the nest is floating. The fledglings are enjoying the cruise but they are soon coming to a great waterfall... ( a little drama to help us remember the story).
column12: Ce pauvre oisillon est tombé du nid et son petit corps flotte sur l’eau.  --

column11: Turtle . . . vulture . . . glue.  -    -  The leader in this race is the turtle! It appears he has covered the vulture’s feet in glue, so that the vulture cannot get off the starting block.  -  X-men and TMNT join forces: Their new leader is an awsome asshole. He is simply Wolverine and Raphael glued together back to back (the biggest assholes from both groups combined).
column12: Ce dirigeant dans lequel on pourra imaginer un chef d’armée, est robuste comme la madrier et possède, collé à ses pieds, son vautour mascotte.  --

column11: Leader . . . St. Bernard dog. Do not confuse with urge (Frame 300).  -    -  It´s easy to picture a LEADER that uses a BIG dog to EXHORT his people to do more.  -  Here we have a St.Bernard exhorting the vulture to become the leader in the race against the turtle, but he can´t because of the glue. see leader (#731).
column12: Dirigeant...grand homme. Ce dirigeant commande à une troupe de grands hommes en les exhortant de sa puissante voix.  --

column11: Unlike pick up (Frame 720), this character is used for picking fruits from trees. Its elements: finger . . . grab.  -    -  You pick cheries with your fingers, then along comes a giant vulture and picks up the whole tree with its claws.  -  Tip: vulture + tree : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called grab (#2090). Story: As you go to pick your nose, your parent grabs your finger and pulls it away (& gives you a lecture on social etiquette). REF: "grab" also appears in vegetable (#734), coloring (#1714).
column12: Vous devez ici recueillir avec les doigts un paquet de dés à jouer joliment colorés.  --

column11: Flower . . . grab.  -    -  A vegetarian vulture is munching on a flower, perched on a tree, patiently waiting for a patch of vegetables to grow.  -  Wolverine is turning into total hippie. He said he only eats vegetables now and last time I saw him sitting in a tree with flowers in his hair.
column12: Ce légume vert semble pousser sur les arbres. Vous pouvez imaginer une plante dont les fruits soient des dés à jouer.  --

column11: Birdhouse . . . crotch.  -    -  The bird house is the brothel (someone else said so) and of course everyone is welcome - thay accept any crotch.  -  A birdhouse is a whorehouse that will accept any crotch even those with STDs. (Image: a birdhouse whorehouse with every kind of bird coming and going. Some old madam at the front hole accepts everyone, even the nasty old crows).
column12: Ce kanji signifie subir, autant que recevoir au sens général. On y verra un nid d’où sort une main droite : assurément celle d’un oiseau, demandant à recevoir sa ration de nourriture.  --

column11: Fingers . . . accept.  -    -  Please accept this finger, you say, imparting it to your yakuza boss.  -  This character depicts a student and teacher. The teacher imparts his knowledge on the student, pointing the way and guiding with the finger. Meanwhile, the student sits there passively accepting the tutelage of his superior.
column12: En effet, voici ici présentée la manne parentale, sous la forme d’un doigt, prêt à accorder sa ration à l’oiseau piaillant.  --

column11: Birdhouse . . . heart . . . walking legs.  -    -  If you really love someone, you won´t keep them in a cage-like bird house relationship, but rather open the door and let their heart walk around freely. Think less about "I" (あい) and more about "we".  -  The man is about to enter the ´birdhouse´ (brothel) when he remembers his true love at home, and, following his heart, uses his walking legs to go straight home.
column12: Les amoureux sont dans leur nid, et seul compte le cœur. Ainsi que, de temps à autre, les jambes qui marchent et vont quérir l’eau fraîche.  --

column11: Finger . . . elbow.  -    -  You´re at a restaurant and raise your finger to indicate to the waiter that you want to pay. Your friend elbows you in the ribs -- it´s his shout, and he insists on taking care of the bill.  -  You are walking out of the restaurant when the waiter uses his FINGERS to grab you at the ELBOW and says, "excuse me sir, didn´t you forget to PAY?".
column12: Voici l’exacte description de ce que l’on fait au moment de payer. On plie le coude, pour permettre aux doigts d’aller fouiller au fond de la poche, que l’on nettoie par la même occasion, et ce kanji signifie aussi nettoyer.   --

column11: Cave . . . elbow.  -    -  The Batcave is very wide and has a lot of elbow room for Batman to do his yoga.  -  A wide cave has a lot of "elbow room".
column12: Si l'appentis est assez large, nous pouvons passer sans nous cogner les coudes.   --

column11: Fingers . . . wide. The connection with the previous character is very close. Beware.  -    -  Japanese girls are tight and may require fingers inserted to broaden them and make them wide enough before you can...  -  Spread your fingers wide to broaden your hand.
column12: Pour élargir un passage, on gratte avec le doigt dans le sens de la largeur. Ce kanji cherche à nous expliquer, quelques milliers d'années avant son invention, comment fonctionne une haveuse.  --

column11: Metal . . . wide.  -    -  Elbonium: a new mineral found in wide caves shaped like elbows and made of metal.  -  A wide range of metals are classed as minerals.
column12: Un minéral est un métal au sens large.   --

column6: conical cap worn during Zhou dynasty
