column11: Elbow . . . two hands.  -    -  Opening a stuck valve requires 2 hands and a lot of elbow grease.  -  The cubans build a pipe to flood the USA. Castro just has to turn the valve on it, and USA is flooded. Suddenly, CIA agents tackle him from behind, grabbing both his arms. But Castro manages to open the valve with his elbow, by raising the elbow above his head. Success! USA is no more...
column12: Ce caractère étrange possède plusieurs sens, allant de valve à pétale, en passant par éloquence. Nous choisirons le sens de éloquence, en imaginant un avocat, fameux par les « effets de manche - coude », qu’il sait pratiquer des deux mains.   --

column11: By one's side . . . elbow . . . turkey. Its match is in frame 605.  -    -  Men walk with their elbows out from their sides in a weird turkey trot when they try to appear very MASCULINE. Think of a 70´s pimp walk.  -  Masculine duties are to offer your elbow to the lady by your left side and to cut the turkey on special meals.
column12: Voici le correspondant du kanji vu au cadre 621. Le mâle est ici celui qui garde la dinde par devers soi, sous le coude.   --

column11: Elbow . . . mouth.  -    -  When someone´s elbow is above your mouth he/she is probably standing on a pedestal.  -  After training your whole life, you manage to get a bronze medal in the Olympics. You´re extremely proud of your accomplishment as you step up to receive your medal. The guy in first place is up on a pedestal, towering above you, his elbow level with your mouth. Being a smug bastard, he "accidentally" knocks his elbow into your mouth, causing you to bleed and lose a tooth. Just cause he won the gold doesn´t mean he can place himself on such a high pedestal and do whatever he wants!
column12: Coude...bouche. Voyez simplement ici l’image d’un piédestal en trapèze, socle de statue à côté duquel nous poserons diverses choses. Ce piédestal porte le sens secondaire de compteur des gros appareils, tout objet dont la taille suffisante permet qu'on l'assimile à un piédestal : voiture ou gros appareil manufacturé en pratique.  --

column11: Pedestal . . . heart.  -    -  While standing on the pedestal at the award ceremony, the recipient heartlessly neglected to mention the people that got him there.  -  Someone you put on a pedestal will NEGLECT your heart.
column12: Piédestal...sentiments. La négligence est ici indiquée par le fait que les sentiments sont sous le piédestal.   --

column11: Water . . . pedestal.  -    -  Build a moat around your pedestal to protect your reign of power.  -  From his water pedestal Neptune reigns over his Sea Empire.
column12: L'eau descend naturellement du piédestal, comme les ordres du roi descendent naturellement de son trône afin de lui assurer la pérennité du règne, la stabilité du pays : c'est ainsi que soigner, notamment au sens médical, fait naturellement partie des champs sémantiques de ce kanji.  --

column11: Woman . . . pedestal.  -    -  Many men, before they commence their relationship with the woman of their desires, place her on something of a pedestal, which often leads to disappointment later on.  -  If you want to commence a relationship, just put a woman on a pedestal and she´ll love ya forever.
column12: Femme...piédestal. Toute l'histoire commença lorsqu'il vit cette femme sur son piédestal.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . pedestal.  -    -  The body part feminists like to put on a pedestal is the womb, especially when they hear a man complain about some responsibility. "We give birth, so it´s your duty to do so-and-so".  -  If any body part deserves to be put on a pedestal, it is the womb from which new life springs forth.
column12: L'utérus est cette partie du corps qui joue le rôle de piédestal à l'embryon qui se développe.  --

column11: Soil . . . elbow.  -    -  Going, going, GONE!, said the gravedigger as he shoveled soil onto the body´s protruding elbow (the last bit left to cover).  -  If you want the soil stains gone from your clothes, then you´ll need to put some elbow grease into cleaning them.
column12: Ce kanji est utilisé pour évoquer des choses ou des êtres qui étaient mais ne sont plus, et ses éléments sont terre...coude. C’est qu’en effet quand on est « parti », on se retrouve... une coudée sous terre.   --

column6: law, rule, regulation, statute; France, French
column11: Water . . . gone.  -    -  This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial method, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the water until they were all gone.  -  There already was a system (#418) for butchering cows, a technique (#421) for turning smoke into flowers - why can´t there be a method of about the same relevance for making water gone? Evaporation anyone?
column12: Eau...parti. Ici est expliquée en termes très simples la méthode employée par Moïse pour faire traverser la Mer Rouge à son peuple : en tendant le bras, il a ordonné à l'eau de partir.  --

column11: Meeting . . . wall. This is the full character for meeting, from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name.  -    -  At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he´s the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.  -  The only thing created in most meetings is a lot of hot air. Imagine a cloud of it rising to the roof.
column12: Voici enfin l’assemblée que nous avions évoquée plus haut. Les éléments étant assemblée...mur, nons imaginerons une réunion de diverses personnes, sous un parapluie, entre quatre murs.   --

column6: reach, arrive; extremely, very; Kangxi radical 133
column11: Wall . . . soil. The key word allows for the full variety of connotations: to peak, to arrive at the end, and the like.  -    -  Sexual climaxes don´t always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground!  -  The climax of the Berlin Wall affair was the tearing of it to ground.
column12: Mur...sol. Il y a ici un mur bien planté sur le sol ; mur où aboutit la rue que vous suivez.  --

column6: room, home, house, chamber; 13th lunar mansion, determinative star α Pegasi (Markab)
column11: House . . . climax.  -    -  You book a room in a love hotel called "Climax House".  -  A simple room is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.
column12: Maison...aboutissement. La maison a abouti quand toutes les pièces sont installées.  --

column11: Climax . . . saber.  -    -  Http://img168.imageshack.us/img168/7731/karatesd3.jpg Just look at this image...  -  Just as we were about to climax her father arrived with a sword.
column12: Arrivé à l'aboutissement de notre voyage, la destination, nous rangeons le sabre.  --

column11: The archaic English form for "does" indicates a humble form of the verb "to do." It is made up of climax and taskmaster.  -    -  To reach climax I doth the bidding of my dominatrix taskmaster.  -  This character is used in two very high-frequency words: "you are welcome" (どう致しまして) and the honorific form of onegaishimasu (お願い致します; おねがいいたします). Can´t you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who DOTH the bidding of his taskmistress, is climaxing and yelling out "お願い致します" while she whips and says "どう致しまして". (This kanji also means "to bring about" and "do humbly", which is perfect for this image).
column12: Il faut voir dans ce kanji une forme humble du verbe faire. On utilisera le mot-clé dans le sens « c’est moi qui ai commis ce travail », en baissant respec­tueusement la tête. C’est évidemment au chef de corvée que l’on s’adresse, après l'aboutissement du travail. Notons que les éléments aboutir et énergie rendent aussi bien le sens du kanji.  --

column11: When you draw this character think of linking two walls together, one right side up and the other upside down.  -    -  The 69 position allows both parties to mutually give themselves pleasure.  -  If you can combined your walls with another house´s walls, both houses would mutually benefit, by the increase in size....
column12: Très rares sont les caractères présentant un centre de symétrie, et il est heureux que celui signifiant mutuel en ait un. Vous pourrez y voir si vous le désirez deux murs se soutenant mutuellement.   --

column11: Infant . . . buckle (See frame 444) . . . tree.  -    -  Think of a really loud and annoying baby, you want to abandon it but it keeps coming back...so you take of your belt by the buckle, and buckle the baby to a tree!  -  As in sash (#415), I treat the one mountain in the middle to mean Mt. Fuji (Japan´s ichiban mountain). Now we see an infant being abandoned on top of Mt. Fuji well above the tree line to die of exposure.
column12: Gamin...boucle(cf. 455)...arbre. Parfois nous sommes appelés à signer des pétitions contre l'abandon des animaux domestiques, que l'on montre alors souvent attachés à un arbre. Les éléments montrent ici une réalité plus cruelle encore, qui nous font voir notre gamin promis à un triste sort.  --

column11: Since the key word has to do with raising children to be strong both in mind and body, it is easy to coordinate the primitive elements: infant . . . meat.  -    -  Bringing up your offspring means raising them from infant until they are meat ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But bring up will forver be infant meat to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs!  -  I will bring up my infants to eat meat. I´ll not endure any vegetarian children in my house!
column12: Gamin...viande. Il s’agit ici essentiellement d’assurer le développement physique d’une jeune personne.  --

column11: Fingers . . . bring up . . . taskmaster.  -    -  Don´t lay a finger on him, a concerned mother says as the state REMOVES her child away for upbringing by a taskmaster foster home.  -  A terrible yakuza taskmaster is bringing up his infant. Every time the infant does something wrong... well, you know what happens to yakuzas when they do something wrong.
column12: Le gamin que l'on élève est entouré de deux éléments importants : le doigté et l'énergie. C'est qu'il faut le doigté et l'énergie de la sage-femme pour retirer le bébé !  --

column11: Infant . . . human legs.  -    -  Scene at the baby factory: Manager: "Good news! Your infant has been allotted human legs". Parent to be: "Thanks a lot!".  -  In China, to prevent too many human legs walking around, couples are alloted only one infant…　RTK2:　ジュウ　補充　ほじゅう(supplement)…　Semi-Pure Group:　銃762　(ﾄｳ): 統1347.
column12: Gamin...jambes. C'est l'heure de l'apéritif, dimanche midi. Et c'est bien entendu le gamin, sur ses courtes jambes, qui va se faire un plaisir de répartir les cacahuètes auprès de tous les invités, en faisant bien attention à ce que chacun ait la dose requise, comme le veut le sens exact de ce kanji.  --

column11: Metal . . . allot.  -    -  Everyone is allotted a metal gun (US constitution according to the NRA).  -  What is a gun but a device for allotting pieces of metal? One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...etc.
column12: Le fusil est un appareil à répartir le métal.  --

column11: Rock . . . infant . . . flood.  -    -  Sulphur is like a rock, but it can stink like a stream of infant doodie.  -  Infants are baptised in streams inorder to prevent their descent into a place of sulphur and brimstone.
column12: On sait que le soufre ressemble à de la pierre. On sait aussi que si le gamin commence à jouer avec, il faut se tenir près du robinet, pour inonder d’un puissant flot le début d’incendie.  --

column11: Water . . . infant . . . flood. Be sure to distinguish the two water primitives from one another in making your story.  -    -  INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the current of the STREAM.  -  A water-breathing infant (genetically modified?) is caught in a flood, and drifts with the current, apparently enjoying himself in the process.
column12: Les gouttes d’eau suivent le courant du fleuve, et le gamin suit le courant de la mode.   --

column6: to grant, to allow, to consent
column11: Elbow . . . human legs.  -    -  In some Asian kung-fu version of James Bond, the main protagonist has a “License To Kill” with his deadly elbows and human legs. His suit is always stained of red blood at the elbows and lower legs (this to help create an image that distinguish the two elements).  -  A midget driver trying to pass the road test to get their driver´s license. Their elbows are too short to turn the wheel and their legs are too short to reach the gas and breaks.
column12: Coude...jambes. Imaginons un individu nous donnant la permission d’entrer dans un lieu. Nous voyons ses deux jambes, ainsi que son bras plié au coude, dont il nous montre l’entrée de la salle : « Entrez, je vous en prie ! »  --

column11: Mouth . . . license . . . walking legs.  -    -  I named the right part legal prostitute has it represents a walker [walking legs] with the license. It´s easy to imagine a legal prostitute tempting a man with her mouth.  -  Prostitutes in Amsterdam have a license to show off their walking legs and tempt customers with their mouths.
column12: Bouche...permission...jambes qui marchent. La présence de la bouche ne surprend pas. L'élément de droite comprend la permission surmontant les jambes qui marchent, et l'ensemble représente par exemple un convive entrant prestement dans une salle. Nous extrayons alors l'idée de mouvement décidé.  --  Chapitre vingt-trois Sortie et entrée   APRÈS ce long voyage, prenons un peu de répit avec ce groupe plus simple, construit à partir des notions d'entrée et de sortie.

column6: go out, send out; stand; produce
column11: The kanji for exit pictures a series of mountain peaks coming out of the earth. Learn it together with the following frame.  -    -  Suddenly, a cactus comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: exit. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning ´cactus´ can be useful later).  -  The exit lays between these two mountains.
column12: Ce kanji montre l’image de pics montagneux sortant de terre, phénomène fréquent au Japon. Apprenez-le de concert avec le caractère suivant.   --  Par une sorte de « mélange des effets et des causes », ce caractère signifie à la fois sortir, donc être absent de chez-soi, et assister à, donc être présent là où on avait décidé d'aller au moment de sortir !

column11: Note the clearer outline of a triangular mountain here.  -    -  Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example).  -  YOU CAN´T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!
column12: Reconnaissez la forme de trois pics montagneux dans ces trois traits.  --

column11: Fingers . . . exit.  -    -  With fingers fumbling around trying to get the key in the door so he could exit, the bungling husband woke his wife as he tried to leave for a rendezvous with his mistress.  -  Horror movie cliche 769: Bungling victim´s fingers fumble & bungle trying to open the exit door.
column12: Doigt...sortir. Le doigt du maladroit a glissé, est sorti de l'endroit où il devrait être. Nous avons déjà noté que plusieurs kanjis définissent la notion d'humilité. Voici la première occurrence de ce phénomène : ce kanji est (ou était) employé pour parler humblement de soi-même. Comprenez-vous la maladroite phrase ?  --

column11: Mountain . . . rock.  -    -  A mountain-sized stone is known as a boulder.  -  Here we see mountain rocks rolling down the mountain, gathering into a single monstrous boulder crushing everything in its path. Think snowball effect, even if it wouldn´t work with rocks.
column12: Cette pierre est si grosse qu’elle a roulé jusqu’au bas de la montagne : c’est donc un rocher.   --

column11: Mountain . . . ashes.  -    -  Burn enough charcoal and you´ll have a mountain of ash.  -  You get charcoal from volcano ("fire mountain", 火山) ashes.
column12: Une montagne de cendres nous donne l’idéogramme d’une charbonnière, où on fabrique le charbon de bois.  --

column11: Mountains . . . branch.  -    -  On the left, there are three mountains. The road branches off to each of them. (Note: This kanji is mostly used for branches in the road).  -  In a lot of Super Nintendo-era RPGs, there are mountain levels to get through. You view them from overhead, so you can see a mazelike path with many branches. Picture your sprite characters at one such fork in the mountain path, as it branches off in two directions.
column12: Montagne...branche. La route de montagne se sépare en deux branches, à cette bifurcation. On peut se demander ce que vient faire ici la montagne, puisque l'idée pourrait être la même en plaine. La montagne confère ici une grande force à l'idée de bifurcation, par le caractère irrémédiable du choix proposé : on ne peut pas facilement passer d'un chemin à l'autre, une fois que l'on s'est engagé sur l'un des deux.  --

column11: Mountain . . . above . . . below.  -    -  Heisig mentions at kanjiclinic.com that he wishes he´d chosen mountain pass for this keyword as it´s closer to what the word means. If we do this, the kanji makes complete sense because a mountain pass is just below the mountain top.  -  To the north of Lorien lies the Misty Mountains, and below their towering peaks are the Mines of Moria. The Fellowship of the Ring first tried for the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes above, but were halted by the wizardry of Saruman at Caradhras, and so are forced to take the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes below, through the mountain - a path long feared by Gandalf for the ancient evil that lurks there. Note : the kanji does in fact refer to a "mountain pass".
column12: Montagne...dessus...dessous. La forme en selle de cheval d’un col de montagne se dessine au travers de ce kanji.  --

column11: Mountain . . . companion.  -    -  Sam and Frodo were steadfast companions even as Mount Doom crumbled above them.  -  September 11. [lol it also has 11 strokes], whoever reported this story is a loser, get alife. This is the best story on the website.
column12: Montagne...compagnon. Le compagnon enseveli sous cette montagne nous donne le kanji effondrement, au sens propre et figuré.  --

column11: House . . . invariably . . . mountain.  -    -  To maintain secrecy, secret societies invariably have to house themselves in the moutains.  -  To maintain secrecy, secret societies invariably have to house themselves on top of the moutains. (Slight tweak of chamcham´s story, using fuaburisa´s idea for remembering where to put the mountain primitive.).
column12: Maison...nécessairement...montagne. Je n’en dirai pas plus !  --

column11: House . . . invariably . . . insect.  -    -  When I think of honey, I think of a bee hive, which is a HOUSE that INVARIABLY has INSECTS.  -  A house with a lot of honey will invariably attract many insects.
column12: Maison...nécessairement...insecte. Certes, on verrait mieux l’idéogramme d’une abeille !  --

column11: Mountain . . . winds.  -    -  Storm is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here).  -  Winds are gathering at the base of the mountain (note the hint to primitive placement), going up, and turning into a huge mountain storm.
column12: De même que c’est au milieu des champs que l’on perçoit au mieux le tonnerre, c’est au milieu de la montagne qu’il faut aller écouter le vent de la tempête.   --

column11: Mountain . . . strange. Hint: you might save yourself the trouble of a story here simply by recalling the kanji for cape (Frame 164) and toying around with the differing images suggested by the key words promontory and cape.  -    -  This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.  -  A promontory is a small, strange mountain that juts out into the sea.
column12: Peut-être pouvez-vous vous épargner la peine de refaire une mise en scène, en vous remémorant le kanji cap, et en jouant avec les images que suggèrent cap et promontoire.   --

column11: This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to enter someplace. Since the "in" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character.  -  * As a primitive, the meaning of the key word is expanded to include: to go in, to put in, to come in, and the like. It generally appears atop its relative primitive, where, unlike the element for umbrella, the two strokes do not touch each other, making it virtually the same as the kanji for eight. When it appears in any other position, however, it retains its original form.  -  Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.  -  Person enters stage left…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ニュウ　入院　にゅういん(admittance into a hospital).
column12: Ce kanji montre quelqu’un marchant vers la gauche, plaçant une jambe en avant afin d’entrer quelque part. Compte tenu du sens de l’écriture, on l’imaginera entrer dans le texte pour retenir l’écriture de ce kanji.  --  En composant, on utilisera les sens entrer et faire entrer. Il apparaîtra en général au-dessus d'autres éléments, et dans ce cas, les deux traits ne se toucheront pas, donnant une image virtuellement identique à celle de huit. En d'autres positions, il gardera sa forme normale.

column11: Enter . . . road.  -    -  During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to enter the roadway as it is crowded with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour.  -  Everybody tries to enter the road during rush hour. That´s why it´s so crowded.
column12: Route...entrer. Imaginez-vous débouchant d’une voie secondaire pour en­trer sur la route principale, encombrée.   --

column6: divide; small unit of time etc.
column11: Go in . . . dagger.  -    -  When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts.  -  (This kanji also has the meanings of "understand" and "minute"). It´s important to understand that were you to enter an hour with a dagger and cut it into parts, those parts would be minutes.
column12: Entrer...épée. Ce kanji vaut aussi une portion de temps : une minute. S'ajoutant au sens de portion, on trouve celui de scinder, mais aussi celui de comprendre. Il est intéressant de constater que le verbe comprendre suggère de « prendre le tout ensemble », alors que le kanji correspondant implique l'idée de « tout mettre en portions ».  --

column11: Part . . . shells/money.  -    -  In the case of true poverty, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn´t really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole.  -  Parting with your money will lead to poverty.
column12: La portion du pauvre se réduit à une pièce de monnaie.   --

column11: Part . . . head.  -    -  The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji PARTITION.  -  The last time I tried to partition a hard drive under Linux, I got a severe migraine that parted my head.
column12: Lors du partage on distribue, équitablement, une portion par tête. Ce caractère anodin nous montre la solution, connue depuis des millénaires, des problèmes actuels de notre monde.  --

column11: House . . . head . . . dagger. Immediately we get another instance of a very odd exception. Notice how the final stroke of the head is lengthened, giving the final two strokes a chance to stretch out and make room for the dagger that fits in beneath.  -    -  The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband.  -  The house´s head, her husband, was murdered with a dagger. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a widow.
column12: Maison...tête...portion. Nous avons vu une première fois auparavant l'allongement du trait inférieur de tête (683). Si cela peut aider, un sens associé est veuve : celle qui a « très peu » de mari.  --

column11: Come in . . . elbows. Use the key word in its adjectival sense, not as a noun.  -    -  I always enter the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don't want to touch the door with my hands.  -
column12: Entrer - huit...coude - privé. Peut-être aurez-vous envie d’utiliser (pour la première et unique fois) le sens dérivé de l’élément huit : comprendre le Tout. La notion de public est alors rendue par une entité comprenant l’ensemble des entités privées.   --  Le sésame sera parfois pouvoirs publics.

column11: Tree . . . public.  -    -  Following up with the "entering public restrooms" story for the right-hand primitive: public restrooms always reek of pine tree scented disinfectant.  -  A pine tree is a public tree: they are frequently planted in public squares, in commemoration of the respect Conficius held for them.
column12: Arbre...public. En France, ce kanji pourrait signifier « platane », l’arbre des places publiques, mais en Asie, il définit le pin.  --

column11: Public . . . feathers.  -    -  The venerable old man is the public figure head of the Native American Village, answering all questions and solving all problems. The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more feathers decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers.  -  The venerable old man is using the public restroom in the park where he feeds the pigeons. But, alas, there is no toilet paper! So, he´s caught a pigeon and is using it to wipe his bottom. (note the feathers on the bottom of the kanji, this helps remember placement). Can you see the feathers flying everywhere?
column12: Les pouvoirs publics protègent les vénérables vieillards avec un duvet bien fourni de plumes qui les tient au chaud.  --

column11: Words . . . public.  -    -  Take care what words you say in public lest you be sued.  -  [+radical_tyro] Socrates was giving a speech in public. Things were going rather well, until his robe opened a bit and people saw his, well, not-public area. He was promptly sued for public indecency. Certain things shouldn´t be made public in public, you know?
column12: Des mots en public envers un tiers constituent l'accusation.  --

column11: Go in . . . an umbrella . . . a mouth. Because of space restrictions, the element for go in is shortened in this character. If you stand on your head and look at this kanji, the image of a valley stands out more clearly: the mouth of the river whose water flows down at the intersection of the two mountains, with the final two strokes adding the element of perspective. Now get back on your feet again and see if the image still remains clear. If not, then return to the primitives and make a story in the usual way.  -    -  This could be seen as a very accurate pictograph of another type of valley: a valley mouth open under the umbrella of inner labia, with the outer labia parted above. There are even more connections to be made among the primitive keywords and the visuals, but i will enter no further...  -  Think of the classic anime 風の谷のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind). We see Nausicaa entering the valley mouth gliding on an umbrella.
column12: Entrer...parapluie...bouche. Pour retenir ce kanji, retournez le livre, et vous verrez apparaître l'image d'une vallée. La source de la rivière (bouche), d'où l'eau s'écoule, entre les deux pans de montagne, les deux traits finaux ajoutant une image de perpective. Puis remettez le livre à l'endroit et voyez si l'image créée subsiste.   --  Si l'image ne subsiste pas, songez que ce caractère évoque un peu l'Origine du Monde, le tableau de Gustave Courbet auquel nous associons facilement l'idée de « vallée des délices ».

column11: Water . . . valley.  -    -  The mountain man uses the water from the valley to bathe.  -  This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴　（こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間.
column12: Eau...vallée. Le bain, institution et loisir numéro un au Japon, trouve son origine dans les sources thermales qui abondent dans les vallées des régions montagneuses.  --

column11: This character depicts a house so large that it can contain an entire valley.  -    -  Imagine a house big enough to contain an entire valley. might want to live there. And now imagine cleaning it. . . . Maybe not . . .  -  Biodome.
column12: Ce kanji montre une maison si grande qu’elle peut contenir une vallée entière.  --

column11: Water . . . contain.  -    -  Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below.  -  [melt; dissolve; thaw] An ice cube is melting, loosing the water it contained.
column12: Faire fondre quelque chose consiste à le placer dans un contenant et à le transformer en liquide.   --

column11: Valley . . . yawn. Be sure to keep the key word distinct from pining (Frame 683).  -    -  Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲; lust. As for a story: the lack of contact with a woman´s valley will leave a man LONGING for love.  -  The valley has something my life is lacking.... something I´ve been longing for.. peace and quiet.
column12: Vallée...manque. C’est en particulier au fond des vallées isolées que le manque d’un objet va en rendre l'envie particulièrement forte.  --

column11: This character shows the typical cloak of valley folk, which, unlike the tailor-made, high-fashion overcoats of city folk, is loose-fitting and free-form. Hence the key word's meaning of abundant.  -    -  Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called "valley of the chest": a woman with abundant cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting cloak, but leaving her valley exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I´ll be here all week).  -  Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are abundant in the valley”.
column12: Ce kanji met en scène les vêtements des habitants de la vallée, qui, au contraire de ceux du citadin, sont amples et flottants : d’où la notion d'aise.   --

column11: Metal . . . gully.  -    -  Picture the molten lead (the heavy metal) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a gully behind.  -  Lead -> Dental fillings -> Metal that enters the mouth to fill a hole in a tooth.
column12: Métal...gouttière. Le plombier travaille le métal dont on faisait les gouttières.   --

column11: Water . . . gully. The key word is meant to refer to things like rivers and railway tracks that run alongside something else.  -    -  Water in a gully runs alongside the path.  -  Picture one of those idiots that run alongside the bicyclists in the Tour de France trying to give them water. Watch as the cyclist shoves the person into a gully that runs alongside the road.
column12: L'image de l'eau longeant la gouttière pourra ensuite être transposée à des rivières, des voies ferrées, etc. longeant quelque chose.  --  Chapitre vingt-quatre Quelques personnes  NOUS abordons un groupe de kanjis concernant les êtres humains. Les quelques composants introduits nous permettront de créer un grand nombre de caractères. Commençons avec un composant couronne.

column11: Outhouse . . . shellfish.  -    -  This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also secret (#904)).  -  As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant´s outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.
column12: Toilette publique...monnaie. Ici est organisé un concours de propreté des toilettes publiques et nous conférons le premier prix.  --

column11: Think of this key word as referring to a political party, not a gala affair. Its elements: human legs . . . sticking out of an outhouse window.  -    -  Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.  -  Every political party is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here´s your answer - a political party memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He´s grown so accustomed to the taste that he´s in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He´ll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.
column12: On voit ici dépasser, sous la porte de la toilette publique, les jambes d’un individu. Le jeu consiste à deviner sa couleur politique, avec comme seul indice la couleur de ses Weston.  --

column11: Outhouse . . . land.  -    -  There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.  -  In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.
column12: Sur le terrain près de l’édifice public, la toilette publique.   --

column11: Outhouse . . . towel.  -    -  It´s usual to take your towel with you when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn´t see your stuff.  -  In the outhouse toilet you´d usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it´s already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.
column12: Il est habituel de trouver une serviette dans la toilette publique.   --

column11: The key word refers to an ancient skirt once used as part of a woman's costume. The primitives you have to work with are: outhouse . . . garment.  -    -  Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business.  -  Haven´t you ever noticed that the men / women signs on the front of outhouses are sometimes very similar? The silhouettes are usually the same, but one will decidedly be wearing a garment in the shape of a SKIRT. Also, we´ve already learned the kanji for "woman", so if the signs are only in kanji you have no right to wander in and claim ignorance, perv!
column12: Cette robe fait partie de l'habillement traditionnel de la femme japonaise. On apprend que c’est l’habit de rigueur pour aller à la toilette publique.   --

column6: palm of hand, sole of foot, paw
column11: Outhouse . . . hand.  -    -  If you´re going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least!  -  Instead of magazines, we keep a Rubiks Cube in the outhouse to manipulate with your hands while you do your business.
column12: Toilettes publiques...main. La mise en scène est simple, mais vous me permettrez de ne pas l'écrire ! Notez ensuite que ce kanji signifie aussi administrer : on voudrait pouvoir « administrer » une bonne claque au citoyen n'ayant pas remplacé le rouleau, comme cela arrive dans les toilettes publiques.  --

column11: The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for branch. The first stroke can then stand for something "hanging" down from the branch, namely its bark or pelt. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with.  -    -  A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.  -  To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to "just remember it" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.
column12: Construisons ce kanji à partir de la branche. Le premier trait sera alors un lambeau pendant de la branche, un morceau de sa peau. Le crochet à l’autre extrémité est le seul autre changement. Concentrez-vous donc sur ce détail à l’occasion des caractères suivants.  --

column11: Water's . . . pelt.  -    -  Waves are the ocean´s pelt (skin).  -  The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.
column12: Eau...peau.  L’onde parcourant la surface de la mer est la peau de l'eau.  --  On associera le sens de vague en composant.

column11: Waves . . . woman.  -    -  An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).  -  You know "The Old Man and the Sea." Well, this is the sequel, "The Old Woman and the Sea Waves.".
column12: La vieille femme fait encore autorité dans la maisonnée, elle fait encore des vagues.  --

column11: Fingers . . . pelt.  -    -  You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.  -  Think of it in this vulgar way. You really want her to expose her “beaver” pelt, so you have to encourage her with your fingers to expose it.
column12: Les doigts sont une des seules parties de la peau qui soient directement exposées aux intempéries.  --

column11: Rock . . . pelt.  -    -  Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to REND PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year.  -  Rend is a violent, primitive kind of word. (Image: cavemen rending pelts right off live animals with stone tools).
column12: Il suffit d'une amorce de rupture pour casser une pierre, même dure. En ce sens, une petite action en surface, la peau, a pour effet la rupture de la pierre.  --

column11: Cloak . . . pelt.  -    -  If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to incur the wrath of animal rights extremists.  -  A cloak of fur (pelt) will incur the wrath of animal lovers.
column12: Ce mot-clé correspond bien aux divers sens du kanji : endosser un vêtement ou une responsabilité, ou encourir une peine. Les composants manteau...peau s’accordent bien avec le mot-clé mais imaginez par exemple le contact froid de la doublure du manteau directement sur votre peau pour bien retenir les deux éléments.  --

column11: Bones . . . (parade) float.  -    -  The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).  -  Throwing all those coins (see coin (#368)) was a really bad idea; people got mad with greed. The only remainders left were the bones of those that was on the float.
column12: À la fin des temps, lorsqu'il ne restera rien, on ne verra plus que quelques ossements entre quelques planchettes.  --

column6: die for cause, be martyr for
column11: Bones . . . decameron.  -    -  Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered martyrdom because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as bones to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off....nothing, not even a pile of bones to bury.  -  The boney man martyred himself during his 10 day hunger-strike.
column12: Souffrir le martyre nous transforme en ossements en une décade.   --

column11: Bones . . . vermilion.  -    -  A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare.  -  Castlevania -- The vermillion skeletons (bones) are particularly hard because they just keep regenerating.
column12: Ossements...vermillon. Si vous imaginez une visite aux abattoirs, des images particulièrement peu ragoûtantes surgiront sans doute.  --

column11: Bones . . . straightaway.  -    -  He wanted to augment his height so had some bone added to his legs straightaway.  -  Wolverine has had his body specially augmented. He has special super-bones and the ability to heal straightaway after any injury.
column12: Pour qu’un ossement  croisse bien, il lui faut croître bien droit.   --

column6: a line; to arrange in order, classify
column11: Bones . . . saber. The sense of the key word is of people or things lined up in a row.  -    -  A line of skeletal warriors, all armed with sabers.  -  Skeleton army rank and file. Dudes made of bones carrying sabres.
column12: Le sens est celui d’une succession de choses ou de gens placés en rang. On imaginera une file de dépouilles à l’abattoir, ossements attendant en file le sabre du dépouilleur.  --

column11: File . . . garment.  -    -  They tried issuing the skeleton warriors with proper garments to wear, but they kept getting split by the sharp bones or by their sabres. In the end, it was decided they look scarier naked anyway.  -  Someone takes a sword made of bone to split the garment right down the middle. Very effective.
column12: La fente dans ce vêtement sera vue au travers d’un bas qui a « filé ».   --

column11: File . . . oven fire.  -    -  The nazis were ardent believers in the master arian race, see them marching everyone else into the oven fires, single file.  -  The undead, marching single file, prove how ardent they are be walking across a field of flame. Fun fact, ardent used to mean to burn.
column12: Une file de gens bouillant d'impatience se trouve devant le chaudron, avec le désir ardent que leur tour arrive bientôt.  --

column11: Bones . . . spoon. Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of "roof" overhead.  -    -  Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they´re out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.  -  Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.
column12: Notez comment le premier trait de ossement s’allonge pour recouvrir la petite cuiller.   --

column11: Flowers . . . death . . . two hands. Do not confuse with bury (Frame 191).  -    -  I imagine an interment as a funeral. At this funeral it´s an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands.  -  During the interment ceremony, the grandchildren placed flowers over the dead body while the widow sat praying with two hands.
column12: Jetez les végétaux des deux mains sur le cercueil du mort à l'occasion de ses funérailles.  --

column6: wink, blink; in a wink, a flash
column11: Eye . . . birdhouse . . . sunglasses.  -    -  Imagine Snoopy winking with his big eyes (and a happy smile) standing next to Woodstocks Birdhouse, woodstock being so cool that he wears little sunglasses.  -  What a dilemna, you wore SUNGLASSES over your EYES when you went to the BIRDHOUSE so you wouldn´t be recognized - but now you can´t WINK at the girl you want!
column12: Notre œil se ferme et s'ouvre un court instant, en un clin d'œil dirait-on, ce qui justement est le second sens du kanji.  --

column6: ear; merely, only; handle; Kangxi radical 128
column11: The pictograph for the ear looks much like that for eye, but note how the stroke order gives it a different look.  -    -  Your ear is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines.  -  Pictograph, see book. * The primitive meaning can easily be extended to ear plugs.
column12: L’oreille pourrait ressembler à l’œil, mais comme l’ordre de tracé diffère, l’aspect est bouleversé.  --

column11: Ear . . . crotch.  -    -  You put your ear next to a womans crotch...and somehow, from it, you hear the words "Take me....".  -  Fuaburisu´s with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to take something out of an someone else´s ear (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s crotch out of their ear. Very painful!
column12: Oreille...main droite. Où l’on conte l’histoire du petit garçon qui s’est fait prendre la main dans la bonbonnière.  --

column11: Run . . . take.  -    -  The gist of it is this: We take the money and run!  -  Pickpocket advice: It´s simple, FIRST run, then take. Yeah, that´s the gist of it!
column12: Saisir la teneur d’un texte consiste à le parcourir et à y prendre les éléments importants.  --

column11: Sun . . . take.  -    -  TAKE the UTMOST care when you SUN bath all DAY, or you´ll get burned from your EARS to your CROTCH.  -  Do your utmost - seize(take) the day.
column12: Icare, fils de Dédale, est mort pour avoir voulu voler le plus haut, et tenter de prendre le soleil.   --

column11: Finger . . . utmost. This character is used for taking photographs. Note how, conveniently, the element for "take" is included in it.  -    -  Take the utmost care that you don´t have your finger in the way when you take a snapshot.  -  When I learned photography from my dad as a little girl, he explained the basics to me: "when you take a snapshot, be careful not to put your fingers before the lens, and don´t look towards the sun (this was in the days that photographs would be spoiled by direct sunlight).
column12: On retrouvera dans ce kanji un excellent argument de vente pour les fabricants d’appareils photo. Ces merveilles sont le plus sophistiquées possible, pour permettre à l’opérateur une prise de vue d’une seule pression du doigt.   --

column11: Ear . . . heart. It is most rare to have the heart at the right, rather than at the bottom. Take advantage of this fact when you compose your story.  -    -  Vincent Van Gogh´s greatest shame was cutting off his ear to win the heart of a woman.  -  Amelia Ear-Heart (sic) brought shame to those who said women couldn´t fly.
column12: Oreille...cœur (exceptionnellement placé à droite). Cet individu est couvert de honte, qui se manifeste par le rougissement de ses oreilles. La cause de sa honte est, évidemment, d’avoir le cœur placé à droite.   --

column11: The key word refers to one's occupation, or position of employment. Its elements: ear . . . kazoo.  -    -  Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!  -  Buckingham Palace guards are famous for staying at their post no matter what, even if you blow a kazoo in their ear!
column12: L'oreille de l'ouvrier à son poste de travail est sourde au tintamarre des machines hurlant autour de lui.  --

column11: Ear . . . mouth . . . king.  -    -  The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his ear to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his mouth to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, kings are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).  -  A holy man hears with his ears before he speaks with his mouth, which places him higher than a king in people´s esteem.
column12: Oreille...bouche...roi. Le saint dont il est ici question est un de ces conseillers du roi, qui par ses conseils (la bouche près de l'oreille) éclaire le roi, comme Saint Eloi éclairant le roi Dagobert. C’est pourquoi l’élément roi vient au bas du kanji.  --

column11: Spike . . . ear . . . taskmaster.  -    -  Only a truly daring Japanese student would wear a spike in his ear under the gaze of the Japanese teacher taskmasters!  -  See that ear nailed over there ? It´s the ear of the last person who was too daring with the taskmistress.
column12: Cette audace est symbolisée par l’énergie qu’il faut pour percer son oreille avec un petit clou.   --

column11: Ear . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Compare frame 427 for this and the following kanji, and then once again when you get to frame 950.  -    -  I promise to use my ear to do nothing but listen ... stick a needle in my eye, cross my heart and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).  -  Listening to others is different from hearing [1626] with the ear. One must allow the words to pierce through the eyes (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the heart...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You´re not listening to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said..." “Yes, but you´re not listening.".
column12: Écouter requiert une oreille attentive. Nous sommes confortablement installés avec la jolie broche faite d'une simple aiguille piquée sur notre châle à l'auditorium, et nous ouvrons grand notre cœur et nos oreilles.  --

column11: State of mind . . . needle . . . eyes . . . garment.  -    -  (re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York State of Mind": you need ten eyes to make sure no one will go through your garments and pick your pockets.  -  Imagine Darth Vader´s state of mind when he discovers his garment has not pockets. " D O NOT WANT!".
column12: Nous retrouvons ici notre fantôme vu en 437, associé à (état d')esprit. Votre mission est d'intervenir auprès de lui pour éviter qu'il ne frotte sa longue robe le long des immeubles voisins : vous devez vous le mettre « dans la poche », ou encore, l'apprivoiser. Maintenant, songez quelques secondes que cette histoire est une histoire vécue, et tentez d'y songer avec nostalgie : vous aurez ainsi fait le tour de ce kanji.  --

column11: State of mind . . . mandala.  -    -  I´ll focus on the mandala primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it´s the "man" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts.  -  He´ s often ridiculed for having his eye on crotches all day.
column12: État d’esprit...mannequin. Selon les associations, le sens peut aller de fierté à endurance.  --

column11: Water . . . mandala.  -    -  Staring at mandalas is a tool in meditation to loosen-up the mind and body, allowing the energy to flow like water.  -  One obscure Tibetan sect-- the Otaku cult-- has an unusually loose interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas (漫画). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew.
column12: Eau...mannequin. La jolie mannequin a été poussée dans l'eau par un farceur, et sa beauté est devenue quelque chose de beaucoup plus flou.  --

column11: Eye . . . shellfish.  -    -  When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and buy before anybody else does.  -  Rules to Buying: 1. You´ve had your eye on it for a while. 2. You have enough shells to afford it.
column12: Pour aller acheter, nous prenons le filet à provisions et un peu de monnaie.  --

column11: Eye . . . straightaway.  -    -  On the JET Programme, many people have their eye on a placement in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside straightaway.  -  Working in retail you learn the placement of any item should be at eye level so it´s seen straightaway.
column12: Filet...droit devant. En entrant à l'hôtel, on est surpris de voir droit devant soi les valises soigneusement placées sous un filet.  --

column11: Eye . . . words . . . saber.  -    -  For Japanese, when the mind´s eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I´m sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I´m sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).  -  There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at penalty shootout: 1. Look directly into the eyes of the player --- 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless words --- 3. Pull out you your saber and ... (that´s up to you).
column12: Filet...mot...sabre. L'homme qui distribue les pénalités place un filet sur les contrevenants, prononce quelques mots, puis tranche la question d'un coup de sabre.  --

column11: House . . . heart . . . eye . . . spike.  -    -  A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d´oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I´d RATHER not.".  -  Rather a house with a heart than an eye with a spike.
column12: Maison...cœur...filet (crépine)...tranche de pâté. Le sens de ce kanji est composite, car il renferme aussi la notion de réconfort moral et matériel, plutôt étant en fait un sens dérivé. Imaginez-vous plutôt aller chez votre ami Marcel, car dans sa maison vous aurez toute son attention, le cœur, et une bonne tranche de pâté dans sa crépine de porc.  --

column11: The key word for this kanji connotes the "muddying" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For example, in English a "j" is voiced while a "sh" is unvoiced. In Japanese, the し is changed to じ when it is voiced. The primitives are: water . . . eye . . . bound up . . . insect.  -    -  The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who´s venom is dripping like water from her fangs.  -  Pour water over the eyes of a bound up insect if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a VOICED consanant.
column12: Cette eau est trouble. Avec une fine mousseline, nous la filtrons et découvrons une multitude d'insectes emballés dans le tissu. Ce kanji est aussi employé pour définir la notion de consonne sonore, dont la prononciation demande que vibrent les cordes vocales. Dans l'esprit japonais, la lettre じ est donc une « lettre trouble », alors que し ne l'est pas.  --

column11: Jewel . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf. The number of elements is large here, so take extra care. Learn it in conjunction with the next frame, since these are the only two cases in this book where the combination of elements to the right appears.  -    -  Together with the next kanji, the keywords spell “send back the ring”. First we have a jewel. Next we have the great eye of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many ceilings during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the mouth of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”; and Pippin´s scarf! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower.  -  In conjunction with send back (#837)....... When I tried to give her the jewel ring, she eyed me, threw it to the floor, opened her mouth and tried to speak, she said nothing. She grabbed her scarf and left.
column12: Bijou...filet...plancher...bouche...écharpe. Ce caractère au sens général d'anneau apparaît dans des mots tels que « atoll », « cycle aromatique » ou « boulevard périphérique ». Essayons de former l'image d'un atoll, un bel endroit pour des vacances paradisiaques. Le bijou sera donc une bague offerte, sur la plage ; sur le plancher, un filet pour la pêche du jour afin de préparer les agapes - la bouche ; et comme vêtement, une simple écharpe de protection contre le soleil. Un peu compliqué mais tout y est, dans le bon ordre.   --  L'élément de droite n'apparaît dans ce livre que pour ce kanji et le suivant. Le sésame sera une rondelle, la forme de l'atoll.

column11: Road . . . eye . . . ceiling . . . mouth . . . scarf.  -    -  You´ve probably guessed it by now, this is the road that Sam and Frodo take to send back the ring to Mount Doom! (see previous frame, the jewel is replaced by the road).  -  Continued from ring (#836)....... So I´m on the road going to send back the ring minus the jewel, the hit to the floor knocked it out.
column12: Route...rondelle. Renvoyer, c'est faire faire demi-tour à l'objet reçu, donc à lui faire suivre un chemin circulaire, en forme de rondelle, un cycle.  --

column11: The kanji for a husband or "head of the family" is based on the kanji for large and an extra line near the top for the "head." Recall the kanji for heavens already learned back in frame 457, and be sure to keep your story for this kanji different.  -    -  Even though it is argued size is not important, I´m sure most women would like their husband to have a big one.  -  Homer Simpson, as a primitive.
column12: Le kanji mari, la tête de la famille, est construit à partir de celui de grand, auquel est ajouté un trait : cette tête, proprement dite. Prenez garde à ne pas le confondre avec cieux.  --  Chef de famille sera employé comme sésame. On imaginera un chef de famille un peu maladroit mais de bonne volonté.

column11: Fingers . . . husband.  -    -  Using his finger the husband sometimes is an erotic aid to his partner.  -  In Homer Simpsons´ house, the first aid kit is usually used for when he smashes his fingers trying to build something (there are countless Simpsons episodes you can draw from for this).
column12: Pour prêter main forte, le chef de famille montre du doigt là où ça ne va pas, puis laisse faire les plus jeunes, plus habiles.  --

column11: Water . . . vulture . . . husband.  -    -  The Simpsons are on vacation. Homer stops to take a leak in a mountain stream but gets snatched by an eagle. Hear his scream?  -  A husband who went fishing at the mountain stream to feed his family, fell in the rapids (we´ll assume this is a large mountain stream). He is saved from the waters by a great eagle. He comes back home with nothing to feed the family, his clothes still dripping wet as he tells his wife of how he was saved by a great eagle, and of course she does not believe him. The story continues in chicken (#1947).
column12: Le sens est identique à celui de vallée. Sur le côté de cette gorge coule un torrent d'eau, alors que les vautours planent dans les hauteurs... Le chef de famille, qui recherche les siens égarés, en gravit lentement le fond.  --

column11: Husband . . . see.  -    -  In the male-dominated world of yesterday, the husband´s way of seeing things was considered the standard point of view. Women who dared to disagree were frowned upon.  -  Unfortunately, Homer Simpson is the standard model of a husband in American society. (Placement: You have to look in the RIGHT places to find one that doesn´t fit that mold.).
column12: Chef de famille...regarder. Avant d’acheter un nouveau meuble, le chef de famille le regarde attentivement, pour s’assurer qu’ils respecte bien les normes.   --

column11: Two husbands . . . day.  -    -  A show like "Trading Spouses" called "exchanging husbands" where 2 husbands are exchanged for a day (thanks dingomick).  -  Marge´s dream: to exchange Homer for another husband for just one day.
column12: Deux chefs de famille...jour. Un second chef de famille est venu se substi­tuer à l’habituel.  --

column11: Two husbands . . . shells.  -    -  Out of two potential husbands, which would you approve of? Well, the one with shells (money) of course!!!  -  Bush´s campaign- "John Kerry approves using taxpayers´ money to support gay marriage. I don´t." "I approve this message".
column12: Deux chefs de famille...monnaie. Peut-être trouverez-vous utile de savoir que l’ancienne forme de ce kanji est : 贊.  --

column11: Water . . . exchange.  -    -  When a submarine or similar vessel SUBMERGES an EXCHANGE of air for WATER takes place in special compartments.  -  The two husbands exchange for a day on the reality TV show (see exchange (#842)) finally goes underway. One of the two husband´s first job is to fix the water faucet in his new family´s apartment. Unfortunately, he isn´t very good at fixing things and after a few failed attempts the entire apartment is submerged in water.
column12: Lorsqu'on s'immerge, il se produit une substitution de forces, dont l'intensité est égale au volume du corps immergé multiplié par la masse volumique de l'eau : Eurêka !  --

column11: "To lose" here takes the sense of "misplace," not the sense of defeat, whose kanji we learned in frame 67. It pictures a husband with something falling from his side as he is walking along, something he loses.  -  * As a primitive, this character can also mean to drop.  -  The drop falling here is the husband´s toupee... he´s already lost his hair once, now he´s losing it again. Such is life, I suppose.  -  Note: Heisig´s stroke order is wrong. It´s the same as vermilion, drop first. Homer loses/drops his wedding ring.
column12: Le kanji perdre met en scène un chef de famille au côté duquel quelque chose pend : quelque chose qu’il est en train de perdre.  --

column11: Metal . . . to drop.  -    -  Iron is a metal that gradually becomes lost due to oxidation and rust.  -  Compare with pig-iron (#270). In moving from pig-iron to iron, some of the metal´s maleability is LOST. (The only difference between the two kanji is that IRON has knee-less, unbending legs, while PIG-IRON (270) has very supple, bendable legs.).
column12: Le fer est un métal qui perd beaucoup de résistance au fil du temps.  --

column11: To drop . . . road.  -    -  When you get lost, you just take an alternate road to get back on track.  -  When you lose your way, you can always try to tell the wife that you merely took an alternate road. To save time you know. I´m not LOST, I´m just taking an alternate road. Ahem.
column12: On imaginera les gros camions utilisés lors du transfert des bureaux d'un ministère, perdant en route force papiers et documents confidentiels.  --

column11: This kanji is actually a pictograph for an eye, distorted to make it appear that the pupil is protruding towards the right. This may not be an easy form to remember, but try this: Draw it once rather large, and notice how moving the two vertical lines on the right as far right as possible gives you the pictograph of the eye in its natural form. The "pop-eye" image belongs to an Emperor's retainer standing in awe before his ruler.  -  * As a primitive, the meaning of the key word becomes slave.  -  Its a pictograph of a teeth with a retainer in the middle.  -  Retainer = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.
column12: Ce kanji est le pictogramme d’un œil distordu, montrant une pupille protubérante sur le côté droit. Notons qu’il ne s’en faut que du déplacement de deux petits traits pour retrouver l’image habituelle de l’œil. L’œil protubérant est celui du serviteur, prêt à servir sa majesté.  --  Le sésame sera esclave.

column11: Woman . . . slave.  -    -  Princess Leia becomes Jabba´s slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”).  -  Cinderella: A woman who was a slave who became a princess.
column12: Femme...esclave. La princesse est une femme esclave de son rang, et dispose d'une foule d'esclaves à son service.  --

column11: Flowers . . . parade . . . slaves.  -    -  The storehouse is overgrown with slaves. The slaves are to be sold in the store, to differentiate from a warehouse, which doesn´t have the word "store" in it.  -  Slaves moved flowers from the storehouse in preparation for the parade.
column12: Les esclaves poussent dru dans la salle de stockage !  --

column11: Part of the body . . . storehouse.  -    -  You signed your organ donor card, right? So, when you die, your entrails and other body parts will be placed in a storehouse.  -  Again with the Pyramids, each Pharaoh had their entrails taken out and put into little jars that were shaped in the forms of their Gods and entombed along with the preserved body. So, the entrails are the parts of the body that are placed in the storehouse along with the Pharaoh! Damnit, why can´t they always be this easy? :(.
column12: La salle de stockage de notre corps est dans nos entrailles.   --

column11: Slave . . . crotch . . . shellfish.  -    -  An intelligent man is neither slave to his crotch nor to money. But an intelligent slave will know how to use his/her crotch to make money.  -  Every intelligent man is a slave to two things, his: 1) crotch, and 2) money.
column12: L’esclave  intelligent a trouvé le moyen de se procurer de l’argent, qu’il tient de sa main droite.   --

column11: Slave . . . crotch . . . soil.  -    -  I'm very strict. I don't want my slaves crotch, to be dirty.  -  It's a strict place...any slave caught violating rules will be buried up to his crotch in the soil.
column12: Grâce à sa ténacité, l’esclave est parvenu à obtenir un petit lopin de terre. Il est ici en train de signer, de la main droite, son nouveau titre de propriété.  --

column11: Slave . . . reclining . . . goods. The key word suggests both looking ahead to something and "seeing to" what is at hand. Consistent with everything we have learned about the role of the key word, this means that you must choose ONE meaning and stick to it.  -    -  The slave is look to the future, "One day" he thinks "I will be able to recline with all my goods, a tv, stereo and washing machine, and when that day comes I shall be truly happy" he sighs.  -  Imagine a slave(or in this case, a female porn star) looking to her new gangbang film where she reclines and gets all 3 holes filled at the same...........OK. Very vulgar, but I was inspired by raulir´s clever use of "3 holes".........
column12: L'esclave couché sur les marchandises ne semble pas faire son travail correctement. Le maître doit donc se rendre sur place pour étudier la question, pour trouver une solution à cette situation exceptionnelle.  --

column11: Slaves . . . reclining . . . floor . . . see.  -    -  The slave reclines on the floor at night to watch the stars. Since that´s the only thing the slave is allowed to “read”, he does so very thoroughly and diligently, hence perusal.  -  [+scottamus] "Please, come in and peruse this fine selection of slaves, all reclining here on the floor for your perusal. Have a look here": http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Slave_ship_diagram.png/440px-Slave_ship_diagram.png.
column12: Pour s'informer de ce qui se passe alentour, le maître demande à son esclave de regarder pour lui.  --

column11: This kanji depicts a gigantic "pop-eye," which accounts for its shape. Be sure not to confuse it with the slave (retainer) we just learned.  -    -  This is actually the top view of a porn star with a gigantic erect penis. The top and bottom are his arms and the middle is his penis. Imagine him making the pumping motion while he´s banging some chick. The arms move in, the penis moves out and vice versa.  -  The letter E, with a GIGANTIC middle stroke.
column12: Ce kanji décrit un « œil exorbité », donc gigantesque, compte tenu de sa forme. Ne le confondez pas avec celui du serviteur que vous venez d’apprendre.  --  Le sens de géant sera quelquefois utilisé en composant.

column11: Fingers . . . gigantic.  -    -  A woman might be REPELLED by a porn star´s GIGANTIC penis, so he kindly offers to use his FINGERS instead.  -  Having gigantic fingers is useful to repel insects. You can swat them away a lot easier!
column12: Pour montrer votre refus à votre interlocuteur, vous avancez votre doigt vers son visage, le plus près possible, de façon à lui faire un immense « doigt d’honneur », géant.   --

column11: With a little imagination, one can see a muscle in this simple, two-stroke character meaning power.  -  * As a primitive, either muscle or power can be used.  -  I always refer to the power of the KATAKANA "KA".  -  I have a very powerful muscle カ in my driveway!
column12: Avec un peu d’imagination, on pourra voir dans ces deux traits le picto­gramme d’un muscle, symbolisant la force.   --  Les sésames seront force ou muscle.

column11: Rice fields . . . power. This character is the gender-specific man, not the generic human person of frame 951.  -    -  Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.  -  When it comes to choosing a MAN, I prefer brains over muscles.
column12: Rizière...muscle. Il s’agit de l’homme au sens de mâle, qui exerce ici ses muscles au milieu de la rizière.  --

column11: Schoolhouse . . . power.  -  Quienes se la pasaban presmiend sus músculos en la escuela ahora solo consiguen trabajos físicos fatigantes.  -  Those jocks who always tried to show their muscles in the schoolhouse are now the ones out there doing manual labor jobs while we sit here and learn Japanese. Ha!  -  At the schoolhouse, the administration develops the children´s muscles by making them do manual labour.
column12: Une escouade de muscles est ici installée sur les bancs d'école, suant sang et eau par leur labeur.  --

column11: Graveyard . . . power.  -    -  The necromancer hangs out at the local graveyard and uses his dark powers to recruit an army of undead. Emphasize the verb form to keep distinct from the noun cadet (#1173).  -  WANTED: Hardworking GRAVEYARD diggers. Must have 6 months experience with POWERFUL muscles as will be working in South Africa burying deceased elephants.
column12: Quand on recrute, on recherche des bras musclés, et pendant l'entretien d'embauche, le candidat esquisse ce qu'il fera, ce que ses muscles feront.  --

column11: Few . . . muscles.  -    -  I have an inferiority complex because I have fewer muscles than everyone else at the gym. They all look like Macho Man Randy Savage (power) to me.  -  I had trouble remembering the relative position of the components, so now I use this story: Even muscular men have inferiority if they have few things above their muscles (i.e., brain cells).
column12: Peu de...muscles. Comme les précédents, ce kanji semble si simple qu'on pense ne pas l'oublier, mais une image est toujours nécessaire. Faites un partie de bras-de-fer contre vous-même, et voyez quel bras, comparé à l'autre, possède peu de muscles ; puis constatez qu'il est bien inférieur à l'autre.  --

column11: Craft . . . power.  -    -  The great achievements of humankind, were crafts completed by muscle power: the pyramids, the Eiffel tower, etc.  -  All of Arnold Schwarzenegger´s achievements started with him crafting his muscles.
column12: Métier...force. Voyez la réalisation d’un excellent artisan, tel un meilleur ouvrier de France, chef d’œuvre réalisé à force de métier.   --

column11: Pegasus . . . power.  -    -  Mnemonic "pegasus persuasion power". I think of the hippogriff from Harry Potter as being like a pegasus. To befriend a hippogriff, you have to persuade it you mean no harm, you can do this if you have "pegasus persuasion power".  -  It would take a powerful argument to persuade me Pegasus was real… RTK2:　カン　勧奨　かんしょう(encouragement)… 　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　歓570　観572 　(ｹﾝ): 権571.
column12: Pégase, faisant voir ses muscles, persuade Bellérophon de monter sur son dos pour aller combattre la Chimère.  --

column6: to exert, strive, make an effort; to pout
column11: Guy . . . muscle.  -    -  GUY POWER!!! Body builders toiling in the gym all day....　　　　　RTK2:　ド　努力　どりょく (effort)...　Pure Group: 　奴702 　怒703.  -  Guy + Power: To reach a position of power in the company, the average guy has to toil very hard for many years.
column12: Machin  s’efforce de bien faire, et c’est avec ses muscles qu’il le fait.  --

column11: A tree . . . cliff . . . ten thousand.  -    -  There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people´s heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.  -  There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don´t worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it.
column12: Arbre...poison violent. Le maronnier d’Inde donnant des fruits non comestibles, on peut l’associer au poison violent.   --

column11: Cliff . . . ten thousand . . . power.  -    -  10,000 Persians are at the base of the cliff, but the leader of the 300 Spartans just flexes his huge muscles and encourages his men by shouting that they have the power to fight them all.  -  People encourage you, giving you the power so you can dive off the 10,000m high cliff into the sea.
column12: Poison violent...muscle. On encouragera ici un sportif en plein effort, tentant de battre un record mondial : dans ses muscles bandés, le taux de toxines, poison violent créé par l'effort, augmente dangereusement.  --

column11: Muscles . . . mouth. This is the only case in which the primitive for muscle appears on the left; note should be taken of the fact in composing one's story.  -    -  If you eat anymore, you will be adding more カロries. (katakana karo).  -  This is Power Mouth, the most annoying neighbour in the world who always has something to add.
column12: Muscle...bouche. Créez une image mettant en avant le fait que le muscle apparaît en position clé, ce qui est très rare.  --

column11: Add . . . shells.  -    -  When someone at work gets married, you pass around an envelope to which you add some money and a card which you sign with your congratulations.  -  Congratulations are so much better when you add money to them.
column12: Ajouter...monnaie. Rappelez-vous la toute première fois que vous avez obtenu les félicitations à l'école primaire. Peut-être ce jour-là aviez-vous reçu une pièce, ajoutée aux Fables de La Fontaine.  --

column11: Add . . . trees. Hint: if you ever played with an "Erector Set" or "Tinker Toys" as a child, don't pass up the opportunity to relate it to this kanji's key word and the element for trees.  -    -  Add wood to erect a structure.  -  Instant wood. Just add Viagra.
column12: Ajouter...arbre. Ce kanji, qui concerne en particulier l'érection des ponts, nous propose, tout simplement d'ajouter un arbre en travers de la rivière.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . muscles (three of which give us "triceps" or "muscles on top of muscles"). You will want to keep the kanji distinct from the one that follows by paying attention to the positioning of the elements.  -    -  What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course!  -  (no important on yomi) The part of Conan´s body that is three times more effective at defeating foes than his muscles are his stinky ARMPITs. [Note: Typically, when the flesh primitive is on the left side it refers to a body part - this helps distinguish in from threaten (#871)].
column12: Partie du corps...trois muscles. On crée avec le second élément la notion de triceps, muscle prenant naissance, à peu près tout au moins, sur le flanc.   --

column11: Triceps . . . part of the body.  -    -  Compare the primitive positions of armpit (#870) and threaten (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.  -  Don´t threaten a warewolf. He´s three times as powerful ON a full moon.　RTK2:　キョウ　脅迫　きょうはく (blackmail)…　Pure Group:　協872.
column12: Muscles...partie du corps. Pour ne pas confondre ce kanji avec le précédent, revoyez 409, et imaginez une relation de force de supérieur à inférieur.  --

column11: This prefix should be kept distinct from inter (Frame 222) and mutual (Frame 819). Its elements: needle . . . triceps.  -    -  The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that needle (syringe) in your triceps won´t hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji.  -  Co-operation: 3 persons can have the power of ten if they co-operate.
column12: Aiguille...triceps. L’infirmière demande votre coopération pour enfoncer son aiguille dans votre triceps, et ce faisant avoir la tâche facilitée.  --

column6: go; walk; move, travel; circulate; Kangxi radical 144
column11: By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for going.  -  * As a primitive, this character has two forms. Reduced to the left side only, it can mean a column, going, or a line of something or other. When the middle is opened up to make room for other elements, it means a boulevard.  -  I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.  -  To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.
column12: En joignant les deux traits du haut, on obtient l’image de la vague provoquée par le déplacement d’un bateau, les deux autres traits formant la traînée. D’où le sens de aller.   --  En composant, ce caractère aura deux formes distinctes. Il pourra être réduit à la partie de gauche et portera les sens aller, cheminer, colonne ou ligne. Il pourra d'autre part être présent en entier, mais en ce cas, il sera ouvert en son centre, libérant la place pour un autre composant. Il portera alors le sens de boulevard. Le sens de faire aller, donc réaliser ou exécuter, est aussi inclus.

column11: This character depicts a calligrapher's brush and its rhythmic sway as it flows down a column writing kanji on the way.  -    -  The calligrapher´s brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation.  -  The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. Picturing the brush as a drum stick is not difficult if you´ve seen such a thing in jazz videos.
column12: Ce kanji dépeint le rythme qu’ordonne le calligraphe au pinceau descendant le long d’une colonne de caractères, traçant les kanjis en chemin. Ordonner fait partie du champ sémantique de ce kanji.  --

column11: Going . . . double back.  -    -  Going past the destroyed column, I felt the need to double back and restore it to its former glory (I'm an archaeologist now).  -  Before going all the way to the Boss in a Final Fantasy game, you should probably double back to save at a restore point.
column12: Aller et se replier nous donne le sens de retourner au point de départ.  --
