column11: Column . . . nightbreak . . . glue.  -    -  To gain more knowledge of what´s goin on in the world I´m reading column after column of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I´m glued to it till nightbreak.  -  Imagine fat people......they avoid going outside to exercise and stay glued to their TV set until nightbreak....so of course they gain weight.
column12: Voici expliqué par le menu comment obtenir une allocation ou un remboursement de l'assurance-maladie : il faut y aller dès le point du jour, et rester collé au guichet jusqu'à obtenir gain de cause.  --

column11: Column . . . animal horns . . . mending.  -    -  The line of viking soldiers is always accompanied by a horn mending specialist.  -  I´m going to accompany the horny girl to her room so I can "mend" her.
column12: Aller...cornes...raccommoder. Malheureux en amour, cet homme reste toutefois complètement soumis, au point d'aller se faire raccommoder les cornes par son épouse infidèle.  --

column11: Line . . . run.  -    -  I'm not sure where Heisig gets the junior keyword, but this kanji is more often used in the sense of either futile (e.g. 徒労 - fruitless efforts) or group(gang) member (e.g. 聖徒 - disciple, キリスト教徒 - Christian). I'll use gang member for this one. The junior gang member is going to represent at the running competition.  -  The junior employee is always RUNNING around GOING here and there for his superiors.
column12: Aller...en courant. Ne vous arrêtez pas au sens premier du mot-clé, car il renferme des notions aussi diverses que élève ou disciple, tous deux inexpérimentés si on les compare à leur maître. Les jeunes inexpérimentés partent en courant, et ratent la première bifurcation que le maître, marchant d'un pas mesuré, ne manquera pas de voir. C'est donc en vain qu'ils se sont précipités.  --

column11: Line . . . Buddhist temple.  -    -  A line queued up outside the Buddhist temple, waiting to see the shrine on New Year´s Day.  -  The COLUMNS of this TEMPLE are a well-know meeting spot. You can always see someone WAITING there.
column12: Lorsqu’on va au temple bouddhique, on attend en ligne, le temps que le prêtre écrive l’amulette que l’on aura rapportée du cadre 728.  --

column11: Column . . . candlestick. This character has the special sense of journeying to someplace or other.  -    -  In Medieval Japan, going to see your lord was often a long journey.  -  The fellowship of the ring is on a long journey through the depths of Khaz Modan. Imagine they walk through the hall of pillars, with only light being from their own candlesticks that. Soon they will meet much more light than they would ever want to...
column12: Aller...maître. Nous avons vu le retour il y quelques instants, voici maintenant l'aller simple, auquel seul le maître participe.  --

column11: Column . . . correct.  -    -  America seeks to GO and CORRECT other nations. But really what they do is subjugate them...  -  To subjugate is to have somebody stand still and stiff as a column and behave one hundred percent correctly.
column12: Aller...correct. Pour l'envahisseur, conquérir de nouvelles terres implique la certitude d'aller au bon endroit et d'y faire les choses correctement.  --

column11: Line . . . spool.  -    -  Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.  -  Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson´s Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in stalk (#715), suspicious (#716), lightly (#717), sutra (#1360).
column12: Ligne...toupie. Votre toupie suit son chemin, une ligne circulaire dont nous évaluons le diamètre. Ce kanji surprenant possède à la fois le sens de diamètre et de chemin.  --

column11: Going . . . pelt. This kanji refers to the third person singular personal pronoun, generally in its masculine form.  -    -  What´s the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.  -  The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.
column12: Les éléments aller...peau nous donnent la troisième personne ; la peau qui va, la peau qui vous va : c’est « lui ». Cette phrase en forme de slogan peut être lue au féminin si vous le désirez, car le mot traduisant elle utilise aussi ce kanji. Et tant que vous y êtes, ajoutez-y aussi le neutre, également compris.  --

column6: service; a servant, laborer; to serve
column11: Going . . . missile.  -    -  Japanese kamikaze pilots (and the American from Dr. Strangelove) are so devoted to their duty that they go with their missiles.  -  Imagine those poor saps in charge of nuclear silos, responsible for ICBMS, those towering column missiles. When the order comes they must decide whether to obey their concience or do their duty and damn the world to atomic annihilation.
column12: Aller...frapper fort. Le bon acteur, qui joue bien son rôle, sait aller en suivant le scénario, mais il sait aussi frapper fort l'esprit des spectateurs.  --

column11: Going . . . needle . . . eye . . . heart. Refer back now to the note in frame 890.  -    -  Benevolence: going to help those who are unable to listen (i.e. have no ears).  -  Note similarity to 聴 (#890). A benevolent person goes a step beyond merely listening to your troubles, but goes and does something about it.
column12: Alors que pour écouter, vous ouvriez grands vos dix yeux et votre cœur, pour être bienveillant, vous suivez votre ligne de conduite, ouvrant grands vos dix yeux et votre cœur.  --

column11: Line . . . bring up . . . taskmaster.  -    -  Ha! In this frame, a bunch of taskmasters are lined up to penetrate the kids they raise/bring up! I´m thinking of some priests and choir boys.  -  The taskmistress in a moment of weakness allowed the man´s column to penetrate her. As punishment he was made to bring up their infant.
column12: Cheminer...élever...énergie. Ce kanji définit le fait de traverser quelque chose de part en part, comme un enfant que l'on élève qui doit cheminer avec énergie dans la vie afin de la traverser sans encombre.  --

column11: Line . . . mountain . . . king . . . taskmaster.  -    -  If you see a column of kings being marched up the mountain under a taskmaster´s whip... indications are, there has been a coup.  -  All indications are that the taskmaster´s son is going to be king of the mountain soon …　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チョウ 象徴　しょうちょう(symbol)…　　　　Pure Group:　懲888.
column12: Cheminer...montagne...roi…chef de corvée. Ce roi chef de corvée sait cheminer dans la montagne sans s'y perdre car il en connaît toutes les caractéristiques, tous les signes.  --

column11: Indications . . . heart.  -    -  Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart (learned one´s lesson). Easily confused with punish (#679) and penalty (#833). Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system ("changing people´s hearts" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there´s no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one´s bad experiences).  -  Judge: You will serve a penal sentence until indications show you have a heart.
column12: Signe...cœur. « Qui aime bien châtie bien. » La punition est donc le signe qui indique les bons sentiments.  --

column11: Line . . . mountain . . . ceiling . . . human legs . . . taskmaster.  -    -  We're going up the mountain announces the taskmaster. Anyone with legs too delicate must stay behind.  -  The Column of 300 spartans were in a delicate situation. They had travelled in one line (using only their legs) to the mountain pass to face the fierce Persian task master.
column12: Cheminer...montagne...un...jambes...énergie. Ici, un homme seul chemine avec énergie sur ses jambes dans la montagne, mais sa petitesse relative le rend fort ténu.  --

column11: This is the character from which the sense of boulevard mentioned in frame 938 derives. Its elements: boulevard . . . ivy.  -    -  The boulevard of boulevards, the Champs Elysées, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in ivy to give the champions a heroes´ welcome.  -  Specifically... ivy boulevard... think hollywood & vine.
column12: Ce boulevard possède une dune en guise de terre-plein central.  --

column11: Boulevard . . . bound up . . . brains . . . St. Bernard dog.  -    -  To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the brains of citizens are bound up (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard´s dogs put alongside the boulevards.  -  I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish´s tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!).
column12: Boulevard...lié...rizière...grand homme. La partie centrale est originellement une balance dont le fléau est en équilibre. Sur le boulevard, un grand homme est occupé à peser ce qu'on lui donne : des paquets, de riz probablement, extraits de la rizière. Son souci consiste à s'assurer qu'à chaque fois, le fléau de la balance soit bien en équilibre, afin de peser correctement.   --  Chapitre vingt-cinq Des plantes  RETOURNONS au domaine des plantes, pour nous pencher cette fois sur trois éléments fréquents : le blé, les grains de riz et le bambou.

column11: The key word connotes the preliminary composition of a plan or manuscript. Its elements: wheat . . . tall.  -    -  The first DRAFT of catcher in the rye was actually called "catcher in the TALL WHEAT"...good thing they changed it. I read it in 高校.  -  Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the tall wheat.
column12: Blé...haut. Plutôt que le beau pinceau, nous choisissons, pour écrire le brouillon, un épi de blé assez haut.   --

column11: Wheat . . . house.  -    -  Your earnings allow you to bring home your daily bread (made of wheat, naturally).  -  Hmm, EARNINGS. Think of the popular saying "Bringing HOME the bacon". Here, EARNINGS is the picture "Bringing HOME the bread(WHEAT) and the bacon (PIG).
column12: Le blé qui entre à la maison constitue nos gains.  --

column11: Wheat . . . display. Do not confuse with extremity (Frame 230) or boundary (Frame 523).  -    -  The extent to which some people will go to create ´wheat displays´, or as some call them ´crop circles´, is truly amazing.  -  The wheat crop has come in, and the mouth of the king is gobbling it all up. Everyone is waiting to see... to what extent will the king manage to eat it this year?
column12: Pour acquérir un terrain d’une certaine étendue, nous dévoilons au proprié­taire la quantité de blé dont nous disposons.  --

column11: Wheat . . . devil.  -    -  Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor.  -  This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.
column12: Blé...diable. Lors de l’apparition au Japon de la première TVA, à trois pour cent, de nombreux Japonais auraient été ravis de pouvoir faire cette association, si l’on sait toutes les aigreurs que cette disposition a provoquées.  --

column11: Wheat . . . turkey.  -    -  I can´t believe I brought you to the fanciest restaurant in town and you asked for turkey on wheat...how immature is that?!  -  Immature turkeys are stuffed with wheat to make it look bigger.
column12: Blé...dinde. Le blé immature est haut comme une dinde, et la dinde immature est haute comme un épi de blé. En pratique, il faut voir un enfant en bas-âge dans ce caractère.  --

column11: Wheat . . . mouth.  -    -  The first step to harmony is having enough wheat to feed every mouth in the world. Once we are all fed it is easier to get along in harmony.  -  People who live in harmony with nature live in the country. they are yokels or hillbillys. See Billy-bob sitting on the porch in their denim dungarees a sheaf of wheat, sticking from their mouth.
column12: Blé...bouche. Harmoniser veut peut-être symboliser la tendance qu'ont les Japonais à tous commander le même plat au restaurant pour ne pas se démarquer, ou à arrondir les angles en permanence afin de mieux vivre ensemble dans un espace parfois trop restreint. C'est un peu comme si toutes les bouches du pays parlaient à l'unisson, imitant ainsi les innombrables épis de blé d'un champ entier.  --

column11: Wheat . . . many.  -    -  Picture the WHEAT field, filled with MANY, MANY stalks of WHEAT. Notice how they SHIFT like waves in the slightest breeze. When you hear SHIFT, just picture that scene.  -  Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.
column12: Blé...beaucoup. Imaginez-vous déménager ou voyager au Japon, voire en France.  --

column6: beard of grain or corn; a second
column11: The reference here is to a second of time. The elements: wheat . . . few.  -    -  An hourglass filled with wheat counts time. A few wheat seeds drop every second.  -  I´ll be with you soon... please wheat a few seconds.
column12: Blé...peu. La seconde est l’intervalle de temps pendant lequel on gagne peu de blé.   --

column11: Wheat . . . fire.  -    -  In AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it´s time to harvest it.  -  Every autumn the wheat is set on fire to clear the way for next year´s crop...
column12: Blé...feu. Repensez à la coutume de l’écobuage, pratiquée à l’automne et consistant à mettre le feu aux champs de blé après la récolte, dans le but de fertiliser les sols.  --

column6: anxiety; to worry about, be anxious
column11: Autumn . . . heart.  -    -  In AUTUMN, the farmer´s HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!  -  Here we have distressed (think "gloomy") people with "seasonal mood disorder" during the autumn season. Hence "autumn heart" is distressed (gloomy).
column12: Automne... cœur. Les sanglots longs des violons de l'automne. Blessent mon cœur d'une langueur monotone.  --

column11: Wheat . . . elbow. Like the characters for I (Frame 17) and ego (Frame 690), this kanji is also representative of the subject, with the special connotation of privacy.  -    -  Warning sign: "Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed".  -  I already know this as watashi, or "I". In order to associate the keyword of private, I´ll think of this one as "Private I", like a detective.
column12: Blé...coude-privé. De même que les caractères moi et ego, celui-ci fait référence à la première personne, avec la connotation particulière de privé.   --

column11: Wheat . . . drop.  -    -  Think of REGULARITY in terms of bowel movements. Enough WHEAT in your diet will help your DROPS with improved REGULARITY.  -  Eating plenty of WHEAT will improve regularity and help you LOSE weight.
column12: Blé...perdre. L'idée exprimée par ce kanji rarement employé est l'arrangement compact d'objets ou d'événements. Pour l'associer aux éléments présents, imaginez une gigantesque trémie pleine de blé, permettant d'en obtenir la meilleure compacité, et qui perd régulièrement son contenu. Ajoutez à cette mise en scène une idée de durée, une décennie, pour être plus précis. Il suffit d'imaginer une trémie en forme de sablier qui se viderait en une décennie.  --

column11: Cereal . . . invariably.  -    -  The prize at the bottom of a cereal box is invariably a secret decoder ring.  -  A young couple meets in secret in the wheat field because their families are enemies. They cross their hearts and swear eternal - even if secret - love. Do not confuse with secrecy (#775).
column12: Blé...nécessairement. Pour éviter d'attirer les malfaiteurs, il est nécessaire de garder secret l'argent et les choses de valeur.  --

column11: Wheat . . . reclining . . . little.  -    -  Taking appellation to mean the act of naming, we have the little baby superman reclining in the space craft that landed in a wheat field. Mr. and Mrs. Kent look down and decide to call him Clark. (I also thought of Jesus but he was born in a barn full of hay not wheat).  -  WHEAT that is RECLINING and LITTLE (small) can´t get the APPELLATION "quality wheat".
column12: Blé...couché...petit. Le « petit couché » peut être vu comme un nouveau-né. Et le blé pourrait être le dessous-de-table que l'on donnerait à l'officier d'état civil pour qu'il lui confère une appellation spéciale, comme un prénom inusité² par exemple.  ² « Chez nous, les prénoms des femmes sont empruntés aux saintes ; ceux des Japonaises sont : marmite, grue, tortue d'eau, espadrille, thé, roseau. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)  --

column11: Wheat . . . saber. Be careful not to confuse with gain (Frame 941) or earnings (Frame 959).  -    -  In the middle ages there where only 2 ways for peasantry to make a profit. one by being a farmer, 2 to be a mercenary and live by the way of the sword.  -  1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!
column12: Blé...sabre. Une façon simple de profiter du travail d’autrui.  --

column11: Profit . . . tree.  -    -  The Japanese pear tree is the most profitable in the world, because it produces its fruit in pairs [sorry for the awful pun].  -  And a profit in a pear tree...12 days of christmas.
column12: Profit...arbre. Il s'agit de la poire japonaise, en forme de pomme mais avec les cellules pierreuses de la poire. Pour déguster les meilleures, allez... en France et demandez des « nachis »「なし」car elles ont meilleur goût que celles des supermarchés japonais, dont l'aspect est en revanche irréprochable.  --

column11: Wheat . . . flowers . . . vessels. Compare frames 756 and 757 for the right side.  -    -  The harvest of genetically modified crops is taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (see the flower vessel in safeguard (#700)).  -  Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.
column12: Blé...attraper. Récolter consiste à attraper le blé préalablement mûri. Revoir 772.   --

column11: Wheat . . . favor.  -    -  The pilgrims only had wheat, so they asked the Indians to do them a favor and trade them for some ears of corn.  -  The "ear of a plant" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- "the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat".
column12: Blé...bénéficier. La plante de blé porte l’épi, elle en bénéficie.   --

column6: rice growing in field, rice plant
column11: Wheat . . . vulture . . . olden times.  -    -  The rice plant is common in Japan because all the wheat was eaten by vultures in the olden times.  -  It used to be that wheat was grown in Japan. However, this was often stolen by vultures, so in olden times, the gods gave the Japanese the rice plant.
column12: Blé...vautour...ancien temps. Dans les temps anciens, avant que l'homme n'apparaisse, le plant de riz, une sorte de blé, était la seule proie des vautours.  --

column11: Wheat . . . sun.  -    -  If you focus the suns though a magnifying glass on to the bottom of a stalk of wheat it will start to smoulder and burn like a stick of incense. The weird thing is that it burns from the bottom upwards, hanging in the air as if by magic. Try it and see!  -  When the sun burns the wheat a smell of incense remains in the air.
column12: Blé...soleil. Imaginez la senteur d’un champ de blé en plein été, le soleil chauffant les épis dorés.  --

column11: Wheat . . . child.  -    -  There´s a season for planting wheat and there´s mating season for having children.  -  Look at this adorable child with a bale of wheat on his head! He´s playing Autumn in his school play the "Four Seasons". Aww...too cute! Perhaps we should light the wheat on fire to complete his Autumn costume. (I know, twisted...but I kept forgetting what was on his head).
column12: Blé...enfant. À chaque nouvelle saison s’ajoutent de nouveaux frais (blé), pour acheter une nouvelle paire de skis ou un nouveau VTT aux minuscules.  --

column11: Wheat . . . woman.  -    -  Female WHEAT farmers decide to create a COMMITTEE, which they fittingly name “The WHEAT WOMEN COMMITTEE.”.  -  At committe meetings, Japanese bureaucrats slurp ramen noodles off of naked women.
column12: Ce kanji me fera irrémédiablement penser aux comités de parents d’élèves des écoles japonaises : on octroie un peu de blé aux femmes qui s’activent pour le bien de leurs progénitures. Il y a toutefois une exception : la présidence du comité revient nécessairement à un homme, seul capable de prononcer le discours soporifique de la fête de l’école.  --

column6: ear of grain; flowering, luxuriant; refined, elegant, graceful
column11: Wheat . . . fist.  -    -  You spend three hours putting all of your wheat sale transaction records into Microsoft Excel, when suddenly it crashes, so you put your fist through the monitor.  -  A soviet-era poster for the 5-year plan shouts "Excel" and shows a fist clenching a sheaf of wheat. Wheat/Fist.
column12: Le meilleur individu, celui qui excelle, brandit dans son poing en guise de trophée un bouquet d'épis de blé : hourrah !  --

column11: Excel . . . road-way.  -    -  If you excel in the Mario Kart road, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a transparent racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4.  -  If you want to excel at driving in the roadway, it´s better if your windows and windshield are transparent. Picture the drivers with opaque windshields all wrecked on the side of the road.
column12: Transparence évoquera la fibre optique, capable de transmettre la lumière avec une très faible atténuation sur des dizaines de kilomètres : une excellente voie pour les informations lumineuses, comme le souffle le kanji.  --

column11: Words . . . excel. Compare beckon (Frame 702), to urge (Frame 300), seduce (Frame 90), and encourage (Frame 931) when choosing your connotation.  -    -  Think of the smooth talker who EXCELS at using WORDS to entice women (including married women if it makes it easier to remember).  -  Word and Excel somehow manage to entice people to use them, despite their plethora of bugs.
column12: Afin que nos amis acceptent notre invitation, nous cherchons les mots excellents.  --

column11: Samurai . . . crown . . . wheat . . . missile.  -    -  There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has samurai cereal. Great Britain has Crowned Wheat ... the United States and Russia have Missile cereals.  -  The samurai crowns wheat as the best cereal, and blows all others up with missiles (he´s a cereal killer).
column12: Notre vieux professeur a posé sa couronne une fois encore, et il se met à frapper fort sur les grains de blé, symbole de toutes les céréales. De son battage au fléau nous obtenons de belles céréales. En revoyant 783, remarquez comment une petite modification change « radicalement » le sens du caractère. Ici aussi nous verrons parfois un trait supplémentaire : .  --

column11: Flowers . . . pent in . . . wheat.  -    -  Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).  -  Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn´t exposed to other plants. That way it can´t catch any germs (like fungi) from them.
column12: Végétal...enceinte...blé. Ce caractère définit divers microbes mais le sens originel est celui d'un champignon capable de se développer comme un végétal en une enceinte fermée, et dont la forme évoque aussi un objet fermé.  --

column11: This kanji has a pictographic resemblance to a number of grains of rice lying on a plate in the shape of a star.  -  * As a primitive, it keeps its meaning of rice, and is meant to connote a very ordinary, commonplace grain, in contrast to the primitive for wheat that we just learned. (This meaning accords well with Japan, where the output of rice far exceeds that of wheat.) It occasionally takes a different shape when it stands on its own, or is joined to a line above. In this case, we shall have it refer specifically to grains of rice. This primitive is not to be confused with the similar-looking primitive for water. While the stroke orders are nearly alike, grains of rice has 5 strokes, while water only has 4 because it joins the second and third strokes into one. Finally, we may note that by itself the kanji for rice is an abbreviation used for the United States, which can then also serve as an alternate reading for the main primitive form, if you so wish.  -  Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.  -  Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.
column12: Ce kanji évoque l'image de huit grains de riz placés en étoile. Avec le sens de riz, il aura la connotation particulière d'une cé- réale ordinaire, en contraste avec le blé vu ci-dessus. Cela est tout à fait en accord avec le Japon, où la production de riz dépasse largement celle de blé. Ce kanji est une abréviation d'Amérique, mais aussi du mètre.  --

column11: Rice . . . part.  -    -  Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...).  -  In the United States, part of every meal is made from flour.
column12: La farine est faite de céréale, ici du riz, scindée en si petits morceaux qu’elle forme une fine poudre.  --

column11: Rice . . . fortune-telling.  -    -  This is another way of fortune telling -- throw sticky rice against the wall, and look for the message in whatever sticks.  -  CONDI RICE was told by the FORTUNE TELLER that she will get STICKY...
column12: Riz...occuper. Oublions un instant le bon riz que l'on sert dans les restaurants au Japon. Pensons plutôt au riz bien collant servi à la louche dans les cantines en France. Voyez alors la cantinière flanquer une bonne louche de l'amalgame dans votre écuelle, et imaginez cette énorme flaque de riz qui occupe toute l'assiette : un truc extrêmement collant.  --

column11: Rice . . . vase.  -    -  A sage is using rice to fill up a vase, but as an exercise in patience, he´s doing it grain by grain.  -  There´s a contest...whoever guesses the number of grains of rice in a vase wins.
column12: Riz...vase. De même que nous stockons les olives dans de grandes jarres, nous pourrions stoker les grains de riz dans des vases.   --

column11: Rice . . . cave . . . soil.  -    -  Condy Rice is actually white, but she uses special cosmetics made from dirt she found in a cave to appear black - it´s better for the political situation.  -  Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT (´cause it´s darker) used in the past.
column12: Dans la maison de campagne, le meilleur cosmétique est une bonne alimentation, un bon bol de riz.  --

column11: Road . . . United States.  -    -  The road that the USA is heading down is, well... let´s just say that they´re astray...  -  If you go astray, just follow the rice you dropped along the road to find your way back.
column12: Routes...Amérique. En voiture !  --

column11: Rice . . . game of cricket. (See frame 121.)  -    -  In extremely chic restaurants, you have to pay 90 bucks for a bowl of rice.  -  Americans think that tattoos with Chinese characters are chic, but nine out of ten times they end up with something trivial tattooed on their arm, like rice.
column12: L'élégance dans le Japon ancien consistait notamment à passer sur le visage une poudre de riz, pour le rendre parfaitement blanc... Ce kanji nous raconte que cette poudre devait être faite à partir de quatre-vingt-dix grains de riz.  --

column11: Rice . . . quantity.  -    -  Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same quantity of rice. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing quantity and the nuance of food "rations", "food supply": the kanji also appears in "military provisions" and "army rice").  -  All Japanese provisions contain a certain quantity of rice... they eat it with just about every meal!
column12: Il n’y a pas si longtemps encore, une quantité suffisante de riz pouvait constituer au Japon l’essentiel des provisions de la ménagère.  --

column11: Flower . . . bound up . . . rice.  -    -  Chrysanthemum flower consists of many tiny petals, just like many rice grains bound up together.  -  [+astgt] Chrysanthemum is a terrorist orginization whose sole objective is to tie up Condi Rice. One day, Condi Rice is standing outside when a group of chrysanthemum agents swoop in from the sides, bound her up with chrysanthemum rope, and dash off. They leave a lone yellow chrysanthemum flower on top of the bound Condi Rice as a sign to let her discoverers know who committed this brave and noble act.
column12: Le chrysanthème n’est pas la fleur des morts au Japon. Allons plus loin encore, en disant que c’est la fleur des mariés : fleur...poignée de riz.   --

column11: A drop . . . pent in . . . rice . . . St. Bernard dog. Notice that the horizontal line of the bottom primitive doubles up as the final stroke for pent in.  -    -  In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It´s very dangerous, so they´ve trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he´s adding more drops of rice as necessary.  -  奥さん　（おくさん) is a common way to say "wife". In the innermost core of the house, the bored pent up housewife drops her chores and consumes so much rice she becomes a very large housewife.
column12: Fond met en scène le saint-bernard, ouvrant la gueule pour avaler une grande bouchée de riz, qu’il a maintenant au fond de la gueule. N’oubliez pas la goutte de salive au coin des babines.  --

column11: Rice . . . woman . . . taskmaster.  -    -  Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. "One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!".  -  Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.
column12: Le chef de corvée est ici chargé de surveiller les femmes, qui comptent les grains de riz. Nombre et compter sont les deux sens du kanji.  --

column6: building of two or more stories
column11: Tree . . . rice . . . woman.  -    -  The young taskmaster (see number (#998)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. "I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!".  -  On the top of the woodmade watchtower we look for our enemies, who will come to steal our rice and our women.
column12: Ciel, le chef de corvée a disparu ! Il est évidemment caché dans l'arbre - tour de guet.   --

column11: Rice . . . St. Bernard dog . . . head.  -    -  Note this character means sort in the sense of what kind, I believe a better keyword would be "variety" and this character does appear in some dictionaries with the primary meaning as variety, my story: I´m in a Chinese restaurant and the waiter says "What sort of rice would you like with your dog head?".  -  Condi Rice is the SORT of person that would give HEADaches to a BIG DOG.....This story has been edited because of people reporting it. I like it better without "aches", but whatever works for you!
column12: Grain de riz...saint-bernard...tête. Ce kanji nous présente deux sortes d’êtres. La première venant du monde végétal et la seconde du monde animal, toutes deux très courantes au sein des kanjis. Puis vient la tête, qui permet la classification.   --

column11: Bamboo grows upwards, like a straight nail, and at each stage of its growth (which legend associates with the arrival of the new moon) there is a jointed rootstock (the first stroke). Two such bamboo stalks are pictured here.  -  * As a primitive, the meaning remains the same, but the vertical lines are severely abbreviated so that they can take their place at the top where, like flowers, they are always to be found.  -  Pandas like to eat bamboo. I´m using panda as the primitive name when it fits the story. ^__^.  -  Two reclining victims impaled on bamboo spheres...　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　チク　松竹梅　しょうちくばい(pine, bamboo, plum).
column12: Le bambou pousse droit comme un clou, et à chaque étape de la croissance (que la légende associe à la nouvelle lune) apparaît une jointure (la goutte). Deux de ces bambous sont représentés. Cet élément viendra souvent en position supérieure, et sera alors compressé sous la forme .  --

column11: Bamboo . . . heavens.  -    -  When the people tried to build a tower of bamboo to reach the heavens, the gods just laughed and laughed.  -  That Panda is in bamboo heaven! Just look at him laugh!
column12: Le kanji rire montre deux très hauts bambous, si hauts qu'ils ont poussé en inclinant leur cime. Le rire est donné par le vent bruissant entre ces majestueux tuyaux d'orgue.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . vase.  -    -  The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn´t know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat.  -  The bamboo part is easy. Just remember that this kanji refers to those particular bamboo hats that are worn primarily by Buddhist monks, who always seem to stand outside of train stations, collecting alms.
column12: Un astucieux système d’armatures de bambou libère un espace entre la tête et ce chapeau de bambou, ce qui permet de supporter les fortes chaleurs estivales et donne une allure insolite à son porteur : bambou...debout.   --

column11: Bamboo . . . generation.  -    -  The bamboo generation smokes bamboo grass.  -  “One of the most attractive aspects of bamboo is that it is a renewable resource; it takes less than a year for a stalk to reach maturity, compared to the decades for most trees, whether needle or broadleaf.” -- Mnemonic : "bamboo grass is the next bamboo generation".
column12: Bambou...génération. Dès que la pousse de bambou apparaît, la génération suivante n’est pas loin.  --

column10: Muscle, trait, nerf, fibre, veine, intrigue, raison, organisme, chose à structure striée ou fibreuse
column11: Bamboo . . . part of the body . . . power. Here we see how the primitive meaning of muscle was derived from the kanji for power.  -    -  Muscle is part of the body that gives strength, and can be both supple and tense like the bamboo.  -  Lifting BAMBOO STICKS is an old way for your BODY to put on lots of MUSCLE.
column12: La partie du corps possédant la force et qui, une fois bandée, devient dure comme le bambou est un muscle.   --  Ce kanji possède en fait de nombreux sens, dont muscle. On trouve en outre trait, nerf, fibre, veine, intrigue, raison, organisme, toute chose à structure striée ou fibreuse, comme le muscle.

column11: Bamboo . . . inter-.  -    -  The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you´ve mastered this kanji.  -  I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.
column12: Interaction...bambous. Imaginez une de ces boîtes à secret dont les Japonais l’ont.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . brush.  -    -  Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.  -  Bamboo would make an excellent writing brush as the ink could flow through the hollow center like an ink pen... 　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ヒツ　鉛筆　えんぴつ(lead pencil).
column12: Bambou...pinceau. Le bon pinceau possède un joli manche de bambou². ² « Nous écrivons avec des plumes d'oies ou de corbeau ; eux avec des pinceaux de peintre faits de poils de lièvre et d'un manche de bambou. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)  --

column11: Bamboo . . . monk.  -    -  Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated?  -  Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same.
column12: Bambou...identique. Si vous consultez un dictionnaire français à l’article cylindre, vous constaterez que les kanjis sont beaucoup plus aisés à comprendre.  --

column6: rank, grade; to wait; equal, “and so forth”
column10: Et ainsi de suite, pluriel peu respectueux, semblables
column11: Bamboo . . . Buddhist temple.  -    -  The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc.  -  So what´d you see in Japan? - "Bamboo, temples...etc.".
column12: Autour du temple bouddhiste, ou trouve des bambous, et ainsi de suite. De plus, les bambous ici évoqués sont de même hauteur, semblables. Nous avions fait état plus haut d'un « pluriel peu respectueux ». Le voilà défini.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . eyes . . . two hands.  -    -  Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It´s not as easy as a calculator, but you don´t need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.  -  Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You´d be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.
column12: En Asie comme en Europe, on calcule depuis longtemps à l’aide de l’abaque dont on voit ici le fonctionnement : l’appareil est en bambou et les yeux regardent le résultat qu’affichent les billes manipulées des deux mains.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . fit.  -    -  The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together.  -  For the frustrated housewife the solution came in form of a BAMBOO stick that FITS her well.
column12: ...et lorsque les bambous de l’abaque correspondent, on a la solution.   --

column11: Bamboo . . . belted tree (See frame 446).  -    -  (Elaboration of jameserb´s story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...  -  The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. (true story)-----------対策　　たいさく　　measure, countermeasure.
column12: Le moyen particulier ici présenté consiste à placer des armatures de bambou autour de notre arbre ceint d’une courroie, pour le consolider.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . water . . . acupuncturist.  -    -  Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 242), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won´t stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon´s story.  -  This doctor dilutes (see 242) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.
column12: Notre docteur ouvre son répertoire pour y écrire votre nom à l'aide de son pinceau à manche de bambou qu'il aura trempé dans l'eau.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . craft . . . mediocre . . . wood/tree.  -    -  Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids´ll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough.  -  A bamboo fabrication is a mediocre substitute for wood.
column12: Contruite en bois, la maison japonaise traditionnelle a une apparence de travail médiocre tant que n’est pas planté le petit jardin de bambous.   --  Chapitre vingt-six L'homme à facettes  CE chapitre va nous mener aux confins de la première moitié de notre route, et la dernière étape sévère que nous allons franchir se trouve dans ces prochaines pages, avec l'apparition d'un élément qui paraît simple mais que nous avions jusqu'ici évité, en raison des difficultés qu'il aurait causées. Allons sans plus tarder à sa rencontre.

column11: The character for enter (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for person, shown here, represents someone walking outwards.  -  * As a primitive, it can keep its kanji form except when it appears to the left (its normal position), where it is made to stand up in the form ⺅ (Similar to イ). The primitive meaning is another matter. The abstract notion of person so often has a relation to the meaning of the kanji that confusion readily sets in. So many of the previous stories have included people in them that simply to use person for a primitive meaning would be risky. We need to be more specific, to focus on one particular person. Try to choose someone who has not figured in the stories so far, perhaps a colorful member of the family or a friend whom you have known for a long time. That individual will appear again and again, so be sure to choose someone who excites your imagination.  -  Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he´s both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.  -  [I appreciate some people´s occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].
column12: Alors que le kanji entrer nous montrait un personnage « entrant » dans le texte, celui de être humain nous montre quelqu’un allant de l’avant.  --  Le composant gardera la forme du kanji, sauf lorsqu'il apparaîtra à gauche, sa place favorite, où il deviendra . Le sens que nous attribuerons à ce composant pose une grave difficulté. En effet, l'idée d'être humain a déjà été employée de façon sous-entendue à de nombreuses reprises dans les images que nous avons créées. Plutôt que d'utiliser le terme général d'être humain qui entraînerait des confusions, il nous faut imaginer un être humain suffisamment inoubliable. Parmi les possibilités, Tintin est un personnage fort suggestif. Il est d'ailleurs aussi connu au Japon, sous le nom de タンタン. Astérix pourrait aussi faire l'affaire, en remplaçant le capitaine Haddock par Obélix, Tournesol par Panoramix, Milou par Idéfix, et ainsi de suite.

column11: Person . . . left.  -    -  Mr T´s assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - "Stay on my left, foo!".  -  On your right is your "right-hand man" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...
column12: Tintin...gauche. À gauche de Tintin, son assistant de toujours, fidèle depuis la première heure.  --

column11: Person . . . nightbreak.  -    -  However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T.  -  MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs.
column12: Tintin...point du jour.  Pourtant souligne qu’une action se produit alors même qu’on n’en est pas conscient. Cette action est ici exécutée par Tintin, au point du jour, alors que les Dupondt sont encore profondément endormis.  --

column6: reside, live at, dwell, lodge; stop
column11: Person . . . candlestick.  -    -  When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.  -  Mister T dwells in a big brass candlestick, the flame of which serves as a beacon for the boats in the nearby harbour. Sometimes in the morning, Mister T has to clear the wax that has landed and solidified in front of the door.
column12: Là où Tintin est maître, c’est là où il réside.   --

column6: throne; position, post; rank, status; seat
column11: Person . . . vase.  -    -  Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred.  -  Rank A person´s standing.
column12: Le vase placé à côté de Tintin en indique la position.   --

column6: middle brother; go between, mediator; surname
column11: Person . . . in.  -    -  When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist.  -  Go-between The person in the middle.
column12: Tintin...milieu. La relation entre Tintin et le milieu qui l’entoure est ici symbolisée.  --

column6: body; group, class, body, unit; inferior
column11: Person . . . book.  -    -  Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).  -  Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.
column12: En tant que héros de bande dessinée, Tintin a pris corps dans un livre.   --

column11: Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . heart.  -    -  Even a person being hit with a walking-stick by the taskmaster, can remain calm if their heart is remote. (i.e. "emotionally remote", kanji also means calm/composed).  -  Yoda, the Jedi with the walking stick who was a hard taskmaster for Luke but who had a big heart, was permanently exiled on the remote planet Dagobah.
column12: Le sens d’infinité spatiale et temporelle est donné par ce kanji dans lequel on imaginera un idéogramme de la machine à remonter le temps. Tintin, bâton de pèlerin en main, est parti en compagnie d’un chef de corvée, sans doute le professeur Tournesol, sachant manipuler cette machine, enquêter dans le Japon ancien et ses temples millénaires... A son retour, vous lui demandez le sentiment qu’il a de l’infinité.   --

column11: Person . . . cow.  -    -  Note: this kanji refers to event or case. Current Affair headline: Mr. T has affair with cow. "It´s only animal ´man´ enough for me".  -  I´m having a hard time keep straight just which animal Mr. T is having an affair with. chamcham´s story made me realize that Mr. T is not having an "affair", he´s having an "heifair." Get it?
column12: Tintin est cette fois-ci maquignon sur le marché de Château-Gontier, et attend de vendre la première vache, première affaire de la journée, pour payer la première tournée, au Café du commerce ou au Bar du bout du Monde, mille sabords.  --

column11: Person . . . samurai. The key word means to wait on someone or serve them.  -    -  Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them.  -  [+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. "I pity da foo....no, really.".
column12: À côté du vieux professeur, Tintin est là pour le servir.   --

column11: Person . . . scorpion.  -    -  Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people).  -  It´s one or the other: fight Mr. T, or be thrown into the scorpion pit.
column12: Si le scorpion croise le chemin de Tintin, il vous faudra trouver un autre Tintin, ou une autre chute à l’histoire pour lui éviter la mort.  --

column11: Person . . . chihuahua.  -    -  Don´t need a silly story for this one: prostration is when a person puts themselves in a low position like a dog, as an extreme gesture of humility.  -  Mr T has beaten up the chihuahua, who lies prostrated in front of him. "Now," Mr T says, "I quiero some Taco Bell!".
column12: Les oreilles baissées, tel un petit chien, Tintin est prostré, face à terre.  --

column11: Person . . . rising cloud. Hint: the Amerindians' smoke signal scan help provide a good image for this kanji, whose key word is meant to include transmissions of all sorts.  -    -  Mister T transmits a message with rising clouds (smoke) signals, to a nearby American Indian tribe. The smoke signals spell : "I p-i-t-y y-o-u f-o-o !".  -  Hanging one-handed under Cloud City, the Jedi-in-training Luke, uses the force to transmit his distress to Leia.
column12: Tintin...nuage qui s’élève. Les Indiens et leurs signaux de fumée vous transmettent comment retenir ce kanji.  --

column11: Person . . . elbow.  -    -  Mr. T says, "I ain´t afraid o´ no foo! I´ll give anyone an elbow to the face, I don´t care if it´s Buddha himself!".  -  Buddha is a person who always seems to have his elbows bent.
column12: Les éléments Tintin...coude - privé définissent mieux encore, peut-être, le second sens de ce kanji : la France.   --

column11: Person . . . tree. Be sure not to confuse with relax (Frame 202).  -    -  Mr T resting by a tree.  -  Chuck norris rests againsts the tree, but wait, no... the tree rests and stands against him.
column12: Tintin est assis à côté d’un arbre, pour prendre un repos bien mérité.  --

column11: Person . . . anti-.  -    -  Mr. T was offered a job in the Iraq Provisional Authority, but he turned it down, because he´s anti-war. "I pity da fool thinks this sand pit worth invadin´ when our schools be in such sad shape!".  -  Mr. T is anti anything provisional. "I pity da foo´ who´s so indecisive that he can´t make nothin´ permanent".
column12: Cet anti-Tintin est un Tintin  factice.   --

column6: older brother; father's elder brother; senior male 'sire'; feudal rank 'count'
column11: Person . . . white dove.  -    -  If Mr T was white I am sure he would have been commander in chief of the USA, he just the sort of clown Americans love to vote for. (NB: I tried with the indian chief motif but kept adding feathers by mistake).  -  Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn´t want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin´ on some crack cocaine. You make the call.
column12: Son panache blanc flottant au vent, Tintin est devenu un chef, sur le chemin de la victoire. Ce kanji possède aussi le sens d'oncle, cette fois-ci l'aîné d'un parent.  --

column11: Person . . . valley. The key word should be taken in its older sense of "popular" or "commonplace."  -    -  Mr. T says, "Don´t be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain´t nothing but foos!".  -  Mr T meets the vulgar (common) people of the valley and participates in the vulgar customs (folkways). Looking at the vulgar (common) people, Mr T says - “I pity you foo!”.
column12: Au fond des vallées, là ou Hergé n’a pas pu l’accompagner, il paraît que Tintin est de la plus grande vulgarité.   --

column11: Person . . . words.  -    -  Mr. T has faith in the Word of God. (Image: Mr. T kneeling and prayering in front of a bible. "Pity me, fool.").  -  Faith is believing that a person will be true to his word.
column12: Notons la place inhabituelle que prend ici l’élément mots, et remarquons que ce choix est judicieux : quels que soient les mots qu’il prononce, nous avons foi en Tintin, avant tout.  --  Communication est un sens associé.

column11: Person . . . ivy. To distinguish from excel (Frame 980), eminent (Frame 52), esteem (Frame 196), and exquisite (Frame 130), give the key word its own unique connotation.  -    -  Mr T wants to go to an excellent school, so he enrolls in Harvard, an ivy-league school.  -  Bill and Ted are walking through medieval Europe when they see a humongous square jewel. "Excellent!" they both yell. But only after grabbing it do they realize it is chained to the neck of Mr. T, who grimaces angrily at them. "Bogus!" they cry, and totally run away.
column12: Tintin...joyau. Tintin reçoit ici un joyau en remerciement de son excellent travail.  --

column6: rely on, be set in; consent, obey a wish
column11: Person . . . garment.  -    -  Mr T is reliant (depends on) on his garment (the gold chains).  -  Mr. T. is so self-reliant he even makes his own garments.
column12: Tintín...vêtement. Dans chacune de ses aventures, Tintín porte un vêtement adapté à son activité, et qui en dépend, en quelque sorte.  --

column11: Person . . . file.  -    -  Mr T shows the example to the kids, and stays in the file (at supermarket, ...). “I pity da foo who does not follow my example !”.  -  When Mr. T. wants to make an example out of a group of people, he lines them up all single file and knocks them all out with one punch!
column12: Déguisé en professeur de gymnastique au collège, Tintin montre l’exemple, devant une file d’élèves médusés par ses prouesses.  --

column11: Person . . . harden.  -    -  This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : "Middle English, single, indivisible". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he´s had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. "I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units.".  -  Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, "Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!".
column12: Tintin...corps solide. Le corps solide qu’il faut voir ici est votre collection d'albums de Tintin, votre propriété individuelle que vous ne laisseriez pour rien au monde.  --

column11: -    -  Dragon Quest - You find a hardened bamboo stick, perfect for a weapon, but you can´t pick it up because your items are full.  -  You´ve entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn´t understand and instead asks - "Two items? Three items?" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something.
column12: Nous trouvons ici l'équivalent de 個 dans le monde des objets, traditionnellement construits en bambou.  --

column11: Person . . . rule. See frame 92 for help.  -    -  Mr. T rulezzz! I am on his side!  -  Chuck Norris´s rules are easy to live by, just be on his side.
column12: Tintin...règlement. Appliquer le règlement...s’appliquer à suivre le règlement : et voilà : voilà Tintin se rangeant docilement du côté du règlement.  --

column6: serve, attend upon; attendant, servant; samurai
column11: Person . . . Buddhist temple. The key word is deceptively modern, but the kanji is actually another way of writing "samurai." Be careful not to confuse with attend (Frame 1033).  -    -  Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: attend (#960)).  -  Remember the kanji for wait, 待. Well, now we have a waiter, and he´s dropped a dish. See: 侍! 待 crash 侍.
column12: Tintin...temple bouddhique. On verrait bien l'idéogramme d'une sorte de sacristain dans ce kanji, mais c'est en fait le visage d'un samouraï qui s'y cache, en une exotique association du sabre et du goupillon.  --

column11: Person . . . pavilion.  -    -  Halt fool - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion.  -  Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World´s Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - "“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it´s the best !".
column12: Tintin a fait une halte à côté du pavillon-clou.  --

column11: Person . . . straightaway.  -    -  Mr. T (person) tells the used car salesman to tell him the real price straight away, and when he doesn´t he throws him through the windshield.  -  Mr. T is shopping for new chains. He knows what he wants and money isn´t an issue. "Cut the jibba-jabba, tell me the price, straightaway!".
column12: Apprenant la valeur des choses, Tintin en reste droit de surprise.  --

column11: Person . . . set free.  -    -  Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. He plays for a different reason, though - he hates to see them poor little foos in the ball so he spends his entire time setting them free.  -  The black slave who was set free (#496) decides to emulate Mr. T, his role model. He uses his compass to head to Cali to start anew.
column12: Mis dans la peau du prisonnier que libère le chef de corvée, Tintin n'a qu'à suivre l'exemple, pour faciliter sa réinsertion sociale.  --

column6: fall over; lie down; take turns
column11: Person . . . arrival.  -    -  The A-Team are planning to overthrow the government. However, they can´t do a damn thing until Mr T arrives.  -  In Return of the Jedi, after a climactic light sabre battle, Luke and Vader overthrow the emperor (literally throwing him over the balcony).
column12: Porteur d'une bonne nouvelle, Tintin arrive en courant et renverse la bouteille du Capitaine Haddock. Mille milliards de mille sabords !  --

column11: Person . . . upright.  -    -  Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. "Why should I hide?! I´ve got nothing to be ashamed of!".  -  NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book.
column12: Tintin...intègre. Tout dépend de quel bord on est...  --

column6: Buddhist priest, monk; san of Sanskrit sangha
column11: Person . . . increase.  -    -  While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest.  -  Mr. T and the artist formerly known as Prince, who by the way is a buddhist, want to form a new heavy metal band. Instead of "Judas Priest" they will be called "Buddhist Priest".
column12: Tintin...augmenter. Devenir prêtre bouddhiste au Japon, c'est voir augmenter sa paye, son statut social et le nombre de mètres carrés dont on dispose.  --

column11: Person . . . idea.  -    -  Mr. T has an clear idea of what he would do if he ever got hundred million dollar. (I guess it would be a enormous gold chain !).  -  Mr. T´s bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. "C´mon, foo! Sign the paper!".
column12: Tintin...idée. La simple idée de faire naître Tintin s’est concrétisée par environ cent millions d’exemplaires vendus.  --

column11: Person . . . righteousness.  -    -  Mr. T is the master of ceremonies because he is a righteous dude.  -  Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo ).
column12: Pendant la cérémonie, Tintin doit suivre rigoureusement le protocole.  --

column11: Person . . . prize.  -    -  Mr. T says, "This ain´t no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!".  -  NOTE: do not confuse with compensation (#476)賠. However, 賠 is always used in conjunction 賠償... But 償 is used in various other compounds. Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams.
column12: Faute d'avoir remporté le premier prix, Tintin se trouve à côté de son récipiendaire, pour ne recevoir qu'une simple compensation.  --

column11: Person . . . mountain.  -    -  A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.  -  After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy ("fairy" is another meaning of this kanji).
column12: Dans la montagne, Tintin va rendre visite aux ermites.   --

column11: Hermit . . . turkey. Note what has happened to the mountain in the element for hermit. In order to make room for the turkey, it was raised and condensed.  -    -  And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. "I pity da foo who don´t have a Mr. T grill!".  -  Mister T sponsors a meeting in the mountains (he´s an hermit), talking over a megaphone “I pity da foo who does not come to my event !”. The old turkey comes, and Mister T catches it and cooks it for dinner, muahaha.
column12: Ermite...dinde. Ayant pris en charge le sort de quelque dinde, l'ermite aura été, pour lui faire de la place, jusqu'à déformer la montagne en la repoussant vers le haut.  --

column11: To refer to the fullness of humanity that can only be achieved in dialogue with another (person . . . two), Confucius used this character.  -    -  The beginning of humanity required at least TWO people. Mr. T and Mrs. T!  -  Mr. T shows his humanity by giving two bucks to every homeless person he sees.
column12: Confronté à deux ennemis jurés, Tintin parvient par sa vertu à les réconcilier. Ce kanji se veut à l'image de tout lien social, montrant que l'on ne devient jamais quelqu'un d'humain qu'en tenant compte de quelqu'un d'autre.  --

column11: Every . . . person.  -    -  Mr. T has scorn for every fool.  -  People full of scorn tend to hate every person (including themselves).
column12: Tintín...tous les. Dans tous les albums de Tintin, on trouve une personne méprisable, un traître qui en permanence attend notre héros au tournant.  --

column6: cause, send on a mission, order; envoy, messenger, ambassador
column11: Person . . . officer.  -    -  Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!  -  Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.
column12: Tintin...préposé. Dans un Japon moderne auquel il ne comprend rien, Tintin doit demander au préposé comment utiliser le distributeur de fioles de whisky qui assouvira la soif du Capitaine Haddock. Mille sabords !  --

column11: Person . . . grow late. Hint: this kanji also means that unmentionable material that one disposes of when one goes to the "conveniences."  -    -  Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!  -  Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn´t wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!
column12: Tintin...encore plus. Grâce à sa souplesse, Tintin s'accommode de toutes les situations et sait faire encore plus que tout autre. Ajoutons que ce kanji définit aussi les excréments dont nous nous débarrassons dans nos « commodités ».  --

column11: Person . . . muzzle. Do not confuse with the kanji for duplicate (Frame 504).  -    -  Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.  -  Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T´s buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn´t he´s rambling on about pity and foo.
column12: Tintin...muselière. Tintin a ici doublé de volume après qu'on lui a fait boire un philtre, et on doit le museler pour éviter que son état n'empire.  --

column11: Person . . . melancholy.  -    -  The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. "No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky". (Careful: benevolence (#885).  -  Someone can’t be melancholic for long if just one person treats them with a little tenderness.
column12: C'est la nature même de Tintin de se faire du souci pour autrui, et ici il est venu consoler un ami mélancolique. Sont associées à ce kanji les notions de doué ou excellent, comme si à l'expression française « bête et méchant » correspondait l'expression japonaise « tendre et doué ».  --

column11: Person . . . fiesta. Hint: recall the German legend of the English missionary, Saint Boniface, who felled the sacred oak tree dedicated to Thor at Geismar (in lower Hessia), occasioning a great fiesta for the Christians in the neighborhood to mark the defeat of their pagan competition. Be sure to fit your special person into the story if you use it.  -    -  At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get "the sucka," he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”.  -  Mr T at the FIESTA fell over blind drunk.
column12: Tintin abat avec une grande hallebarde un arbre gigantesque.  --

column6: stop, rest, lodge, stay overnight; constellation
column11: House . . . person . . . hundred.  -    -  The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T.  -  The inn is like a big house that can addomodate a hundred persons. Only this time, there´s just Mister T and he´s booked all the rooms!
column12: Maison...Tintin...cent. Pour entrer dans cette auberge, il n'en coûtera que cent yens à Tintin.  --

column11: Person . . . reclining . . . piggy bank.  -    -  If someone doesn't have a fat piggy bank to cover their medical costs and happen to get wounded somewhere, they'll be reclining there forever.  -  Mr. T gets wounded by reclining on his piggy bank.
column12: Tintin soigne un blessé que nous voyons ici couché. Pour le soigner, il ne dispose, comme pour nous expliquer ce kanji, que des ultraviolets de la lumière solaire...  --

column11: Person . . . mouth . . . tree.  -    -  Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying "I pitty da foo who don´t protect the trees!".  -  Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 dumbfounded (#2181). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.
column12: Ici conservateur des arbres, Tintin le crie bien fort, en ouvrant grand la bouche.  --

column11: Top hat and scarf . . . protect. Note that the "tree" in protect becomes a wooden pole here.  -    -  Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively.  -  An old lady puts a top hat and scarf on her poodle and praises him for how cute he is. The dog thinks, "Someone protect me from this psycho!"...　RTK2:　ホウ　過褒　かほう(excessive praise).
column12: Des paroles élogieuses sont prononcées à l’adresse de notre conservateur, par une notabilité en chapeau haut de forme et écharpe.   --

column11: Person . . . sunglasses . . . tree.  -    -  My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone.  -  Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. "Recognise, foo!".
column12: Tintin...pieds écartés...arbre. La prouesse de Tintin est de parvenir le premier au sommet de l'arbre, bien qu'il marche pieds écartés, de façon peu orthodoxe.  --

column6: give, deliver, pay, hand over; entrust
column11: Person . . . glue. The few cases in which this character serves as a primitive should include some connotation of "adhering to" that distinguishes it from "glued to." Two examples follow.  -    -  賀 TO EVERYONE WHO MADE IT TO 千 kanji!! Remember, after this, you´ll be 読ing japanese novels, the news, and the internet like a native. 吉 to ALL of you in your amazing japanese 往. :).  -  If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE.
column12: Tintin...colle. Pour bien mettre l'oreille cassée là où il faut, Tintin la colle bien sur la statuette Arumbaya.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . adhere.  -    -  I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it.  -  At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly.
column12: Bambou...mettre. On met une plaquette de bambou sur le sac postal pour en faire un ticket.   --

column11: Cave . . . adhere.  -    -  Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies.  -  A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see government office (#591)).
column12: Le sens et la forme sont voisins de ceux présentés en 653, 庁. Liberté est laissée cependant quant à la façon de mettre le portrait au mur.  --

column6: trust to, rely on, appoint; to bear, duty, office; allow
column11: Person . . . porter.  -    -  It is always Mr. T´s responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone´s luggage because he´s so strong.  -  In pregnancy (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can´t you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?
column12: Tintin...porteur. Cela rappelle certains numéros de cirque dans lesquels l'un des artistes, tenant un comparse à bout de bras, porte l'entière responsabilité de la réussite du numéro.  --

column11: Responsibility . . . shells/money.  -    -  It´s your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.  -  In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. "un.CHIN".
column12: Responsabilité...monnaie. À partir du moment où un prestataire perçoit la monnaie correspondant au tarif fixé, alors sa responsabilité est engagée et il s'acquittera de sa tâche avec la plus grande minutie.  --

column6: replace, replacement (of person or generation); era, generation
column11: Person . . . arrow.  -    -  Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It´s best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to "mediator" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.  -  Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.
column12: Tintin...flèche. Évitez toute confusion avec le kanji du cadre 1082, qui est plus rare. Les sens associés sont nombreux montant d’argent et génération car ils sont fréquents.  --

column11: Substitute . . . garment.  -    -  A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.  -  A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 "bag", and although the later really refers to a "straw sack", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a "plastic bag" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).
column12: Substituer...habit. On lit sur les sacs de supermarché de ne pas laisser les enfants jouer avec, les utiliser en guise d’habit. Ce kanji semble pourtant indiquer qu’un sac n’est jamais qu’un substitut d’habit.   --

column11: Substitute . . . shells/money.  -    -  In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money.  -  The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.
column12: Substituer...monnaie. Les mots japonais correspondant à prêter et louer sont tous deux rendus par ce kanji. C’est le contexte qui enseigne s’il s’agit d’un prêt ou d’une location. En utilisant le mot-clé louer, on construira une mise en scène incluant la substitution de monnaie.   --

column11: Person . . . spoon.  -    -  Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare change", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".  -  Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.
column12: Par une alchimie secrète, Tintin (debout) devient un personnage assis, au cours de cette transformation.   --

column11: Flower . . . change.  -    -  The flowers change with the seasons.  -  The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.
column12: Végétal...transformation. Dans une plante, le lieu où se produisent les plus spectaculaires transformations, c'est à n'en pas douter la fleur.  --

column11: Change . . . shells.  -    -  Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don´t confuse with the similar 賃 fare (#1004).  -  This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there´s actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.
column12: Pour le transporteur, le fret se transforme avant tout en espèces sonnantes et trébuchantes.  --

column11: Change . . . head. The key word has the sense of leaning on or toward someone or something.  -    -  Mr. T gave a girl some change to lean over and give him head.  -  Leaning over changes the position of the head...　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ケイ　傾向　けいこう(tendency).
column12: Avant de transformer un essai, le joueur de rugby incline la tête. Attention à l’écriture du second élément, coincé entre Tintin et la tête.  --

column11: Person . . . can.  -    -  What can Mr T do? ´You mean: what can´t MR T do, you fool´.  -  What can´t Mr. T not do?
column12: Tintin... pouvoir. La question que sous-entend ce kanji est de savoir de quoi Tintin sera-t-il encore capable.   --

column11: Flowers . . . what.  -    -  TSA guard: What´s in the baggage?! It´s just flowers, I swear!  -  Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says "here, carry my BAGGAGE." Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, "what?".
column12: Quoi...végétal. Le douanier vous demande de « quoi » sont remplis vos bagages, quel végétal vous rapportez de votre lointain voyage.  --

column11: Person . . . license . . . walking legs.  -    -  The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.  -  (re: sweetneet) Since he is not very sagacious, Mr. T failed his driver´s license and now needs to resort to his walking legs to get around.
column12: Nous avons déjà vu la partie droite en 843, et lui avions associé l'idée de mouvement décidé. Bien avisé, Tintin prend la juste décision en un clin d'œil et part d'un mouvement décidé.  --

column6: by side of, beside, near, close
column11: Person . . . stand . . . crown . . . compass.  -    -  In Japan, the emperor is a bystander - he stands on his crown but can´t really affect the direction of the country. (thx shimouma).  -  Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he´s asking the bystander if they know how to get to buckingham palace (!).
column12: Le sens du kanji définit l'observateur extérieur à l'action, placé de côté. L'action est ici le numéro d'un pigeon voyageur tenant une une couronne debout sur sa tête, tel un phoque et son ballon.  --

column6: long time (ago); time passage, grow late
column11: This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for bound up and a person. Think of a mummy, and the key word will not be far behind.  -    -  Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person).  -  This is a picture of a person bowing "long time no see!".
column12: Le second trait de ce caractère est commun à emballage et être humain. Pensez à une grand-mère tenant son petit-enfant dans ses bras, et le mot-clé ne sera pas loin.  --

column11: Think of the three kinds of furrows shown here in this character - a top hat's rim, a rice field's ridges, and the wrinkles that show you've been around a long time.  -    -  Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!  -  A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he´s got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. [trigger: furrow your brain].
column12: Ici sont représentées trois sortes de sillons. Le liseré du chapeau haut de forme, les sillons de la rizière, et les rides, prouvant notre présence en ce bas-monde depuis déjà bien longtemps.   --

column11: Person . . . pent in.  -    -  A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.  -  Mr. T can´t be captured. This kanji is lying.
column12: Que Tintin soit enfermé dans une enceinte indique assez qu'il est incarcéré.  --

column11: Person . . . belt. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of hood here because the person runs THROUGH the element, not under it.  -    -  Mr. T´s new belt is huge! When he´s inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!  -  How is a person ever supposed to get inside that girl when she´s wearing such a huge chastity belt? I guess that´s kinda the point, eh?
column12: Tintin...ceinture. En guise de ceinture, imaginez une sorte de cloche de verre, de l'intérieur de laquelle le prisonnier Tintin tente de s'extraire.  --

column11: Those no-frills flights the airlines offer to attract customers should help create an image from ceiling . . . person . . . belt. The kanji meaning "inside" should not be used because of its proximity to the element for "in."  -    -  In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it´s almost pictographic here!).  -  But third class is so small Mr. T´s head hits the celing.
