column12: Les éléments plafond...Tintin...ceinture sont à l'image de ces vols à bas coût offerts sur certaines lignes aériennes. Encore parfois utilisé comme numéral, ce kanji désigne à l'origine la troisième des soixantes années du cycle zodiacal chinois.  --

column11: Tree . . . third class.  -    -  This is a "design" as in a "pattern", not a verb as in "to design". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it.  -  Half Way!!!!
column12: Arbre...troisième classe. Pour faire un bon manche, il suffit d'un arbre de troisième classe ; manche où vous observerez les motifs (second sens du kanji) dessinés par les fines nervures du bois.  --

column11: Let this doubling of one of the elements for "inside" yield the sense of "insides" to approach the key word, meat. The abbreviated form of this character gave us the primitive meaning of flesh or part of the body for the kanji 月.  -    -  Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.  -  A person´s inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat.
column12: Le redoublement d’un élément de intérieur nous mènera aisément au concept de « entrailles », puis à celui de viande ou chair. La forme abrégée de ce kanji vous est connue depuis le premier chapitre, et avait formé le composant chair ou partie du corps.   --

column11: Municipality . . . meat.  -    -  The rotting meat adheres to the cave walls.  -  Smaller municipalities are well known for filling their budgets with pork (meat). Thats why they are also well known for being rotten.
column12: Bureau de gouvernement...chair. Pensez au verbe corrompre, qui, en français comme en japonais, concerne aussi bien les personnes que leur nourriture.  --

column11: Cave . . . assembly line . . . soil.  -    -  CONGRATULATIONS YOU´RE HALFWAY THERE!!!! =).  -  Coal mine (cave); tea break time; the assembly line stops and everyone sit or squat on the dirt floor, in a long line, to rest.
column12: Maison de campagne...chaîne d’assemblage.  Il s'agit de la façon traditionnelle qu'ont les Japonais de s'asseoir. Quand les chaises apparurent, on pensa que pour tenir sur un tel engin, il fallait s'y attacher (742, 掛) les reins.  --

column11: Top hat . . . assembly line . . . needle.  -    -  Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(needles) with the cap and tassel(top hat). It took them 10 years (Bachelor´s, Masters, PhD) to get there.... :-p.  -  When you graduate, you wear a hat and graduate in an assembly line while your parents sit on pins and needles because it will take ten years to pay off those loans.
column12: Au sortir de la chaîne d'assemblage qu'est l'université et avant d'intégrer une entreprise début avril, les étudiants japonais ont droit à une cérémonie de fin d'études, où ils reçoivent leur aiguille de spécialiste. Le chapeau est là pour la forme.  --

column11: Umbrella . . . two assembly lines . . . needle.  -    -  FOUR PERSONS can fit under this UMBRELLA if they are thin as a NEEDLE.  -  There are two assembly lines at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. The two lines cross at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.
column12: Parapluie...double chaîne d’assemblage...aiguille. La fabrication d'un parapluie, travail complexe, nécessite une double chaîne d'assemblage pour joindre les multiples aiguilles qui en forment l'ossature.  --  Chapitre vingt-sept Vrac   NOUS abord ous abordons un groupe de caractères ne présentant guère d'unité, car ils tombent en dehors des mailles tissées dans les chapitres précédents. Ce phénomène dû à la rareté des composants présentés se reproduira une fois.

column6: Japanese unit of weight (1/1000 of a kan)
column11: This character obliges us once again to make use of a Japanese key word for want of an English equivalent. It refers to an old unit of weight, equal to about 3.75 grams. The word is only slightly more useful in modern Japanese than cubits and kites are in modern English. Its primitives, if you look closely, are: bound up . . . arm.  -    -  Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! "Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!".  -  Dude! What happened to your arm! It´s all bound up! "Yeah man, it´s a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!" "You´ll never be able to use your dagger now!" (adapted from ergerg).
column12: Un monme est une unité de masse valant un millième de l'unité définie par le kanji percer, donc 3,75 grammes. Vous y décèlerez les éléments emballé et bras. À supposer que l'on veuille emballer quelque chose avec le bras, dans le creux du coude par exemple, on ne saurait guère y placer plus de 3,75 g.  --

column6: by means of; thereby, therefore; consider as; in order to
column11: Picture a person dragging a plow behind, and the drop of sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living "by means of the sweat of their brows."  -    -  A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.  -  Mr T now makes a living by means of a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.
column12: Courbé vers l’avant, Tintin tire la charrue vers lui et une goutte de sueur perle sur son front. Imaginez-le tirant la charrue  au moyen de la sueur de son front.   --

column6: resemble, similar to; as if, seem
column11: Be sure to keep this key word distinct from likeness (Frame 104). Its elements: person . . . by means of.  -    -  Mr. T finds that living by means of dragging a plow is similar to slavery.  -  A Mr T impersonator is becoming similarer (more like) by means of plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.
column12: On dévoile ici la méthode employée pour faire apparaître Tintin en double, au chapitre précédent. Ce double, fabriqué au moyen de Tintin, lui ressemble parfaitement.  --

column11: The sense of the key word is one of joining things together that were previously separate. Its elements: person . . . puzzle.  -    -  Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society.  -  Why do I gotta join these two puzzle pieces? I ain´t got time for joining no jigsaw-jabba! Mr. T apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles.
column12: Le sens est bien d'assembler des choses auparavant disjointes. Tintin vient ici vous aider à réunir les pièces de votre casse-tête. Un autre sens de ce kanji est cependant. Cependant exprime l'idée d'événements simultanés mais disjoints, et destinés ultérieurement à se trouver réunis.  --

column11: Ceiling . . . plow . . . fishhook . . . a drop of.  -    -  Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor.  -  [true stroke order] First draw T for Tile, which then becomes I. Then draw an ´L´ fish hook with a dash in the middle to make a mediocre ´e´ that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).
column12: Plafond...canne...crochet...glace. Notez comment le second trait de glace s’allonge pour refermer et étanchéifier la tuile. On pourrait y voir la glaçure (émail) dont sont recouvertes les tuiles japonaises, pour les étanchéifier, en augmenter la longévité et leur apporter une touche colorée.  --  Cette tuile étonnante pèse exactement un gramme².  ² Quand ils adoptèrent le système métrique, les Japonais l'adaptèrent en associant un caractère à chacune de ses unités. Le gramme dont il est ici question est peu usité mais le mètre est fréquemment employé. Cela dit, sauriez-vous lire ou comprendre ces kanjis : 、 、、 ou 瓩 ?

column11: Puzzle . . . tile.  -    -  A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.  -  To solve this puzzle all you need is to put the flower pot on top of the proper tile. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).
column12: Un objet tombe du toit : « c’est la tuile ! » pensez-vous aussitôt. Erreur, le kanji vous répond que c’est avant tout un casse-tête. Alors vous vous approchez et découvrez enfin la vérité : une bouteille.   --

column11: Way back in lesson 2 we learned the character for spine. The two other characters in which it is used we can now learn together in this and the following frame. Here a Shinto shrine is composed of house and spine.  -    -  This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for "sedlec ossuary", it´s quite a sight.  -  A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, Shinto shrine"!
column12: Maison...grand bâtiment. On reconnaîtra sous le toit de cette maison le kanji épine dorsale, que l'on sait aussi signifier grand bâtiment contenant de nombreuses pièces. On s'imaginera visitant un palais, pendant des heures et des heures, chaque pièce débouchant sur une autre, et ainsi de suite.  --

column11: Schoolhouse . . . spine.  -    -  Stay in school so you can get an occupation that doesnt require breaking your backbone all day.  -  During the German occupation, this Nazi officer´s occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : "the occupation´s spine schools"). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also "barracks; camp; encapment". This story should help avoid confusion with post (#887) and employ (#1164). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 "detention barracks".
column12: École...épine dorsale. Ici ce sont les échines courbées des élèves menant leur activité que nous imaginons.  --

column11: Sheep . . . horns . . . mouth. Pay special attention to the writing of this character.  -    -  Imagine a priest´s teaching: "To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God´s flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell.  -  To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, "discretion is the better part of virtue".
column12: Mouton...cornes...bouche. Dans la procession des moutons, seul le premier compte, et les autres doivent suivre. Ce premier est un bélier aux longues cornes, et de sa bouche sort la bonne parole, le bien. Tracez d'abord le mouton, puis les cornes et le « trait de stabilisation », et enfin la bouche.  --

column11: In an odd fashion, the kanji for year joins together the element for horse, on the top, and the right half of the element for sunglasses. Think of it as a horse wearing sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.  -    -  A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.  -  A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like descend (#1308).
column12: Étrangement, le kanji année associe le cheval et la moitié droite des pieds écartés, comme pour nous enjoindre à ne pas nous lever du pied gauche à la nouvelle année.  --

column6: night, dark; in night; by night
column11: First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of night with those of evening (Frame 114) and nightbreak (Frame 30). Its elements: top hat . . . person . . . walking legs . . . drop.  -    -  Actually, the lower-right primitive isn´t quite "walking legs." It´s a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...  -  Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed).
column12: Chapeau haut de forme...Tintin...jambes qui marchent...goutte. Tintin met son chapeau haut de forme et s'enfonce en marchant vers la nuit où l'on n'y voit goutte.   --

column11: Water . . . night.  -    -  A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night....  -  I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?
column12: Eau...nuit. Après s'être évaporée durant la journée sous l'effet de la chaleur, l'eau redevient liquide dans la fraîcheur de la nuit.  --

column11: Soil . . . crown . . . sow. Compare frame 582.  -    -  There´s already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the Hillock. It´s Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown.  -  The crowned sow (we met her in overpowering) is standing atop her little mound of earth - hillock - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.
column12: Terre...couronne...truie. Repensant à l’image du cadre 595, cette butte pourrait bien être le ring sur lequel s’affrontent les lutteurs sumo.  --

column11: Shredder . . . towel.  -    -  A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) .  -  In order to create some cash, first you feed a towel through a shredder to get the raw materials. ("Paper" money isn´t plain paper; it´s mostly linen.).
column12: Miettes...serviette. Une bourse faite d'une vieille serviette est employée pour conserver les miettes, ici des espèces sonnantes et trébuchantes.  --

column10: Défaut, impropre à tout usage, humblement
column11: Shredder . . . two hands.  -    -  The Bush administration taskmasters hid their abuse of power by shredding documents as fast as they could using both hands....　　　　　RTK2: 　ヘイ　弊害　へいがい(abuse)...　　　Pure Group:　幣1041.  -  You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips.
column12: Mis en miettes, avec les deux mains, un objet est affecté du pire des défauts, celui de devenir impropre à tout usage. Comme bien des mots à connotation négative, ce kanji est utilisé pour faire humblement référence à soi-même.  --

column11: The mouth on the left is obvious. The rest is harder. Try this: four St. Bernard dogs bound up in a bunch. Together they should supply a clear enough portrait of a yell, provided you are careful to see all four of them. Note how the final stroke of the four is supplied by the long horizontal stroke of the St .Bernard.  -    -  Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1626). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I´m imagining lots of yelping.  -  Yell? You mean, Old Yeller. Here, we see four St Bernard dogs all yelling for a chance to play a part in Old Yeller. They´re so loud that you have to bound them, and their mouths, up.
column12: Après la bouche en position clé, nous verrons quatre saint-bernard empa­quetés, soit l’idéogramme d’un chenil.   --

column11: Fingers . . . four St. Bernard dogs bound up.  -    -  After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions.  -  On the snap of your fingers, the four St. Bernard dogs bound up interchange places.
column12: Tout compte fait, votre saint-bernard ne vous plaît pas et, au chenil, vous montrez du doigt celui avec lequel vous désirez l'échanger.   --

column11: Ceiling . . . mouth . . . hood . . . human legs . . . spike . . . insect. This is the maximum number of elements to appear in any story in the book.  -    -  I have created the element "old camera" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject´s point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air.  -  I´ve seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It´s a venus flytrap, btw).
column12: Dissoudre et fondre sont deux notions intimement liées à ce kanji. Prenons avantage du fait que l'insecte n'est pas à sa place habituelle, pour lui donner le sens secondaire de grenaille. Dans notre marmite à trépied, nous jetons cette grenaille afin de produire un lingot. Cela nous convient car ce kanji s'emploie dans des mots en relation avec la finance.  --  Chapitre vingt-huit  Bannière  UNE bannière et un drapeau qui se transformera en une paire de fesses vont nous occuper durant ces quelques pages.

column11: Banner . . . scorpion.  -    -  Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims.  -  ALMS for the poor cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl.
column12: Bannière...scorpions. Cette bande de scorpions est décidée à passer à l’action, ce qui ne laisse pas présager d’un sort enviable à qui se trouvera sur leur route. On trouve en corollaire le sens de « bonne action » : aumône.  --

column11: A banner . . . a zoo. Hint: think of a merry-go-round.  -    -  A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos...  -  Don´t confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.
column12: Bannière...zoo.  Pensez à un manège.  --

column11: Banners . . . children . . . road.  -    -  The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.  -  There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean "drive slowly", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play.
column12: Route...bannière...enfants. Pensez aux panneaux de prévention que l’on trouve souvent dans les campagnes, pour que les enfants puissent jouer près de la route.   --

column11: Let the last 4 strokes, which are also the concluding strokes to the character for garment, represent a rag as its primitive meaning. We shall meet this only on one other occasion. This gives us as our elements: banner . . . rag.  -    -  The boat starts to leave on it´s trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says "Bon Voyage", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.  -  After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.
column12: Bannière...Tintin...morceau de tissu. Les deux derniers traits, semblables aux deux derniers traits de habit, représentent un morceau de tissu. Ce pourrait être le brassard que porte plus d’un Japonais en voyage, pour identifier son groupe et éviter de se perdre. La bannière est portée par la jeune guide en uniforme, suivie de près par Tintin et son brassard.   --

column11: Cow . . . knot.  -    -  The cow´s "thing" is tied in a knot! ouch.  -  A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
column12: Une vache n’est pas un objet.   --

column11: Sun . . . knot.  -    -  The sun is not an easy place to get to.  -  Under the sun, it is easy to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so easy.
column12: Imaginons dans la bouche et sa langue qui s'agite suivie du faisceau que forment ses quatres pattes un caméléon dont la couleur varie et s'adapte au terrain. Nous arrivons ainsi très vite au concept de variations puis échanges, mais aussi de facile : aussi facile qu'il peut l'être à un caméléon de gober une mouche.  --

column11: Shells . . . easy.  -    -  A grant is easy money.  -  Do you want free shells from the government? It´s easy with my new book, "How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!" Call today!
column12: Le verbe traduisant recevoir dans sa forme la plus respectueuse propose l’image d’un caméléon nous tendant la monnaie du bout de la langue.  --

column11: Flag . . . water.  -    -  Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their "country" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick).  -  Someone is pissing on the American flag, but since the urine is clear it looks like water.
column12: Fesses...eau. Notez combien il est rare de voir l'eau utilisé tel quel comme composant.  --

column11: Flag . . . spoon.  -    -  Red cross nuns sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry.  -  A nun sits in protests under an American flag.
column12: On imaginera la « bonne sœur en deux-chevaux » de nos campagnes, s'occupant à nourrir les indigents à la cuiller, et plantant son aiguille dans les fesses lors des épidémies de grippe.  --

column11: Water . . . nun.  -    -  TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they´re doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next?  -  Water monks live in a den, but water nuns live in the MUD.
column12: Notre nonne n’hésite pas à conduire sa vaillante deux-chevaux dans les ornières boueuses et gorgées d'eau.   --

column11: Soil . . . flag . . . puzzle.  -    -  [fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don´t you think it looks like a giant puzzle?  -  Why the Earth has to be fenced off and flags used to represent each "country" is a puzzle to me - we´re all just monkeys on a big rock spinning round the Sun!
column12: Terre...drapeau...casse-tête. Plantée en terre, la barrière est surmontée d'un drapeau que le paysan aura placé pour prévenir de quelque danger. Vous tentez de la refermer mais un mécanisme à base de fil de fer et de vieux clous en fait un casse-tête qui vous occupe quelques minutes.  --

column6: footwear, shoes; walk on, tread; hexagram ䷉
column11: Flag . . . restore.  -    -  NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG.  -  You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear.
column12: Fesses...retourner. Nous avons vu le kanji enfiler en 612. Voici maintenant celui employé pour enfiler un pantalon ou chausser une paire de bottes. Il montre aussi ce qu'on a « dans les bottes », le « chemin parcouru », ou l'expérience personnelle. Il nous propose tout simplement de faire retourner le pantalon là où il doit être : autour des fesses.  --

column11: Flag . . . climax. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a "roof" used in the primitive for house.  -    -  Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle roof.  -  A couple climaxing on the roof, draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady...
column12: Drapeau...aboutissement. Lorsque le toit arrive à son aboutissement, on y plante un drapeau, en fêtant l’événement. Cette fête se pratique en Europe comme au Japon.  --

column6: grasp, hold fast, take by hand
column11: Fingers . . . roof.  -    -  Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.  -  (This is the にぎ of sushi). A sushi chef climaxes into a rice ball, wraps it in an American flag, and grips is firm with his fingers to form the "Fuck You America Onigiri.".
column12: Doigts...toit. Un film « avec Jean-Paul Belmondo » devrait fournir des images satisfaisantes.  --

column11: Flag . . . exit.  -    -  When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches.  -  If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you.
column12: En se courbant, on adopte une posture par laquelle on fait sortir les fesses.   --

column11: Fingers . . . yield.  -    -  If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields.  -  When you dig, you´d better hope that whatever you´re digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you´re bound to lose some nails.
column12: Creuser ne consiste-t-il pas à contraindre la matière à se courber sous l'effort des doigts ?  --

column11: Soil . . . yield.  -    -  (See dig (#1061)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch.  -  Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it´s patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare.
column12: Et voilà le résultat, lorsque la terre s’est courbée : un canal.   --

column11: Flag . . . old. Do not confuse with dwell (Frame 1027).  -    -  A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside.  -  It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. set (#1064).
column12: Drapeau...vieux. Ce drapeau est celui de la vieille famille, dont le domaine se trouve là depuis des temps immémoriaux.  --

column6: to occupy, take possession of; a base, position
column11: Fingers . . . reside.  -    -  The man set his finger firmly on the map and said "Here is where they reside, I am certain of it".  -  Cf. reside (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.
column12: Doigt...se trouver. Pour avoir une bonne assise, les doigts doivent se trouver sur la couture du pantalon ou posés bien à plat sur la table.  --

column11: Flag . . . increase.  -    -  The strata have piled up in an ever increasing pile of dirt. As the geologists go down the rocks, they flag each stratum with the name of the corresponding era.  -  Archaeologists at a dig site place small flags marking layers or strata of rock. Each of these layers was formerly the top layer. (This is not increase! Hseige keeps messing up).
column12: Drapeau...augmenter. On peut imaginer des fouilles archéologiques, où seraient placés, à chaque strate, des drapeaux à mesure de la progres­sion, de l'augmentation des fouilles. Mais vous pouvez bien entendu utiliser fesses...augmenter si vous le désirez.  --

column11: Flag . . . phrase. Note how the flag's long stroke doubles up for the first stroke of phrase.  -    -  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has email scanners that flag certain phrases.  -  They do nothing at the bureau other than repeating the stupid catchphrase they have on their flag.
column12: Drapeau...phrases. Le mot-clé bureau (de poste ou d’émission de radio­-télévision) serait peut-être plus approprié, mais ne rendrait pas compte du second sens : l’adjectif local, avec la connotation d'extrémité des diverses branches d’un système. Une signification associée est pièce (à l’intérieur d’un palais).  --

column11: Flag . . . sheep . . . road.  -    -  A sheep crossing guard waves a SLOW flag for his fellow sheep crossing the road.  -  Road sign (flag): "Sheep on highway! Drive slowly.".
column12: Route...fesses...moutons. Imaginez-vous bloqué sur une petite route des Causses et le mot-clé s'éclairera.  --

column11: Water . . . flag . . . rain.  -    -  WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water.  -  Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.
column12: Eau...drapeau...pluie. Une fuite dans le toit laisse passer la pluie : vous remédiez tant bien que mal en plaçant un vieux torchon, un drapeau qui traîne là, pour absorber l'eau.   --

column11: Flag . . . towel . . . saber.  -    -  We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.  -  The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools.
column12: Fesses...torchon...sabre. Mieux vaudra repenser à l’imprimerie pratiquée par Gutenberg. Le sabre était utilisé pour graver le bloc de bois, et je vous propose de tirer votre papier des fibres fournies par l'élément de gauche : drapeau...torchon.   --

column11: The key word shaku has actually come into English in the word shakuhachi, the ancient Japanese flute that measured "one shaku and eight sun" (the "sun" being about an inch in length). Since the shaku is about one foot in length, this makes about 20 inches. Let the final sweeping stroke be like a tape measure added to the flag.  -  * As a primitive, this will mean the shakuhachi flute.  -  Slang for blowjob and that´s priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length.  -  Since this is SLANG for BLOW JOB and since it looks like an "R", let´s have the primitive be the R in BROW JOB. :).
column12: Ce mot-clé vous est peut-être connu sous la forme de shakuhachi, la flûte japonaise aux accents lancinants, dont le nom provient du fait qu'elle mesure un shaku et huit . Rappelons qu'un shaku vaut 30,303 cm.   --  Le sésame sera flûte shakuhachi, ou shaku, 30,303 cm.

column11: Shakuhachi . . . ice.  -    -  A women is so exhausted by her "shakuhachi" that see needs to ice her jaw.  -  That´s not ice...it´s my last drops and I´m exhausted! ;).
column12: Flûte shakuhachi...glace. Si vous repensez un instant à l'histoire vue en 525, et à la pénurie de glace, le mieux sera de vous imaginer au bout de la queue, lorsque le stock de glace est épuisé : « Flûte ! »  --

column11: Water . . . shakuhachi.  -    -  You´re hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water.  -  Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp!
column12: On marche en se mouillant les pieds dans ce torrent, où l'eau coule en abondance, atteignant la profondeur de 30,303 cm. La même image illustre aussi l'autre sens du kanji : marais.  --

column11: Words . . . shakuhachi.  -    -  You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi!  -  You all know that ´shakuhachi´ is a slang word for blowjob, right? In this kanji you got a job as a TRANSLATOR for Japanese porno movies. So you sit there all day translating dirty WORDS and watching girls perform SHAKUHACHI. This is the life!
column12: Mots...30,303 cm. Au sens de traduire s'ajoute celui d'excuse : c'est même une excuse assez longue, qui se traduit par une phrase de 30,303 cm.  --

column11: Fingers . . . shakuhachi.  -    -  Hand job or "shakuhachi", choose.  -  Depending on where you choose to put your fingers, the shakuhachi will produce a different note.
column12: Doigts...flûte shakuhachi. Les doigts  choisissent sur la flûte les trous à obturer pour bien jouer la mélodie.  --

column11: Shakuhachi . . . nightbreak.  -    -  Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime.  -  In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don´t have a shakuhachi.
column12: Flûte shakuhachi...point du jour. La journée débute par une mélodie jouée à la flûte shakuhachi, au point du jour.   --

column11: Ceiling . . . flag.  -    -  Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don´t usually hang from the ceiling.  -  A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).
column12: Plafond...drapeau. La version imprimée du premier trait diffère de son tracé à la main, comme c'était aussi le cas pour  (359).  --

column11: Door . . . flesh.  -    -  The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don´t ever try this. Use your foot).  -  The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm´s story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below.
column12: Porte...partie du corps. Retournez en France un instant, oubliez toutes ces portes qui s’ouvrent automatiquement, et vous retrouverez de suite le sens de ce kanji.  --

column6: house, building; room; 4th lunar mansion, determinative star π Scorpii
column11: Door . . . compass.  -    -  Explanation here: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?pid=14684#p14684.  -  When you graduate from a school, after they gave you your tassel, they shove you to the door and give you a compass saying "Sayonara & Good Luck out there!" (ボウ).
column12: Pour ne pas se perdre dans le fouillis de cet atelier, une boussole est pendue sous la porte d’entrée, à la façon d’un pompon ou d’une grappe, autres sens du kanji.  --

column11: Door . . . wings.  -    -  It´s insanely hot today! I´m standing in the doorway, fanning myself with feathers.  -  I am a fan of the Doors but I also like the Wings. I have a fan that I take to rock concerts with the picture of each band on the sides.
column12: Porte...plumes. Avant l'apparition des « ventilateurs à logique floue » dont sont si fiers les Japonais d'aujourd'hui, leurs ancêtres jouissaient d'un confort certes rudimentaire, mais peut-être plus agréable.  --

column11: Hearth fire . . . door.  -    -  This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.  -  -"Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?" -"Aagh, just use the frickin´ door!".
column12: Feu...porte. Bien que la logique voudrait que l’on place le feu derrière la porte, étant élément essentiel, il doit venir en premier lieu.  --

column11: The key word signals a "coming back" or return to some place or activity. Its elements: door . . . St. Bernard dog.  -    -  The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside.  -  Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn.
column12: Vous êtes allé voir votre ami, mais en son absence seul son saint-bernard était là, couché sous la porte : il vous faudra revenir.   --

column11: Water . . . re-. Do not confuse with cry (Frame 463).  -    -  I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.  -  Tears are watery (water + re).
column12: Les gouttes d'eau perlant aux yeux du saint-bernard, triste d’attendre son maître, sont ses larmes.   --

column11: Door . . . turkey. Be sure to keep distinct from both employee (Frame 59) and use (Frame 1065).  -    -  Our company has no standards. We´ll employ any turkey who walks in the door.  -  Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: "Damn it, you might be good. But that don´t account for your behavior. You keep this up and I´ll fire your ass." "No, you won´t." "What damn it, I´ll fire you your ass so fast you won´t...know..."-. "And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --"The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door".
column12: Il s’agit ici de faire travailler quelqu’un et de le rémunérer : la dinde placée sous la porte peut alors être vue comme le salaire que l’employeur gratifie quotidiennement à son employé.  --

column6: look back; look at; look after
column11: Employ . . . head.  -    -  I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move.  -  The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don´t want to be caught playing solitare on company time.
column12: Employer...tête. Il s'agit de considérer les divers aspects d'un sujet, consciencieusement.  --

column11: Door . . . taskmaster . . . mouth.  -    -  Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information.  -  You signed a non-disclosure agreement with the taskmaster but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the door!
column12: Porte...chef de corvée...bouche. L'idée contenue dans ce kanji est l'une des nombreuses formules de respect, difficilement traduisibles, qui abondent en japonais. On s'imaginera franchissant la porte de notre chef de corvée en ouvrant la bouche pour révéler « nos sentiments les plus dévoués ».  --  Chapitre vingt-neuf  L'autel  VOYONS MAINTENANT un groupe de kanjis basés sur l'image d'une étrange graine. Mais tout d'abord un élément qui s'insère difficilement dans quoi que ce soit, mais s'avère utile pour former de nombreux kanjis courants : l'autel.

column11: Although the elements two and little are available for the using, it may be easier to remember this character as a picture of an altar. Something placed atop the altar is put on show for all to see.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji means altar. At the left, the abbreviated form that this element takes is made by chopping the altar in half and leaving only one dot behind to represent the right side. The new appearance of this primitive form, ネ, should be kept distinct from that for cloak, identical except for the one final short stroke.  -  A boy made an altar, but he´s afraid to show it to God because he thinks it´s two little.  -  I´ll SHOW you mine if you show me yours!, she said. I did & she scoffed because it was TWO LITTLE.
column12: On comprendra cette forme comme la représentation pictographique d’un autel. Vous pouvez éventuellement créer votre propre association à partir des éléments deux...petits, en imaginant deux enfants de chœur. On placera diverses choses sur cet autel, pour les montrer à tout le monde.  --  En composant, on gardera le sens autel. Placé à gauche du caractère, il s'écrira  , qu'il ne faut pas confondre avec le manteau  qui possède un trait supplémentaire.

column11: This key word refers to the polite bows and ceremonious forms of salutation so important in Japanese culture. Its elements: altar . . . fishhook.  -    -  Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away.  -  You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.
column12: Ce mot-clé est directement relié aux diverses formes de politesse, ou plus exactement de « respect du code social » si important dans la tradition japonaise. En premier lieu, on trouve le salut, la « courbette ». Les compo­sants sont autel...hameçon.   --

column11: Altar . . . sheep.  -    -  Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering.  -  On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.
column12: Le mot-clé suggère un animal donné en offrande aux dieux : autel...mouton.   --

column11: Altar . . . teenager.  -    -  It´s a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We´ll all celebrate when that part is over!  -  When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.
column12: Autel...adolescent. Pensez à une communion solennelle.  --

column11: Altar . . . wealth.  -    -  This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you´re called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah.  -  Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.).
column12: La meilleure façon de connaître le bonheur est d'atteindre la paix spirituelle et l'aisance matérielle. C'est ce que figure bien ce kanji, qui associe l'autel où trouver la première, et l'abondance promise par la seconde.  --

column11: Altar . . . footprint.  -    -  And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others.  -  Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.
column12: Autel...arrêt. Pourquoi ne pas voir ici un avatar du jour du Seigneur, durant lequel on savoure le bien-être d'une journée chômée, après une semaine de dur labeur.  --

column6: god of the soil and altars to him; group of families; company, society
column11: Altar . . . soil. The company referred to here is that of the modern business world.  -    -  When you enter a Japanese company it´s like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.  -  Some Japanese companies, including Toyota, have a Shinto shrine on their grounds to bring luck and prosperity to the company and its employees.
column12: Autel...terre. Le temple shintoïste (religion originelle des Japonais) peut être vu comme le trait d'union entre la terre et le Ciel que constitue l'autel. Ce qui est moins clair, ou peut-être qui éclaire tout, est le sens secondaire de ce kanji : la Compagnie, véritable pivot unissant l'industrie et la société japonaise.  --

column11: Altar . . . see.  -    -  The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a "visual once over" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?).  -  [inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 show (#1086) and someone else 見 see (#57).
column12: Autel...voir. Une équipe de bonzes se penche sur le tronc qu’ils ont déposé sur leur autel afin d’inspecter du regard la recette².  --  ² Père jésuite, Luís Fróis se montre d'une férocité sans borne à l'égard des bonzes dans son Traité : « Nos ouailles appartiennent tous à une même paroisse et non à quelque prêtre en particulier ; les bonzes les répartissent entre eux, pour que chacun puisse se faire nourrir par ceux dont il a la charge. » (Traité de Luís Fróis)

column11: We choose the city of Nara as the key word in this case because this kanji, frequently used in proper names, appears in Nara; and also because of Nara's famed religious monuments, which help us with the primitives: St. Bernard dog . . . altar.  -    -  It´s beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!  -  Nara is just a big show for tourists.
column12: Nous choisissons Nara en guise de mot-clé, car ce kanji, essentiellement utilisé dans les noms propres, apparaît dans le nom de cette ville. De plus Nara est célèbre pour son grand Bouddha qu'y abrite le plus grand bâtiment de bois du monde, en accord avec les composants grand...autel.  --

column11: Flag . . . altar . . . glue.  -    -  Of course it had to be the military officer’s idea to glue a national flag to the altar he’s stationed at.  -  Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground.
column12: L’officier militaire donne ses ordres, les fesses collées sur son autel, et il n’en décollera pas.  --

column11: Military officer . . . heart.  -    -  A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.  -  This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II "comfort women" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.).
column12: Officier...sentiments. Cet officier tente de réconforter les jeunes recrues.  --

column11: Samurai . . . altar . . . yawning.  -    -  Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!  -  For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings.
column12: Vieux professeur...autel...bâiller. Ce kanji possède plusieurs sens concernant les relations entre personnes, les échanges financiers ou encore les clauses d'un document. Le vieux professeur sur son autel est en train de bâiller en lisant les clauses d'un contrat.  --

column11: Grove . . . altar.  -    -  Similar to radical tyro´s story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably "no smoking" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).  -  Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol "for sacremental purposes" and share it with his kin (きん).
column12: Si vous associez le bois à la matière, vous obtiendrez une image aisément retenue, les gens d’Eglise ayant préféré depuis longtemps les calices d’or ou vases d’argent à de simples ustensiles qui seraient faits de bois : bois...autel.   --

column11: Cloak . . . prohibition.  -    -  A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing.  -  Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. Blood purists say they´re too muggle.
column12: Habit...interdiction. La nuque doit être découverte, apprend-on ici.  --

column11: House . . . altar.  -    -  I never really did figure out what religion my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an altar in their home.  -  All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are houses where they place their altars.
column12: Maison...autel. Le toit d'une maison abritant un autel, modeste sanctuaire au coin d'une rue ou temple imposant, c'est au Japon le symbole le plus visible de la religion.  --

column11: Mountain . . . religion.  -    -  In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus.  -  I would adore the religious people if they just went and threw themselves off a mountain top.
column12: Montagne...religion. Temples et sanctuaires japonais, comme adoration de nombreux lieux saints en Europe, sont fréquemment situés au sommet des collines.  --

column11: Flesh . . . crotch . . . altar. Note how the second element is cut short, giving a tent-like effect to the character.  -    -  A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.  -  There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.
column12: Chair découpée...main droite...autel. C'est bien à un sacrifice que nous invite ce kanji. Notez la déformation du second élément.  --

column11: "Guess" here has the sense of a measured conjecture. Its elements: house . . . ritual.  -    -  I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.  -  It´s anyone´s guess who´s house she will wake up in the morning after the festival (祭-matsuri)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　サツ　警察　けいさつ(police)…　Pure Group:　擦1104.
column12: Il faut comprendre le mot-clé dans le sens de « conjecture mesurée ». Tentez d'imaginer, à partir des éléments maison...rituel un détective exerçant se talents en intérieur, à l'instar d'un Columbo ou d'un Sherlock.  --

column11: Fingers . . . guess.  -    -  If you mis-guess the cheese you´ll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).  -  Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!).
column12: Doigts...supposition. Le même Columbo se grattant la tête face au délinquant qui refuse d'avouer, voilà qui devrait vous mener à la notion de friction.  --

column10: C’est pourquoi, raison, essence, idée brillante
column11: The "wherefore" of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a rice field sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and wherefore of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the flower appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full seedling.)  -  * As a primitive, in conformity to the explanation above, this kanji will be taken to mean shoot or sprout.  -  Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo? (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet´s dinner plate and rolled off).  -  Cogito ergo sum. Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it´s often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it´s an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.].
column12: Il faut voir dans ce mot-clé la raison ou l’essence des choses. On peut interpréter les sésames, la rizière ou le cerveau d’où dépasse une protubérance, de deux façons différentes, en imaginant d’une part une idée brillante qui germe dans le cerveau d’un individu, ou d’autre part une pousse qui germe au milieu de la rizière. Dans les deux cas, la rizière ou le cerveau forment la raison d’être de cette idée ou de cette petite pousse.  --  L'origine du caractère serait le dessin d'un mortier et de son pilon, avec lesquels on extrait l'essence d'un corps. Notre sésame sera un mortier.

column11: Fingers . . . sprout.  -    -  [When I see the word pluck, I think eyebrows, not vegetables. So, to avoid confusing with pick (#733):] Each time this singular, long, wiry black hair starts to sprout out of my chin again, I pluck it with my fingers.  -  If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).
column12: Doigts...mortier. Il s’agit ici autant d’extraire une matière que l’essence d’une idée.  --

column11: Water . . . sprout.  -    -  The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.  -  In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills.
column12: Liquide...mortier. Ce liquide sortant du mortier est de l’huile.   --

column11: Cloak . . . sprout.  -    -  Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves.  -  The bad magician says, "As you can see, there´s nothing up my sleeves!" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere.
column12: Manteau...mortier. Nos bras ressortent de la manche du vêtement comme le liquide ressort du mortier.  --

column11: House . . . shoot.  -    -  Jack´s beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT.  -  Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there´s a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring "Don´t mind the sprouts!".
column12: Maison...mortier. Le toit de la maison est un symbole du ciel, et le mortier sera la fascinante usine à éléments qui œuvre dans les étoiles les plus lointaines. Tout cela s'unit pour nous offrir notre univers.  --

column11: Flag . . . sprout.  -    -  In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don´t have that in Australia.).  -  A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).
column12: Fesses...mortier. Il s'agit de remettre un colis à destination. Voyez un pressoir mû par l'homme, d'où sort le liquide à mesure que l'ouvrier en actionne la manivelle.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . sprout.  -    -  Flute is made of bamboo sprout.  -  You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.
column12: Bambou...raison. Faite en bambou, la flûte est la raison qui explique sa musique harmonieuse.  --

column11: Car . . . shoot.  -    -  The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.  -  An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car´s wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.
column12: Voiture...raison. L'axe est en substance la raison d'être de tout véhicule.  --

column11: This kanji reverses the element for sprout, giving the image of roots being sent down into the earth by a seed planted in the rice field. From there you must invent a connection to the keyword, armor.  -  * The primitive meaning is roots. Important to that word is the image of "pushing downwards," as roots do.  -  Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai´s armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.  -  It looks like a bird´s eye view of a tank (modern armor).
column12: Ce kanji montre la forme inversée de la pousse, avec une racine poussant vers le sol. Mais ce sol est formé d'une solide croûte, formant une carapace sur laquelle butent les racines.  --

column6: mortgage, pledge; deposit; to pawn; to arrest, detain, guard
column11: Fingers . . . roots. Compare and contrast with pluck (Frame 1187).  -    -  Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling.  -  Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down.
column12: Doigt...carapace. Notez le contraste avec extraire, vu un peu plus haut. Ici, c'est le sens propre qu'il faut voir.  --

column11: Like the cape (Frame 164) and the promontory (Frame 840), the headland refers to a jut of land. Its elements: mountain . . . roots.  -    -  A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!).  -  Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).
column12: L’avancée de terre est une montagne formant carapace contre les assauts de la mer.  --

column11: Fingers . . . thousand . . . roots. Observe how the writing order does not follow the elements in order, because the final stroke is used for two different elements.  -    -  A rice farmer´s delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.  -  Imagine a crazy japanese hentai: multiple fingers and thousand of root-like tentacles are inserting themselves in... well, I think you can fill the rest.
column12: L'union fait la force : ici, mille doigts s'insèrent dans la carapace. Alors qu'en 1204, un seul doigt ne pouvait qu'appuyer, ici ils parviennent à s'insérer.  --

column6: to state to a superior, report; extend; ninth earthly branch
column10: Je vous dis, signe du singe
column11: The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb "to speak." It is written by a tongue wagging in the mouth with a walking stick rammed through it and coming out at both ends.  -  * While this kanji has obvious affinities to the "seed" group, it also happens to be the zodiacal sign of the monkey (the one who speaketh no evil, among other things). We shall therefore take monkey as its primitive meaning.  -  I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.  -  I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 sayeth (#578). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X speaking.".
column12: Ayant rapport avec la parole, on trouvera normal de trouver la bouche et sa langue en mouvement au sein de ce kanji. La canne nous force à rester bien droit lorsque nous nous adressons avec respect à notre interlocuteur. Ce kanji est également le signe du singe dans le zodiaque chinois. N'en déplaise à mes amis japonais, j'ai pendant longtemps eu l'impression qu'ils « parlent en faisant des singeries » lorsqu'ils emploient les phrases par trop polies et inutilement respectueuses, du moins aux yeux du débutant, que l'on pourrait après tout symboliser par ce kanji. Mais bien qu'ils m'aient exaspéré quelque temps, cela m'a permis d'établir une relation entre singe et je vous dis. Merci encore ! Singe ou je vous dis seront donc nos sésames.  --

column6: extend, stretch out, open up; trust
column11: Person . . . monkey.  -    -  Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.  -  A person expands into an ape man. I swear this is the only time I'll use Dragon Ball, but think of Goku expanding into that Saiyajin giant ape beast.
column12: Tintin...singe. Le mot-clé est notamment lié à la nature élastique des corps. En pratique, le singe s’étire ici pour atteindre la même longueur que Tintin.   --

column11: Altar . . . monkey.  -    -  The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus´ latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .  -  Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.
column12: Autel...je vous dis. Même Jacques Prévert vouvoyait les divinités : « Notre père qui êtes aux Cieux, restez-y... »  --

column11: Fingers . . . monkey . . . crotch.  -    -  The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.  -  If you are familiar with the Monkey legends (西遊記 Journey to the West) there is a good image for this character: While searching for the end of the universe, monkey reaches to his crotch and urinates on Buddha´s fingers. (Update: new link http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RYXFppaKLL4).
column12: Pour nous aider à retrouver un objet qui a disparu, nous nous aidons ici des doigts de la main droite du singe.   --

column10: Fruit, but est atteint, porter ses fruits
column11: The final stage of the seed is reached when the plant has reached its full growth (the tree) and comes to fruition, producing fruit full of new seeds that can return to the earth and start the process all over again. The main thing to notice here is the element for brains at the top, which might prove more helpful than rice field for creating an image. The writing, however, follows the order of a sun with a tree whose trunk runs through the sun.  -    -  If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.  -  Eve ate fruit from the tree and knowledge filled her brain.…　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　果汁　かじゅう (fruit juice)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group:　菓1122　課1123　(ﾗ): 裸1124.
column12: Le cerveau placé au sommet de cet arbre veut symboliser le fruit, qui contient, dans la graine placée en son centre, l’ensemble des informations pour donner un nouvel arbre : la boucle est bouclée, et le but est atteint. Pour comprendre ce second sens, pensez à « porter ses fruits ».   --

column11: Flowers . . . fruits.  -    -  This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit.  -  Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.
column12: Végétaux...fruit. On choisit les meilleurs végétaux et les meilleurs fruits pour confectionner les meilleures friandises.  --

column11: Words . . . fruit.  -    -  After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I´ve learned. (Thanks Misha!).  -  Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It´s good to disambiguate the keyword from paragraph (#82). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy´s "War and Peace" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you´d very quickly run out of fruit).
column12: Des mots fructueux sont prononcés pendant la leçon.  --

column11: Cloak . . . fruit.  -    -  Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak.  -  Hey honey, I´m naked underneath this cloak. I´ve got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don´t you want to taste my forbidden fruits...?
column12: Le fruit  nu est déjà couvert de son plus beau manteau : sa propre peau.  --

column6: a catty (approximately 600 g); an axe; keen, shrewd; Kangxi radical 69
column11: This character represents a picture of an ax, the two vertical lines being the handle and the horizontal strokes of the blade. Note the writing order carefully.  -    -  Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.  -  The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).
column12: Ce caractère est l’image d’une hache, Les deux premiers traits en repré­sentent le manche, et les deux seconds la lame. Notez bien l’ordre des traits.  --  Cette hache pèse exactement 600g.

column11: Tree . . . ax.  -    -  We chop down trees with axes to analyze their rings.  -  Wood + axe = chop? how much more simple can it get?
column12: Ce kanji nous propose d’analyser l’âge de cet arbre, en le hachant (sens premier) et en comptant le nombre de lignes de croissance.  --

column11: Ax . . . road. Be careful not to confuse with draw near (Frame 204) or bystander (Frame 1090).  -    -  The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...  -  An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.
column12: En 305, , vous étiez un farouche terroriste écologiste. Le danger s’approche ici, sur la route jusqu’au plus près de vous, et cette fois vous sortez la hache.   --

column11: Door . . . ax.  -    -  You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.  -  A place for everything and everything in its place. To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.
column12: Ce lieu pourrait être votre logis, où, juste derrière la porte, vous venez de ranger la hache.  --

column11: Altar . . . ax.  -    -  Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe.  -  A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready.
column12: Autel...hache. Un des premiers soucis des explorateurs découvrant le nouveau monde fut de faire dire une messe sur les territoires nouvellement découverts. En moins de temps qu’il n’en faut pour le dire, ils construisirent un autel à coups de hache, pour pouvoir prier; puis commencer la mise à sac.  --

column10: Plier, s'écarter du droit chemin, tournant, diffracte
column11: Fingers . . . ax. Hint: make an image out of the Japanese art of "origami" (paper-folding).  -    -  It´s the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they´re not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.  -  Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It´s even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!
column12: Ce kanji contient l’idée de plier, ainsi que celle, voisine, de s’écarter du droit chemin, comme on le fait en tournant à droite ou à gauche, comme le fait la lumière qui diffracte, ou plus prosaïquement comme le fait un doigt qui aurait « croisé » une hache.   --

column11: Fold . . . mouth.  -    -  A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.  -  I fold my mouth, therefore I am.
column12: Le philosophe est ici un « contorsionniste de la parole » : plier...bouche.   --

column11: The connotation is of a "dearly departed" who has passed away. The elements: fold . . . road.  -    -  One of the dearest of Japan´s dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes.  -  The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the roads folded (from the earthquake).
column12: Ce défunt a « tout plié » et a pris la route.  --

column11: Fold . . . words.  -    -  This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the folded words are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive "fold".  -  A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.
column12: Jurer revient à écrire quelques mots sur un papier qu'on plie et qui contient notre serment.  --

column11: Chop off . . . days.  -    -  Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.  -  Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.
column12: Décapiter...journée. Ce certain temps définit une durée variable, de quelques secondes à quelques mois. S'élucide ici le certain temps que le condamné devra attendre l'exécution de son jugement, et qui se compte en journées.  --

column11: Water . . . chop off.  -    -  I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.  -  Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.
column12: Eau...décapiter. Il est passé bien de l'eau sous les ponts, graduellement le juge s'est forgé une opinion, et finalement le jugement de décapitation a été prononcé. Ce caractère étrange signifie à la fois finalement et graduellement.  --

column11: Fishhook . . . rice . . . ax.  -    -  [Based on fuaburisu´s] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths.  -  When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.
column12: Le sens de décision est aussi inclus. Rien d'étonnant à cela, une décision n'étant après tout qu'un refus qu'il en aille autrement que comme on l'a décidé. Le caractère l'illustre en faisant voir l'hameçon décider de soulever le grain de riz, mais refuser de soulever la lourde hache. Cette image ambivalente sera reprise ultérieurement.  --

column11: Two axes . . . shells.  -    -  What is this substance on this clam? I´ve already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).  -  Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don´t like clams).
column12: Deux haches...huître. Il y a quelques années parut dans les journaux un fait divers dont le héros était un ostréiculteur exacerbé de voir une partie de son élevage régulièrement volé et vendu par un indélicat. Notre homme eut alors l'idée d'ouvrir quelques unes de ses huîtres, de les vider de leur substance pour la remplacer par un papier sur lequel était écrit en substance : « Veuillez m'appeler d'urgence, c'est au sujet d'un vol - forte récompense », puis de rejeter dans le parc à huîtres les animaux piégés. Un client coopératif lui permit de remonter la filière parallèle et de confondre le malfrat. De ce fait divers, retenez que l'huître salvatrice a été ouverte deux fois, par deux « haches » différentes, et que le mot-clé substance se comprend ici au sens matériel ou spirituel.  --

column11: Ax . . . a drop of.  -    -  The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?  -  The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there´s one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.
column12: La hache  rejette goutte à goutte les morceaux de l’aubier.  --

column11: Words . . . reject.  -    -  I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.  -  Words that make you feel rejected.
column12: Mots...rejeter. Porter plainte est une façon de rejeter, ou refuser, les arguments d’autrui.  --

column11: Day . . . saw.  -    -  One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.  -  Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away...
column12: Jour...scié. Voyez votre agenda, dont vous sciez consciencieusement le coin de chaque feuillet à chaque jour qui passe, à chaque fois que « aujourd’hui » devient « hier ».   --

column6: cheat, defraud, swindle; trick; to feign
column11: The lie in this character refers to falsehoods and fibs. Its elements: words . . . saw.  -    -  Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.  -  Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.
column12: Mots...scié. Quand on nous trompe par de belles paroles, ne dit-on pas que « les bras nous en tombent » ou qu'en un mot, on est « scié » ?  --

column6: make; work; compose, write; act, perform
column11: Person . . . saw.  -    -  Mr T.´s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he´s a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.  -  When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, "I don´t know about y´all foos, but I´m gonna make a raft.".
column12: Tintín fabrique un objet avec une scie.   --

column11: Rain that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a broom is snow.  -    -  SNOW isn´t all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.  -  Rain just soaks into the soil. Snow has to be swept away with a broom...　RTK2:　セツ　積雪　せきせつ(pilled up snow).
column12: Si on doit balayer après une forte précipitation, c’est qu’il a neigé.   --

column11: Metal . . . broom . . . rice. Note how the final stroke of the broom is extended slightly when an element below is attached directly to it.  -    -  A monk won a gold metal for breaking the current record for most swept rice in one minute.  -  This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.
column12: Métal...balai...irrigation. On verra là une de ces boîtes à musique dont les Japonais raffolent. Le son est produit par de vibrantes lames métalliques balayant le cylindre, et les notes s'écoulent en une mélodie aussi douce que celle d'un ruisseau d'irrigation.  --

column11: Broom . . . craft . . . mouth . . . glue.  -    -  The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.).  -  As a verb this means, this means "to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire.
column12: Collée à son balai, la concierge travaille de la bouche quand vous la questionnez. Mais si vous tentez d'entrer dans l'immeuble, elle se change en un redoutable cerbère, et vous ne voyez bientôt plus que sa large envergure en travers du couloir. Envergure est le second sens de cet étonnant kanji.  --

column11: Bound up . . . broom . . . heart.  -    -  She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow.  -  Fantasia: Bound up brooms out of control send Mickey´s heart racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!
column12: Empaqueté...balais...sentiments. Une façon de « mettre les balais dou­bles ».  --

column11: Person . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch. Gather the elements on the right into a composite image that can serve you in the next two frames.  -    -  Mr T. ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little BROOM, dainty TIARA and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (CROTCH)!  -  Mr T. hits a condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch) over the head with a broom because the dude ENCROACHed Mr. T´s privates area during the sale.
column12: Tintín...balai...couronne...main droite. Pour vous représenter une image de cette instrusion, imaginez un stakhanoviste du nettoyage, tentant sans cesse de reprendre le balai des mains droites d'autrui.   --  En composant, seule la partie de droite est utilisée.

column11: Water . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch.  -    -  The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!).  -  After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water.
column12: Eau...intrusion. Tout corps immergé laissera l'eau faire intrusion en lui, comme dans les soutes du Titanic par exemple.  --

column11: Do not confuse this key word with either the element for reclining or the character for prostrated (Frame 1035). Its primitive elements are: house . . . turtle . . . broom . . . crown . . . crotch.  -    -  After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he´s sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!).  -  After being hit on the head encroach (#1148), the condom salesman goes back to his house to lie down. He hasn´t made a single sale today, so he doesn´t have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet turtle and cries himself to sleep.
column12: Maison...madrier...intrusion. À l'heure du coucher, on fait intrusion dans la maison et on s'étend sur le lit fait de solides madriers.  --

column11: Woman . . . broom . . . apron.  -    -  In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron.  -  The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who´s a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?).
column12: Femme...balai...tablier. Autant d'éléments qui ne sont guère prometteurs, encore conformes à une réalité nippone qui n'évolue que lentement.  --

column11: Fingers . . . broom . . . apron.  -    -  Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.  -  FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor.
column12: Doigts (main)...balai...tablier. Balai en mains et ceint d'un tablier, vous voilà prêt à chasser la poussière !  --

column11: Little . . . broom.  -    -  Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.  -  Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, "Whoa, really?! (本当?!)".
column12: L'idée de frapper au bon endroit, ou viser juste, ou correspondre, est rendue par ce kanji dont les composants sont : petit...balai. On a coutume en France de ranger le balai derrière la porte, où il subsiste en général un espace suffisant, d'environ dix centimètres. Même coutume au Japon, où ne subsiste qu'un espace d'environ deux centimètres et demi. Diable, comment font-ils ?
