Une fois encore, la technique japonaise est au rendez-vous, car le balai, épais de deux centimètres, laisse encore ce qu'il faut de place pour accrocher le calendrier. Cette image, aussi niaise que frappante n'est pas si ridicule, car c'est peut-être par ce genre de détails dérisoires que le Japon a su frapper juste et bâtir sa prospérité et sa réputation. Ajoutons pour finir que l'étonnement qui peut-être vous frappera à la lecture de cette histoire est rendu par un mot japonais très courant où il apparaît : .  --

column11: Bound up . . . rake.  -    -  This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.  -  A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.
column12: Emballage...râteau. Imaginez simplement une joute à coups de râteaux.  --

column11: Water . . . contend.  -    -  Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.  -  The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.
column12: Eau...querelle. Vous pouvez imaginer des lavandières au verbe haut, comme les décrivit Zola par exemple.  --

column6: affair, matter, business; to serve; accident, incident
column11: This key word here refers to abstract matters. The elements are: one . . . mouth . . . rake. Note how the rake handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.  -    -  I had to take one day off from work due to ´personal matters´ after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn´t going to tell anyone about it.  -  Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.
column12: Les faits concrets et abstraits sont définis par : un...bouche...râteau. Si vous pratiquez le japonais à l'oral comme à l'écrit, vous prononcez déjà ce kanji trois ou quatre fois par phrase.  --

column11: The key word here refers of course to the T'ang Dynasty in China (and not to the name of the drink astronauts take with them into outer space, though this could be useful for the next frame). Its elements: cave . . . rake . . . mouth.  -    -  Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, "What about this – T´ang, do you think?" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, "Yes, it does tang a bit".  -  Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it´s tasty or not.
column12: Foin d'anachronisme, établissons une corrélation entre l'armée de terre cuite découverte en 1974 en Chine et ce kanji qui désigne la dynastie Tang (618-907). Appentis évoquera alors les fouilles lors desquelles cette armée fut mise au jour, le râteau sera l'outil des archéologues, et les bouches seront celles des soldats et chevaux délivrés de leur prison de terre : armée de terre cuite sera notre sésame.  --

column11: Rice . . . T'ang.  -    -  Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.  -  The T´ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice.
column12: Riz...armée de terre cuite. On ne sait trop ce qui a présidé à la construction de cette armée de terre cuite, regroupant plusieurs milliers de soldats et de chevaux grandeur nature, mais il n’est pas impensable que quelque politicien se soit « sucré » au passage, en détournant à son avantage quelques sacs de riz destinés à l’alimentation des sculpteurs.  --

column11: Cave . . . sieve.  -    -  People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).  -  A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).
column12: Appentis...tamis. On imaginera une sorte de « père tranquille », tamisant diverses choses au fond de son appentis.  --

column11: Think of apprehending criminals. The elements are: sieve . . . road.  -    -  Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.  -  In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying "Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!".
column12: Pensez à appréhender un criminel : route...tamis.   --

column6: third person pronoun; he, she, this, that
column11: Used chiefly in proper names, and given the sound "i," this kanji can be remembered as an abbreviation of Italy, for which it is still used today in Japan. Its primitives: person . . . mop.  -    -  The "boot" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?  -  Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy).
column12: Ce kanji n’est pratiquement plus utilisé de nos jours que dans certains noms propres, dans lesquels il porte le son « i », ce qui en a fait depuis longtemps le symbole de l’Italie. On pourrait donc voir Tintin dans la peau d’un gondolier vénitien, utilisant en guise de rame un simple lave-pont.   --

column11: The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: mop . . . mouth.  -    -  There´s a tendancy in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well old boy," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago".  -  The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.
column12: Ce kanji est utilisé pour s’adresser à son subordonné, comme le ferait le capitaine envers le mousse : lave-pont...bouche.   --

column11: Old boys . . . sheep.  -    -  Good ol´ boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.  -  A little girl herder calls out, "羊君、きて！" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once.
column12: La notion de troupeau concerne diverses choses, telles que les poissons, les oiseaux, les îles, et évidemment le cheptel... Le jeune homme garde ici son troupeau de moutons.   --

column11: The key word is a suffix used to indicate "safe from" or "protected against," as in the words rustproof, waterproof, and fireproof. It is composed of: comb . . . glue.  -    -  [akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.  -  I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.
column12: L’idée contenue dans le mot-clé est la résistance à diverses contraintes. On peut voir un bataillon de puces à l’épreuve du peigne, car elles se sont enduites de forte colle, et s’accrochent aux cheveux.  --

column11: The sense of demand is best captured by thinking of the economic principle of "supply and demand." The primitives: rain . . . comb.  -    -  Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair.  -  If it´s raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop.
column12: Le concept de demande sera compris au travers du principe de « l’offre et la demande », et l’on imaginera une foule demandant à être approvisionnée en peignes « comme s’il en pleuvait », probablement pour régler leur compte aux puces du cadre précédent. Ne mettez pas de colle ici, ou faites une autre histoire si vous craignez la moindre confusion.  --

column11: Person . . . demand.  -    -  No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it´s raining combs!".  -  One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, "You will find happiness with a new love".
column12: Les écrits laissés par les disciples de Maître Kong,  au Japon, qui n'avait laissé que des témoignages oraux, font encore aujourd'hui l'objet d'une forte demande, si l'on en juge par le nombre d'ouvrages traitant de sa pensée publiés régulièrement au Japon. D'ailleurs, à chacun de ses passages au pays du Soleil-Levant, Tintin en demande un exemplaire à sa libraire.  --

column11: Vase . . . mountain . . . comb.  -    -  Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn´t seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.  -  When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the mountain (#768) kanji.
column12: Vase...montagne...peigne. Comme le vase est rarement placé seul à gauche, il est bon d’insérer ce détail dans l’image. Voyez par exemple un vase placé tellement au bord de la montagne qu’il est en train de tomber, en chute libre. Au bas de la montagne, le peigne nous permet de ramasser les morceaux.  --

column6: two, both, pair, couple; a tael, ounce
column11: Ceiling . . . belt . . .  mountain. Note that the writing order follows the order in which the primitives are given here.  -    -  Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.  -  Both of Tiger Wood´s initials is the logo on his belt... 　　　　　　　　RTK2:　リョウ　両親　りょうしん(one´s parents).
column12: Clou...ceinture...poubelle. Notons que l'ordre d'écriture suit celui dans lequel les composants sont donnés, mais qu'il est possible de retenir ce caractère en remarquant sa symétrie par rapport à l'axe vertical et en imaginant une sorte de pantin articulé en carton suspendu au plafond. Tirez sur la ficelle et voyez comment se baissent les deux bras et se lèvent les deux jambes.  --

column11: Water . . . flowers . . . both. Given the abstract nature of this last primitive, you may want to borrow the image from the previous frame.  -    -  Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.  -  I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I´m afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.
column12: Eau...végétaux...les deux. Pour correctement remplir votre vase, il vous faudra un bouquet et de l'eau, les deux.  --

column6: a painting, picture, drawing; to draw
column10: Trait de pinceau, dessin, écran, compteur des traits
column11: In forming an image for the key word, it is helpful to know that this kanji is used for artistic representations (like a completed painting), and as a counter for the number of brush-strokes in a character (as, for instance, in Indexes II and III at the end of this book). Its elements are: ceiling . . . sprout . . . shovel.  -    -  You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.  -  To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb´s].
column12: À trait de pinceau sont associés dessin et écran, de télévision ou de cinéma. Ce dernier sens est fort utile car en retournant le kanji on découvre une télévision, sous la forme d'un ordinateur sans clavier mais avec un joli pied, et recouvert d'un beau capot, notre poubelle. Trait de pinceau est aussi le compteur des traits des kanjis.  --

column6: teeth; gears, cogs; age; a form of Kangxi radical 211
column11: Footprint . . . rice . . . shovel.  -    -  Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you´ll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.  -  My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.
column12: Arrêt...poubelle...riz. Arrêter les aliments et faire le tri du riz quotidien, telle est bien la double fonction de la dentition.  --

column10: Courber, morceau de musique, courbes musicale, courbes
column11: Picture yourself grabbing hold of the two strokes poking out the top of the kanji and wrenching them apart, thus giving the sense of bend. If you think of them as deriving from the element for brains beneath (of course, the middle stroke has been reduplicated and pulled out to where it can be grabbed hold of), you can associate the key word with bending someone's mind to your own point of view.  -    -  It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening´s animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.  -  Also means "melody". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody.
column12: Imaginez-vous accroché aux deux barres dépassant au sommet de ce kanji, et tentant de les courber. Morceau de musique est son autre sens : laissons-nous bercer par les courbes musicales, en laissant aux irréductibles le soin d'établir une corrélation à base de courbes sinusoïdales.  --

column11: This character is written in the order of its elements: one . . . bend . . . sun.  -    -  A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).  -  Bender lasted just one day in the space cadets.
column12: Un...courbé...langue qui s'agite. Cet exécutant réalise les tâches pour lesquelles il a été formé, habituellement dans le domaine militaire ou juridique. Le kanji montre le caractère univoque de son activité, au cours de laquelle l'homme se courbe pour suivre l'enseignement reçu, représenté ici par la langue qui s'agite.  --

column11: Cadet . . . road.  -    -  Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.  -  Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an "encounter of the third kind" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg´s 1977 movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO´s while driving on the road.
column12: Route...exécutant. Notre exécutant voit ici son action contrariée par un obstacle croisé en chemin.  --

column11: Water . . . cadet.  -    -  Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he´s very afraid of water (Bender is a robot).  -  The space cadet is in training, rowing in the water (see it splash).
column12: Eau...exécutant. Le travail de l'exécutant est répétitif, comme l'est le mouvement de la rame dans l'eau.  --

column6: trough; manger; vat, tank; groove; a distillery
column11: Tree . . . cadet.  -    -  Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example).  -  Bender the Cadet (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a tree, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69.
column12: Bois...exécutant. Cette cuve est faite en bois, et elle exécute son œuvre avec constance, s'appliquant à conserver tout le liquide qui lui est fourni.  --

column6: a dipper; unit of volume (ten 升 or litres); Kangxi radical 68; 8th lunar mansion, determinative star φ Sagittarii
column11: The Big Dipper here is of course the constellation of Ursa Major, of which this kanji is a sort of pictographic representation.  -  * Since we already have a primitive element for a "dipper" - namely, the ladle - we shall let this one stand for a measuring cup. By the way, it would make a rather large one, since the kanji is also used for a measure of about 18 liters!  -  Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.  -  Is it just me, or do all of these traditional kanji pictographs look like they were drawn by a retarded bunny rabbit?
column12: Cette grande casserole définit la constellation de la grande ourse, dont on peut voir là une représentation.  --  Elle est en fait très grande, puisque qu'elle représente une unité de mesure de 18,039 1, dont nous connaissons déjà les multiple et sous-multiple.

column11: Measuring cup . . . rice.  -    -  When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don´t just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.  -  Samurai(s) once received their fee in the form of rice that had been carefully weighed in a measuring cup beforehand.
column12: La recette du riz est simple : il faut du riz et une grande casserole. Le double sens du mot recette en français existe exactement de la même manière en japonais.  --

column11: Think here of the faculty or department you entered in university, using the elements: measuring cup . . . wheat.  -    -  The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.  -  Agriculture/astronomy departments...　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　カ　科学　かがく (science).
column12: Blé...grande casserole. Les tarifs exorbitants pratiqués par les universités japonaises tombent à point nommé pour établir une liaison entre le tracé et le sens de ce kanji qui définit aussi le concept de science.   --

column11: Pent in . . . Big Dipper. Hint: among the songs dating from the days of slavery that have become part of American folklore is one called "Follow the Drinking Gourd." It referred to the nighttime travel of runaway slaves (those pent in) who had no maps other than the stars to guide them, among them the bright and predominant Big Dipper, the "Drinking Gourd."  -    -  Can´t see direct relation to Big Dipper (#1177) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it´s written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.  -  A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do.
column12: Encadré...grande casserole. On retiendra le sens de étoile polaire dans le second composant, avec son sens de nord. Moyennant quoi on obtient exactement une carte japonaise, qui indique systématiquement la direction du nord, mais omet tout aussi systématiquement l’échelle.  --

column11: Meat . . . walking stick. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for use (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.  -  * As a primitive element, we shall substitute the image of a screwdriver, perhaps the most utilized of all tools around the house.  -  To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!  -  I´ll confuse this with use (#1065), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize "utilize" when you´re trying to puff up what you´re saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!" I´m seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.
column12: Viande...bâton de marche. L’ordre des traits est dicté par celui des com­posants.  --  En composant, on utilisera parfois le sens de tournevis, l'outil dont on se sert le plus pour les petites réparations domestiques.

column11: Cave . . . rake . . . screwdriver.  -    -  To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.  -  When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see bed (#592)). But now I´ve settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable.
column12: Appentis...râteau...se servir de. Dans l'appentis, sont entreposés des râteaux et autres outils, dont tout le monde peut se servir. Cela correspond exactement au sens originel de l'adjectif banal. Le trait vertical se trace en dernier.  --

column11: Person . . . flowers . . . cliff . . . screwdriver. In cases like this you can jumble up the primitive into any order that seems best for the composition of a story, provided you feel confident about the relative position that those primitives take to one another in the completed character.  -    -  Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.  -  An RPG where you´re using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.
column12: Mettez Tintin dans la peau d’un alpiniste tatillon, et vous le verrez bientôt, pour équiper une nouvelle voie, arracher toutes les mauvaises herbes à l’aide de son tournevis pour les rejeter en haut de la falaise.   --  Chapitre trente et un  Reconstruction   LES six composants présentés dans de ce chapitre se verront attribuer des significations parfois sans rapport direct avec la réalité de l'étymologie. Cela ne gêne en rien la compréhension des kanjis dans lesquels ils interviennent, à tel point que les sens de salade, complexe souterrain, meule de foin, homme de paille, quart et augmentation rapide finiront par vous paraître assez vraisemblables.

column11: Salad . . . days. This is the character with which Japanese fairytales commonly begin.  -    -  Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.  -  For those who don´t know the expression, "salad days" means the time of one´s youth. (originally from Shakespeare´s Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose "salad" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...
column12: Salade...(un) jour. Une salade assaisonnée la veille est tellement flétrie qu’on a l’impression qu’elle date d’autrefois.   --

column11: Metal . . . once upon a time.  -    -  A long time ago, people of the world got confused because there were so many kinds of Metal coins. today we only have the euro.  -  Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.).
column12: Or...autrefois. On fera de préférence une image basée sur les alchimis­tes d'autrefois, compte tenu du fait que ce kanji définit aussi la notion de complexe, au sens chimique du terme. L’or, dont la « synthèse » était un but des alchimistes, peut être dissout par certains sels dits « complexes ».   --

column11: Person . . . once upon a time.  -    -  Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won´t give it back. "This be mine now, foo!".  -  Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won´t give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.
column12: Vous n’avez pas revu Tintin depuis autrefois : rien que de très normal, puisque vous ayant emprunté quelque argent, il cherche à vous éviter.  --

column11: State of mind . . . once upon a time. The sense of the key word is that of a lost opportunity or bad turn of affairs, as in the phrase "What a pity!"  -    -  What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.  -  Data says "What a pity" when he hears that once upon a time there were no robots.
column12: Repensant à autrefois, on se dit : « Quel dommage ! ».  --

column11: Fingers . . . once upon a time.  -    -  Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it´s 昔 once upon a time (#1184) rather than 旧 olden times (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.).  -  Once upon a time... Oh hell, you´re just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers.
column12: Doigts...autrefois. De la main, nous remettons en place chaque objet, comme nous le dicte la coutume établie depuis autrefois.  --

column11: Salad . . . flesh . . taskmaster.  -    -  The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she´s served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up.  -  Perhaps you´ve heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. Scatter salad over the flesh of the taskmaster in preperation for some nantaimori :).
column12: Le chef de corvée disperse. la salade et des bouts de viande, et toute la basse-cour d'accourir !  --

column11: The two tens joined at the bottom by a short line is actually the old character for twenty, which we might as well learn since we need its primitive form. It is written the same as salad, except for the shorter final stroke.  -    -  A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.  -  Ten plus ten is twenty (see generation (#28)).
column12: Les deux dix joints à la base (par une barre d’addition) représentent le kanji vingt, que nous apprenons au passage, puisque nous avons besoin de cette forme en tant que composant. Notons de même que la boucle de la ceinture vue en 455  est une autre façon d’écrire trente.   --

column11: Caverns . . . oven fire.  -    -  Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.  -  If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.
column12: Le peuple peut être vu comme cette masse qui s’enfourne quotidiennement dans les complexes souterrains.   --

column11: Commoner . . . road.  -    -  The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!  -  If don´t want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road.
column12: Peuple...route. Ce kanji contient l’idée de « barrer le passage ».  --

column11: Caverns . . . towel.  -    -  Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).  -  You´re tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there´s no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).
column12: Dans le complexe souterrain, on fait d’une simple serviette un siège sur lequel se reposer.  --

column11: This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: caverns . . . crotch.  -    -  The cavern refugees are so poor that they can´t afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs...  -  The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.
column12: Dans le complexe souterrain, la main droite sur la main courante de l’escalier roulant, on descent d’un degré supplémentaire vers les entrailles de la ville, et à chaque fois la température s’élève d’un degré.   --

column11: Water . . . degrees.  -    -  This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it´s not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.  -  The transit system in Tokyo is one of the best in the wrold, but why is it that when it is 35 degrees outside, it is about 2 degrees on the train? Or when it is 2 degrees outside, it is 35 degrees inside the train. This degree of difference means I am always sweating then getting the chills! I think I caught a fever!
column12: Eau...degré. Au contraire de transmettre qui implique un non-transport de matière, ce kanji renferme l’idée de « passage de matière d’un point à un autre ».  --

column6: run fast, flee; rush about; run
column11: The hustle and bustle of this character is depicted by a St. Bernard dog and a haystack.  -    -  Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.  -  A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here´s a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.
column12: L'agitation et la précipitation sont rendues par un grand personnage ouvrant largement bras et jambes sur une meule de foin.  --

column11: Mouth . . . haystack . . . clams.  -    -  History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.  -  A bit nasty (but makes the whole thing much easier to remember) is to take the right side and call it a bearded clam. For erupt, you can make your own story about the mouth/opening on the left.
column12: Bouche...meule de foin...huîtres. Il faut ici voir quelque chose sortir avec violence, comme dans un volcan ou un jet d’eau. La bouche montre l’orifice de sortie, et il faut imaginer dans le composant de droite un magma d'huîtres enterrées sous une meule de foin, prêtes à s’échapper sous l’effet de la pression. Gardez cette image pour les deux cadres suivants.  --

column11: Soil . . . haystack . . . clams. In order not to confuse this kanji with that for a grave (Frame 246), something like the image of an Egyptian tomb should be adopted, with all its special connotations.  -    -  After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.  -  Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money.
column12: Terre...huîtres sous la meule de foin. Vous remplacez dans votre atelier imaginaire le trou (la bouche) par une grosse motte de terre, et l’ensemble va devenir un tombeau majestueux pour les pauvres animaux.  --

column11: State of mind . . . haystack . . . clams.  -    -  Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn´t seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!  -  Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn´t even notice he was feeling emotion.
column12: Etat d'esprit...huîtres sous la meule de foin.  L’indignation décrite dans ce caractère confine à la colère, comme sans doute vous l’avez ressenti à la vue des éléments.  --

column11: Hearth . . . straw man. Take care to distinguish this kanji from cook (Frame 507) and burn (Frame 549) when you compose your story.  -    -  Ah, there´s no better way to bake a pizza than an oven fueled by a burning strawman. And if you listen carefully, there are stifled strawman screams coming from the kitchen. Think of this image: http://users.mtrx.net/funnypics/content/-rdm1-ABCD1234-rdm1-/2005/2005-08-23-0002/Doughboy.jpg.  -  Too lofty (#2095)尭 a career choice for the strawman becoming a baker. He was fired soon after starting his first shift. Literally!...　　　RTK2:　ショウ　全焼　ぜんしょう(entirely destroyed by fire).
column12: Feu...homme de paille. Lorsque l’on demande du feu à l’homme de paille, il sort son énorme lance-flammes.  --

column11: Sun . . . straw man.  -    -  The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.  -  The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.
column12: Soleil...homme de paille. À l’aube, le soleil intime à l’homme de paille l’ordre de ranger son énorme lance-flammes.  --

column11: Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a little needle - the kind used for splitting hairs in half. (Again, according to rule, little takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.)  -    -  Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.  -  I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.
column12: Bien que l’ordre d’écriture diffère, on peut voir cette forme comme une petite aiguille, semblable à celles que l’on emploie pour séparer les cheveux en deux moitiés. Comme vu précédemment, un trait est ajouté entre les élé­ments petit et aiguille.   --

column11: Person . . . half.  -    -  The person who is your consort is most commonly "your other half".  -  Mr. T wants to splits himself in half so he can be his own CONSORT.
column12: Imaginez deux choses ne pouvant aller l’une sans l’autre, comme ici Tintin, accompagné par son inséparable Milou, sa canine moitié.   --

column11: Rice field . . . half. The key word here refers to the ridges that rise up between the sections of a rice paddy.  -    -  A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.  -  Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that´s how it´s done.
column12: Cette levée de terre est celle qui sépare en deux moitiés les sections d’une rizière.   --

column11: Half . . . saber. You might recall the famous judgment of King Solomon, who offered to slice a baby in two with a saber to give half to each of the mothers who claimed it as her own.  -    -  In the bible, King Solomon´s JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.  -  It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.
column12: Un jugement bien fait ne désavantage ni l’un ni l’autre des parties, ce qui est rendu en français par l’expression « couper la poire en deux » : moitié...sabre.   --

column11: Quarter . . . dagger.  -    -  Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile.  -  In Japan, the JR railway ju-hachi-kippu seasonal discount ticket can be cut into quarters with a dagger and shared with your friends. (its actually sort-of true).
column12: Quart...poignard. Le conservateur du musée ou l'employé de gare découpe votre coupon avec un outil tranchant comme un poignard et en garde un talon gros comme un quart.  --

column10: Enrouler, manuscrit roulé, un volume, un tome
column11: Quarter . . . snake. The key word refers to a manuscript rolled up into a scroll, not to a hanging scroll (Frame 435).  -    -  At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...  -  How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.
column12: Quart...serpent. Ce kanji comprend également la notion de manuscrit roulé, ce sens allant jusqu'à la notion de volume et de tome ; un peu comme en français avec le mot « rôle ».  --

column11: This key word refers to a realm or orbit, not to a ball. Its elements: pent in . . . scroll.  -    -  I associate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.  -  [RPG] You´re fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he´s pent in a sphere of protection.
column12: Enceinte...enrouler. Le mot-clé comprend l’idée de domaine, orbite ou bloc. Pensez à diverses choses « enrôlées » dans un même système.  --

column11: Moon . . . quarter . . . muscle.  -    -  After your VICTORY cut your enemy´s FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.  -  After England´s victory over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his flesh drawn and quartered and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their power.
column12: Une augmentation rapide de la force mène à la victoire.    --

column11: Flower . . . moon . . . quarter . . . rice grains.  -    -  According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon.  -  The wisteria is a type of hanging vine covered with flowers. By the light of the quarter moon, the flowers look like clusters of rice grains.
column12: Végétaux...augmentation rapide...irrigation. La glycine est bien connue pour sa grande vivacité. On la sait capable de tordre les grilles en fer forgé de nos jardins, et on peut voir, au Japon ou au parc du labyrinthe à Barcelone, des glycines centenaires aux troncs noueux couvrant d'énormes surfaces. Les Japonais en font des chaises, tant est grande la résistance du bois de glycine. Nous avons en résumé en présence végétaux...augmentation rapide...irrigation. Ainsi, il suffit d'irriguer la glycine pour en faire une plante à la croissance rapide et à la force démesurée.  --

column11: Moon . . . quarter . . . words.  -    -  Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.  -  As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word "asshole". Don´t forget it´s flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words.
column12: Augmentation rapide...mots. Augmentation rapide de mots. Augmentation rapide de mots. Augmentation rapide de mots. Augmentation rapide de mots. Augmentation rapide de mots. Augmentation rapide de mots...  --

column11: This kanji is based on the pictograph of a tree with some branches going upwards and others hanging down, split right down the middle. When that picture's right side is isolated, it becomes the kanji for one-sided, in the sense of only one part of a whole.  -    -  Fuaburisu´s pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.  -  Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn´t see any trees or branches in there).
column12: Ce kanji est basé sur le pictogramme d’un arbre dont les branches s’élèvent et retombent de chaque côté. Lorsque de cette image, on ne conserve que la partie droite, on obtient le kanji simple face, au sens de « une partie d’un tout », dont nous avons vu l'autre moitié en 254 . Cette moitié est plus fine que la moitié gauche, nous rapportent les spécialistes.   --  L'ordre des traits est parfois controversé.

column11: Although this character also carries the sense of an "edition" of a publication, the elements, one-sided and anti-, more readily suggest its other meaning of a printing block.  -    -  Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn´t be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.  -  Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.
column12: Simple face...anti. Le sens originel est bloc d’impression. On pensera que le bloc d’impression est gravé sur une seule face, et que le dessin est tracé à l’envers. Édition est un sens moderne dérivé.  --

column6: marks preceding phrase as modifier of following phrase; it, him her, them; go to
column11: This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it.  -  * In order to give this kanji a more concrete meaning when it is used as a primitive element, think of it as referring to building blocks with the hiragana written on them, much the same as the A-B-C blocks you played with as a child.  -  Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.  -  The Z of Zorro (and yes he has a hat).
column12: Surtout utilisé dans les noms propres, ce kanji sera le plus simplement retenu en vertu de sa ressemblance avec le hiragana え. Vous trouverez aussi une ressemblance avec le composant route, ce qui semblera normal si l’on connaît le second sens de ce kanji : aller.   --  En composant, nous utiliserons le sens « à l'aide de ».

column11: Drop of . . . building blocks.  -    -  Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed.  -  Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro´s living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it´s pictographic).
column12: Si le pompiste ne fait le plein qu'à l’aide d’une goutte, vous saurez quoi lui dire.  --

column6: sesame; a purplish or brown mushroom thought to have miraculous powers; 'a divine and felicitous plant' (Karlgren)
column11: Flowers . . . building blocks.  -    -  Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere.  -  Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. "This is my turf! And this...is for the lady.".
column12: À l'aide de...végétaux. À l'aide de divers moyens, une herbe bien soignée donnera une belle pelouse.  --

column11: You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish (ceiling . . . person . . . a drop of), but you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is.  -    -  [Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer´s face, he says "Negative, fool".  -  One below zero is a negative number.
column12: Ce kanji montre un amusant ensemble de quatre traits, chacun cherchant à contrarier le précédent. Le second coupe le premier en son milieu, mais est lui-même coupé par le troisième. Enfin, le quatrième tente de mettre un point final à cette dispute graphique, mais termine son chemin bloqué par le second ! Le tout donne négation.   --

column6: not, no, negative; final particle; hexagram ䷋
column11: Negative . . . mouth.  -    -  To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 negative (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate.  -  Negative mouths negate everything.
column12: Peut-être estimiez-vous les Japonais incapables de dire « non », car c’est le discours souvent tenu. Ce mot est en fait beaucoup plus courant qu’on ne le pense, et s’écrit négation...bouche.   --

column11: Tree . . . negative.  -    -  The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it.  -  A few cupfuls of sake can create a very negative situation. Like smashing into that tree...　　RTK2:　ハイ　一杯　いっぱい(one cupful).
column12: Comme ce kanji intervient dans le mot signifiant « à la vôtre », pensez « négatif » si vous vous rappelez à temps la présence d’arbres sur la route du retour.  --  Chapitre trente-deux Dernières cartouches   TERMINONS-EN avec les armes. À l'épée, au sabre et à la fléchette, ajoutons trois composants pour parachever la liste.

column11: When shot high into the heavens, the dart gets so small it looks like a mere drop. Although this character could as well mean "arrow," it has no connection with the primitive of that meaning. Hence the new key word.  -    -  Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.  -  Do not mistake with LOSE 失.
column12: Lancée haut dans le ciel, la fléche devient si petite qu’on ne distingue bientôt plus qu’une minuscule goutte.  --

column11: Dart . . . angel. Compare your stories for correct (Frame 405), revise (Frame 362), and reformation (Frame 567).  -    -  Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...  -  The darts of the angel Cupid are supposed to bring people joy, but usually just make things a lot worse. Here we see another angel flying around shooting people with the anti-darts (antidote), to rectify the situation.
column12: Fléche...ange. Ayant raté son coup, Cupidon redresse la trajectoire et fait mouche.  --

column6: a family clan, ethnic group, tribe
column11: Banner . . . dart.  -    -  With a banner declaring "Keep Out!" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly.  -  Once tribes shot darts under their war banners, now they are putting banner ads on the internet for betting on dart-games at their casinos :(.
column12: Bannière...fléche. Le sens s’étend à famille. Pensez à une tribu d’Indiens.  --

column11: Dart . . . mouth.  -    -  I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!  -  [know; wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth.
column12: Le kanji savoir associe la fléche qui permet de « viser juste » à la bouche qui symbolise la parole, le savoir qui est transmis.  --

column11: Know . . . sun.  -    -  Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).  -  Knowing more each day, brings wisdom.
column12: Savoir...bouche et sa langue qui s’agite. Il faut donc savoir tourner sept fois sa langue dans la bouche avant de parler.   --

column11: The halberd's battle-ax head and long shaft are depicted here. Take care with the number and order of the strokes.  -    -  マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.  -  Make the halberd a heroic warrior (perhaps of scandinavian origin) who weilds this polearm - the most effective, brutal and vicious one - with great skill. He can use it to hook, pierce and chop (the three strokes).
column12: Ce kanji est le pictogramme d’une lance. Attention à l’ordre et au nombre de traits.  --

column11: Halberd . . . tree.  -    -  [tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I´ll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...  -  Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it´s all good!
column12: Une bonne lance doit toujours être taillée dans un arbre suffisamment souple.   --

column11: Halberd . . . taskmaster . . . muscle.  -    -  It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.  -  So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles.
column12: Cette œuvre difficile est faite à l’aide d’une lance, par un chef de corvée élevé « au carré », ou plutôt « à la puissance...musculaire ».   --

column11: Weather/rain . . . task.  -    -  This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.  -  FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.
column12: Le brouillard est l'œuvre du temps.  --

column11: Spear . . . two balls.  -    -  Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your "spear" in the middle there.  -  Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.
column12: Deux rois, les capitaines d'équipes, se disputent la pique. Le vainqueur aura le droit de constituer les équipes, de répartir les joueurs, pour suivre le second sens du kanji.  --

column11: Spear . . . broom . . . apron. The character for lady (Frame 1234) shares the same right side as this character, which does not bode for a very happy homecoming.  -    -  Well, the boss man warrior upon his homecoming has set aside his spear. Remember the lady (#1151) (who put aside her broom and apron)? I wonder what they´re doing now?  -  A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).
column12: En rentrant chez lui, cet homme range sa longue pique et retrouve sa femme, balai en main et tablier noué.  --

column11: This character pictures the bent wooden bow. Later we will learn how to make the bowstring that goes with it (Frame 1490). If you stretch this character out and see the indentation on the left as its handle, the pictography should be clearer.  -    -  My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.  -  I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn´t happy!
column12: Ce kanji est le pictogramme d’un arc, dont on reconnaîtra le manche dans l’indentation centrale.  --

column6: to pull, draw out, attract; to stretch
column11: Bow . . . walking stick.  -    -  Put a walking stick in the bow and pull it back, ready to fire at the geezer.  -  This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!
column12: Arc...bâton de marche. Vous pouvez imaginer dans le bâton de marche la corde sur laquelle on tire pour bander l’arc.  --

column11: A bow . . . wrapped around a walking stick.  -    -  Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier´s weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.  -  Send your condolences to the old geezer whom you shot the walking stick into with your bow. (see pull (#1232)).
column12: On présente ses condoléances à la veuve ou au veuf, arc bouté sur sa canne.   --

column11: Bow . . . elbow.  -    -  If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance.  -  The valley was so vast that if you yelled elbow! you could hear it echo bow, bow, bow.
column12: Lorsque du coude, vous tirez sur votre arc, vous demandez à ce qu’un espace suffisamment vaste soit dégagé autour de vous.  --

column11: Vast . . . insect. Note how the elbow of vast is shrunken and elevated to make room for the insect beneath.  -    -  An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.  -  Legolas is so strong that he can even shoot down vast numbers of tiny insects at vast distances with ease.
column12: Notez comment l’insecte repousse votre coude, le rendant plus fort encore.  --

column11: Two bows . . with ice on them.  -    -  Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it´s wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.  -  BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.
column12: Deux arcs...recouverts de glace. Ce kanji relate l’histoire de deux chasseurs perdus dans l’extrême nord du Labrador, et dont on n’a retrouvé que les deux arcs, recouverts de glace; preuve que les deux malheureux, parvenus à l’extrémité de leurs forces, étaient particulièrement faibles.   --

column11: Water . . . dollar sign.  -    -  Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).  -  When his daughter used a lot of water for her shower, the father could practically see the dollar signs, so he was seething with anger.
column12: Eau...fluor. Indice : l’acide fluorhydrique est un des plus dangereux qui soient.  --

column11: Dollar sign . . . shells/money.  -    -  An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money.  -  A dollar sign next to an amount of money denotes an expense.
column12: Négatif...monnaie. À chaque dépense, nous ajoutons une ligne à la liste du débit, et nous créons de la monnaie négative, ce que dit le kanji.  --

column11: The key word No. is the abbreviation for "number." Its elements: bamboo . . . dollar sign.  -    -  The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.  -  Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now.
column12: Bambous...négatif. À chaque fois que l'on tire un numéro, il en reste un en moins dans la réserve de numéros, qui sont de simples plaquettes en bambou. D'où le lien avec le sens de négatif.  --

column11: Horns . . . dollar sign.  -    -  Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.  -  The younger brother was a horny dollar -chasing bastard.
column12: Cornes...négatif. Le frère cadet est le petit qui s'amuse à faire des cornes par derrière la tête de ses aînés dans les photos de famille. Bien entendu les autres n'apprécient pas : négatif !  --

column11: Craft . . . snare.  -    -  Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I´ll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.  -  To be adroit one must have mastered the crafting of snares.
column12: Poutrelle en I...clou tordu. La poutrelle symbolise les travaux artisanaux ou industriels, et le clou tordu représente les merveilles que l'artisan adroit sait fabriquer, même avec des ressources limitées.  --

column11: Mouth . . . snare.  -    -  My nickname is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn´t have put my mouth on that bear trap...  -  When certain nickname snares to people´s mouths, they will call you that way forever.
column12: Un surnom est souvent attribué subitement, comme si une bouche maligne inventait un sobriquet en se basant sur une déformation de la personne, considérée comme une sorte de « clou tordu » qui la caractérise.  --

column11: Tree . . . snare. Do not confuse with rot (Frame 1099).  -    -  This snare isn´t terribly effective, because it´s swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.  -  枯 wither The decay of an animal in the TREE was from something caught in a SNARE.
column12: Alors que le vieil arbre dépérissait, l'arbre délabré est, quant à lui, tout recroquevillé et nous lui voyons le profil d'un clou tordu.  --

column11: Words . . . St. Bernard dog . . . ceiling . . . snare.  -    -  The hunter´s boast: I say, it was a "big one", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before).  -  A dog owner boasts about how obedient, not how smart, his Saint Bernard dog is. "Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!" With a single word, "go!", his dog obediently runs into a snare trap hanging from the ceiling. In a flash, the dog is netted tightly and swinging from the ceiling. Don´t forget the ceiling!
column12: Ce grand vantard raconte qu'il est un vrai fakir, capable de marcher sur une planche hérissée de clous tordus.  --

column11: Water . . . two . . . snare. Note that the first two strokes for snare doubles up with the first stroke for two.  -    -  A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty.  -  Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.
column12: Eau...clous tordus. Le double clou tordu veut représenter un tas de clous rouillés longtemps oubliés dans l'eau. Ils se sont naturellement oxydés et l'eau est devenue bien sale.  --

column6: and; with; to; for; give, grant
column11: Slingshot . . . one. Later we shall learn the character for give (Frame 2046), but even so, it is a good idea already at this point to distinguish this key word from impart (Frame 795) and grant (Frame 1131).  -    -  David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel.  -  In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, one of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the slingshot.
column12: Pince...un. Le sens général de donner est porté par ce kanji. On donne ici un morceau, en le présentant avec une pince.  --

column11: Crown . . . bestow.  -    -  A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.  -  True fact: in the UK the right to print a copy of the KJV Bible is bestowed by the crown -- there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status).
column12: Couronne...donner. Imaginons un musée offrant une couronne à chaque visiteur, mais bien entendu ce ne sont que des copies.  --  Chapitre trente-trois Une personne  BIEN qu'il reste encore quelques composants concernant les activités humaines, nous pouvons à ce point de notre étude épuiser ceux ayant trait aux gens et aux parties du corps.

column11: The key word somebody was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the nose (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for oneself). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of somebody with a prominent paunch.  -    -  Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than someone (#1256) is that the story is full of body descriptions.  -  Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
column12: Le mot-clé implique le double sens de corps et personne. Son écriture est basée sur le composant nez - symbole de soi-même. Les extensions qui suivent montrent un individu à la panse proéminente.  --

column11: "I shot an arrow into the air, And it landed I know not where" goes the poem. (The poor poet obviously loses a lot of arrows.) This kanji, however, tells us where it did land. Its elements: somebody . . . glued to.  -    -  You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.  -  The aim of shooting is to end up with a bullet stuck in someone´s body.
column12: Si vous ne savez pas dans quelle direction vous avez décoché votre flèche, ce kanji vous précise où elle s'est fichée : individu...collé.  --

column11: Words . . . shoot.  -    -  Dick Cheney...  -  The famous speech by the man that Dick Cheney shot in the face: "I´m sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President".
column12: Mots...décochés. Il est parfois trop tard quand on s'aperçoit du caractère blessant de mots décochés trop rapidement, et il faut alors qu'on s'en excuse.  --

column11: First, do not confuse this character with venerable old man (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an old man begins with an abbreviation of the character for somebody, the nose having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the soil drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning; the diagonal walking stick for getting around; and the spoon for being spoon-fed.  -  * As a primitive, the meaning is the same, but the final two strokes are omitted so that they can be replaced with other elements.  -  An old man, wondering what it´s like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.  -  Old man sits in the dirt, having a stroke.
column12: Tout d'abord, ne confondez pas avec vénérable vieillard vu en 865, plus rarement employé. Voyez d'abord dans ce kanji la terre, indiquant au pauvre homme qu'il va bientôt retourner à la poussière. Puis, la panse proéminente caractéristique des seniors, vue en 1351, et enfin la cuiller pour se faire nourrir.   --  En composant, la signification ne change pas, mais les deux derniers traits sont omis, laissant la place à d'autres éléments : .

column11: Old man . . . slingshot. Remember: you already have kanji for discriminating (Frame 521), deliberation (Frame 692), and think (Frame 651).  -    -  Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.  -  Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped.
column12: Vieillard...pince. Le mot-clé suggère une réflexion approfondie quant au sujet qui nous occupe.  --

column11: Old man . . . child.  -    -  This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders.  -  +dilandau23: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders. There is a picture of a statue depicting this here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filial_piety.
column12: Vieillard...enfant. Ce concept est à peine en perte de vitesse au Japon, et les éléments parlent d'eux-mêmes.  --

column11: Filial piety . . . taskmaster.  -    -  In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.  -  You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, "Who´s your daddy?!".
column12: Piété filiale...chef de corvée. Ce kanji témoigne de l’art japonais de l’enseignement : l’élève doit répéter les gestes du maître, le chef de corvée, avec la plus parfaite piété filiale, jusqu’à les reproduire sans faute.  --

column11: Fingers . . . consider.  -    -  In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) ).  -  Aaaargh, stop! cries the victim of torture, his fingers being squeezed by the thumb screws. "I´ll consider it," the torturer says coolly, "if you tell me the names of all the agents in your organization.".
column12: « On frappe d’abord et on discute ensuite », suggère ce kanji heureusement peu employé : doigts...réfléchir.   --

column6: that which; he who; those who
column11: Old man . . . sun. This key word looks to be difficult because of its proximity to somebody. In fact, it is a very common kanji that will cause you no difficulty at all. Its meaning should be seen as the human referent for the abstract noun "something."  -  * As a primitive it means a puppet-on-a-string.  -  I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it´s 者 who can 忍 great 拷!  -  Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child´s Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.
column12: Vieillard...langue qui s'agite. On tentera, compte tenu des éléments, d'imaginer une personne pleine d'expérience, par opposition à l'individu de 1351, qui évoque au contraire la notion de personne physique.  --

column11: Puppet . . . oven fire.  -    -  I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use "puppet." So i thought of "voodoo doll" but then found "love doll" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...  -  There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!
column12: Personne...chaudron. Nous laissons ici notre personne pleine d'expérience mijoter dans le chaudron jusqu'à ce qu'elle nous délivre tout son savoir.  --

column11: Flowers . . . puppet.  -    -  Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll´s head and pretending she is someone of great renowned.  -  This someone is so renowned they are covered with flowers every time they perform on stage.
column12: Végétaux...personne. Si vous imaginez la remise d'un prix littéraire, ce sera parfait car le sens associé est auteur, à qui l'on remet un superbe bouquet.  --

column11: Eye . . . puppet.  -    -  Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.  -  The ninja´s signature move was to paralyse people just by looking in their eyes.
column12: Filet...personne. La signature permet de nous assurer que la personne est bien qui nous pensons, comme si elle était retenue dans un filet. Un sens associé est autorités publiques, celles qui possèdent la signature.  --

column11: The key word refers to the heat of summer. Its elements: sun . . . puppet.  -    -  Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she´s getting a tan!  -  [from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you´ve ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing "Atsui! Atsui!" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow "Atsui! It´s so sultry!".
column12: Soleil...personne. Il s’agit du temps estival japonais, accablant de chaleur et d’humidité : le Soleil en personne vient ici nous rendre visite.  --

column11: Words . . . puppet. Do not confuse with miscellaneous (Frame 604).  -    -  Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too.  -  When you pull the string at the back of Chucky, he will say various things. "Hidey-ho! Ha ha ha!" "Hi, I´m Chucky. Wanna play?" "I´m going to eat your liver, bitch!".
column12: De multiples points de vues sont donnés par les mots de multiples personnes.   --

column11: Pack of wild dogs . . . puppet.  -    -  My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!  -  (Image: a pack of wild dogs chasing Pinocchio who´s trying to escape by riding on the back of a boar. See him bouncing around as they race along?).
column12: Le sanglier à lui seul équivaut à une entière meute de chiens : meute...personne. Notez que  convoie le sens d'unité, et que sanglier en français est une déformation de singulier, le solitaire. C'est donc la même idée, exprimée de deux façons différentes.  --

column11: The strand referred to here is the stretch of land along a beach or shoreline. Its elements are: water . . . puppet.  -    -  I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn´t upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!  -  A lovely romantic walk on the strand, splashing in the water with my love doll.
column12: Il s’agit du bord de mer, là où les vagues viennent se briser, et rapportent quelquefois les corps des noyés : eau...personne.   --

column11: Shells/money . . . puppet.  -    -  When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.  -  People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.
column12: Monnaie...personne. Le parieur est à fond à son affaire, sa monnaie occupe entièrement sa personne. Comme en 1364, nous verrons parfois un trait supplémentaire : sans doute une goutte de sueur perlant au front de l'anxieux parieur.  --

column11: Mountain . . . scissors.  -    -  A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.  -  A kid cuts a gorge into a paper mountain, with a pair of scissors.
column12: Montagne...ciseaux. Les versants des deux montagnes qui cernent cette vallée étroite la resserrent, comme feraient les deux lames d’une paire de ciseaux.   --

column11: Pack of wild dogs . . . scissors.  -    -  A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular.  -  In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.
column12: Meute...ciseaux. Quand le cerf est aux abois, il commence à se sentir à l’étroit, la meute de chiens se resserrant sur lui comme une paire de ciseaux.  --

column6: clasp under arm; hold to bosom
column11: Fingers . . . scissors. Do not confuse with the kanji for pinch (Frame 709).  -    -  挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..  -  Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don´t move or else!
column12: Doigt...ciseaux. En serrant, on place les doigts comme une paire de ciseaux.  --

column11: Maestro . . . road.  -    -  Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.  -  Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I´m thinking of the car chase in ´The Man with the Golden Gun´ - NOT pursue (#539). I think about ´Race N Chase´ (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in ´Race N Chase´, only cars.
column12: Maestro...route. Le maestro voulait partir avec la caisse, et c’est l’orchestre entier qui le pourchasse, sur la route.   --

column6: teacher, master, specialist; multitude, troops; hexagram ䷆
column11: Maestro . . . ceiling . . . towel.  -    -  A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow.  -  Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him.
column12: Maestro...plafond...serviette. Notre maestro est devenu un expert, maniant la serviette à la perfection, sous le plafond. On peut alors imaginer ici l’un de ces fameux coiffeurs japonais, pour retenir le kanji expert.   --

column11: Maestro . . . towel.  -    -  The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.  -  The greatest of them all; Commander James Bond, 007. Here he is the maestro of undressing women, removing the towel from some bond girl. Of course the towel symbolises her last vestige of resistance.
column12: La simple disparition du plafond indique que nous sommes en présence d’un expert de rang supérieur, également capable de pratiquer son art à l’air libre. En d’autres termes, son rayon d’action n’a pas de limite.  --

column11: By replacing the maestro's baton (the drop) with the roof of a house, we have his equivalent in the institutional world of big government: the bureaucrat.  -    -  No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.  -  Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.
column12: En remplaçant la baguette du maestro par le toit d’une maison, on obtient son « correspondant » dans le monde institutionnel : le fonctionnaire.   --

column11: Wood . . . bureaucrat.  -    -  The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in.  -  An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.
column12: Bois...fonctionnaire. Mais la vie du fonctionnaire est assez morose, et le seul avenir qu’on lui imagine se résume à bien peu de choses.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . bureaucrat.  -    -  Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an inter-office bamboo pipe system.  -  The Japanese internet is a series of bamboo pipes said one ignorant bureaucrat trying to draft Internet legislation.
column12: Les bambous placés au-dessus de la tête de notre fonctionnaire représentent l’ensemble des tuyaux qui lui permettent de bien faire son travail, d’être bien « tuyauté ». Cette image permet d’accéder au second sens, gestion, bien faite par le fonctionnaire bien tuyauté.  --

column11: The kindness and hard work of the ideal father is seen in this abbreviation of the taskmaster that leaves off his rod or whip (the first stroke) and replaces it with the sweat of the father's brow (the two drops at the top).  -    -  Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).  -  Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.
column12: La gentillesse et le courage du père sont représentés dans cette abréviation du chef de corvée qui, abandonnant son bâton, l’a remplacé par deux gouttes de sueur perlant à son front.  --  RÈGLE 10 : Lorsque deux traits diagonaux coexistent, on trace d'abord celui du haut à droite vers le bas à gauche. Ici, nous voyons deux exemples caractéristiques.

column11: Top hat . . . father.  -    -  Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can´t give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.  -  Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).
column12: Il faut imaginer un échange de choses se faisant en douceur, dans le but d’une amélioration mutuelle des choses. Le kanji nous montre le papa échangeant des coups de chapeau haut de forme avec les papas du voisinage.  --

column6: efficacious, effectiveness; to toil, to serve in the army
column11: Mingle . . . power. Note the distinct connotations that separate merit from achievement (Frame 927).  -    -  Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.  -  There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.
column12: Échanges...force. La force des échanges est sans doute le secret de l'efficacité.  --

column11: Cars . . . mingle.  -    -  The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.  -  Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.
column12: Echanger sa voiture contre une autre, plus belle ou plus puissante, permet de bien saisir le contraste entre deux choses pourtant semblables.  --

column11: Tree . . . mingle.  -    -  With the exam scores posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around looking at the results. test. 試.  -  Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).
column12: Pour les petits, l'école est notamment le lieu où l'on échange des billes au pied des arbres.  --

column6: foot; attain, satisfy, enough; Kangxi radical 156
column11: Mouth . . . mending. Note that the last stroke of mouth and the first of mending overlap.  -  * As a primitive on the left, it is amended to something similar to correct in place of mending. Its meaning remains leg, but should be thought of as a wooden leg in order to avoid confusion with other similar elements, namely human legs, animal legs, and walking legs.  -  Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale´s mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.  -  I´ll use my mouth to mend your leg, I´ll kiss it all better :).
column12: Bouche...raccommoder. Notez que le troisième trait est commun aux deux éléments. Le second sens du kanji est suffire. Cette notion implique la satisfaction d’un besoin, et donc que la « base », ou pour ainsi dire la jambe, le pied d’une condition est remplie.
