column11: Spoon . . . dart . . . chop-seal . . . zoo.  -    -  (Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. ´Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.´ cool ´and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong´ ....´ please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.´ ´lion feeding time is. bla bla´ You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo.  -  A very doubtful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special spoon (to feed the animals) and a dart gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).
column12: Cuiller...fléche...sceau...zoo. Il y a fort à douter que, muni d’une cuiller, d’une fléche, voire de votre sceau, vous puissiez capturer un animal du zoo.   --

column11: Fingers . . . doubt.  -    -  Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER.  -  I doubt you can mimic all these animals with just your fingers: http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Raymond+Crowe%22+Letterman (shadow puppets -- you´ll love it!).
column12: Doigts...doute. Lorsqu’on fait des ombres chinoises avec les doigts, le spectateur se doute bien qu’il ne s’agit que d’une imitation.  --

column11: Ice . . . doubt.  -    -  I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox.  -  Is there any doubt that ice is congealed stuff?
column12: Glace...douter. Comme le revolver, la glace peut refroidir, mais comme lui, ne peut congeler : d’où le doute. 凝 signifie aussi polymériser.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . car . . . fingerprint.  -    -  This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.  -  I just had a new bamboo-leaf pattern spray-painted on my car. Don't touch it, you'll leave fingerprints!
column12: Bambou...voiture...bourgeon. Il s’agit d’un modèle à suivre. Le modèle particulier de voiture à suivre est celui que nous montre le vendeur qui désire sans nul doute gonfler ses ventes, ce que viendra confirmer le coup de bambou de la facture.  --

column11: Wild dogs . . . fingerprint.  -    -  Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.  -  This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.
column12: Chiens...gonflement. Il s'agit d'enfreindre un règlement ou d'envahir l'espace d'autrui. Nous voyons une meute de chiens, gonflés, qui envahissent le jardin... Vous pouvez revoir 362.  --

column11: Cliff . . . fingerprint.  -    -  Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.  -  Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.
column12: Falaise...gonflement. Un simple et léger coup de vent venant gonfler robe, cape ou ombrelle suffit pour qu'il devienne coup du sort, portant malchance et malheur aux promeneurs au bord de la falaise.  --

column6: dangerous, precarious; high; 12th lunar mansion, determinative star α Aquarii (Sadalmelik)
column11: Bound up . . . unlucky.  -    -  If you live a dangerous life, eventually you're bound to get unlucky.  -  While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it´s so dangerous.
column12: Emballage...malchance. On ne recherche pas les situations dangereuses. Elles surviennent comme un concours de mauvaises circonstances, un paquet emballant de la malchance.  --

column11: House . . . mailbox.  -    -  Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.  -  For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese mailbox, it automatically lights up in the evening, and has a biometric fingerprint scanner. --- Each house´s address, even if it´s hard to see in the evening, is like its own unique fingerprint.
column12: Maison...boîte à lettres.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . address.  -    -  Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don´t forget it.  -  In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story).
column12: Partie du corps...adresse (postale). Le double sens du mot adresse en français est bien utile.  --

column11: Flowers . . . mailbox.  -    -  Japanese "gardens" aren´t anything more than a pot of flowers on top of the mailbox.  -  My mailbox is actually right in the middle of my garden, which kind of sucks since the mailman has to trample all my flowers to get to it.
column12: Végétaux...boîte à lettres. Regardez votre boîte à lettres au milieu des plantes dans votre jardin, puis souvenez-vous que vous êtes maître chez vous, tel un empereur en ses jardins impériaux.  --

column11: Mailbox . . . heart.  -    -  I couldn´t drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig´s heart in his mailbox. He got the message.  -  To hold a grudge is actually the act of keeping negative feelings you received in the mailbox of your heart.
column12: Boîte à lettres...sentiments. Nous éprouvons de la la rancune quand nos sentiments dépendent du contenu de la boîte à lettres, que nous ouvrons alors avec appréhension.  --

column11: Receipt . . . stamp . . . and a drop in each side to represent a little smear of egg yoke. The third stroke is drawn slightly higher to close the egg up tightly and keep the yoke inside.  -    -  The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.  -  The 卯sign of the hare (#2041) hides eggs in his ears for Easter...　RTK2:　ラン　卵巣　らんそう(ovary).
column12: Reçu...tampon avec une goutte à l'intérieur, représentant l'embryon en train de croître dans l'œuf. Le quatrième trait s'allonge pour fermer le premier œuf.  --

column6: willow tree; pleasure; 24th lunar mansion, determinative star δ Hydrae
column11: Tree . . . receipt . . . stamp.  -    -  Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE´s ears.  -  A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?
column12: Imaginons le saule comme l’arbre dont on fait les paniers d’osier dans lesquels on s’en va ramasser les œufs du jour. Et comme on voudrait ne pas les voir éclore, l’embryon-goutte n’apparaît pas.  --

column11: Receipt . . . dagger . . . rice field.  -    -  The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to an empty FIELD.  -  Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we´re going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.
column12: Reçu...poignard...cerveau. Songez à l’évasion des « cerveaux ». Retenu devient alors un euphémisme disant que ces brillants chercheurs sont « retenus ». avec à la clé un petit pactole (le reçu) ou la menace (le poignard).   --

column11: Receipt . . . dagger . . . shells. Though the meanings are related, do not confuse with make a deal (Frame 471) or wholesale (Frame 1499).  -    -  There´s a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it´s quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.  -  The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.
column12: Reçu...poignard...monnaie. Il s'agit ici de payer, signer le reçu, et découper l'emballage avec le poignard.  --

column11: At last we come to the general character meaning stamp. Its elements: staples . . . stamp.  -    -  Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.  -  Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn´t stick! Okay I´ll just staple it.
column12: On verra ici l’impression pratiquée par l’artisan, autant que vos impressions. Le kanji montre deux objets qui s’emploient en appuyant fort, en leur imprimant une forte pression : les agrafes et le timbre.   --

column11: Mortar . . . same . . . tool. Be careful to make an image that keeps same in the middle.  -    -  Wacky Japanese TV entertain-ment show: a monk is stapled to the wall on both sides with huge staples, whilst contestants throw tools at his face.  -  To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24].
column12: Ce kanji représente une roue de loterie truquée. Sur les côtés se trouvent les agrafes séparant chaque numéro de son voisin, et au centre le composant identique, signifiant que la roue est truquée de façon à s’arrêter toujours sur le même numéro. En bas l’établi, référant à la roue elle-même. L’ensemble forme alors un amusant symbole de intérêt, en particulier si vous êtes le propriétaire de la roue, si c’est vous qui faites prospérer (sens associé) l’entreprise.  --  Chapitre trente-sept Boire, manger  PASSONS à table dans ce chapitre qui aborde le boire et le manger ainsi que quelques notions connexes : le trop manger, le trop boire, les contenants, les épices parfois surprenantes, et ainsi de suite.

column6: a wine vessel; tenth earthly branch; Kangxi radical 164
column11: Though we shall later encounter the kanji for bird, we introduce this one for the tenth sign of the zodiac mainly because of its use as a primitive, where it has a different meaning.  -  * As a primitive, it means whiskey bottle. In its pictograph, you can see the loosely corked lid, the bottle and the contents (about one-third full). You might also think of the Spanish "porrón," a decanter shaped like a long-necked bird.  -  The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.  -  Normally birds fly south, but one bird flew west. People were worried about it and kept asking "Is there any sign of the bird – you know, the one that flew west?".
column12: Bien que nous verrons le kanji oiseau dans un prochain chapitre, nous présentons ici le dixième signe du zodiaque chinois, surtout parce qu’il est employé comme composant, avec un sens tout à fait différent.  --  En composant, cette forme signifiera bouteille de whisky. Vous reconnaîtrez dans le pictogramme le goulot de la bouteille et son bouchon mal fermé, ainsi que le contenu, dont il ne reste qu'un tiers.

column11: Water . . . whiskey bottle.  -    -  Sake is just watered down whisky.  -  Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.
column12: Eau...bouteille de whisky. Il s’agit d’une boisson alcoolique non distillée, comme le vin ou le saké.   --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . ladle.  -    -  At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.  -  Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn´t just about bottles of whiskey, it´s about ladling out advice.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...louche. Dans les clubs nocturnes du Japon, il suffit d’à peine « loucher » sur la bouteille de whisky pour que l’hôtesse nous en remette une louche. Ensuite, elle remet une louche de conversation.  --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . filial piety.  -    -  The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.  -  Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn´t, sink back some whiskey and it will.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...piété filiale. Afin d’activer la fermentation, on brasse le mélange pour apporter de l’oxygène, grâce auquel les levures se reproduisent. Puis on cesse de brasser, pour les laisser transformer le sucre en alcool. Elles exécutent cette tâche avec la plus fervente piété filiale.   --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . revelation.  -    -  It´s cruel to pour alcohol down a cow´s mouth.  -  There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a bottle of whiskey, you may get some revelations about their cruelty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...révélation. In vino veritas. L'alcool contribue parfois à révéler les sentiments secrets ; en ce sens il peut se montrer cruel.  --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . state.  -    -  Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.  -  Hint: bottle deposit refund - the state will repay the recycling deposit for each alcohol bottle returned.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...province. Les excédents de vin si fréquents en France sont à l’origine de remboursements destinés à renflouer les finances de la province en difficulté.  --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . each.  -    -  Imagine if at each supermarket you went to, the section for dairy products was next to the alcohol aisle. so for each wheel of cheese you decide to buy, you get an accompanying bottle of wine...perfect for a "wine & cheese" party. :).  -  In an attempt to increase sales of dairy products, the grocery store is giving away a free miniature whiskey bottle with each dairy product you buy.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...chacun. C'est à l'initiative de Pierre Mendès-France que chaque enfant des écoles avait droit chaque matin à un verre de lait à l'heure de la récréation.  --

column6: toast one's host with wine; to express juice by pressing
column11: Whiskey bottle . . . saw.  -    -  Drinking alcohol that´s turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.  -  I spent ages sawing that whiskey bottle open, but when I got in, it had all turned to vinegar!
column12: Bouteille de whisky...scie. On dit d’un vin âcre qu’il « râpe ». Le vinaigre, lui, « scie ».   --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . baseball . . . needle.  -    -  God you´re drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?  -  Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you drunk. I don´t care who you are.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...quatre-vingt-dix (degrés ou litres).   --

column11: Whisky bottle . . . snake.  -    -  To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.  -  I imagine a bartender serving whiskey to his patrons, and using that snake-like sprayer to distribute soda water into each glass.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...serpent. Peut-être vous-est-il déjà arrivé de déguster une fondue savoyarde dans un village de haute montagne. Alors peut-être avez-vous vu apparaître l'inévitable bouteille de marc avec un serpent lové au fond, pour effrayer les convives. Vous avez alors remarqué que le seul souci du patron était alors de bien distribuer la boisson, pour que chacun reçoive son dû.  --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . license . . . walking legs.  -    -  The prostitute carries an old whiskey bottle filled with acid to throw at any difficult Johns.  -  Dealing alcohol requires a license, dealing acid requires fast legs (to run from the police).
column12: Bouteille de whisky...mouvement décidé. Contenu dans une bouteille de whisky, l'acide ronge la pierre d'un mouvement décidé dès qu'on le verse. Revoyez 843 et 1102 si vous le désirez.  --

column6: like, similar to, just like, as
column11: Wild dogs . . . animal horns . . . whiskey bottle.  -    -  The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.  -  I wavered when the pack of wild dogs was blocking the way, but then I drank some Red Bull and charged through. (thanks shakkun).
column12: Meute de chiens...cornes...bouteille de whisky. Bien que cela n’ait a priori rien à voir², prenons ce kanji comme le pictogramme d’une outre, comme on peut encore en voir dans certains bars en Espagne. Faite de peaux de meute de chiens, nantie de cornes (reliquats de l’emplacement des pattes), elle sert à conserver l’alcool, comme une bouteille de whisky. Puis de outre, nous « étendons » le sens à en outre.   ² Le sens de « en outre » comprend l'idée d'allongement qui est rendu dans le dessin du kanji par la présence du chien, animal à la peau extensible.  --

column11: Animal horns . . . whiskey bottle . . . glue.  -    -  People don't know this, but ("revered" patriot) Paul Revere had trouble staying awake during his midnight ride, so he drank Red Bull (horns) and whiskey (a drink invented by his friend Sam Adams) and glued himself DOWN to the saddle. [thanks to akahige].  -  Red Bull, the chieftain (#2906) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue.
column12: Cornes...bouteille de whisky...collé à. Cette bouteille avec des cornes pourrait être une fabrication spéciale de cognac à l'effigie de l'empereur au bicorne. Napoléon est sans doute un des Français les plus connus sur l'archipel, et unir une bouteille en forme de bicorne et l'élément collé nous mène tout droit au concept de révération.  --

column11: This kanji depicts a pot of beans, although it looks more like a table on which the pot is resting.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji will mean table.  -  If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.  -  I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let´s call this one Mr. Bean! He´s an easy character to build stories with.
column12: Ce kanji décrit un pot de pois, bien qu’il ressemble plutôt à une table, que nous prendrons parfois comme sésame.  --

column11: Here we meet at last the full kanji on which the primitive for head is based. The elements: table . . . head.  -    -  The head of the family sits at the head of the table.  -  Mr Bean´s head.
column12: Pois...tête. Voici enfin le kanji d’où fut tiré l’élément tête. Il faut voir dans le pois un pot de pois, censé représenter le crâne. Ce kanji est aussi le compteur des gros animaux, comme le bétail.  --

column11: Dart . . . table.  -    -  He is so short so he has to throw darts from the table.  -  Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.
column12: Flèche...table. Cette flèche a été tirée sur une si courte distance qu’elle n’a même pas traversé la table.   --

column11: Bend . . . table. Think of a bountiful harvest, and you will not be far from the meaning of this character.  -    -  The bountiful feast was so bountiful that it bent the table below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.  -  Her bust and bum was so bountiful I couldn´t resist the urge to bend her over a nearby table and...
column12: Courber...table. Pensez à une récolte abondante, et vous cernerez bien le sens de ce kanji.  --

column6: drum; beat, top, strike; Kangxi radical 207
column11: The full kanji for the drum adds a branch, apparently to serve as a drumstick, to the primitive for drum.  -    -  Japanese festivals have drums so big, a samurai has to SIT (not stand) on a table to beat one with a tree branch! http://www.d2.dion.ne.jp/~hidafyh/furukawayh/gyouji/image/maturi03.jpg.  -  I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH".
column12: Le kanji tambour, qui est aussi une clé, ajoute à son composant une branche, la baguette.  --

column11: Drum . . . mouth.  -    -  The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.  -  In the taiko (drum (#1444)) song of rejoicing, the drummers shout with open mouths.
column12: Tambour...bouche. Souvent, les réjouissances japonaises comportent un défilé pendant lequel les habitants de chaque quartier de la ville crient leurs slogans au rythme des tambours.   --

column11: Trees . . . drum . . . glue.  -    -  In the middle of the 村 village there is a drum the villagers use to signal to everyone that the loggers have come to cut the TIMBER-TREES.  -  Everyone likes to see big trees fall down. For this kanji imagine hundreds of spectators glued to their chairs, then a drum roll and then a cry of "timber!!!" as the huge tree crashes to the ground.
column12: Si d’aventure vous frappez l’extrémité d’une grume comme si c’était un tambour, vous aurez bien vite les mains collantes, enduites de résine.  --

column11: The kanji for a dish is, clearly, the pictograph of a painted or carved bowl, seen from the side.  -    -  Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.  -  Pictograph of a dish with a three-layer cake slice on it.
column12: Ce kanji montre le dessin d'une assiette peinte ou gravée.  --

column11: The drop in the dish is blood. It is similar to the drop we saw earlier on the dagger in the character for blade (Frame 88).  -    -  Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.  -  Image: Holy Grail with a drop of Jesus blood on it.
column12: La goutte sur l’assiette est du sang. Elle est de même nature que celle tachant la lame de notre poignard.  --

column11: Part . . . dish.  -    -  The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.  -  I'm not an expert, but it seems that as a basin this refers more to an oceanic basin that a kitchen one, and in any case seems most common in reference to the famous O-Bon festival. So, a story: in the O-Bon festival, so many dishes are broken that all the parts have to be thrown into a deep oceanic basin.
column12: C’est dans le plat, ou bassin, que l’on prépare les portions avant de les placer dans les assiettes.   --

column11: Bright . . . dish.  -    -  In order to form alliances, you should sit down for a meal and eat until your dish is bright or clear; in other words, get to know people first, before you talk business.  -  A new alliance is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their alliance they clean up together one dish, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very bright, and it´s pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning´s newspapers, with the title "New alliance, one bright dish!".
column12: Clair...assiette. L’alliance de votre grand appétit et de l’excellence de la nourriture proposée a permis de « clarifier » l’assiette, de la vider de son contenu.  --

column11: Next . . . dish.  -    -  You are so poor you dont know where your next dish will come from all you know is that you will have to steal it.  -  The first thing to steal is the silverware; next, the dishes.
column12: Suivant...assiette. Le voleur va son chemin d'une maison à l'autre, d'une assiette à la suivante.  --

column11: Water . . . sun . . . dish.  -    -  If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.  -  To distinguish from warmth (#1949), which refers to warm weather, remember that this means warm objects or feelings. Imagine a plastic kiddy pool in the backyard full of lukewarm water. The kiddy pool is shaped like a huge dish, and it's been under the sun all day - that's why the water is warm now.
column12: Eau...soleil...assiette. Nous voyons ici un capteur solaire très rudimentaire mais doit fonctionner.  --

column11: Slaves . . . reclining . . . floor/one . . . dish.  -    -  While the slave-buyer is perusing (perusal (#855)) the stack of slaves reclining on the floor, the slaves' overseer supplies them with dishes of gruel -- don't want the slaves starving to death before they can be sold!  -  The slaves are reclining on the floor when the overseer comes in. They tell him "We´re not goofing off, a dish fell and broke and we´re cleaning it off the floor".
column12: Esclave et son maître...assiette. Ici l’esclave surveille l’assiette du maître.  --

column11: Water . . . oversee.  -    -  Who´s job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It´ts overflowing!  -  The overseer isn´t doing his job and he lets the slaves overflow the sink!
column12: Eau...surveiller. Voyons ce qui se produit lors d’une inondation. On doit surveiller au plus près de nombreuses installations, afin de leur éviter la destruction par l’eau qui déborde.  --

column11: Metal . . . oversee.  -    -  The overseer tags his slaves with gold earrings, just like specimens.  -  (Thanks bodhisamaya) The authorities are suspicious about the athlete that won GOLD at the olympics. They are now OVERSEEING a thorough drug test, taking all sorts of SPECIMENS.
column12: Métal...surveiller. Pour chaque coulée métal produite, on prélève un échantillon afin d’en surveiller la qualité. Cela se fait encore ainsi dans nos aciéries.  --

column11: Wild dogs . . . child . . . dish.  -    -  The fierce WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.  -  If you want to make your wild dogs fierce, feed them a child. Children are the holy grail of dogfood you know...
column12: Meute de chiens...enfant...assiette. Ici, vous avez placé une meute de chiens féroces pour protéger votre enfant qui tarde à terminer son assiette.   --

column11: Here boom refers to something that is popular and prospering. Its elements: turn into . . . dish.  -    -  Japan´s economic boom turned their empty plates into full ones.  -  The boom of satellite TV has made antennas turn into dishes.
column12: Se changer en...assiette. La prospérité que connaît le Japon moderne s’est matérialisée par divers changements, notamment concernant l’alimentation.  --

column11: Ground . . . reclining . . . mouth . . . dish.  -    -  In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt.  -  The eccentric explorer lay down on the earth 土, opened his mouth 口, and licked it. "As I suspected!" he said, "It's salt. Something to spice up our dishes 皿 with!"
column12: Terre (minéral)...couché...bouche...assiette. On imaginerait bien un empereur romain décadent, couché à côté de son assiette, la bouche ouverte en quête de sel, un minéral qui eut pendant des siècles une valeur inestimable. D’ailleurs, seuls les empereurs romains décadents pouvaient s’en offrir.  --

column11: Metal . . . silver.  -    -  Like gold, silver is a metal.  -  Not sure why Heisig find the right side so troublesome. My grandma´s hairpin (just before long (#1920)) is made of silver, the metal that best reflects sun light. I´m sure you can see the flash from her hair as she walks by on a sunny day. Note that the two elements (sun and hairpin) share not only a horizontal stroke, but also the left vertical one. Therefore a bit odd stroke order.
column12: Métal...fixer. L'argent est le métal qui doit être fixé par le fixateur, dans le laboratoire photographique d'antan.  --

column11: State of mind . . . silver.  -    -  The athlete´s state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.  -  Data´s greatest resentment is getting a silver medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: Data fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).
column12: Etat d’esprit...fixe. Quand on aime, on ne compte pas, mais lorsque s’installe le ressentiment, notre état d’esprit subit une sorte de fixation, et seuls les défauts nous apparaissent.  --

column11: Tree . . . silver.  -    -  Since trees eat through their roots, one could imagine roots as tree silverware.  -  The roots of the magical tree are silver.
column12: Arbre...fixer. Par sa racine, l'arbre se fixe à la terre.  --

column11: Silver . . . stamp.  -    -  He scratches off the silver stamp and discovers that he is an instant winner.  -  For instant postal delivery, buy a silver stamp!
column12: Fixer...tampon. Il suffit de fixer un coup de tampon sur l'enveloppe pour instantanément pouvoir la poster.  --

column11: Vulture . . . eye . . . silver . . . glue.  -    -  The baron is very suspicious, always looking around with vulture eyes and keeping the silver glued to the table so no one can steal it.  -  Here we see an evil baron - a vulture perched on his shoulder, and a siver eye-patch glued to his eye.
column12: Un vieux vautour cherchant à protéger ses biens avec un filet fixé-collé, est l'image insolite proposée par le kanji baron.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . instant.  -    -  Counting the nodes on bamboo is an instant way to tell its age.  -  A certain species of bamboo is considered the fastest growing plant in the world. A new node can be formed in an instant.
column12: Bambou...instantané. Nœud (du bambou) est le sens premier de ce kanji. Au sens figuré, il définit l’instant-charnière dans le cours des choses : le temps météorologique ou encore le temps qui passe.  --

column11: Road . . . silver.  -    -  If you see silver on the road (eg. gun, armour, sword) => retreat!  -  In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the Silver Road.
column12: Ce kanji nous montre comment battre en retraite consiste à se fixer un nouveau cap, une nouvelle route à suivre, et à se mettre en chemin.  --

column11: Pinnacle . . . silver.  -    -  He was pushed to the limit at the end of the marathon, climbing on top of the Acropolis, but had to settle for the silver medal.  -  At The Pinnacle, they limit how much silver you can have. Too much silver will lead to wrongfulness.
column12: Cette limite nous permet de nous rappeler le sens du premier élément - point le plus élevé d’un village, qui fixe l’infranchissable limite d’altitude.  --

column11: Eye . . . silver.  -    -  Be careful putting silverware near your eyes: you could lose an eyeball!  -  Eyeballs made of silver. That´s what they use to play pachinko with, isn´t it?
column12: Les globes oculaires sont des yeux fixés de chaque côté du nez.  --

column11: Drop of . . . silver.  -  * As a primitive, use the image of a saint's halo. As with silver, when this element is drawn on the left, the penultimate stroke is omitted.  -  With a drop of silver, the forces of good can vanquish the werewolves.  -  A drop of silver is good, but a whole bar of it is better!
column12: Goutte...fixer. Une petite goutte de gomina sur la tête pour bien fixer les cheveux, et c'est bon, succès assuré !  --  Le sésame sera halo, le symbole pieux de la bonté des saints. Comme ce fut le cas pour fixer, le pénultième trait sera omis lorsque ce composant sera placé à gauche.

column11: Halo . . . moon.  -    -  [Image: ´Moonlight sonata´] The moon has inspired many good composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) to write something melodious.  -  A glowing halo surrounds a magnificent full moon. A perfect image of the mythic and melodious music of the spheres.
column12: La lune radieuse laisse voir un léger halo.  --

column11: Water . . . halo.  -    -  Water is a good thing to have when you´re out wandering.  -  John the Baptist with a halo sprinkling water on people as he´s wandering the wilderness.
column12: Eau...halo. Voyons dans ce halo les cercles que dessine la surface de l’eau dans laquelle on vient de lancer un caillou pour y créer un phénomène vibratoire.  --

column11: Woman . . . halo.  -    -  Your daughter is a good girl......well, let´s hope so... :-).  -  Be careful not to think woman + angel here, which has already been seen for attractive (#430). Suggest using woman with a halo, as in an innocent girl, something that everyone sees their daughters as being.
column12: Femme...halo - sainte.  --  Ce caractère définit la fille par rapport à son père. Si vous avez entendu parler des « mousmées » du Japon, maintenant vous savez écrire le mot, dont la prononciation française dérive du mot japonais.

column11: If halo and umbrella aren't enough, break the halo down into drop and silver - or "silverware," an additional primitive.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji can mean either eating or food. As with silver, on the left the final two strokes of this element are combined into one.  -  That umbrella looks good enough to eat!  -  Umbrella + Good: Let's go eat at that restaurant - the table with the umbrella looks good.
column12: Sous le parapluie de ce saint son regroupés tous les disciples, rassemblés pour manger en compagnie de Jésus, qui partagent sa nourriture.   --  Le sésame sera manger ou nourriture, aliment, et à gauche le pénultième trait disparaîtra.

column11: Food . . . anti-.  -    -  After I eat a meal, I always have to take an anti-acid.  -  I´m anti-fastfood. Sit down and eat a real meal!
column12: Lors du repas est créée de l’« anti nourriture ».  --

column11: Food . . . yawn.  -    -  My experience with Japanese enkais (dinner parties): plenty to drink drink drink, but a severe lack of food, T_T.  -  When you lack food, just drink something to fill you up.
column12: Nourriture...bâiller (ennui).  --

column11: Food . . . wind.  -    -  The smell of cooked food wafts past you in the wind, making your stomach rumble and feeling hungry.  -  The wind blew away my food, so now I´m hungry.
column12: Lorsque la faim se manifeste, nous approchons de la table et commençons à manger.  --

column11: Food . . . ego.  -    -  All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to eat, but their ego (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!  -  He starves for FOOD but his EGO won´t let him beg.
column12: Nourriture...ego. Ici, les choses se corsent et le kanji nous souffle que « ventre affamé n'a pas d'oreille ».  --

column11: Food . . . reclining . . . towel.  -    -  [decorate; ornament; adorn; embellish] We decorate a table before eating, reclining a towel over it.  -  Naked sushi: a lady reclining on a towel as decoration for the food laid out on her.
column12: De la nourriture couchée sur une serviette donne l’image d’un cochon de lait garni et décoré.  --

column11: The abbreviation of Building suggests that this kanji is used in proper names, as indeed it often is. Keep your connotation distinct from Inst. (Frame 1401) when working with the elements: food . . . bureaucrat.  -    -  This Bldg. is like all the other government buildings - they house bureaucrats who sit around sipping wine and eating expensive meals at the taxpayers expense.  -  A building that eats bureaucrats!!!!!!!!
column12: Le Bâtiment dont il est ici question est rempli de fonctionnaires qui prennent leur repas. La majuscule suggère que ce kanji est employé dans les noms propres, comme c’est le cas.  --

column11: Sheep . . . food. The key word has the sense of promoting the development of something, especially in a psychological or spiritual sense.  -    -     You foster ("promote the growth of") your sheep well when they have food right at their feet.  -  A sheep became the foster parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well...
column12: Mouton...repas. Le sens du mot-clé concerne le développement d'un être, dans tous les sens : psychologique, spirituel ou alimentaire.  --

column11: Eat . . . wrap.  -    -  My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!  -  This guy is sated only after eating the hamburger AND its wrapping!
column12: Quand on commence à saturer, on demande un petit récipient pour emballer la nourriture qui reste.  --

column11: Silver . . . waitress. Do not confuse this kanji's key word with before (Frame 263).  -    -  Distinguish from formerly (#501). Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.  -  For the waitress primitive, I don´t really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.
column12: Le personnage vu ci-dessus s'apprête à s'installer à sa table favorite dans le café où il a ses habitudes, mais son pire ennemi se trouve déjà installé (fixé) à la table, et bien entendu notre homme ne manque de s'étrangler de surprise en le voyant.  --

column11: Roots . . . waitress. Note that the kanji meaning of the two primitives to the right is not used here because we shall later meet a primitive meaning beforehand and want to preempt any confusion. The same holds true in the following frame.  -    -  The police tried to draw a chalk outline around the dead waitress, but it was kinda tough with all the tree roots underneath her.  -  If you attempted to outline the biography of most famous actresses, you´d find that they have roots working as waitresses before getting their big break.
column12: Lorsque les arbres sont apparus, l'essentiel de l'évolution était déjà tracé.  --

column11: Resentment . . . waitress.  -    -  If you don´t leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.  -  The resentment of a waitress who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She rues that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).
column12: Il arrive que le sentiment de repentir soit déjà là au début d'une action.   --  Chapitre trente-huit D'autres plantes  RETOURNONS un instant au monde végétal. Certains des composants présentés dans ces pages seront rarement employés, mais il faudra bien les assimiler, afin de mieux comprendre comment fonctionne le système d'écriture japonais et de mieux pouvoir, plus tard, retenir d'autres caractères.

column11: This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of even. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.  -  * As a primitive, this kanji can keep its pictographic meaning of a water lily.  -  There´s an even covering of water lilies on the pond at 金閣寺（きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.  -  Frogs stay dry (#1648) 干 even as rain drops on their lily pads... RTK2:　ヘイ　　平均　へいきん(an average)　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　ビョウ　平等　びょうどう(equality).
column12: Le mieux sera de voir ici le pictogramme d'un nénuphar, flottant à la surface de l'eau, induisant la notion de plan ou surface plane. Les trois premiers traits montrent la fleur du nénuphar posée sur la feuille (quatrième trait) à la surface de l'eau, et le cinquième forme la longue tige s'enfonçant profondément.  --

column11: Mouth . . . water lily. Note: this is the one time that the "stem" has a barb at the end. Work this fact into your story.  -    -  I´m a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a lily pad with a fishing hook at the stem and a mouth to call me whenever it catches something.  -  (NB: The RHS, 乎, is a kanji in its own right, meaning QUESTION MARK. [thx hereticalrants] Think of a DISTORTED LILY, bent over, by the weight of its heavy flower, into the shape of a QUESTION MARK.) All the CALLs I get these days are phone polls. These poor devils have to ask so many questions every day that their MOUTHs take on the shape of QUESTION MARKs!
column12: Bouche...nénuphar déformé. Le nénuphar est ici un petit peu déformé. En toute rigueur, il s'agit du caractère 平, qui n'est autre que la marque de l'interrogation, le fameux か que l'on prononce en fin de phrase interrogative. Imaginons que la fleur est un peu aplatie et que la racine tend à s'accrocher, car une grenouille s'est perchée sur notre nénuphar, et de sa bouche, elle nous appelle.  --

column11: This kanji belongs to an old Japanese system of measurement and indicates an area of about 36 square feet, or the area taken up by two tatami mats. Its elements: ground . . . water lily.  -    -  A two-mat area is just about as much ground as you will need for a lily pond.  -  A two-mat area is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won´t be comfortable unless the ground is even.
column12: En unité de surface, un tsubo vaut six shakus au carré (3,305 m2), et en unité de volume, il vaut six shakus au cube (6,016 m3). Ce kanji est donc employé au choix pour mesurer le volume de la terre, ou la surface des nénuphars.   --

column11: Words . . . water lily.  -    -  Good evaluation should always be words of even fairness.  -  You get an evaluation copy of MS Word because you want to evaluate whether it´s worth buying the full version. At the end of the evaluation period the CD turns into a lilypad so you can´t use it any more (an innovative new copy-protection trick).
column12: Mots...nénuphars. Les éléments rappelent l'histoire (mots) du nénuphar doublant de surface chaque jour, et couvrant la surface de l'étang en cinquante jours ; la question posée par l'histoire est d'évaluer en combien de temps le nénuphar parvient à recouvrir la moitié de l'étang.  --

column11: Sheaf . . . saber.  -    -  A SABRE is used to cut the stalks of plants being REAPED at harvest. They are then combined into a SHEAF.  -  The Grim Reaper´s name is メリ(Mary)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　Rare or no official Chinese reading.
column12: Gerbe...sabre. De la gerbe associée au sabre naît l'idée de moissonner ou tondre.  --

column11: Sheaf . . . linen.  -    -  I hope this works, you say as you stuff a sheaf of stalks under your blanket but above your linens. Your real hope is that your parents don´t find out that you left the house.  -  Wolverine (sheaf, see reap (#1488)) hopes they invent linen sheets that he won´t keep shredding in his sleep.
column12: Gerbe...linge. Une gerbe de linge évoque le linge à repasser qui s’accumule, et dont on espère en secret qu’une bonne fée passe et repasse.  --  De même que « jeune » porte le sens associé de « faible quantité », le présent ca­ractère peut aussi être rendu par le mot-clé infime, comme dans « infime espoir ».

column11: -    -  "Tip: ""snack"" or ""appetizer"" would be better keywords for this kanji."  -  Wolverine posesses the most treats at the party because he's entreated for being famous.
column12: Gerbe...posséder - thon. Ces amuse-gueule sont faits de petits morceaux de thon séché, disposés en gerbe sur une petite assiette à l’apéritif.  --

column11: Sheaf . . . shovel.  -    -  Here the villain digs a hole with a shovel and covers it with a sheaf, hoping someone will fall in.  -  Wolverine (sheaf, see reap (#1488)) takes out a villain who can´t be cut by smacking the crap out of him with a shovel.
column12: Gerbe...poubelle. Ce kanji représente l'ensemble des phénomènes ou actions néfastes. Imaginons une mauvaise année, où la récolte est si néfaste que nous sommes contraints de la jeter. C'est ainsi que cette gerbe finit tristement à la poubelle. Notre sésame sera une poubelle pleine, afin de suggérer des images assez grotesques.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . bound up . . . villain.  -    -  Just think of the heroine's bosom in a movie. The villain ties up the heroine (to the traintracks or the conveyor belt etc) but her bosom is the body part that is always left sticking out.  -  As you know, female comics villains are always binding the flesh of their bosom up in interesting ways. One has to wonder how these clothes stay on their body at all...
column12: Partie du corps...emballage...poubelle. Le poitrail est cette partie du corps emballée dans une forme volumineuse, grande comme une poubelle pleine.  --

column6: leave, depart; go away; separate; trigram ☲; hexagram ䷝
column11: Top hat . . . villain . . . belt . . . elbow . . . turkey. This is potentially one of the most difficult characters to remember. Tackle it positively and let the image "sink in" by carrying it around with you today and calling it up in your spare moments.  -    -  I´ve finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I´m about to fight him. But what´s this? He´s suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!  -  The left side isn't too hard---a top-hatted villain whose villainy involves belts around elbows? Clearly he's a drug dealer. And the best way to detach yourself from the drug dealer's influence is to go cold turkey.
column12: Chapeau haut de forme...poubelle pleine...traces d'animaux...dinde. « Les poules s'étaient enfuies dès qu'on leur avait ouvert la porte. » Les traces d'animaux sont au pied de la poubelle pleine et couverte. Ce sont des oiseaux, ce que montre la dinde, qui se sont enfuis parce que le personnel d'enlèvement n'aura pas refermé la porte... Alors nous en retenons le sens de séparation, dont le sens est inclus en pratique dans l'élément de gauche.  --

column11: -    -  The imperial seal is usually an impressive mark made with a jewel. However when the letter arrives it has been raining on it and you see that the drops of rain have been transformed into little x’s where some animal legs have run over it.  -  Primitives (to give correct stroke order): tool bench, towel, 4 Xs, jewel. Story: the Imperial Seal is like a kind of coat-of-arms the Emperor can stamp on stuff. Picture that coat-of-arms as depicting a big jewel (say, a diamond) with a motto on a banner above it saying 'let it be (#2074)'. (The emperor must have been a huge Beatles fan).
column12: En haut se trouve l’établi, sur lequel fut fabriqué le sceau impérial, l’un des bijoux de la famille impériale, comme il est écrit au bas. Entre les deux vient une sorte de pluie spéciale, peut-être est-ce le sable employé pour sécher l'encre.  --

column6: kill, slaughter, murder; hurt; to pare off, reduce, clip
column11: Sheaf . . . tree . . . missile.  -    -  X marks the spot on the tree where the missile hit. No doubt, it was meant to kill us.  -  I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to kill your enemies with sheafs of wood used as missiles.
column12: Cette gerbe d'arbres lancés pour frapper fort est là pour tuer.  --

column11: Thread . . . earthworm.  -    -  For remembering the primitive earthworm: Drops of rain were falling so I took my shovel to dig up some earthworms to put them on my fishook..... My story: To have a genuine fishing line you don't just pick up a stick but you also attach some thread onto it and at the end an earthworm must be hung.  -  You need to attach a genuine earthworm to the thread. With plastic bait you won´t catch anything.
column12: Fil...grand rassemblement. Un fil authentique de coton ou de soie, au contraire d'une fibre synthétique, contient un grand rassemblement de fibrilles véritablement nanoscopiques. Il est amusant de former ici une image qui met à contribution des progrès techniques récents.  --

column11: Metal . . . earthworm.  -    -  The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....  -  From the earthworm´s perspective, it most be pretty dull when you are put in a metal bowl, just waiting for being put on the hook on the fishing trip the next day.
column12: Le métal des outils des soldats de la garnison s'émousse peu à peu, à mesure de l'usage.  --

column6: bitter; toilsome, laborious; 8th heavenly stem; Kangxi radical 160
column11: This character pictures food whose taste is so hot and spicy that it makes the hairs on your body stand up as straight as needles.  -  * As a primitive, we shall use this meaning of spicy, except when the two extra strokes are added to the bottom, giving it the form of a tree. Then we take its alternate meaning of a red pepper plant. The connection is obvious.  -  Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, ´cause you just need to get something to drink!  -  Eating spicy food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.
column12: Cette nourriture est si épicée que nos cheveux se dressent comme des aiguilles sur la tête. Un sens figuré est pénible.  --  En composant, nous conservons le sens d'épicé, sauf lorsque deux racines supplémentaires apparaîtront, apportant la connotation d'arbre. Notre sésame sera alors piment.

column11: Tongue . . . spicy.  -    -  This guy´s job is tasting the spicy curry at the local Indian Food Factory. He has to resign from his job before his tongue is rendered completely useless after all the spicy food that he has to try all day long...  -  After my tongue touched the most spicy pepper of all, I had to resign from the contest...too hot for me!
column12: Ce mot-clé rend le double-sens du kanji : démission et mot,  les deux sens du mot terme. Lorsque la langue est chargée de choses trop épicées, elle vous propose de mettre un terme à votre repas.  --

column11: Tree . . . spicy.  -    -  The CATALPA is the tree that bears the SPICY Indian bean (NOTE - The Catalpa is also known as the "Indian Bean" due to the bean pods that grow from it).  -  The caterpillar´s favorite tree is the catalpa because it tastes spicy.
column12: Arbre...épicé. Originaire d’Amérique du Nord, le catalpa, arbre à larges feuilles, se trouve maintenant couramment dans les villes européennes, en raison de sa bonne résistance aux atmosphères polluées - épicées des grandes villes.  --

column11: House . . . spicy.  -    -  The superintendent of a Japanese school district needs a spicy relationship at home after watching girls in miniskirts all day.  -  The superintendent of an old-age house has to make sure the food is never too spicy.
column12: Maison...pénible. L'administrateur ne sort pas de la maison, où il effectue son pénible travail.  --

column6: partition wall; walls of a house; 14th lunar mansion, determinative star γ Pegasi (Algenib)
column11: Ketchup . . . ground.  -    -  Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?  -  Primitive for Ketchup: When the taste is too spicy your mouth has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white flag of surrender. But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
column12: Supplice...terre. On précise ici le lieu du supplice.  --

column11: Ketchup . . . road.  -    -  You can try and evade them, but they´ll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn´t resist it.  -  In order to evade the bear, you lie down on the road, put ketchup on yourself, and play dead.
column12: Supplice...route. Fort heureusement, la victime parvient à éviter le supplice en s'enfuyant par la route.  --

column11: Red pepper . . . ax.  -    -  Don't confuse left primitive with catalpa (#1498). Every time the farmer cuts down the peppers from the red pepper plant, he has to use a brand new axe. This is because the spicy peppers cause the metal to erode very quickly, thereby rendering the axe completely useless.  -  Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden. He rubs red peppers on the edge of his axes, and this seems to keep them sharp like brand new.
column12: Piment...hache. On hache le piment  nouveau pour en faire ressortir le goût. (Vous pouvez aussi voir un arbre debout, lançant un nouveau défi à la hache du bûcheron.)  --

column11: Flowers . . . new.  -    -  New flowers grow in areas of forests which have been chopped down for firewood.  -  If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it´s unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood.
column12: Végétaux...nouveau. On pourra imaginer la tourbe, combustible parmi d'autres, formée par l'entassement successif des couches de végétaux, à chaque nouvelle année.  --

column11: Red pepper . . . see.  -    -  A wise parent lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the red pepper plant, the wise parent says "Try it and see for yourself".  -  I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.
column12: Piment...regarder. Ce qui fait un parent, c'est l'enfant qu'il regarde avec attention et qui lui pimente la vie. On peut aussi voir un parent regardant son enfant grimpé debout sur les plus hautes branches d'un arbre. Un sens associé fort bienvenu est intimité.  --

column11: Simply by turning the dot at the top of the primitive for spicy into a cross shape, we move from things bitter and spicy to things happy.  -    -  Happiness adds a bit (or ten) of spice to your life.  -  This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. 「幸せから一本取ると辛い」 -- if you take but one stroke away from happiness, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百).
column12: Ce petit garçon a renversé de la terre sur le plat très épicé qu’il devait manger, et un sourire de joie se dessine sur son visage : on ne le forcera pas à manger dans un plat souillé.  --

column6: hold in hand; keep; carry out
column11: Happiness . . . fat man.  -    -  Tenacious-D is happy band led by a fat man. (It´s Tenacious-D time, ya muthafucka´, gwaoh!).  -  To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don´t discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn´t drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!
column12: Joie...homme rond, bien en chair. Cette personne ronde et joviale s'attelle à sa tâche avec entrain. C'est un régisseur qui exécute et organise la tâche, dominant parfaitement son affaire.  --

column11: Happiness . . . stamp . . . crotch. Compare frame 1501.  -    -  Recall the fashion model wearing just a stamp over his crotch (clothing (#1399)). When he got happy, of course, it ended up in the news report.  -  The long awaited report, 'Maximising Male Happiness In The Workplace' concluded that making bikinis, with only a stamp sized piece of cloth covering the crotch, compulsory for attractive female staff, was the most cost-effective means of achieving this aim.
column12: Joie...diriger. Lorsque nous recevons une nouvelle ou une récompense, c'est que simplement le destin dirige notre joie.  --

column11: Mouth . . . cornucopia.  -    -  There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.  -  You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.
column12: À crier trop fort, on finit par s’égosiller, et l’on a bientôt le sentiment de cracher des morceaux de barbelé.   --

column11: Thread . . . cornucopia.  -    -  A cornucopia is a twisted goat's horn decorated with coloured threads.  -  [twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of twists are difficult to write, because of the cornucopia of threads the author has to manage.
column12: Fil...fil barbelé. Le sens premier de ce kanji définit l'action de fabriquer une corde, en rassemblant plusieurs brins en une seule a tresse. Au sens figuré, nous trouvons enquêter ou vérifier, qui consistent à s'assurer que tout suit l'ordre global que représente la corde.  --

column11: Cornucopia . . . crotch. Keep distinct from both fare (Frame 1079) and salary (Frame 1449).  -    -  Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the "come" in "income." (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like profit (#906) or earnings (#893)).  -  Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornucopia of crotches.
column12: Fil barbelé...main droite. Après avoir fourni le rouleau de barbelé commandé la veille, le livreur fait un salut de la main droite, et la camionette repart en cahotant sur le chemin vicinal.  --

column11: A drop of . . . brains . . . cornucopia.  -    -  Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.  -  A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.
column12: Une goutte de...cerveau...fil barbelé. Les éléments pourront fournir l'image d'un individu doutant de ses propres capacités mentales, fort humble. Notons surtout que bas ou vil sont les premiers sens du kanji ; humble est un sens dérivé. Enfin, ce kanji est classé sous la clé 十.  --  Les kanjis sont souvent classés au sein des dictionnaires selon des catégories basées sur les « clés », qui sont semblables à ce que nous avons appelé les « composants ». Il y a deux différences essentielles : le nombre de clés a été fixé à deux cent quatorze, elles sont immuables, et le classement est fait en fonction de critères graphiques plutôt que sémantiques, de sorte qu'il n'est pas nécessaire de connaître la signification des clés alors que notre technique de mémorisation des kanjis fait intervenir la signification des composants.   Lorsque vous connaîtrez la prononciation des clés, répertoriées p. 497, vous constaterez qu'elle est souvent une sorte de « traduction » des mots-clés ou des sésames em- ployés dans ce livre. Les clés apparaissent aussi dans l'index par nombre de traits, p. 395, et dans celui des prononciations, p. 407.

column11: Rock . . . lowly.  -    -  There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.  -  A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.
column12: Pierre...humble. La pierre tombale est celle devant laquelle chacun redevient parfaitement humble.   --

column11: The sense of land carried by this kanji is distinct from soil (Frame 161) and ground (Frame 554) in that it is meant to represent land seen from a distance, that is, land as opposed to "water." Its elements: pinnacle . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.  -    -   Everyone is saying that "rice seedling" is actually a mushroom, and it has legs, so I'm making it a Goomba from the Mario games. Also, GOOMBA + GROUND = Mushroom Kingdom. This creates a lot of really great Mario based stories in the upcoming Kanji.   -   About the rare kanji I'm going to use as primitives: [1] http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/圥 - mushroom [2] http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/坴 - land -- I'm going with Smurfland ;-) [3] http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/夌 - to dawdle -- That's the way Mario's mushrooms move Story: From the Pinnacle, when the air is clean and clear, you can see far away, even beyond the sea: Smurfland! (and that land's creatures, the smurfs, of course ;-).
column12: Le continent est cette masse de terre immense formant bloc, et sur laquelle se trouve notamment une grande quantité de tertres.   --

column11: Eye . . . rice seedlings . . . ground.  -    -  Almost everyone in the Mushroom Kingdom has big staring eyes, which makes it hard to get intimate with the residents no matter how hard I try. [+1 decals].  -  My EYEs widened when I saw two GOOMBAs (see land for my story) getting intimate in the Mushroom kingdom. What's Nintendo trying to teach our children?
column12: Nos amis intimes nous regardent, l’œil bienveillant : œil...grande quantité.   --

column11: Rice seedlings . . ground . . . fat man . . . muscle.  -    -  Mushroom...Fat man....= Mario. Mario jumps on top of Bowser's forces, crushing their evil power.  -  Mario may be a fat man in the Mushroom Kingdom, but he's actually pretty small and has to use the forces of gravity to defeat the pure muscle power of his enemies. You can see that that muscle power being flattened here.
column12: Grande quantité...hommes ronds...muscles. Ce kanji nous rappelle le proverbe « l’union fait la force ».  --

column11: Rice seedlings . . . ground . . . fat man . . . oven fire.  -    -  (NB: The top of 熱 (埶) is a rare kanji meaning "art". We already have 術 (#1644) so I call it ARTISTRY.) Keeping a primitive dwelling HEATed ain't easy! It requires much ARTISTRY to keep those EMBERS glowing. (I decompose ARTISTRY as DIVOT (坴) ... ROUND: Tiger Woods' uncanny ARTISTRY for whacking DIVOTs as ROUND as golf balls. 坴 is a rare kanji meaning "clod"; we already have 塊 (#2180) so I call it DIVOT; I see it pictographically: a golfer [above] whacking a divot [below].)  -  This is Mario avoiding the fire's heat.
column12: Grande quantité...hommes ronds...chaudron. Imaginant une grande fête rassemblant de nombreux convives autour d’un chaudron, il est aisé de percevoir la chaleur du soleil nous chauffant les épaules.  --

column11: Named after a diamond-shaped flower (the water caltrop), this key word refers to things shaped like a diamond. Its elements: flower . . . rice seedlings . . . walking legs.  -    -  Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!  -  Not a real diamond but a baseball one. No proper bases so we improvise, 1st is a bunch of flowers, 2nd is the pile of rice seedlings and so on... watch the running legs charge around after a big hit!
column12: Ce kanji définit la macle d'eau ou châtaigne d'eau, dont le fruit comestible est en forme de losange. On peut lire les éléments végétal...tas qui se remet à marcher (les jambes qui marchent apparaissant en bas). On pourra aussi penser à la macle du cristallographe, qui fait apparaître des cristaux en forme de losange, par un mouvement global de tous les atomes du cristal, que l'on peut associer au tas qui se remet à marcher. L'élément végétal ne vous étonnera pas mais ne l'oubliez pas pour autant.   --  Ce kanji est parfois abusivement traduit par « diamant », alors que les Japonais écrivent diamant en katakana depuis longtemps : ダイヤモンド. Or en anglais, « diamond » signifie aussi losange, mais aussi carreau (◊). Bientôt nous entendrons parler de « la face sombre de la Lune » ou d’autres sornettes, et il faudra déployer une grande énergie pour expliquer la méprise. En tout état de cause, diamant s’écrit traditionnellement comme ceci: 金剛石(こんごうせき)

column11: Pinnacle . . . rice seedlings . . . walking legs.  -    -  Ancient Japanese built a mausoleum for the "unknown rice farmer". It's on the pinnacle of Mt. Fuji, and it has a statue of a guy with huge walking legs planting rice seedlings as he goes.  -  At the pinnicle is a mausolem. The ground is sown with rice seedings to stop the dead from rising on walking legs.
column12: Tertre...tas qui se remet en marche. La foule (tas qui se remet à marcher) quitte le mausolée placé au tertre, après la cérémonie funéraire.  --

column11: This kanji is the 12th sign of the Chinese zodiac: the sign of the hog. It is best learned by thinking of an acorn-eating hog in connection with the primitive meaning given below.  -  * The top hat represents the external shape of the acorn, and the unusual but easily written complex of strokes beneath it (which you might also see as distortions of an elbow and person) stands for the mysterious secret whereby the acorn contains the oak tree in a nutshell.  -  A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.  -  Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him.
column12: Symbole du douzième signe du zodiaque chinois, ce kanji représente le signe du cochon. Le mieux sera d'imaginer un cochon mangeur de glands, en raison du sésame ci-dessous.   --  * Le chapeau haut de forme représente la pipe du gland et l'ensemble insolite qui suit, dans lequel nous reconnaissons le coude et Tintin en train de s'extraire du cœur du gland, symbolise le mystérieux secret par lequel le petit gland contient le chêne entier gravé en sa coquille. Nos sésames serons gland et cœur.

column11: Tree . . . acorn.  -    -  In the nucleus of the acorn, all the DNA is stored -- the building blocks for a new tree.  -  The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.
column12: Arbre...cœur du gland. Les notions de cœur des choses, noyau de l’atome, ADN, germe sont regroupées dans ce kanji.  --

column11: Acorn . . . saber.  -    -  This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.  -  While it´s traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre.
column12: Gland...sabre - stylet. Je serais bien étonné qu'il n'y ait pas un artiste japonais qui ne se soit un jour amusé à graver des visages, sur des glands, à l'aide d'une sorte de stylet par exemple. Ce kanji fait aussi référence à une portion de temps, de deux heures, comme si le temps était un être matériel gravant peu à peu sa marque temporelle dans l'éther.  --

column11: Words . . . acorn.  -    -  I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!  -  The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.
column12: Ce qui est concerné est la chose dont il est question : le cœur du sujet de conversation.  --

column11: Acorn . . . muscle.  -    -  Censure is the political equivalent of a "strongly worded letter," according to Cornell's School of Law. It is a flex of muscle by congress against the current president, but it is a very weak one. Imagine censure as congress flexing as hard as it can, only to have a little acorn-sized bump of muscle pop up suddenly.  -  Acorn Power is the people´s way to CENSURE a congressman you don´t agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.
column12: La commission de censure va faire appliquer la force sur le noyau révolu­tionnaire qui prend naissance.  --

column11: Resin . . . road.  -    -  Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...  -  No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I´m stuck!
column12: Résine...route. Après le « poteau Michelin », fait de solide béton, sont apparus des panneaux indicateurs en plastique (résine),  mentionnant l’ensemble des lieux importants, sur les routes. L’histoire ne le dit pas, mais le kanji fait surtout référence au discours oral.  --

column6: art, skill, special feat; method, technique
column11: Boulevard . . . resin.  -    -  Behold the "Boulev´Art" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.  -  The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!
column12: Boulevard...résine. On se demande parfois avec quelle technique les graphistes des temps modernes parviennent à atteindre des endroits inaccessibles, enduisant de résine les murs surmontant les boulevards.   --

column11: House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . ice.  -    -  Don't mix up with cool (#1404), when the cool boys order each other around. This kind of cold has to do with weather. When its cold outside, I stay at home and have hot celery soup with chicken legs to keep out the ice. 寒い　＝　さむい　＝cold.  -  Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn´t get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.
column12: Il fait si froid que sous le toit et sous la carcasse de la maison placée sur des plots, les pattes, le gel parvient à passer et nous refroidir.  --

column11: Whiskey bottle . . . grass skirt.  -    -  Grass Skirt primitive: Picture some Hawaiian girls, wearing grass skirts and tropical scarfs (or leis), doing a dance. "3, 4, 5, 6 pick up all the celery sticks!".  -  A classic alcohol commercial: whiskey being brewed while girls dance around, scantily clad in their grass skirts.
column12: Le brasseur fabrique un alcool à partir de végétaux fermentés, et doit aérer le mélange pour activer les levures. Lors du brassage, c'est notre puissant hercule qui remue la lourde masse. Un sens figuré signifiant réaliser ou œuvrer fait pendant à notre verbe « brasser ».  --  Il existe un sens figuré signifiant réaliser ou œuvrer, comme c’est le cas du verbe brasser en français.

column11: Words . . . grass skirt.  -    -  Speaking complicated words to set her head spinning, the island girl in the grass skirt says demurely "I defer (yield) to your judgment, wise one".  -  I talked to my Japanese spouse, who confirmed that this kanji does not mean "defer" as in "put off, delay". It means "defer" in the sense of "submit" or "yield".
column12: Mots...hercule. Le jeu d'écriture (les mots) permet de faire passer la possession de l'ancien au nouveau propriétaire, avec la force de la loi, forte comme hercule.  --

column11: Ground . . . grass skirt. The lot of this key word refers to a portion of land.  -    -  My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.  -  On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a lot, a ground must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a grass skirt.
column12: Un nouveau lot de terrain vient s’installer parmi ceux déjà en place. Il s'incruste avec une telle force qu'on imagine notre hercule repoussant les limites de la mitoyenneté ; bientôt une nouvelle maison se construit.  --

column11: Woman . . . grass skirt.  -    -  Conversation at a party: A: "Who is that lass?" B: "Which one?" A: "The woman wearing the grass skirt." B: "Alas, I don´t know".  -  Two Irishmen visit Hawaii and see a woman wearing a grass skirt and nothing else. "That´s some lassie," says one to the other. "But alass Danny Boy, you can´t be bringing her home.".
column12: Cette demoiselle est une femme attirante qui a pris notre hercule à son service pour sa protection.   --  Chapitre trente-neuf  D'autres plantes   LES composants concernant les plantes restant à voir sont généralement formés de lignes horizontales et verticales, représentant les plantes et le sol sur lequel elles poussent. En conséquence, il serait bon d'étudier les éléments de cette section d'une seule traite, ou de les avoir bien assimilés avant d'aborder le groupe suivant.

column11: Grow up . . . breasts.  -    -  If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it´s poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.  -  I'm creating a new primitive meaning here: Grow up = Alice in Wonderland. Alice in Wonderland finds a bottle marked "poison". She drinks it, and her breasts grow to an enormous size!
column12: Grandir...seins. Le poison pourrait être ce bébé qui commence à bouger dans le ventre de sa maman, et qui provoque la croissance des seins.  --

column11: Grow up . . . thread.  -    -  This kanji has nothing to do with elementary school - it means element, elemental, basic, bare. Imagine the thread as a thread connecting all life, starting from the basic elements and growing up into everything.  -  This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself.
column12: Il s’agit de ce qui est à la base des choses, comme un atome, une enzyme grandir...fil.   --

column6: wheat, barley, oats; simplified form of Kangxi radical 199
column11: Grow up . . . walking legs.  -    -  BARLEY beverages give GROWN UPs teetering WALKING LEGS.  -  "Grown up" barley, i.e. beer, is what gets you tottering legs.
column12: Croître...jambes qui marchent. Cette orge magique croît derrière les jambes qui marchent à mesure que le semeur répand les graines.  --

column11: Grow up . . . moon.  -    -  The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.  -  Once in a blue moon refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we´re talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.
column12: Grandir...lune. La couleur bleue est très importante au Japon. C'est la couleur des arbres, des grenouilles, des feux de la circulation, et aussi de la lune qui grandit, nous dit-on ici.  --

column11: Rice . . . blue.  -    -  Very refined people in the upper classes have skin as pale as rice and blue blood.  -  "Uh, why is your rice blue?" "It's been refined! And by 'refined' I mean it's been in the back of my fridge for a few months.".
column12: Riz...bleu. On peut imaginer le riz  raffiné comme traité à l’aide d’un azurant, pour le rendre encore plus blanc. De raffiné, le sens de ce kanji s’étant à précision ou exactitude.   --

column11: Words . . . blue.  -    -  He seldom said a word 言; but once in a blue 青 moon he would solicit some help.  -  That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he´s blue in the face. There´s a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say "No Soliciting".
column12: « Je lui dirais les mots bleus, les mots qu’on dit avec les yeux... » chantait Christophe en 1975. Ces mots bleus traitent en pratique des demandes, sous diverses formes.  --

column11: State of mind . . . blue. Do not confuse with emotion (Frame 662).  -    -  Data is feeling blue about not having any feelings ... hey, wait a minute.  -  Feeling blue is a state of mind where you´re dominated by your feelings.
column12: Etat d’esprit...bleu. Plutôt que « voir la vie en rose », le kanji compassion nous propose de la voir en bleu, ou d’avoir l’état d’esprit bleu.   --

column11: Take the key word in its associations with the weather (unless that tempts you to include the primitive for weather, which doesn't belong here). Its elements: sun . . . blue.  -    -  Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather´s cleared up!  -  When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.
column12: Soleil...(ciel) bleu. Vous pouvez bien entendu former une image basée sur le temps clair, mais notez que le sens du kanji n’est pas limité aux phénomènes atmosphériques.  --

column11: Water . . . blue.  -    -  Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.  -  Bottles of water claim to be pure. They´re generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure.
column12: Eau...bleue. L’énorme majorité des piscines sont peintes en bleu, ainsi l’eau paraît plus pure.  --

column11: Blue . . . contend. Do not confuse with calm (Frame 1230).  -    -  When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it´s usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.  -  Don't confuse with silence (#240), something achieved through action. On the other hand, quiet refers to a personal quality of not speaking out. Members of Blue-man group jump into the wrestling ring of contenders for tag-team wrestling. Though the other contenders are screaming, the blue men never say anything - they are a very quiet bunch, that Blue-man group. Primitive order: blue man group's first and main characteristic is being blue and quiet; only later did they decide to become wrestling contenders.
column12: Bleu...querelle. Voyez le « calme avant la tempête », alors que le ciel encore bleu laisse présager une querelle divine.  --

column11: Wheat . . . blame. This key word has to do with measurement, and should be kept distinct from the kanji for quantity (Frame 189) - even though the meanings are similar.  -    -  On many wheat cereal boxes, there is a disclaimer stating that "This package is sold by weight, not by volume. Some settling of contents may have occurred." well they only say that because they don´t want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains.  -  The volume of the wheat crop is way down this year! Blame the weather!
column12: Blé...bourriche d’huîtres. On nous propose ici de mesurer le volume du blé en utilisant une bourriche d’huîtres en guise de mesure. Il s’agit d’un « n- volume », au sens mathématique du terme : en pratique, la notion de surface est incluse au même titre que celle de volume.   --

column11: Person . . . blame. The key word refers to financial bonds.  -    -  Bonds are guarnteed by the government so if they fail there is one person you can blame - the prime minister!  -  Mr. T´s plot of world domination is foiled. Who is to blame? Bond. James Bond.
column12: Tintin...obligation. Une dette est une obligation du débiteur envers le créditeur, et ici Tintin est le débiteur. Vous pouvez revoir 1280.  --

column11: Water . . . blame.  -    -  When pickling you MUST use distilled water! When it doesn´t come out right, generally it is the water that is to blame.  -  Bad water is to blame for the process of pickling.
column12: Eau...obligation. Pour les aliments à faire saumurer, c'est obligatoire : « j'ai piscine ». Traduit avec nos éléments, cela donne obligation de séjour dans l'eau.   --

column11: Grow up . . . rags. This character represents the "outside" of a garment, just as the kanji for back (Frame 426) depicted the "inside" or lining.  -    -  When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.  -  (Thanks to zerOrange) I grew up underground, and whenever I went to the surface I wore a scarf to avoid scrutiny.
column12: Grandir...écharpe. Ce kanji décrit l'extérieur d'un vêtement, la partie que l'on montre, alors que le kanji arrière (436) en décrit l'intérieur, la partie occulte.  --

column11: Keep this kanji distinct from that for sack (Frame 1081). Its elements are: person . . . surface.  -    -  Superficial people (ie those who are only concerned about the surface) are obsessed with expensive bags.  -  Do you know why every person in Japan has a Louis Vuitton bag? After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world´s worst). An image on tv of the crash showed Louis Vuitton bags (whose LV logo covered surface was somehow impervious) litering the crash site. From that point on they stuck in Japanese people´s mind´s as durable and high quality. (True story).
column12: Tintin s’est revêtu de ce sac de paille, traditionnellement destiné à conserver le riz. Tintin...surface.   --

column11: Water . . . grow up . . . dagger . . . thread.
