Do not confuse with upright (Frame 58).  -    -  To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her threads, even when she went into the water.  -  (rgravina) To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her Spiderman underwear (to remember the position of thread), even when she went into the water.
column12: Eau...grandir...poignard...fil - tradition. A viril est associé immaculé. Evoquons alors les preux chevaliers du Moyen-Age qui, lors d’une cérémonie s’apparentant à un baptême (l’eau) célébrée à la maturité (grandir), rece­vaient selon la tradition (le fil) un sabre béni (le poignard). Vous pourrez passer quelques minutes à remettre les éléments dans l’ordre, mais ce kanji, complexe car il ressemble aux deux suivants, trouvera aisément sa place.  --

column11: Grow up . . . dagger . . . St. Bernard dog. The connotation of this character should be kept distinct from that for vow (Frame 1214) and promise (Frame 1462).  -    -  Imagine a totalitarian regime where, while growing up, you have to pledge allegiance to the flag at dagger-point and with St. Bernard guard dogs watching you.  -  In order to pledge into her sorority, Alice had to stab a St. Bernard with a dagger. (Come on! DO it, Alice!).
column12: Grandir...sabre...grand homme. Le grand homme prend ici l'engagement de bien manier le sabre lorsqu'il aura grandi.  --

column11: Mouth . . . pledge.  -    -  This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it.  -  I make my mouth pledge to consume less.
column12: Bouche...engagement. Il s’agit de consommer une tasse de thé ou de café, par exemple.  --

column11: House . . . grow up . . . mouth.  -    -  With kids growing up in your house, you have to keep them from harm of putting anything in their mouth, paint chips, bleach, knvies, etc.  -  This is silly, but.. If a house suddenly grows up from your mouth, you will come to great harm.
column12: Maison...grandir...bouche. Lorsque la maison grandit, chaque membre commence à émettre sa propre opinion, et cela peut causer du tort à la bonne marche de l’ensemble. Trop de cuisiniers gâtent la sauce.  --

column11: Car . . . harm. Hint: the image of an auto going "out of control" may help keep this key word distinct from others like it, such as manipulate (Frame 864).  -    -  The roads are icy, and a whole bunch of cars have spun out of control! Luckily, it was just a couple of dents; nobody was harmed.  -  Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!
column12: Voiture...tort. Pensez à une voiture dont le chauffeur ne sait plus conduire.  --

column11: Harm . . . saber.  -    -  [proportion; comparatively; divide; cut; separate; split] Hey, don´t take this out of proportion! I did you just a little harm, no need to come over here with a saber...  -  As shown on this pie-chart, the proportion of people harmed by sabres is relatively a small slice compared to those harmed by guns.
column12: En tentant de briser quelque chose avec notre sabre, nous risquons de causer du tort au sabre, à la chose ou aux deux.  --

column11: The key word refers to the fundamental guiding principles of a government or other organization. Its elements: House . . . grow up . . . eyes . . . heart.  -    -  The constitution is important. At least my parents thought so. In the house where I grew up, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) eye of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by heart.  -  The constitution states the following rights: You may live in your own house and grow up. And you will never be watched by big brother's eye so they cannot control your heart (your believes).
column12: Maison...grandir...filet...cœur. Est ici définit l'ensemble des principes d'un gouvernement ou d'une organisation. Le filet rassemble les vues de tous les habitants, le cœur ici, afin que l'ensemble grandisse au mieux à l'intérieur des frontières, la maison.  --

column11: A single drop added to the element for grow up gives us the character for life.  -  * As a primitive, we may think of a microscopic cell, that miraculous unit that grows up to become a living being.  -  This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.  -  Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.
column12: Une simple goutte ajoutée à l’élément grandir lui donne vie, avec la connotation de naissance. Le sésame sera un ovule, qui grandit et devient un être vivant.  --

column6: a star, planet; any point of light; 25th lunar mansion, determinative star α Hydrae (Alphard)
column11: Sun . . . cell.  -    -  The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.  -  Sun is a star that has given life. Can´t say that of any other stars yet.
column12: Soleil...vivant. Songez que certains recherchent des signes de vie dans l’univers, scrutant toutes les étoiles, chacune étant un Soleil.  --

column11: Woman . . . cell.  -    -  When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon).  -  Woman change their surname when they "start their new life".
column12: Lorsque la femme donne la vie à son enfant, il hérite aussi son nom de famille.   --

column11: State of mind . . . cell.  -    -  Sex is the only state of mind for many men through their whole life.  -  When you´re in the state of mind for creating new lives.
column12: Ne cherchez plus : le sexe de l’enfant dépend tout simplement de l’état d’esprit de l'ovule lors de la fécondation. On trouve en significations annexes caractère et propriétés.   --

column11: Cow . . . cell.  -    -  Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.  -  In the 21st century, animal sacrifice is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.
column12: Vache...vie. Peut-être désirerez-vous revoir le cadre 710.  --

column11: Vase . . . cliff . . . cell.  -    -  If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff.  -  The salesman is standing on the cliff´s edge. "Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I´ll take my own life"! Man, that´s selling on pressure.
column12: Vase...falaise...ovule. Il s’agit de production industrielle autant que de reproduction.   --

column11: This character, used for everything from little humps of hills to camel humps, easily suggests the hunch on the pig's back and hind parts where the best cuts of meat are to be found (and hence the English expression for luxury, "living high off the hog.") The elements we have to work with are: pinnacle . . . walking legs . . . cell.  -    -  You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.  -  A woman takes her bra off and what happens? Nine months later the hump in her belly pops out between her legs as a new life.
column12: Voyons une sorte de mini-séisme dans ce caractère: la vie qui apparaît sous les jambes qui marchent est à comprendre comme la terre qui enfle, créant une protubérance sur le sol. Il apparaît donc une sorte de tertre à l’endroit en question.  --

column11: Mountain . . . walking legs . . . bushes.  -    -  Walking legs over "bushes" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 sew (#1563), 逢 tryst (#2417), 蜂 bee (#2687), and 鋒 sword´s point (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. "Pointy" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.  -  Upon reaching the summit of the mountain, I noticed my walking legs were all gouged up from walking through prickly bushes.
column12: Le sommet est la partie de la montagne sur laquelle les arbres ne poussent pas, à cause de l’altitude. On y voit donc un individu dont les jambes qui mar­chent sont empêtrées dans les rares buissons qui s’accrochent aux rochers.  --

column11: Thread . . . walking legs . . . bushes . . . road.  -    -  Pointy primitive; with a pointy needle you sew a road (-------) of threads.  -  Good thing I brought some thread, cause I need to sew my pants that I tore up walking through the bushes (see summit (#1562)) before we hit the road to go back down the mountain.
column12: Imaginons un individu aux prises avec une machine à coudre dont il ne maîtrise pas le fonctionnement. Le fil est bienvenu. Puis nous voyons le pied-de-biche (les jambes qui marchent) suit son chemin - route mais à la suite d’une fausse manœuvre il se coince et la machine est bloquée par un amoncellement de fil (le buisson).   --

column11: Fingers . . . bush . . . suspended from the ceiling.  -    -  I put my fingers together in worship of the bush that hangs from the ceiling -- that wonderful mistletoe which has gotten me kissed by many a girl.  -  A bush hanging from the ceiling = mistletoe. Mistletoe was worshipped by ancient pagans because it's evergreen and the viscous juice of its white berries resembles human semen. Of course, in kanjiland, they don't worship mistletoe, but mistlefinger.
column12: Doigts...buissons...suspendus au plafond. On pourra imaginer ce culte comme celui consistant à suspendre des rameaux de buisson bénis.  --

column11: Bushes . . . glue.  -    -  In an attempt to increase a bush's longevity, an incompitent gardener glues all the leaves back on that have fallen off. Maybe he should have tried watering it instead.  -  This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !
column12: Buissons...colle. Pour assurer au rameau de buis(son) la plus grande longévité, on place un point de colle sur chacune de ses petites feuilles.  --

column11: Metal . . . longevity. As you probably guessed from the elements, the key word refers to the casting of metals.  -    -  We take a casting because metal will have much greater longevity than the original.  -  They made a metal casting of the Chinese man who glued shrubs to himself to increase his longevity. It´s now sold around the world as it´s thought that having one will increase your own longevity..
column12: Métal...longévité. Comme le suggèrent les éléments, le mot-clé fait notamment référence au coulage des métaux.   --

column11: Bamboo . . . Christmas tree . . . once upon a time.  -    -   Once upon a time, Santa Claus visited Asia and left presents under bamboo Christmas trees for all the children who enrolled in his Asian beta-testing...  -  Japanese father enrolls his student in a well-rounded school: they teach eastern traditions (the way of the bamboo), western traditions (like Christmas trees), and also teach literature (once upon a time).
column12: Bambou...bêche...autrefois. Ce registre est l'endroit où tous les actes d'état-civil sont consignés, originellement sur des tablettes de bambou, depuis des temps immémoriaux, autrefois ; la bêche est employée pour planter les bornes du cadastre.  --

column11: Bonsai . . . sun.  -    -  In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.  -  When it´s springtime you can only leave the bonsai out when the sun has gone down. Their little leaves can´t handle too much heat.
column12: On sort les bonsaïs au printemps pour les habituer au soleil.   --

column6: father; a plant with white flowers
column11: Tree . . . springtime.  -    -  The tree of spring. Fact: Camellia are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter [early spring?].  -  Anyone who´s lived in Japan knows camellia are by far the first tree of spring to flower. And how can you miss those shockingly pink flowers!
column12: Arbre...printemps. Au début du printemps, le camélia donne des fleurs splendides qui annoncent le printemps.  --

column11: Bonsai . . . rice grains.  -    -  Simplistic and peaceful life: A bonsai to trim and enough rice to eat...　RTK2:　タイ　泰国　たいこく (Thailand).  -  If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.
column12: Bonsaï...irrigation. Ce paysage paisible nous montre une impressionnante collection de bonsaïs... et un puissant système d'irrigation.   --  On peut encore percevoir cette impression de paisibilité dans certains pays d’Asie. C’est par exemple la Thaïlande, dont ce kanji est le symbole.

column11: Bonsai . . . heavens.  -    -  When you play music to them, your bonsai will grow like they are in heaven.  -  In heaven you are surrounded by bonsai trees (full-sized ones fall through the clouds) while you play music on your harp. I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds.
column12: Bonsaï...cieux. Les bonsaïs se rassemblent quelquefois dans le plus grand secret et laissent le vent jouer entre leurs petites feuilles une musique céleste. Rassembler est un sens associé.  --

column11: House . . . bonsai.  -    -  Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn´t survive.  -  On this rather boring ´big brother´ type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.
column12: Maison...bonsaï. Le message est clair: pour un bonsaï, la réalité consiste à se trouver dans une maison.   --

column11: Bonsai . . . cornstalk. Use a ritualistic, religious meaning.  -    -  You have to be really dedicated to make a bonsai tree out of a cornstalk.  -  To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.
column12: Imaginez un rite au cours duquel sont donnés en offrande aux Dieux un bonsaï et une tige de maïs, comme pour garantir l’abondance de la récolte.  --

column11: Person . . . dedicate.  -    -  The stipend is given to the student-PERSON who has come to Japan DEDICATED to study.  -  People who are highly dedicated to their jobs get good salaries/stipends.
column12: Tintin...offrande. Il s’agit d’un salaire: celui dont par exemple Tintin a fait offrande à Hergé durant sa longue carrière.  --

column11: Tree . . . dedicate.  -    -  This wooden rod has one very simple dedication engraved on it: "Spare the rod, spoil the child...".  -  The wood from this tree is dedicated to making rods to flog naughty kids.
column12: Arbre...offrande. Cet arbre entier est débité en bâtons de pèlerin, pour lesquels chaque pèlerin a fait une considérable offrande.  --

column11: Words . . . cabbage.  -    -  Cabbage primitive: When a cabbage is growing up, you must put it in your mouth before it flowers, because that´s when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it´s called ´bolting´ or something. When you´re discreet, you try to make your words like a cabbage: well-layered, but in an unassuming way.  -  Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.
column12: Mots...chou. Vous êtes reçu par l'empereur et commencez l'entretien : « Bonjour mon chou ! »  --

column11: Cabbage . . . muscle.  -    -  With enough diligence, Koreans can turn ordinary cabbage into powerful kimchi.  -  Growing cabbages takes muscle and diligence.
column12: Chou...muscle. Le travailleur assidû chérit ses muscles pour mieux les motiver.  --

column11: Water . . . scarecrow. The key word has come to refer to things Chinese in general, including the kanji themselves (for which this character is used).  -    -  Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat/water into learning the kanji. For right-hand kanji primitive - The dumb Western husband of a Japanese woman buys her flowers to apologise, after he opened his big mouth and said "kanji are a stupid writing system"..  -  In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.
column12: Gouttes d’eau...épouvantail. Le mot-clé fait référence à diverses choses chinoises, y compris les kanjis eux-mêmes, malheureusement trop souvent perçus comme une succession d’horribles épouvantails arrivant l’un après l’autre, au goutte à goutte.   --

column11: Mouth . . . scarecrow.  -    -  A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: "...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji".  -  I will let out a huge sigh of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.
column12: Bouche...épouvantail. Celui qui ne cesse de se lamenter finit par épouvanter le monde avec sa simple bouche.   --

column11: Scarecrow . . . turkey.  -    -  It is difficult for a scarecrow to scare a turkey or else they would´ve been called scareturkeys.  -  Learning Kanji is difficult for Turkeys.
column12: L’ épouvantail crée une difficulté à la dinde.  --

column11: Flower . . . silage . . . needle.  -    -  The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: ´Excuse me, I couldn´t help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.´ The villager gruffly replies: ´No it ´aint. It´s all muck. An´ I´m gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.´.  -  (I'm substituting greenhouse for silage. It is also full of all types of plants, and the shape resembles the windows that cover the building to let in the light.) See the splendor of the roses filling the greenhouse, beauty atop a stem of needles (thorns).
column12: Les kanjis étant nés en Chine, l'Empire du Milieu, il n'est pas surprenant que ce caractère élogieux en soit aussi un symbole : on n'est jamais mieux servi que par soi-même. Les éléments ne nous éclairent pourtant guère : végétaux...ensilage...aiguille. Imaginons alors un symbole de la médecine chinoise, à base de décoctions (l'ensilage de végétaux) et d'aiguille d'acuponcteur, quelque chose d'assez splendide somme toute, puisque cette ancienne médecine tient encore la dragée haute aux médecines actuelles.  --

column11: A drop of . . . silage . . . walking stick . . . floor. The character is written in the order of its elements.  -    -  The porter drooped under the heavy load of silage placed on his back.  -  Even a drop of silage is enough to make an old man with a walking stick droop low down to the floor. (rgravina - fixed up order).
column12: Une goutte de...ensilage...bâton de marche...plancher. Le caractère se trace dans l’ordre d’apparition des éléments. A pendre est associé goutter, plus utile pour former une image.  --

column11: Eyes . . . droop.  -    -  Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.  -  Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see droop (#1582)). When you are drowsy you have "droopy eyes". That is, you have Droopy´s eyes!
column12: Œil...pendre. Nos yeux « pendent » de sommeil.   --

column11: Metal . . . droop.  -    -  Wasn´t it a cursed spindle that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the spindle was the metal that caused her to droop and eventually sleep for 100 years.  -  Spindle: the needle that drops on an LP record player. This is made of metal. It droops. Viola.
column12: Métal...pendre. Il s’agit des poids de la balance, ou du filet de pêche.  --

column6: ride, ascend; avail oneself of; numerary adjunct for vehicles
column11: The simplest way to remember this character is to find the sprig of wheat in it, hidden because it doubles up with one stroke of silage.  -    -  The hardest part about being a farmer is when it comes to the slaughter. "Come on boys, we're going for a ride!" "Oh boy, a ride!" say the little wheat sprigs, hopping onto the tractor. The farmer then takes them off to become silage, tears in his eyes.  -  [ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus.
column12: Le plus simple est de reconnaître dans ce kanji le blé, dont le trait hori­zontal est commun avec l’ensilage. Le kanji exprime l’idée d’embarquer dans un véhicule. Si vous peinez à retenir les éléments, imaginez une remorque agricole sur laquelle a été embarquée une cargaison d’ensilage, et comme aucun transport n’est gratuit, le blé représentera le prix de la course.  --

column11: Ride . . . saber.  -    -  Remember the wheat we cut with scythes (farmer's equivalent of a saber) for profit (#906)?　Well, we harvested too much and have to use the surplus for silage. 過剰 (かじょう) : excess.  -  If there is a surplus of people on the ride, they may just need to get rid of a few passengers using a saber.
column12: Chevaucher...sabre. Le chargement excède la norme admissible, alors d'un coup de sabre on coupe tout ce qui dépasse, ce qui est en excès.   --  Chapitre quarante  Sept heures moins le quart  QUELQUES composants nous restent à voir, qui concernent le temps, deux derniers points cardinaux, à partir desquels nous aborderons quelques kanjis supplémentaires.

column11: The final stroke of this kanji is a rare shape, which we have not met before and will only meet in this character and others that include it as a primitive. We are more accustomed to seeing it straightened out as part of other shapes - for instance, as the second stroke of mouth. If you need any help at all with this character, you may picture it as two hands of a clock pointing to what time it is now. The element above it, meeting, should easily relate to that image.  -  * We shall use clock as the primitive meaning of this character, in line with the above explanation.  -  My MEETING is at 7- but that´s NOW!  -  (re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!
column12: Le dernier trait de ce kanji est une forme rare, que nous ne verrons que dans ce caractère et dans ceux où il intervient. Nous sommes plus habitués, à dire vrai, à le voir descendre verticalement, comme par exemple, lorsque nous traçons le second trait de bouche. Imaginez-y les deux aiguilles d'une horloge, indiquant l'heure qu'il est maintenant (environ sept heures moins le quart). L'élément du dessus, assemblée devrait trouver aisément sa place, mais notez que le tracé à la main diffère un peu.   --  * Horloge sera quelquefois employé comme sésame, compte tenu de cette image. Les deux caractères suivants pourront vous donner quelques angoisses, car ils sont formés des mêmes composants, et l'élément-clé ne change que d'emplacement, passant du bas à la gauche.

column11: Clock . . . mouth.  -    -  This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.  -  Batteries included with this clock. Open the mouth at the back and insert them after purchase.
column12: Horloge...bouche. Une horloge vient de tomber dans votre bouche, et s’y trouve maintenant incluse. Notez que la scène propose bien de placer la bouche sous l’horloge, pour que cette dernière puisse vraiment y tomber.  --

column6: sing, hum; recite; type of poetry
column11: As we have already learned characters for poem (Frame 370), chant (Frame 21), and song (Frame 508), it is important to protect this key word with an image all its own. Its elements are the same as those above; only the position has changed: mouth . . . clock.  -    -  To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.  -  Versify this kanji as follows: Hickery dickery dock, the mouth ran by the clock.
column12: De notre bouche sort ce que nous avons maintenant présent à l’esprit lorsque nous récitons. Nos paroles partent vers les auditeurs, horizontalement. C’est pourquoi la bouche est cette fois placée du côté gauche.  --

column11: Clock . . . heart.  -    -  Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.  -  Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man wished for a heart and the wizard gave him that dinky little clock instead?
column12: Horloge...cœur. Le coeur exprime ici la volonté, l'aspiration, et le désir n'est autre qu'une aspiration qui demande à être satisfaite maintenant.  --

column11: A pair of jewels . . . clock.  -    -  Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a clock built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.  -  Jesus is coming soon. Prepare to meet the king of kings now. Practice your harp playing skills all future angels!...　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　キン　琴線　きんせん("heart strings").
column12: Une paire de bijoux...maintenant. Le kanji désigne la harpe japonaise, le koto, une sorte de harpe posée horizontalement. Notre harpe se dit « koto vertical » en japonais.  --

column6: the passive, female principle in Chinese philosophy (yin); dark; secret
column10: Ombre, principe féminin, négatif, Yin, ubac
column11: Just as the sunshine (Frame 1397) represents the masculine principle in nature (Yang), the shade stands for the feminine principle (Yin). Its elements are: pinnacle . . . clock . . . rising cloud.  -    -  There are three types of shade: 1. natural (a high pinnacle), 2. man-made buildings (a clock tower), 3. meteorological (a cloud).  -  Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!
column12: Tertre...maintenant...nuage. Les deux derniers éléments se combinent aisément, et si vous vous imaginez sur le tertre, vous retiendrez le premier. Alors que le soleil (1410) représente le principe masculin, positif, l'ombre qui se dessine ici représente le principe féminin, négatif, (Yin). Il montre la partie de la montagne à proximité du tertre la moins exposée au soleil, l'ubac.  --

column11: Think of this character as identical to the halberd (Frame 1311) except that the final stroke has been omitted. Return to that character and devise some image to take this difference into account.  -    -  Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat.  -  Your halberd doesn´t have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand).
column12: Pensez à ce kanji comme un ancêtre de notre lance de 1325, car il lui manque un trait : la pointe. Cet ancêtre induit alors auparavant.  --

column11: Cave . . . beforehand.  -    -  The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.  -  Rename the "beforehand" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can´t get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface.
column12: Appentis...auparavant. L'idée contenue dans ce kanji se rapporte à quelque chose fait avant de commencer le gros du travail, comme l'appentis que l'on édifie avant de commencer une construction.  --

column11: Beforehand . . . head.  -    -  Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you´re in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.  -  You bang your head on the ATM, wishing you´d deposited some money beforehand.
column12: Pensez à un dépôt bancaire ou à placer un enfant en dépôt : la tête est donc celle de la gardienne ou du banquier, dont on s’assure auparavant qu’elle est respectable.  --

column11: This character refers to rustic life and rustic fields primarily, and from there gets derived meanings. Its elements: computer. . beforehand.  -    -  These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.  -  The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer´s battery beforehand, or you won´t get anything done.
column12: Hameaux...auparavant. Les éléments parlent d’eux-mêmes, et vous ajouterez les significations dérivées champ, rustique.   --

column11: At the top we have the animal horns and the single horizontal stroke to give them something to hang onto. Below that, we see one rake with two handles. Finally, we see a pair of strokes splitting away from each of the handles, indicating that they are both splitting under the pressure. The composite picture is of someone holding down two jobs concurrently, using the same kit of tools to move in two different directions and ending up in a mess. Take the time to find this sense in the kanji and it will be easy to remember, despite initial appearances.  -    -  Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).  -  You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your´s and your neighbours´ garden. But unfortunately, it´s not long until your rake splits in two.
column12: En haut, les cornes et le trait de stabilisation. Puis nous voyons un râteau à deux manches. Et enfin, une paire de traits s’écartant des deux manches, indiquant qu’ils s’écartent sous l’effet de la pression. L’image à comprendre est celle d’un individu cumulant deux tâches, utilisant le même ensemble d’outils pour se déplacer dans deux directions opposées et terminer dans un désordre insensé, si vous prenez le temps de donner du sens au kanji de cette façon, vous parviendrez à le tracer très aisément, en dépit de son apparente complexité.  --

column11: Woman . . . concurrently.  -    -  Naturally, if you´re dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!  -  Attempting to court two women concurrently will make them both dislike you.
column12: Femme...cumuler. Voyez une histoire d’adultère.   --

column11: Metal . . . concurrently.  -    -  This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently!  -  The gold sickle of the USSR flag represents both leaders and workers laboring concurrently.
column12: Or...cumuler. Pensez par exemple à Panoramix, le druide bien connu, seul habilité à manier la faucille, et qui de surcroît cumule de nombreuses tâches dans le village : chimiste, gestionnaire, diététicien, conseiller familial, cueilleur de gui. Sa faucille (certes une serpe, mais ce dernier mot s’écrit avec le même kanji) est en or.  --

column11: Words . . . concurrently.  -    -  When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.  -  Though the man´s words were self-effacing, his actions concurrently made it clear that his modesty was false.
column12: Mots...cumuler. Il est amusant de constater que les dignitaires japonais, ceux qui cumulent les casquettes, dépensent une grande énergie à affirmer (les mots) qu’ils ne sont que peu de choses et ne sauraient rien faire sans le groupe qu’ils dirigent.  --

column11: Cave . . . concurrently.  -    -  Stores don´t want you to know it, but if you find the secret cave, they run bargains there concurrently to their regular prices. (Image: pulling a certain level in a store to find the "bargain cave).  -  If you have several sellers competing concurrently, one will cave in and give you a bargain…　RTK2:　レン　廉売　れんばい(bargain)…　MIXED GROUP: 鎌1599　(ｹﾝ): 兼1597　嫌1598　謙1600.
column12: L’idée de « cumuler les cavernes » évoquera cette opulence permettant de spéculer, opportunité de bonnes affaires.  --

column11: To our way of counting directions, the west always comes fourth. So it is convenient to find the character for four in this kanji. But since we want only one of the four directions, the west adds the one at the top and sucks the human legs a bit out of their mouth in the process.  -  * As a primitive, the meaning of west can be expanded to refer to the Old West of cowboy-movie fame, just as the meaning of the character for east was expanded into the East. Note, however, that in its primitive form the legs are straightened out and reach down to the bottom of the mouth. Hence, we get the shape ⻃. With the exception of one kanji, given in the following frame, this element always appears at the top of its relative primitives.  -  The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare sign of the bird (#1427) whiskey bottle about one third full).  -  Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.
column12: Dans nos manières de citer les quatre directions, l'ouest vient toujours en quatrième. Il semble donc logique de trouver le kanji quatre dans ouest. Mais comme nous ne voulons que cette unique et dernière direction, le kanji ouest ajoute le composant un au sommet, quitte à étirer quelque peu les jambes dans le processus.   --  * En composant, ouest sera associé à l'occident, de même que l'est avait été associé à l'orient. Nous adopterons parfois le sens secondaire de désorienté, car en effet, comme le sous-entend peut-être l'expression populaire « à l'ouest », cela revient à avoir « perdu l'orient ». Au sein d'un autre caractère, les jambes sont allongées jusqu'au bas, donnant  ou . À l'exception d'un cas, ci-dessous, cet élément apparaît toujours au-dessus des autres composants.

column11: Person . . . Old West.  -    -  Mr. T has a high value in the Old West because you see him in "Wanted" posters all over the place! (thanks fiminor).  -  In the West, people have no value. Only money is important.
column12: Tintin, un « homme de l’occident », est étonné par le prix des choses lorsqu’il arrive sur l’archipel nippon.  --

column11: Old West . . . woman.  -    -  When Richard Nixon met Chairman Mao he quipped that western countries were in need of women to boost their populations. Mao actually suggested sending a million Chinese women to the United States. True Story.  -  In the old west the needs of a woman were always at the bottom.
column12: Occident...femme. Inversement, une fois arrivées en occident, les femmes japonaises se pressent dans les boutiques pour couvrir leurs « besoins ».   --

column11: Part of the body . . . need.  -    -  If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It´s the part of the body that needs massaging.  -  To the puritans reading this site - please stop reporting stories that have anything to do with sex! Although (as wrightak said) this kanji really refers to the hips, Heisig clearly chose the keyword ´loins´ because it was anatomically close enough, and the primitives lent themselves to an easy-to-remember story. Just because you´re all sexually repressed doesn´t mean other people won´t benefit from a story such as "the part of the body people need more than any other are the loins".
column12: Partie du corps...nécessité. Les hanches bien formées constituent une partie du corps dont le développement de la civilisation a besoin, peut-être en raison de leur pouvoir d'attraction sur la gent masculine.  --

column6: slip of paper or bamboo; ticket
column11: Old West . . . altar.  -    -  In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn´t fight in the church.  -  In western political elections (US), peoples ballots will often depend on religion and at which altar the prospective president prays.
column12: Occident...autel. On peut penser en particulier à un bulletin de vote, mais le sens ne s’y limite pas strictement. Que la « démocratie » ait été « inventée » en occident revient à pouvoir affirmer que, d’une certaine manière, les bulletins de vote y furent pour la première fois mis en valeur, comme « placés sur l’autel de la démocratie ».  --

column11: Water . . . ballot.  -    -  In Florida, Bush through Kerry´s ballots into the water, watching them drift away and setting the whole country adrift.  -  The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.
column12: Eau...bulletin (de vote). Pensez au mot « ballotage », qui présente une relation avec le bulletin de vote autant qu’avec le sens de dériver, balloter au gré des flots.  --

column6: a mark, symbol, label, sign; standard
column11: Tree . . . ballot.  -    -  Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots.  -  Large wooden signposts are planted on peoples lawns, with the faces of their representatives all saying: "Vote [1] Me!" for the upcoming ballot.
column12: Un bulletin fixé à un arbre devient un panneau.   --

column11: Old West . . . tree.  -    -  Chestnut tree, west nut tree.  -  The cowboy climbed the tree to see where they were in the woods. The poor guy chose a chestnut tree. ouch ouch.
column12: Occident...arbre. Sachant que 「マロングラセ」 « marron glacé », en fait une châtaigne confite, est le mot employé en japonais pour définir cette friandise, disont que c’est véritablement un occidental arbre !  --

column11: West . . . St. Bernard dog . . . snake . . . road.  -    -  Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads.  -  The west has gone through quite a transition, gone are the days when dogs and snakes roamed the desert, it´s all roads and casinos now.
column12: Occident...grand homme...soi...route. Ce que nous voyons « à l'ouest », c'est un grand homme un peu hagard et son propre soi. On vient de le limoger, et il en est tout désorienté. Ce caractère porte le sens général de déplacer et en particulier ceux de limoger ou exiler.  --

column11: West . . . restore.  -    -  The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright.  -  Remember Oregon Trail? Remember how you had to float your wagon across rivers to get to the Old West? Well, sometimes that wagon capsizes. Once that happens you´d better quickly head to the nearest town to restore.
column12: À l'ouest...retourner. Chavirer est une façon bien concrète de se retrouver un peu « à l'ouest » à la suite d'un malencontreux retournement.  --

column11: Hearth . . . Old West . . . ground.  -    -  In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals.  -  Should be easy. SMOKE brings to mind "Where there´s SMOKE, there´s FIRE". So, the FIRE in the OLD WEST can tell people we´re you´re at, so put out the FIRE with SOIL to keep the SMOKE to a minimum.
column12: Feu...occident...terre. « Il n’y a pas de fumée sans feu », se dirent les marins de Christophe Colomb lorsqu'ils virent, une fois parvenus à leur nouvel occident, les feux allumés sur cette nouvelle terre.  --

column11: Belt . . . happiness. Note how the belt runs through the middle of happiness.  -    -  South of my belt leads to happiness.  -  In the south (Southern Alabama, Southern Africa, picture any south, but choose one and stick with it) "they measure happiness by the belt". If someone has a larger belly (and a longer belt), it is believed they are well fed and thus are happy.
column12: Ceinture...joie. Notez comment la ceinture est placée au milieu de l’élé­ment joie.   --

column11: Tree . . . south.  -    -  We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It´s what we came for.  -  Trivia: Cinnamomum camphora is native to Taiwan, southern Japan, southeast China and Indochina,.
column12: Arbre...sud. Arbre des régions chaudes dont on extrait le camphre - et le ravintsara à Madagascar, le camphrier dont les éléments rappellent le sud évoquera la Provence et ses arômes. On peut aussi l'écrire 樟, qui sert également à transcrire le mot camphre, comme si la puissante 樟 odeur de l'extrait faisait office de badge pour reconnaître l'arbre.  --

column11: South . . . chihuahua.  -    -  If you go to someones place and the food sucks, you lower it down south of the table as an offering to their dog.  -  In the far south (think Mexico), they make offerings to the chihuahua deity.
column12: Sud...petit chien. Offrir à un supérieur est la principale signification de ce kanji qui définit aussi le menu, l'offre, d’un restaurant. Vous êtes en vacances dans le sud et décidez d’offrir un repas spécial à votre petit chien qui a souffert du long voyage. La forme originelle, plus complexe, 獻, montre un plat décoré d’une image de tigre et portant un chien offert en sacrifice aux divinités.  --  Chapitre quarante et un  Portail  FAISONS une nouvelle pause, pour nous intéresser cette fois au sens exact des kanjis. Vous savez maintenant que la question n'est pas tant de savoir écrire sans faute chacun d'entre eux que d'en saisir le sens exact. Ce sens exact ne sera clairement perçu qu'en voyant les caractères dans leur contexte, au cours de lectures ou conversations, mais il faut savoir que nous avons parfois employé des méthodes rocambolesques pour retenir les divers sens d'un caractère, alors qu'en fait dans l'esprit japonais ce ne sont que diverses représentations d'une même idée. Par exemple déshabiller  a été présenté avec un second sens : s'évader. En fait, une définition de ce kanji pourrait être « ôter quelque chose ou quelqu'un de l'endroit où il se trouvait normalement placé ». Cette définition explique ces deux sens pourtant présentés comme différents. Le paragraphe précédent amène une autre remarque. On y lit en effet « quelque chose ou quelqu'un ». Il existe fréquemment une sorte d'assimilation entre les choses et les gens dans le monde des kanjis. Par exemple, groupe  sera utilisé pour former des composés aussi divers que groupe de personnes ou boulet de charbon. Ces remarques recèlent la façon dont nous avons procédé pour retenir chacun des kanjis jusqu'à présent. On tente d'y trouver un « moyen de préhension », permettant de manipuler le caractère, tant bien que mal et sans doute maladroitement au début. Puis après quelque temps, on perçoit une autre face, un autre aspect du kanji, fournissant une autre prise, jusqu'à prendre entière possession du caractère : dans ces lignes est décrite la méthode pour cerner le « premier moyen de préhension » . Cela dit, certains caractères possèdent vraiment plusieurs sens sans aucune rela- tion. Ils sont souvent la forme finale identique de divers caractères originaux. C'est par exemple le cas pour 弁 qui peut signifier petale 瓣, valve 辨 ou eloquence 辯. Ce livre ne saurait donc représenter une vérité absolue, ni ne le revendique. Il tente simplement de proposer une logique le plus simple possible dans un monde où la logique se perd dans la nuit des temps ou des approximations nébuleuses. Mais continuons la route et poussons un nouveau portail, avec quelques nouvelles têtes.

column6: gate, door, entrance, opening; Kangxi radical 169
column11: The pictograph of two swinging gates is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The gates usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose.  -  * As a primitive, we shall continue to give it the meaning of gates, but recommend the image of swinging doors (like the kind once common at entrances to saloons) to distinguish it from the primitive for door.  -  Heisig´s stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you´ll get the stroke order exactly correct.  -  The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?
column12: Le pictogramme des deux battants d’un portail est si évident ici que seul l’ordre des traits mérite attention. Le portail entoure généralement d’autres composants, et se trace en premier.  --  * Le sésame sera une porte coulissante, comme celles, bien souvent automatiques, que l'on trouve un peu partout au Japon. Cela évitera toute confusion avec la porte vue en 1165.

column11: Gates . . . mouth.  -    -  A mouth on the Gates of Hell says "Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be".  -  Hark! Who goes there? is the expected question from the mouth of the guard at the gate…　　　RTK2:　モン　質問　しつもん(question).
column12: Porte coulissante...bouche. Voyez que parfois dans les petits restaurants de quartier, ceux qui ne paient pas de mine mais souvent recèlent des trésors, un habitué passe la tête dans l'entrebâillement de la porte ouverte juste ce qu'il faut, et ouvre la bouche pour demander discrètement si c'est encore ouvert. Voilà une petite question ordinaire, mais bien utile pour retenir le kanji.  --

column11: Gates . . . devil. Keep the connotation of this key word distinct from those of inspection (Frame 1174), revise (Frame 362), and perusal (Frame 919).  -    -  A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you´re evil enough to get in.  -  As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that´s cheating. Besides, I´m just reviewing things I already know. I won´t fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.
column12: Porte coulissante...diable. Pour passer un texte ou des hommes en revue, on se montre le plus critique, se mettant dans la peau du diable pour ne rien laisser passer.   --

column11: Gates . . . fell.  -    -  You only get through the gates into that person's fiesta if you are in the same clique.  -  The felled souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the gates of hell and join the clique.
column12: Porte coulissante...abattre. Pour pouvoir intégrer cette coterie, vous devez ouvrir la porte coulissante, et abattre beaucoup de boulot !  --

column11: Gates . . . sun/day. This interval applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image.  -    -  The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.  -  We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.
column12: Porte coulissante...soleil. Cet intervalle s’applique au temps ou à l’espace (six shakus : 1,8181 m), et l’on pourra voir un rayon de soleil passer à travers l’espace que laisse la porte coulissante.   --

column11: Bamboo . . . interval.  -    -  [simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).  -  The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.
column12: Bambou...intervalle. La simplicité raffinée du bambou est symbolisée par l’intervalle régulier séparant chacun de ses nœuds.  --

column11: Gates . . . two hands.  -    -  Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands.  -  To open the gate, use your both hands.
column12: Porte coulissante...deux mains. Pour ouvrir la porte coulissante dans le soufflet entre deux wagons, il faut s’y prendre à deux mains.  --

column11: Gates . . . genie.  -    -  The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. "Close sesame!".  -  Alright none of you GENIUSES could figure out how the door is CLOSED, so I invented these. They are called the SALOON DOORS. With these, you don't need to.
column12: Porte coulissante...génie. Pour fermer la porte coulissante dans le soufflet entre deux wagons, il faut invoquer les bons génies du train.  --

column11: Gates . . . each.  -    -  To keep this distinct from other kanji such as "watchtower" and "pagoda", I use the mnemonic "towering tower". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee´s last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the "towering tower".  -  Remember the two towers from lord of the rings... each has it´s own - very difficult to master - entrance gate.
column12: Chacun des ministres entre dans le cabinet ministériel par la porte coulis­sante. À cabinet ministériel est associé tour: une tour d’ivoire peut-être.  --

column11: Gates . . . tree.  -    -  Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You´re not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees.  -  Imagine Leisure Suit Larry walking through the saloon doors with wood in his pants, hoping to get lucky.
column12: Porte coulissante...arbre. Un loisir typique au Japon consiste à cultiver de petits arbres et à les amasser devant la porte coulissante de l’entrée, sans doute parce qu’il n’y a pas de place ailleurs, dans un désordre étudié; et sans crainte des vols.  --

column11: Gates . . . ear. Compare the story you invented for the kanji meaning listen (Frame 890).  -    -  Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.  -  To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate).
column12: Porte coulissante...oreille.  Entendre et demander relèvent du même concept dans l'esprit japonais. Le flou règne en maître.  --

column11: Water . . . gates . . . king.  -    -  Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet.  -  (I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all wet, dripping drops of water.
column12: Eau...porte coulissante...roi. Il « mouille » très fort aujourd’hui, et notre roi passe la journée sous la porte coulissante à regarder tomber l’eau.   --

column11: Tree . . . gates . . . east.  -    -  A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.  -  [column; handrail; blank; space] I think about oriental (eastern) Torii gates: they have two supporting columns made of wood.
column12: Arbre...porte coulissante...Orient - Japon. Chacune des colonnes de la première page du journal, disposées l’une à côté de l’autre comme des arbres dans une pépinière, est une manière de porte coulissante d’entrée dans le journal. Toutes ces passionnantes colonnes traitent du Japon, apprend-on aussi.  --

column11: -    -  "The orchid thief tries to steal exotic flowers from the east, only to be stopped customs at the departure gate * 蘭 【らん】orchid."  -  The Asian lesbians are partial to this flower because it reminds them of their favorite classic video game character: B. Orchid.
column12: Végétal...porte coulissante...Orient - Japon. Avant la restauration Meiji, et pendant pratiquement deux siècles, le Japon - Orient, coupé du monde, avait conservé une seule porte coulissante de communication avec l’ouest, la Hollande, dont le symbole pourrait être l’orchidée, le végétal ici présent.  --

column11: Gates . . . table . . . glue. Do not confuse with contend (Frame 1238).  -    -  During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates. But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.  -  Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.
column12: Porte coulissante...table...colle. Pour aller voir le match de lutte, on passe la porte coulissante de la salle, et un homme aux bras forts, assis à la table de l’entrée nous colle un coup de tampon encré au poignet.  --

column11: The single gate is used here not in order to represent one gate, but many of them, indeed a meeting of gates. Add mouth (as an entrance here) and you end up with godown. That should help keep this character distinct from warehouse (Frame 633).  -    -  Imagine a godown (dockside warehouse) where you can meet girls who will godown on you with their mouth. To keep the place a bit of a secret, they only have one gate.  -  Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.
column12: La porte coulissante unique que nous voyons ici doit être comprise comme un grand nombre de portes, une assemblée de portes. En ajoutant la bouche, nous obtenons un cellier où garder les provisions de bouche. Imaginez, si cela aide, l'immense cave d'un grand immeuble.  --

column11: Godown . . . saber.  -    -  Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.  -  Genesis v.2: In the Beginning, there was a godown crammed with all the material of the universe, and the Almighty took Her saber and slashed it open, releasing all the material into existence. [Scientists like to call it the Big Bang, but it was really the Big Slice.]
column12: Ce kanji fait référence à la création d’une entreprise ou d’un courant de pensée. Lors de la fondation de votre cellier, n’oubliez pas d’inviter tous les amis, et de sabrer le champagne.  --

column6: not, negative, non-; oppose; Kangxi radical 175
column11: This key word, a negating prefix, is a doodle of a heavy iron pole with bars extending in both directions, to create the picture of a jail cell. From there to "un-" is but a short step.  -  * As a primitive, we shall draw on the explanation above for the meaning of jail cell.  -  This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That´s an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.  -  People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative.
column12: Ce kanji montre un gros poteau métallique vertical, duquel partent hori­zontalement six barres, pour créer l’image d’une cellule de prison. De cette image, le sens général du préfixe de négation in- est aisément extrait. Pour chacune des deux moitiés, tracer d’abord le poteau vertical puis les trois barreaux.  --  * En composant, nous utilisons l'image précédente et créons le sésame cellule de prison.

column11: This character is used for the haiku, the 17-syllable poem that is one of Japan's best-known literary forms. Its elements: person .. . jail cell.  -    -  I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).  -  I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.
column12: Tintin ici est un acteur écroué dans une cellule de prison, prisonnier du texte qu’il doit réciter chaque soir.  --

column11: Fingers . . . jail cell.  -    -  When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.  -  He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she repudiated him and left.
column12: Les notions de répudiation et, plus généralement, évacuation sont rendues par les doigts montrant la cellule de prison : « Pas de ça chez moi ! »  --

column11: Jail cell . . . heart.  -    -  Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again.  -  Stuck in a jail cell with his heart crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so sad.
column12: La tristesse est ce que nous ressentons lorsque nos sentiments ne peuvent évoluer librement, comme s’ils étaient dans une sorte de cellule de prison.   --

column11: Eye . . . jail cell.  -    -  Guilty under the eyes of the law, therefore sentenced to jail. [note: ´UNDER the eye of the law´ works in penalty (#833) as well.].  -  It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor.
column12: Filet...cellule de prison. Le coupable du délit est tombé dans les filets et se retrouve dans la cellule de prison.  --

column11: Jail cell . . . car.  -    -  Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.  -  (+fuaburisu) But it´s the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.
column12: In-pas de...voiture. Le bon camarade est très gentil, car n’ayant pas de voiture mais il sait que vous seul pouvez l’emmener chaque jour au travail gracieusement.  --

column11: Door . . . jail cell.  -    -  The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.  -  An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers "Which door?", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - "The front door !".
column12: On apprend chaque jour à ses dépens au Japon à faire le tour des choses, car c’est bien souvent à l’arrière que se trouve la vérité. Ici, le kanji porte d’entrée semble abonder dans le sens de cette constatation quotidienne : porte...in-.   --

column11: Person . . . key . . . dart. Hint: the pun suggested by the pronunciation of the key word and the primitive for key may come in helpful.  -    -  Marquis Keydartee (make-believe french name, Key+dart+T).  -  (Going off various) Mr. T. is made a marquis and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.
column12: Tintin...clé...fléchette. Ce marquis éprouve quelques difficultés chaque soir pour faire entrer la clé dans la serrure.  --

column11: Marquis . . . walking stick. Note where the walking stick is positioned in this kanji.  -    -  The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He´s old and near death. [Don´t forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.].  -  The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.
column12: Chaque matin, le marquis, canne en main, fait le tour de sa propriété, pour analyser le climat particulier qui règne parmi le petit personnel et ausculter le ciel. Le sens du kanji comprend non seulement les phénomènes météorologiques, mais aussi l’ensemble des éléments formant une ambiance, exactement comme en français.  --

column11: The etymology of decide (de-cidere = cut off) will help here; the elements are: water . . . guillotine.  -    -  Decide! "Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?" I asked.  -  To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don´t drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.
column12: Une fois de plus nous trouvons un outil coupant associé à l’idée de décider. Le liquide est l’encre que fait couler la décision ou le sang du condamné : à vous de décider.   --

column11: State of mind . . . guillotine.  -    -  A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.  -  A cheerful crowd of insulted aliens applaude as Data´s head is chopped off by guillotine.
column12: Etat d’esprit...guillotine. Il faut voir dans cet état d’esprit celui du bourreau le jour où il a troqué sa hache contre une guillotine : « Ah, c’est tout de même plus agréable ainsi ! »  --

column11: Person . . . locket.  -    -  LOCKETs often carry inside them a picture of a PERSON we find ADMIRABLE.  -  For locket: The locket (key dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a mouth, but you need a jeweler´s monocle to make out the pictures within. ----- Dracula survives a staking attempt when the locket with Mina´s admirable picture deflects the blow. "It was an admirable attempt," he admits as he sucks his attacker´s blood.
column12: Tintin...fouet. Voyez par exemple un dompteur.  --

column6: disobey, violate, defy; be apart from
column11: Locket . . . road.  -    -  You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they´ve seen it, but no luck. "Just buy another one," someone says. "I mean, what´s the difference?" Then of course you say "Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don´t want a different one! " Then of course they understand.  -  An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: "I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference.".
column12: Un fouet sur la route évoquera une colonne de bagnards, tombés pour avoir, ne serait-ce qu’une fois, été différents. Dans la société consensuelle qu'est le Japon, être un peu différent, c'est presque déjà une faute.  --

column11: Thread . . . locket.  -    -  The thread that holds the locket around my neck is choker-length so it stays horizontal.  -  Hint : this kanji also means "latitude", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 "black ink" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his "thread locket" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the "thread-locket" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread.
column12: Le fil cinglant du fouet part à l’horizontale, et sonne d’un claquement sec.  --

column11: Boulevard . . . locket. Do not confuse with ward off (Frame 1399), protect (Frame 1072), guard (Frame 198), or safeguard (Frame 756).  -    -  [defense; protection] For "defense against the dark arts" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket.  -  Since it was in the middle of the boulevard, everyone could see she hit the man only in self-defense, as he was trying to steal her valuable locket.
column12: Le fouet sur le boulevard évoque la défense, tant militaire contre les ennemis que antiseptique contre les microbes.  --

column11: As with Italy (Frame 1245) and Africa (Frame 1391), this character simply abbreviates the full name of Korea. Its elements: mist . . . locket.  -    -  There´s a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama´s picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".  -  This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.
column12: Connue sous le nom du pays des matins calmes, la Corée est célèbre pour son alimentation très épicée, à tous les repas. Nous voyons donc ici la rosée, fraîcheur matinale, suivie du coup de fouet que constitue le petit-déjeuner fortement pimenté.  --  Chapitre quarante-deux La pomme de terre  UNE pomme de terre SURPRENANTE puis un rivet inattendu sont les composants formant le cœur de nos préoccupations. Et voici tout d'abord un séchoir à linge.

column11: It is best to see this kanji as a pictograph of a revolving circular clothesline (viewed from the side). Spin it around quickly in your mind's eye to give it the connotation of to dry.  -  * The primitive meaning is clothesline.  -  Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.  -  Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.
column12: Voyez dans ce kanji l’image d’un séchoir à linge tournant, vu de profil, semblable à celui qui se trouve dans votre jardin ou dans votre catalogue de vente par correspondance. Faites-le tourner de mémoire, pour bien le faire sécher.   --

column11: Part of the body . . . dry.  -    -  Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).  -  The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.
column12: Partie du corps...sec. Nous avons vu la vésicule biliaire il y longtemps, et avions noté comment ce kanji symbolisait le courage. Il en est de même pour le foie.   --

column11: Dry . . . saber.  -    -  The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.  -  The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published.
column12: Lorsque l’encre (revoyez le cadre 1158) est sèche sur le sabre de l’impri­meur, l’ouvrage est prêt pour publication.   --

column11: Water . . . dry.  -    -  The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.  -  When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline.
column12: Lorsqu’il fait très sec, le seul liquide qui subsiste est notre sueur.  --

column6: carriage; high; wide; balcony; surname of the Yellow Emperor
column11: This kanji, a counter for houses, is made up of cars . . . dry.  -    -  Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.  -  Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.
column12: Les éléments voiture...au sec suggéreraient plutôt l’image d’un auvent, à l’abri duquel on pourrait ranger la voiture. Et en effet, auvent est le sens premier du kanji. Puis on a constaté un jour qu’une façon de compter les maisons était d’en compter les auvents ! C’est ainsi que auvent est devenu le compteur des maisons.  --

column11: Mountain . . . cliff . . . dry.  -    -  At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim.  -  Three impossibilities for a beach: There cannot be a beach at the top of a mountain. There cannot be a beach on the top of a cliff. There cannot be a beach that is completely dry.
column12: La ligne côtière est vue par le marin comme une sorte de montagne sous laquelle se trouve une falaise haute et sèche, car les vagues n’en frappent que le bas.  --

column6: trunk of tree or of human body
column10: Tronc d’arbre, pièce essentielle, pièce principale
column11: Mist . . . umbrella . . . dry. The meaning of this key word extends beyond tree trunks to represent the main stem or line of anything from railway lines to managerial staffs. This should help distinguish it from the stories used earlier for book (Frame 224) and body (Frame 1030), both of which made use of the image of a tree trunk, as well as the kanji for trunk (Frame 194).  -    -  By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.  -  A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
column12: Rosée...parapluie...sec. Le tronc d’arbre est cette pièce maîtresse qui permet aux branchages faisant parapluie de garder au sec, à l’abri de la rosée, ce qui se trouve au-dessous. Ce kanji est surtout employé au sens figuré de pièce essentielle ou principale.   --

column11: Flowers . . . potato.  -    -  If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.  -  If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don´t accumulate moisture on the floor.
column12: Végétaux...pomme de terre. Voici le kanji dont nous tirons l'élément pomme de terre.  --

column11: -    -  "Due to potatoes in the road, there was a detour."  -  "A truck had spilt its load of potatoes on the road, forcing us to make a detour."
column12: Un camion de pommes de terre s’est renversé sur la route, et une déviation est immédiatement organisée. Vue d’avion, la route suit un trajet détourné, en forme de patatoïde.   --

column11: House . . . potato.  -    -  Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.  -  Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.
column12: Le cosmos est une sorte de grande maison en forme de patatoïde qui héberge toute la création. Voir le cadre 1199.  --

column11: Umbrella . . . potato . . . little. The last stroke of potato and the first of little coincide in this character.  -  * Since the phrase "too much" is overly abstract, we shall take the image of a scale whose indicator spins round and round on the dial because too much weight has been set on it. It will help to use this image in learning the kanji itself.  -  You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.  -  This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol ">" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using two (#2) and little (#105) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means "two much" (more than 2) or "two little". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).
column12: Parapluie...petite pomme de terre. Le dernier trait de pomme de terre et le premier de petit coïncident.  --

column11: Pinnacle . . . scale.  -    -  You won´t make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude.  -  To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you.
column12: Si trop de monde se rend sur le tertre en même temps, il faudra en exclure une partie.  --

column11: Line . . . scale.  -    -  You can´t expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.  -  I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.
column12: Aller...trop. « Qui veut aller loin ménage sa monture » nous dit le proverbe dont ce kanji est un peu l’écho, qui propose d’aller lentement si l’on veut aller trop loin.  --

column11: Scale . . crotch. The key word has to do with conferring ranks, titles, and awards. It should not be confused with bestow (Frame 1335) or impart (Frame 795).  -    -  Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.).  -  If there is such a thing as too much crotch, the guy who gets that much should have an honor conferred upon him.
column12: Trop de mains droites. Vous conversez avec un interlocuteur qui parle « avec les mains » et bientôt vous pensez qu’il a trop de mains droites, alors qu’il vous décrit son nouveau projet.  --

column11: Scale . . . road.  -    -  On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.  -  There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route.
column12: Trop de route. Parfois le trajet menant à un résultat paraît plus long qu’il n’est raisonnable, et c’est ce que semble indiquer ce kanji.  --

column11: Scale . . . measuring cup.  -    -  The constellation of libra (meaning " scales" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper.  -  The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.
column12: Si vous penchez la grande casserole (de 18,039 litres), il se produira la même chose que si vous la remplissez trop : elle va déborder.  --

column11: Water . . . scale . . . ground.  -    -  A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.  -  If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.
column12: Ici, si on met trop de peinture, le liquide, sur un mur, il en tombera par terre.  --

column11: In the same way that we were able to see the sun in the tree within the kanji for east, here we see a square container in the shape of a mouth.  -    -  Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn´t drop the bundle.  -  Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn´t content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.
column12: Il faut voir dans la bouche placée autour de l’arbre une sorte d’énorme lanière, et dans l’arbre unique une multitude d’arbres pour obtenir la notion de fagot.   --  La notion de promesse fait partie du champ sémantique du kanji fagot, et fagot doit être pris au sens le plus large.

column11: Bundle . . . head.  -    -  When you trust in something, you've got your head 頁 all bundled 束 up (wrapped up) in it.  -  We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you.
column12: Fagot - promesse...tête. Il s’agit ici par exemple de commander un service à un ami ou un plat au restaurant. Il importe de remarquer que ce même kanji définit aussi la confiance. C'est qu'au Japon, la confiance en quiconque est la règle ; commander quelque chose et faire confiance sont deux idées intimement liées.  --

column11: Water . . . bundle . . . head.  -    -  You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.  -  You can never trust the water in the rapids, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the rapids to cross the river.
column12: Eau...confiance. Ce kanji définit l'endroit peu profond d'une rivière ou des hauts-fonds marins: des endroits où l'on pourrait se trouver comparativement en confiance.  --

column11: In order to keep this character distinct from that for an imperial edict (Frame 366), we must draw again on a pun. Think of the order here as a mail order or an order of pizza phoned in by the Emperor for delivery to the imperial palace. Then it will not be hard to put together bundle and muscle to form a story about an imperial order.  -    -  This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.  -  Imperial order carries quite a bundle of executive power.
column12: Un rescrit est une réponse faite par un Empereur aux magistrats ou gouverneurs qui lui soumettant un cas. Les éléments sont fagot  - promesse...force.   --

column11: Zoo . . . bundle. Note that the element for zoo is flattened out on the left just as leg (Frame 1372) had been. This is the only time we will meet this form in this book.  -    -  [True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.  -  This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.
column12: À négligence sont associés délaisser et clairsemé. Les composants sont zoo...fagot. Notez que zoo est déformé, comme ce fut le cas pour jambe. Imaginez un émondeur négligent ou délaissant son travail, qui laisse traîner les fagots préparés et les laisse épars sur le terrain.  --

column11: Bundle . . . road.  -    -  Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the bundled sticks in the middle of the road. (dingomick).  -  Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!
column12: Fagot...route. En imaginant en guise de fagot un camion surchargé d’énor­mes grumes dont les freins ont lâché, vous le verrez dévaler une pente raide, prenant à mesure de la vitesse. Si dans l’histoire, vous êtes propriétaire de la maison située dans le virage au bas de la côte, gageons que vous n’oublierez jamais que l’association des éléments route et fagot donne le kanji vite.   --

column11: Bundle . . . taskmaster . . . correct.  -    -  Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won´t accept them.  -  When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won´t be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.
column12: Le chef de corvée a décidé aujourd’hui de mettre en ordre correctement le paquet de fagots qu’il aura coupés la veille.  --

column11: Awl . . . saber. As we promised way back in frame 87, here at last is the kanji on which the primitive element of the same name is based.  -    -  If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They´re basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...  -  Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of "The Awl and the Sabre". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill.
