And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : "The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can´t use the sabre.".
column12: Rivet...sabre. Un gros rivet relie au samouraï le fourreau où il range son sabre.  --

column11: Pinnacle . . . awl.  -    -  The rock climber trying to get up to the pinnacle is dangling from a precipitous edge, hanging only one with his icepick.  -  Well I have someone climbing an inflatable precipitous pinnacle. Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.
column12: Tertre...rivet. Pour atteindre le tertre dont la pente est très raide, vous avez planté des rivets sous vos souliers.  --

column11: Tree . . . awl.  -    -  After intense cross-examination from the prosecutor, the tree confessed to murdering the wood-pecker with an awl... "He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case.  -  Don´t confuse with exam (#1278), test (#354), evaluate (#1487). Think of examination as a doctor´s examination. You´re having problems getting wood in bed. You go in for a doctor´s examination. The doctor shoves an icepick into your manhood as part of the examination.
column12: Arbre...rivet. Sur les arbres de l'école, le directeur a fixé avec des rivets les feuilles portant les noms des élèves reçus à l'examen.  --

column11: Person . . . awl.  -    -  Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.  -  Khatzumoto needs to be frugal after spending all his money on Japanese media and none on food. His waist has shrunk and he needs a new belt, but being frugal he just punches another hole with his awl.
column12: Tintin...rivet. Vivant dans l'austérité, Tintin n'a besoin que d'un rivet pour ranger tous ses biens.  --

column11: Thousand . . . ri. Note how the long vertical stroke doubles up to serve both elements.  -    -  The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.  -  To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first "wheel" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.
column12: Mille ordinateurs. Notez comment le trait vertical est commun aux deux éléments. Imaginez ensuite les mille ordinateurs  empilés, donnant une gigan­tesque pagode à mille étages, et vous retiendrez le second sens : empiler.   --

column11: Heavy . . . muscle.  -    -  Even though the furniture is heavy, it´ll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has.  -  His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can move...thats ironic.
column12: Lourd...muscle. Le muscle fait bouger le lourd wagon.   --

column11: Move . . . oven fire. So as not to confuse this kanji with the general character for merit (Frame 1369), you may associate the key word with military decorations and medals of distinction, both of which it is used for.  -    -  A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.  -  Prometheus did a meritous deed for humanity by MOVING FIRE from the gods to us humans.
column12: Bouger...au-dessus du feu. La performance particuliere que l’on imaginera est un saut en longueur au-dessus d’un feu de la Saint-Jean, comme on le pratique encore quelquefois dans les campagnes.  --

column11: Person . . . move. Do not confuse with labor (Frame 924).  -    -  A person who moves something is doing work, physically speaking.  -  Mr T, move. Mr Ts new exercise video called "Work it suckaz". Here is shouting "move it work it move work it!".
column12: Tintin...bouger. Pour Tintin, bouger de par le monde a toujours été synonyme de travail.   --

column11: Wheat . . . heavy.  -    -  Our species has a wheat heavy diet...  -  This kanji also means "Seed." STORY: Scientists have developed a new SPECIES of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world.
column12: Blé...mille ordinateurs. L'ingénierie de l'agriculture qui invente sans cesse de nouvelles espèces ou graines de blé parvint en quelques décennies à multiplier le rendement à l'hectare, et il faudra bientôt mille ordinateurs pour dénombrer et classer toutes ces espèces de blé.  --

column11: Boulevard . . . heavy.  -    -  Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.  -  衝 【しょう】 (n) (1) important point (e.g. on a route); (2) important role (responsibility, etc.); (3) (astronomical) opposition. STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).
column12: Boulevard...lourd. Boum!   --

column11: Flowers . . . heavy . . . oven fire. Do not confuse with incense (Frame 977) or perfumed (Frame 532).  -    -  The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.  -  Do you know how they make those FRAGRANT air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp perfume (#493)).
column12: Végétaux...lourd...chaudron. Dans un chaudron, le parfumeur verse trois tonnes de lavande, une lourde quantité de végétaux, et en tire un litre d'extrait de lavande, une chose parfumée.  --  Chapitre quarante-trois Maladies   APRÈS une visite chez le médecin, nous allons découvrir dans quelle boîte il range ses affaires ; puis nous nous remettrons sur pieds.

column11: Sickness . . . third class.  -    -  Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).  -  If you hang around a third class hospital, you´ll get ill with the sickness everyone else has.
column12: Maladie...troisième classe. Imaginez un monde où l’on contraindrait les malades à voyager dans des wagons de troisième classe, à exécuter des tâches de troisième classe, etc.  --

column11: Know . . . sickness.  -    -  Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn´t know anything. He´s a caveman!  -  This kanji shows stupidity as a "knowledge-sickness". Everybody can be stupid at times, and it usually happens because of a lack of experience. Hence the stupidity is a "knowledge sickness".
column12: Qui souffre de la maladie du savoir est un idiot.  --

column11: Sickness . . . beans.  -    -  Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.  -  Pox is a sickness which symptoms include bean-shaped bumps on the skin.
column12: Maladie...pois - pustule.   --

column11: Sickness . . . correct.  -    -  Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.  -  A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.
column12: Maladie...juste. Connaître les symptômes d’une maladie permet d’en définir le traitement avec justesse.  --

column11: Be sure to keep this character distinct from quick (Frame 1799) and swift (Frame 298). Picture a succession of poison darts (the sort that inflict sickness) flying out rapid-fire from a blowgun, so that "rapid-fire" can conjure up the proper image.  -    -  I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire.  -  If shot with a poison dart, sickness develops rapidly.
column12: Voyez une flêche empoisonnée dans le second élément. Elle vous permettra de cerner le double sens du kanji : malade et rapide. Il suffit en effet de l’imaginer fendre l’air très rapidement (comme une « malade »), et aller se planter sur une victime pour transmettre la maladie.   --

column11: Sickness . . . profit.  -    -  For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness!  -  Caveman doesn´t have any skills, so he sells his diarrhea as chili to peasant wheat farmers for an amazing profit.
column12: Maladie...profit. Etrange profit que celui procuré par cette maladie, par laquelle on perd surtout beaucoup.  --

column11: Sickness . . . pelt.  -    -  I picture an exhausted sick caveman snuggling up in a comfy pelt blanket.  -  Your body feels tired when you have a sickness. All you want to do is wrap yourself up in a nice warm pelt and get better.
column12: La fatigue est une maladie de peau qui se manifeste par des traits tirés.  --

column11: Sickness . . . missile.  -    -  Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as "flu", "plague", etc.  -  SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some EPIDEMIC or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. [C].
column12: Nous voyons ici une maladie qui frappe fort ; c'est donc une maladie très virulente, une épidémie.  --

column11: Sickness . . . chop-seal . . . utilize.  -    -  Think of the phrase pain in the xxx. Then think of a pogostick up your xxx. That's painful, right? The real question is why a pogostick is up your xxx. That's sick, dude.  -  When I was feeling sick my mum said I shouldn´t go out to play on my pogo stick until I felt better. Well I wasn´t strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the pain to prove my mum right.
column12: Maladie...usure. Comme la douleur est souvent le moyen par lequel se manifeste la maladie, l'élément usure vient ici tout naturellement.  --

column11: Sickness . . . ketchup.  -    -  Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. I guess that´s ok since raw mammoth can´t be too good...  -  This mannerism is a sickness of the modern generation. It was only recently that we started putting ketchup on everything.
column12: Maladie...supplice. Une manie est une sorte de maladie par laquelle on subit son propre supplice.  --

column11: Box . . . young.  -    -  Young kids likes to hide in cardboard boxes. (Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.).  -  Note that stroke order with box primitive is as follows: first horizontal line, then enclosed element, and then a hook (it´s incorrect in 4th edition).
column12: Boîte...jeune. La boîte est ici un placard sous l'escalier et le jeune reste caché pendant tout le jeu de cache-cache.  --

column11: Box . . . ax.  -    -  Hint: Artisan/Ax Def: An artisan is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the artisan's ax stored in his toolbox.  -  We here have the axe-man who´s an artisan at making sculptures with his axe... The only thing is, he never shows anyone, keeping all his sculptures inside a box down in the basement. He doesn´t want any attention.
column12: L'artisan possède dans sa boîte une hache, pour faire les plus beaux objets en bois parfaitement dégauchi.  --

column11: Box . . . dart.  -    -  Easily confused: Dr. (#47), doctor (#1694), examination (#1673), check-up (#1724), medicine (#1736). To avoid confusion I renamed this medic, and picture the medic from Team Fortress 2 returning to his box of darts in the supply cupboard every time his syringe gun is empty.  -  This DOCTOR prefers to use DARTS instead of syringes for injections. Here, he pulls out his BOX of DARTS, and the child on the examination table squirms.
column12: Le médecin, quant à lui, possède une flèche. On repensera à l'acuponcture, ou aux saignées des temps anciens.  --

column6: bolt of cloth; counter for horses
column10: Égal, paire, compteur des animaux domestiques
column11: Box . . . human legs.  -    -  This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL´S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He´s probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).  -  Imagine a magician doing that trick where he puts his assistant in a box and proceeds to saw her in half. Don’t the human legs sticking horizontally out of the box remind you of an equal sign?
column12: À la notion de base, paire, s’ajoutent celles de égal et compteur des ani­maux domestiques. Ces trois sens sont en fait communs, en vertu de cette association : il faut voir dans les jambes et la boîte la représentation pictographique de la paire de fesses de cheval. À paire fut ensuite ajoutée la notion d'égalité et, de même qu'on dénombre les maisons en comptant leurs auvents, on décida de compter les chevaux et les animaux domestiques en comptant les paires de fesses.  --

column11: The ward referred to here is a subdivision of a large city. Its elements: box . . . sheaves. When used as a primitive element, it may be helpful at times to break it up into these same composite elements.  -    -  In the homeless ward of the city you see people sleeping in CARDBOARD BOXES using a SHEAF as a pillow.  -  That´s the homeless ward of the city. Wolverine lives in a cardboard box there.
column12: La notion de circonscription, ici dans un sens extrêmement général, est vue par une gerbe dans une boîte. Imaginons un champ lors des moissons, et nous voyons sortir de la botteleuse des balles de foin (les gerbes), que nous nous empressons de ranger dans une boîte. A chacune de ces balles correspond une certaine surface du champ, une circonscription.   --

column6: door hinge; pivot; center of power
column11: Tree . . . ward.  -    -  Make sure you install the hinge the right way. If it opens treeward (= tree ward), you won't be able to get the fence open, make sure it opens houseward.  -  You notice a hinge on a tree and realize there´s a secret door. You open it up to find an Xbox!!!
column12: Arbre...circonscription. Pour imprimer tous les livres que Bernard Pivot, point central des réunions littéraires, reçoit chaque matin sur son palier, il faut sans doute abattre quotidiennement les arbres d’une entière circonscription  !   --

column11: Ward . . . missile.  -    -  The biggest assault on Japan during WW2 is when the wards in Hiroshima and Nagasaki were wiped out by nuclear missiles.  -  In this hospital ward, the personnel is assaulted by missiles. Think of a ward where crazy old people assault the personnel because they don´t like the food, they don´t want to take their medicines, they want to go home, etc. The patients use whatever they can get their hands on as missiles.
column12: Circonscription...frapper fort. Pour monter à l'assaut de la ville, on attaque circonscription par circonscription, et on frappe fort, car la meilleure défense, c'est l'assaut, comme on sait.  --

column11: Ward . . . yawn. Like the kanji of frame 1776, this character is an abbreviation of the name of a geographical region.  -    -  Do japanese consider Europe like just a ward, boring enough to make them yawn?? This kanji is offensive!  -  [Europe] X-Box was first released in America and Japan (the biggest videogame markets). Europe had an X-Box lack for a while...
column12: Circonscription...bâiller. Sachant le rythme auquel les Japonais mènent leur vie, on comprend que l’Europe puisse être un endroit où l’on s’ennuie.  --

column11: Fingers . . . box . . . stamps.  -    -  They would repress dissents by cutting off their fingers and mailing them to relatives in small boxes (of course including stamps for proper postage).  -  A true stamp collecting nerd won´t be able to repress the urge to get his fingers on the latest box of collector stamps!
column12: Doigts...boîte...timbre. Répression est un sens particulier de ce caractère, défini essentiellement par la maîtrise d'une situation. Repensons à l'auto-répression dont font preuve certains membres de la pègre Japonaise ; pour racheter une faute commise par leur clan, ils envoient une phalange au clan adverse ; imaginons un de ces malandrins plaçant un morceau de doigt dans une boîte et y collant un tampon... et c'est dans la boîte !  --  Maîtriser une situation signifie qu’on la domine depuis le début, et c’est une chance, car ce kanji signifie aussi pour commencer !

column11: Box . . . stamps . . . road.  -    -  Welcome home daddy! Is that box for me? You were on the road a long time! I collected all the stamps from the letters you wrote me　:-) ...　　RTK2:　ゲイ　歓迎　かんげい(welcome).  -  Stamp-collectors sit and wait on the road to welcome new mail arrivals.
column12: Boîte...tampon...route. On envoie sur la route un éclaireur qui part à l'accueil de la boîte tamponnée.  --

column6: raise the head to look; look up to, rely on, admire
column10: Regarder en l’air, vous me dites
column11: This character is used both for lying on one's back faceup, and for looking up to someone with respect and awe. Its elements: person . . . box . . . stamps.  -    -  Mr T with the post package at the post office: ´these stamps don´t stick to the box, foo´ Postguy:´ Try it again but this time with the stamp, face-up.´.  -  Mr. T, his "acting career" in its twilight, must now FACE-UP to the fact that his mug will never appear on a BOX of cereal or on a STAMP.
column12: Tintin...boîte...tampon. C'est Tintin qui assure la livraison et lorsque l'éclaireur s'approche de lui pour lui prendre la boîte tamponnée, il regarde en l'air en sifflant, l'air de rien. Puis il s'adresse à lui : « Vous me dites que cette boîte est la vôtre ? » En effet, « vous me dites » est un autre sens de ce kanji. Voyez la note de 50.  --

column11: Teepee . . . table. Do not confuse with rise up (Frame 43).  -    -  When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.  -  When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually ascended in the air!
column12: Deux pieds...table. Avant le départ pour gravir la montagne, on inspecte avec soin les deux pieds en les mettant sur la table pour s'assurer que tout ira bien lors de l'ascension.  --

column6: purify water by allowing sediment to settle; clear, pure
column11: Water . . . ascend.  -    -  Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.  -  A few drops of acid/peyote and the Indians obtain lucidity on their vision quest, as if they were floating in the lucid sky.
column12: Eau...gravir. L'eau devient limpide lorsque les impuretés plombent, donc quand l'eau monte.  --

column11: This key word refers to the discharging of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: teepee . . . two . . . human legs. Contrast the writing with frame 63.  -    -  Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there´ll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.  -  I spent some time in her TEEPEE...just the TWO of us...but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty DISCHARGE...so I made my 出発　rather hastily.
column12: Deux pieds...deux...jambes. À vos marques ! prêts ? partez ! Le kanji départ nous raconte exactement ce départ de course. Pour commencer on vérifie que les deux pieds sont bien en place ; pour le second point, deux, on s'assure que tout est prêt ; enfin au signal « partez », les jambes se mettent en marche. Et voilà, retenez bien les éléments et dites la formule du départ. Le kanji fait référence au départ de canons, trains, gens, et même de sons.  --

column11: Cave . . . discharge.  -    -  Slaves have been discharged from the caves where they were kept thanks to the abolition of slavery.  -  Guns were abolished, so gun enthusiats left for the hills to discharge their guns in caves.
column12: Appentis...départ. Il s'agit ici de supprimer ce qui est devenu inadapté ou usé, de jeter ce dont on n'a plus usage. On met alors le tout sur la carriole devant l'appentis puis on donne le signal du départ.  --

column6: companion, colleague; officials; bureaucracy; a pretty face
column11: Person . . . pup tent. Choose some connotation of the key word that will keep it distinct for you from companion (Frame 19), friend (Frame 760), consort (Frame 1287), and comrade (Frame 1765).  -    -  A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as companion (#19), friend (#704), consort (#1203) and comrade (#1637). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent.  -  Mr. T began working in a japanese compagny. As he sees that his colleague accept to do some extra work during the week-end and even sleep at the office, he says to them: "I pity da fool who work during week-end! You might as well install a pup tent in the office and forget about your home".
column12: Tintin...démesure. À côté de Tintin se trouve une file démesurée de personnes, qui ne cesse de grandir ; ce sont tous ses collègues.  --

column11: House . . . pup tent.  -    -  A dormitory is right in the middle between living in a house and living in a pup tent.  -  This guy would rather use his pup-tent as a house, than sleep in the dormitory. So he effectively turned that pup-tent into a house by getting a postal address for it etc. (just to emphasize house).
column12: Un dortoir est une maison d'une longueur démesurée dans laquelle tout le monde peut loger aisément.  --

column11: Sickness . . . pup tent.  -    -  On the battlefield, the only place to heal from your sickness is inside the medic's pup tent. Think of M.A.S.H.  -  Sick caveman has to sleep in his pup tent. Not the cave because to humid and cold but a nice small pup tent in the sun will heal him from his cold.
column12: Maladie...démesure. De nombreux malades attendent dans cet endroit d'une longueur démesurée. Il y un nombre démesuré de salles et dans chacun de ces salles, chaque patient reçoit une partie des soins, et cela n'en finit pas.  --

column11: The two primitives here, circumference and shape, belong naturally to the special connotations that differentiate carving from engraving (see frame 1639).  -    -  A lathe is used to carve a shape with circumference into wood or metal.  -  Start with a circumference and carve away until you get the shape you want.
column12: Circonférence...forme. En sculptant une bille de bois, on creuse dans la circonférence pour obtenir la forme imaginée.  --

column11: Two hands . . . shape.  -    -  Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands.  -  With your two hands, outline the shape of a curvaceous woman. Is that a universally understood gesture? [Careful: mould (#680) which has two hands and soil/clay].
column12: Deux mains...forme. Parmi les premiers outils dont nous disposons pour donner une forme à un objet, nous trouvons nos deux mains.   --

column11: Scenery . . . shape.  -    -  The sun over the capital cast a shadow with the same shape.  -  You're out hiking looking at the SCENERY, suddenly out of the corner of your vision you see a large SHADOW's indistinct SHAPE... could it be a grizzly? (cmp shade (#1592)).
column12: La forme du paysage devient son ombre portée, une sorte d’ombre chinoise du paysage.  --

column6: various species of pine and fir
column11: Tree . . . shape.  -    -  Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn´t loose its needles/leaves in the winter.  -  Cedar is a wood that keeps its shape. (This is true, it's rot resistant.).
column12: Arbre...forme. Cette variété de cèdre, cryptomeria japonica en langue savante, est un arbre en forme d'arbre. On en voit souvent les larges fûts dans les forêts de temples.  --

column11: Vulture . . . tree . . . shape.  -    -  In Sydney we occasionally get exotic birds. You first notice a colouring in a tree. You look more carefully and you make out the shape of a bird (here represented by its claws).  -  When coloring something in you grab the crayon of choice to fill in the shapes.
column12: Serre...arbre...forme. Pour colorer une forme, il suffit d’un pinceau, une sorte d’arbre, que l’on tient dans la main, une sorte de serre. Revoyez 807 au besoin.  --

column11: Badge . . . shape. The key word is synonymous with "clear" or "openly expressed."  -    -  The shape of a sheriff´s badge makes it patent who he is.  -  It was patently absurd when the fellow tried to arrest me--his badge was the wrong shape: a vase and a sunflower? Come now.
column12: Chapitre...forme. Ce qui se conçoit bien s'énonce clairement. Cette célèbre citation de Boileau s'accorde bien avec le kanji signifiant manifeste, qui nous montre une sorte de chapitre en bonne forme.  --

column11: Vase . . . cliff . . . shape.  -    -  A lad standing on the top of a cliff, looking into the far, and thinking how to shape his future.  -  A young lad is standing atop a cliff, looking at the writhing shape of his fallen lass below.
column12: Ce bonhomme debout au bord de la falaise en regarde le fond où se trouve une forme qui l’intrigue et pourrait bien l’enchanter.  --

column11: Lad . . . head.  -    -  A lad's head still has a baby's face.  -  When I was a lad, a pretty face was all it took for someone to get in my head, and I´d fill pages of lovelorn letters to them.
column12: Bonhomme...tête. Notre bonhomme en regardant sa tête se préoccupe peut-être ici de son visage, car sans doute y voit-il les rides qui s'accumulent.  --

column6: must, have to, necessary; moment; whiskers
column11: Shape . . . head. This is the only time that shape is placed to the left of its relative element, the head.  -    -  Why, I OUGHT to RESHAPE your HEAD...  -  Since this Kanji is exceptional, the shape ought to be on the left side. Got that into your head?
column12: Forme (de poils de barbe trop longs)...tête. Lorsque les poils de la barbe deviennent trop longs, la tête se rend à l’évidence de la nécessité d’aller visiter le barbier. Avec les mêmes éléments, on appréciera aussi les innombrables serviettes brûlantes placées sur la tête, et le vigoureux massage de remise en forme.  --

column11: Part of the body . . . drum . . . shape. Compare expand (Frame 1199).  -    -  This kanji does not mean swell as in a inflammation. There is a different kanji for that meaning (腫れる). This kanji means swell as in, a tire swelling/expanding, your income swelling/expanding, dough swelling/expanding, etc. Johnskb's story is best b/c it does not involve swelling in the sense of inflammation, just general expansion of the stomach. STORY: "If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet.".  -  Which part of your body can change shape and, when it does, swells up and throbs like a drumb? Hmmm...
column12: Partie du corps en forme de tambour.  --

column6: take part in, intervene; ginseng; 21st lunar mansion, determinative star ζ Orionis (Alnitak)
column10: Dérouté, je vais vers vous, participer
column11: Elbow . . . St. Bernard dog . . . shape.  -    -  I´m going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right!  -  Whenever the postman has to pay a visit to this place, he brings an elbow-shaped thingy that he throws to the St. Bernard.
column12: Les éléments peuvent se lire saint-bernard en forme de coude. Le malheureux s’est donc fait renverser par un véhicule, et se tord de douleur. Par contre le chauffeur, ou le véhicule, est dérouté. Puis il se rend humblement vers (je vais vers vous, dont participer est un sens associé) le commissariat de police pour remplir le constat en trois (III) exemplaires. Vous connaissez déjà 壱 et 弐, voici donc le suivant.  --

column11: A state of mind . . . visit.  -    -  Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.  -  Data feels wretched because he has no family to visit.
column12: Le mieux sera sans doute de vous imaginer témoin de la scène décrite au cadre précédent, et de sentir votre état d’esprit,  choqué.   --

column11: Person . . . walking stick . . . taskmaster . . . shape.  -    -  Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.  -  You may not have known it, but Mr. T is into discispline. Not just self discipline, in order to get into shape, but what he really likes is when the Task master spanks him with her walking stick. Don´t tell Mr. T I told you. I pity da fool, and da fool would be me!!!
column12: Tintin...baguette...chef de corvée...forme. Formation porte l'idée de forme car il s'agit bien de former un esprit, et le kanji contient aussi l'élément forme inscrit en son sein. Pour se former, Tintin est son propre chef de corvée : il se fait lui-même marcher « à la baguette », pour former son esprit.  --

column11: Jewel . . . umbrella . . . shape.  -    -  It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea).  -  Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "parasol" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , check-up (#1724), measles (#2574), fallible (#2720).
column12: Bijou en forme de parapluie. Imaginez un parapluie incrusté de diamants, et vous obtiendrez un objet rare, peu habituel. Le sésame ne comprend que la partie de droite.  --

column11: Words . . . umbrella . . . shape. The key word refers to a medical examination.  -    -  At my last check-up, the doctor said to me: "Start carrying a parasol, or you might get skin cancer. You've been tanning too much!" [Umbrella over shape = parasol].  -  The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.
column12: Pendant l’auscultation, le médecin prononce, puis écrit sur l’ordonnance, des mots rares et on est surpris que le pharmacien puisse les lire.  --

column11: Under the familiar top hat we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with sentence by thinking of a sentence as a grammatical pattern.  -  * The primitive meaning for this character will be plaid, the familiar crisscross pattern frequently used in textiles.  -  A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.  -  The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect sentences.
column12: Sous le chapeau haut de forme qui nous est familier, est tracé un élé­ment ressemblant à la gerbe. Il faut y voir la stylisation d’un motif ou dessin, symbolisant l’écriture. Ce kanji concerne donc plus le texte que la parole, mais cela ne nous empêchera pas d’utiliser la notion de phrase orale en composant.  --

column11: Plaid . . . glue.  -    -  When sitting vis-a-vis, Scots will glue their kilt down to avoid embaressment.  -  The word vis-a-vis is like sentence glue, it kind of joins sentences together.
column12: Phrases...colle. Imaginez deux personnes en dialogue, et vous aurez une idée du sens de base de ce kanji.  --

column11: Thread . . . plaid.  -    -  The Scottish weave their family crests with thread on plaid fabric.  -  A family crest sown on to a garment with thread sometimes has a Latin sentence as a motto.
column12: Les armoiries contiennent une phrase qui garantit les traditions (le fil) familiales.  --

column11: Insect . . . plaid.  -    -  The mosquito (an insect) knows only one sentence: Bzzzzz.  -  Mosquitoes are the insect who love Scots in plaid kilts because it makes for easy access to the best parts.
column12: Zzzz... est la seule phrase que sait prononcer cet insecte: c’est un moustique.   --

column11: Plaid . . . fenceposts . . . two. Do not confuse with just so (Frame 414).  -    -  The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.  -  HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean goalkeeper. The "fence posts" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means uniform as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team.
column12: Phrase...deux vieillards...tendant deux fils (les deux traits). Nos deux vieillards ont entrepris de tendre deux fils pour les placer uniformément à la même hauteur.  --

column11: Adjust . . . saber. Think of this as a dose of medicine.  -    -  When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber.  -  We had to adjust his dose slightly, after he went on a rampage with a sabre.
column12: Uniforme...épée. Il s’agit d’un produit dont on ajoute une petite quantité pour uniformiser les choses (on en taille une petite noisette, du bout de l’épée), comme un agent de lavage par exemple.  --

column11: Water . . . adjust. Do not confuse with complete (Frame 101), end (Frame 1452), or perfect (Frame 199).  -    -  When the goalkeeper finishes the game, he drinks a lot of water and adjusts himself.  -  Finish him! Subzero adjusts the water in your body and crushes you into a few million pieces.
column12: Eau...uniforme. Une fois que cessent les remous, le niveau de l’eau peu à peu s’uniformise. Il en est de même dans toute affaire, que l’on peut percevoir comme un écart par rapport à la situation habituelle : tout « rentre dans l’ordre » (s’uniformise) quand cela se termine.  --

column11: Plaid . . . fenceposts . . . altar. This is a "religious" purification, which distinguishes it from the simple kanji for pure (Frame 1659).  -    -  Purification? I think of Japanese during new year's eve praying(saying sentences) in front of Itsukushima's shrine torii(fenceposts) and its altar. They expect to enter the new year totally purified.  -  Kind of vulgar, but here the SCOTSMAN got tired of adjusting himself so decided try PURIFICATION. Sadly, he did it by straddling the ALTAR with his skinny LEGS.
column12: Phrase...deux vieillards...autel. Pensez à une purification religieuse, notamment le repas du prêtre bouddhiste, et vous verrez apparaître nos deux vieillards, deux prêtres, réunis autour de l'autel pour recevoir leur revigorante purification : un verre d'eau bénite ou de vin de messe !  --

column11: Rake . . . rice . . . fenceposts. Take special care to draw this character in the same order as the primitive. Note too, that the fourth stroke for rice is already taken care of by the fourth stroke of rake.  -    -  Even though it´s a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.  -  Note: This is not sieve as it has a full rice and not rice grains and the hook is missing from rake. Also the given stroke order is incorrect (fenceposts should come last).
column12: Rateau...deux vieillards...riz. Dans leur vie quotidienne, qui consiste à nettoyer leur demeure et à s'alimenter, nos deux vieillards se comportent le plus solennellement possible.   --  La clé sous laquelle ce kanji est classé est pratiquement introuvable si on ne la connaît pas ; il s’agit de 聿.

column11: The kanji of this frame refers to the four bases that are placed at the corners of a baseball infield. The elements: field . . . sparkler . . . ground.  -    -  Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases.  -  The traditional New Year´s baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a rice field. They stick sparklers in the ground for the bases so they can be seen, and to be more festive.
column12: Champs...tube...terre. Du fortin, monticule de terre et de pierres, sortent les tubes des canons pointés vers les champs. En pratique, ce kanji est surtout employé dans le jeu de base-ball, pour signifier la « base ».  --

column11: Dove . . . sparkler . . . tree.  -    -  Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. She´s hovering/dancing around a tree to the legendary Lost Woods music.  -  There we were at the concert...her voice was like a dove...her dress sparkled...then suddenly, a tree fell on her.....
column12: Colombe...tube...arbre. Perchée sur son arbre, la colombe nous chante son tube sans se lasser. Musique est le sens premier, et plaisant le second.  --

column11: Flowers . . . music.  -    -  New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment.  -  Oh man, this medicinal marijuana is making me hear MUSIC and see FLOWERS everywhere...
column12: Des végétaux et de la musique fournissent un médicament qui pourrait être efficace.  --

column11: Mysterious . . . sparkler . . . ten. Do not confuse with proportion (Frame 1673).  -    -  It´s quite mysterious how each sparkler gives of sparkles at a precise ratio of ten to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.  -  It's mysterious how there's always a ratio of ten sparklers to one package.
column12: Mystère...tube...dix. Par quel mystère votre banquier parvient-il à faire entrer dix bâtons dans un étrange tube à la sortie duquel il ne reste plus qu’une brique.  --

column11: Water . . . footprint . . . sparkler.  -    -  I think that Heisig meant this as the "slightly bitter but fresh" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail (water), feeling like he´s been kicked in the face (footprint) and sparks are flying from his tongue. ´How did it taste?´. ´Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh".  -  If you eat something astringent water will stop the sparkly sensation in your mouth.
column12: Eau...arrêt...tube. En passant dans le tube digestif, le liquide est ralenti s’il est astringent.  --  Ce kanji traduit aussi le raffinement sobre, mais encore la pingrerie ou la bougonnerie.

column11: The elements depict a St. Bernard with its head and paws keeping their stick-like form, but with the middle or center of its body filled out in a box-like shape.  -    -  Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box).  -  The center of a dog´s universe is his mouth: bark, eat, bite. What a life! RTK2:　オウ　中央　ちゅうおう(center)…　　　　　　　　　　　　　Semi-Pure Group　(ｴｲ): 英1741　 映1742.
column12: Le kanji décrit un saint-bernard dont la partie centrale du corps est placée dans une sorte de boîte. Ou serait-ce le soleil couchant, couché, que la grande personne peut regarder dans le centre.  --

column6: petal, flower, leaf; brave, a hero; England, English
column11: Flowers . . . center. This is another abbreviation used to identify a country by the pronunciation of the kanji.  -    -  The original great seal of the king of England had a very ornate flower in the center.  -  England is a country where people think they´re the flower at the center of the world. (a description that would fit China much better.. 中華).
column12: Végétaux...centre. Les sens associés sont brillant et Angleterre.  --

column11: Sun . . . center.  -    -  In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just reflects it.  -  A solar power plant consists of thousands of mirrors reflecting the sun´s rays, concentrating the energy on a focal point at the centre. See here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two.
column12: Soleil...centre. Avant que ne commence la séance, le projectionniste ajuste l'éclairage de son projecteur, le soleil, afin qu'il soit bien centré.  --

column11: Ground . . . dagger . . . little. The two strokes of the dagger take the place of the middle stroke of little.  -  * As a primitive on the left, this kanji keeps the same form. Elsewhere, the first two strokes are abbreviated to a single dot. This latter form will take the meaning of an apple.  -  He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.  -  There was red all over the soil after Little Red Riding Hood plunged a dagger into the wolf. Those two dots we see are wolfies animal legs we see, by the way (a la smithsonian).
column12: Sol...sabre...petit. Les deux traits du sabre tiennent lieu du trait central de petit.   --  * En composant à gauche, la forme sera inchangée. En d'autres endroits, les deux premiers traits seront abrégés en un seul trait, devenant , forme à laquelle nous attribuerons le sens de pomme.

column11: Red . . . taskmaster.  -    -  The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to pardon him.  -  There aren´t many pardons given by the Red taskmasters in China. 80% of the world´s death penalties are performed there...　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　シャ　赦免　しゃめん(pardon).
column12: Le chef de corvée s’est fâché tout rouge, et nous implorons son pardon.   --

column11: Apple . . . walking legs.  -    -  It´s quite unusual and abnormal to see an apple with walking legs running away from the person who wants to eat it!  -  Imagine an apple on walking legs on stage singing "It´s not unusual to be loved by anyone" (Tom Jones). Keyword can be confused with uncommon (#1797).
column12: La présence de jambes qui marchent sous une pomme évoque un insecte que vous voyez sortir de la pomme juste avant de la croquer : une image insolite, si j’ose dire.  --

column11: Wooden leg . . . apple.  -    -  Pirate pokes the tip of his wooden leg into an apple to disguise his tracks.  -  To hide his distinctive wood-leg tracks, this pirate is throwing apples after his tracks in order for animals to come and confuse his tracks.
column12: Jambe de bois...pomme. Pour pouvoir retrouver son chemin à la trace, le petit Poucet laisse tomber une pomme à chaque pas.   --

column11: Apple . . . insects.  -    -  The barbarian picks an apple from above and eats it even though there is a worm (insect) in it.  -  Barbarians eat apples with worms still in them.
column12: Pomme...insecte - batracien. Ce kanji qualifie « l’étranger, cet inconnu », à la manière du mot barbare originellement en français. Voici la recette du jour de notre barbare : le batracien aux pommes !  --

column6: love; long for, yearn for; love
column11: Apple . . . heart.  -    -  The romance between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison apple and her heart stopped.  -  A childhood romance: a boy takes a red apple to school to try to win the heart of his beloved.
column12: Pomme...sentiments. Pensez à une « pomme d’amour ».   --

column6: bay, cove, inlet, bend of stream
column11: Water . . . apple . . . bow.  -    -  In his most daring feat, William tell used his bow to shoot an apple off the head of his son across the water of the gulf.  -  An army of archers must cross a gulf of water. Fortunately there are millions of apple trees growing in the cliffs above the gulf. The archers use their bows to shoot down apple after apple, which all fall into the water and slowly fill up the the gulf until the archer soliders can cross on foot.
column12: Eau...pomme...arc. Le golfe est au bord de l’eau, et il est incurvé comme un arc. Imaginez-le planté de pins, lâchant leurs pommes de pin sur la tête des bons amis...  --

column11: Salad . . . sprout . . . animal legs.  -    -  The salad did not look very appetizing... The sprouts were yellow and there were animal legs sticking out of it.  -  I order a salad with sprouts. I´m asked if I´d like to add chicken. Yes please. My salad then arrives . . . . topped with these horribly gnarled yellow things. Chicken feet! (animal legs) ugh.
column12: Salade...pousse...pattes. Jaune pourrait être la belle couleur d’une bonne salade au cœur ferme. Cette salade n’est en fait rien de plus qu’une pousse de salade ayant suffisamment grandi pour se retrouver sur l’étal du marchand de légumes. Et pour s’y rendre, plutôt que monter dans un grand camion, elle est partie sur ses petites pattes. Attention : ce kanji est aussi une clé.  --

column11: Tree . . . yellow.  -    -  A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up sideways.  -  In a horrible accident, a yellow schoolbus gets wrapped sideways around a tree.
column12: Arbre...jaune. Songez que le cœur du tronc est souvent d'une couleur sombre, alors que l'aubier, la portion latérale du tronc d'arbre est, comme son nom l'indique, de couleur plus claire, tirant sur le jaune.  --

column11: Fingers . . . mosaic.  -    -  Japanese censorship laws require pornos to use a mosaic screen, so you can´t see what the porno chick is grasping with her fingers (but you can assume, neetch).  -  Your fingers grasp the Rubic´s cube... if only your brain could too.
column12: Empoigner ou saisir, au propre et au figuré, sont rendus par les doigts associés à mosaïque - sac à main en peau de serpent - Paris. C'est aussi le compteur des liasses ou des fagots.  --

column6: color, tint, hue, shade; form, body; beauty, desire for beauty; Kangxi radical 139
column11: Bound up . . . mosaic.  -    -  Ever look closely at mosaics? They contain a bunch of images bound up into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their colour.  -  Bound up in the Rubik´s cube are the 6 different colours.
column12: Empaqueté...mosaïque - sac à main en peau de serpent - Paris. Les sens secondaires de ce kanji concernent les relations galantes.    --

column11: Thread . . . color.  -    -  I can't finish my sewing project because the thread color I was using was discontinued.  -  As times move on and fashion tastes inevitably change, threads of certain colors often get discontinued.
column12: Fil...couleur. Lorsqu’un fil (blanc) devient coloré, c’est qu’il devient si fin que des couleurs, dues à des phénomènes d’interférence, apparaissent. Et s’il est si fin, c’est qu’il est proche de sa disparition.   --

column11: Bountiful . . . color.  -    -  To print something with bountiful colour, they use glossy paper.  -  Glossy prints bring out bountiful colors more so than matte...　　　　　RTK2:　エン　艶聞　えんぶん(love affair).
column12: Abondance...couleur. Comme le kanji de couleur, celui-ci porte le sens secondaire d’aventure galante.   --

column11: Flesh . . . mosaic.  -    -  PART OF YOUR BODY excretes something that is commonly used for FERTILIZER. Sometimes this process is slow, so you solve a RUBIK´S CUBE while you sit and wait.  -  If you´re sick, a part of your body may produce fertilizer that makes a colorful mosaic.
column12: Chair...mosaïque. La viande de bœuf de Kobé dessine une sorte de mo­saïque de filets blancs, résultat de la technique d’engraissement.  --  Chapitre quarante-cinq  Quelques contenants  RASSEMBLONS quelques contenants, dont la plupart n'ont qu'une utilisation limitée en tant que composants, mais ne devraient pas encombrer votre mémoire : au contraire, rangez-y ce qui suit !

column11: This kanji is a pictograph of a small wicker basket. (The extra short stroke in the middle helps keep it distinct from the character for twenty.) All one needs to add is some image of sweet cakes or breads carried in the basket, and the union of picture and meaning is complete. Take care not to confuse with confectionary (Frame 1203).  -  * As a primitive, the pictograph's meaning of a wicker basket is used, a small one like the kind used for picnics.  -  Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.  -  Girls are kinda sweet and sexy until they reach their twenties. So 20 minus ONE.
column12: Ce kanji est le pictogramme d’un petit panier d’osier (le trait supplémentaire du centre nous aidera à le distinguer du nombre vingt). Il suffit alors d’imaginer un petit panier d’osier rempli de friandises, et la relation avec le sens du mot-clé, doux, sera faite. Le sens est très général.  --  * Petit panier d'osier sera notre sésame.

column11: Thread . . . wicker basket.  -    -  Thanks raulir - As many Japanese perverts know, navy blue threads conceal school girl sweetness underneath.  -  Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Spiderman failed to heed Willy Wonka´s warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of navy blue.
column12: Le nœud du petit panier d'osier dans lequel grand-maman range les bonbons est fait d'un joli fil bleu marine. Plongez-y la main en fermant les yeux pour prendre un bonbon.  --

column11: The key word here refers to the adjective for an unspecified person or thing. Its elements: wicker basket . . . tree.  -    -  I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.  -  Two girls with a lollipop in a tree gossiping´ so-and so did this.´ ´really? so-and what did she do´ ´ o she is sooo wrong..´.
column12: Qui a placé le petit panier d’osier dans un arbre ? La notion d'anonymat est la clé de ce kanji.  --

column11: Words . . . so-and-so.  -    -  I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.  -  You might hear the words of someone conspiring... "If you do so-and-so...".
column12: Mots...untel. Jusqu'au moment où tout devient publiquement connu, les mots des conspirateurs restent anonymes.  --

column11: Woman . . . so-and-so.  -    -  The woman 女 hoped her friend would act as mediator to set her up with the guy she liked. She didn't mention his name, just referred to him as "A certain unnamed person -- I'll call him 'Mr. So-and-So 某' ...."  -  The two little gossiping girls with their lollipops are having a fight. Now an adult woman (mom or teacher) has to come between them an serve as a mediator.
column12: Femme...untel. Il ressort de ce kanji au sens étendu que le médiateur doit avoir la finesse de l'intelligence féminine là où règne l'anonymat.  --

column11: Bushel basket . . . yawn.  -    -  Kasparov practices deceit by grabbing your rook while pretending to yawn.  -  He escaped using deceit. That is, he ran past while the guard was yawning and hid in the bushel basket.
column12: Lors d'une tromperie ou escroquerie, on se rend soudain compte que notre interlocuteur a manqué de parole.  --

column6: chess; any game similar to chess
column11: Tree . . . bushel basket.  -    -  Tree + Bushel Bucket: Chess pieces carved from trees were tossed into a bushel bucket for sorting into sets.  -  Ever seen those huge chess games in parks? The large wooden chess pieces need to be carted in a shopping trolley.
column12: Il s'agit des échecs japonais, dont les pièces sont en bois, et qui fonctionnent comme chez nous : une fois joué, c'est à l'adversaire, ou l'interlocuteur de continuer.  --

column11: Banner . . . bushel basket.  -    -  The national flag of Croatia. It's a banner with the Croatian coat of arms, commonly referred to as the Chessboard (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Croatia).  -  The national flag is the banner of a country; stored in a whicker basket at night and taken out to the flagpole in the morning.
column12: Le drapeau est une bannière que l’on range à côté de la malle d’osier, au fond du grenier.  --

column6: period of time; date; time limit
column11: Bushel basket . . . month. As the month indicates, this has to do with periods of time.  -    -  The slowest remote chess game ever: a one month period between every move.  -  The girl´s panties are all in the bushel basket as it´s that time of the month again... her period.
column12: Malle d’osier...mois. Comme l’indique le mois, nous avons ici affaire à une période de temps. La remarque suivant le 543 pourra d’ailleurs être utile pour retenir l’ordre de tracé des deux éléments. À la fin de chaque période scolaire, on remplit la malle d’osier et on quitte la pension pour la durée des vacances.  --

column6: chess; any game similar to chess
column11: Bushel basket . . . stones. The key word refers to the Japanese game played with black and white colored stones on a lined board.  -    -  Go is chess played with stones.  -  The ignorant gaijin put a rook on top of his opponent´s stone when playing Go, much to the consternation of the Japanese players.
column12: Les pièces du jeu de go sont des cailloux, et ça marche comme les échecs : une fois joué, c'est à l'adversaire, ou interlocuteur, de continuer.  --

column11: Bushel basket . . . soil.  -    -  Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground.  -  A Bushel-basket full of earth contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.
column12: Les fondements sont ici l’assise de terre où nous posons la malle d’osier. Revoyez 1665 qui est un peu semblable.  --

column11: Bushel basket . . . equal. Note how the first stroke of equal doubles up with the sixth stroke of the bushel basket, and how the animal legs of the bushel basket are dropped to make room for the human legs of equal.  -    -  It´s a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother´s equal.  -  These two bushel baskets are tremendously huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly equal in size.
column12: Malle d’osier...égal - compteur des petits animaux. Ce kanji est une sorte de superlatif, que nous rendons en disant qu’on peut mettre une très grande quantité de petits animaux dans la malle d’osier.   --

column11: Tremendously . . . muscle.  -    -  Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.  -  Using Zareon´s story for the previous frame "tremendously"... The two chessplayers who are eachother´s equals are so good at chess that they don´t have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don´t even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. This is: extreme chess.
column12: L'intuition nous rend très forts, hyperlucides.  --

column11: Soil . . . tremendously.  -    -  Because I hid myself behind a huge dirt barrier I dug, I was able to withstand the tremendous nuclear blast.  -  Plain old soil can withstand tremendous amounts of pressure.
column12: Sol...très. Imaginez un barrage-poids, construit avec une très grande quantité de terre, afin de résister à la poussée de l’eau.  --

column11: Purse . . . shells.  -    -  Inside your purse is all of your money and your keys (き) etc. All of your precious valuables.  -  Frodo kept the precious in the purse but did a switch with some worthless shells when he went to sleep. Heres gollum opening the purse "ahhh my preciousssssss.....why you m***** *****!!!!!.
column12: Porte-monnaie...monnaie. On remplit ici le porte-monnaie d'espèces sonnantes et trébuchantes, notre précieuse fortune.  --

column11: Precious . . . road.  -    -  Bequeath is an odd old word, isn´t it? Basically, it just deals with how I want my precious possessions dealt out, after I die, later down the road. "Being of sound, but antiquated, mind, I bequeath this to you!".  -  Bilbo bequeathes the "PRECIOUS" to Frodo, who will carry it on the long ROAD to Mordor.
column12: Les objets précieux légués par le défunt prennent un nouveau départ sur une nouvelle route.  --

column11: This kanji takes away the maestro's baton and replaces it with a purse. The road represents his being dispatched on his way a san obvious misfit. You will remember that when he did have his baton, he was being chased down the road by his fans. All of which shows what a difference a single stroke can make!  -    -  Dispatch all cars and chase the maestro! He's gone crazy and stolen a ladies purse!  -  Apart from meaning DISPATCH, this kanji can mean "to give (to someone lower than you)," "to do," and to even "have intercourse." STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO´S baton? You don´t wanna know...
column12: Route...porte-monnaie...maestro. Ce kanji occupe probablement une pleine colonne dans votre dictionnaire de japonais. L'idée de base exprime la notion d'action, en langue parlée. En corollaire, nous trouvons donner (je donne à mon chien). Le mot-clé expédier exprime l'idée et le niveau de langue. Notre maestro est sur la route, expédiant les affaires courantes en vidant son porte-monnaie. Rappelez-vous qu'il était pourchassé par l'orchestre lorsqu'il n'avait que son bâton.  --

column11: The top two strokes show someone reclining, and the next six are a pictograph of an oaken tub ribbed with metal strips, like the kind once used for bathing. At the bottom, the sunglasses round off the character.  -    -  The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances naked for him.  -  I learned nothingness (#1775) first because it is a very common kanji. Probably easier to think of this kanji in that context. Attractive dancers should dance wearing nothing but sunglasses.
column12: Les deux premiers traits montrent un individu couché, et les suivants une sorte de baquet de bois cerclé de fer, semblable à ceux utilisés autrefois à l’heure du bain. Au bas, les pieds écartés du danseur complètent le kanji.  --

column6: negative, no, not; lack, have no
column11: This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: nothingness. Make use of the oaken tub from the previous frame, and add to that the oven fire at the bottom.  -    -  When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness.  -  In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into nothingness.
column12: Ce kanji définit un principe philosophique important dans la pensée orientale : le néant. « Nous n'avons même pas de mot pour le désigner », écrit Robert M. Pirsig dans son Traité du zen et de l'entretien des motocyclettes. - Le mu [無], c'est l'absence de toutes choses. Comme la Qualité, il échappe au processus de discrimination dualiste. Le mu dit simplement : ni 1, ni o, ni oui, ni non. Il indique que le contexte d'une question donnée est tel qu'une réponse par oui ou non serait erronée, ne peut être donnée. « Reprenez votre question », voilà sa réponse². Beaucoup plus prosaïquement, utilisez le baquet que nous venons de décrire, puis ajoutez le chaudron au-dessous pour parvenir au néant.  ² Robert M. Pirsig Traité du zen et de l'entretien des motocyclettes (1978) éd. du Seuil, coll. Points-romans p. 270-271.  --

column11: Thread . . . shelf.  -    -  A common thread associates the knick-knacks on your knick-knack shelf. Souveneirs from Spain on one, from Japan on the other.  -  Watch this: http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular).
column12: Fil...étagère. Pensez à assembler une de ces étagères minimalistes, faites de planches unies par de fins filins.  --

column11: Rice . . . shelf.  -    -  Japanese carpenters don't use sandpaper, they use rice-paper(rice glued on to some paper). Here the carpenter is using the coarse paper to smooth out the shelf he's making.  -  Ugh, why does this shelf feel so coarse? Because it´s made of rice, of coarse! Get it? Of coarse?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.
column12: Riz...étagère. Nous avons vu en 1674 le riz pur, « bleu azuré ». Ici se trouve son contraire, le riz impur, grossier. On l'a placé sur l'étagère, en attente du traitement de purification.  --

column11: Wheat . . . shelf.  -    -  The EU and US impose such high tariffs on food imports that third world wheat (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket shelves.  -  According to Henshall, this kanji originally represented the harvested rice (the wheat primitive) that farmers paid as a tithe. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested wheat on a shelf in order to pay the tariff to his lord.
column12: Blé...étagère. Ce kanji est relié au monde des emprunts et taxes, mais le mot-clé montant d’argent permet de former plus aisément une image, à partir des éléments blé...étagère.   --

column11: Altar . . . shelf.  -    -  The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.  -  The urns of ancestors are kept on shelves next to the altar.
column12: Autel...étagère. Pensez par exemple au tokonoma, dans lequel on place l’autel des ancêtres.  --

column11: Pinnacle . . . shelf.  -    -  Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).  -  The shortness of the Japanese thwarts their attempts to reach the topmost (pinnacle) shelf without grabbing a chair.
column12: Tertre...étagère. Il faut percevoir l'étagère comme un outil permettant de s'élever, et le tertre comme un maximum absolu, qu'on ne peut dépasser : il fait donc obstacle à l'ascension. Vous pouvez revoir 1592.  --

column6: an ape, monkey; to spy, watch for; to lie
column11: Pack of wild dogs . . . shelf.  -    -  When her home was invaded by a pack of dogs, the little girl climbed on the shelf and aimed various items at the dogs below.  -  I think the dogs purposely aim at your shelves to deal the most damage.
column12: La meute de chiens ici placée à côté de l’étagère n’y est que pour une seule raison : il s’agit d’un trophée de chasse et ce sont des animaux empaillés. Il a donc fallu qu’un chasseur vise bien pour qu’on puisse la voir ici.  --

column11: Tree . . . shelf.  -    -  Like the "ero inquiry" that had been partially swept under the rug (see inquire (#1145)), this kanji depicts the investigation into the forestry scandal being shelved.  -  The result of the inverstigation of the missing Trees? Why, most of them had become shelfs!
column12: Etagère...tombée d’un arbre. Mais que fait la Police ? Cette investigation concerne aussi bien une inspection technique ou policière que la vérification d'un simple document postal.  --

column11: This kanji, a polite way of expressing one's best regards to another. Its elements: house . . . shelf.  -    -  It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I´ve gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.  -  We have a shelf in our house where we put Christmas cards from people who send best regards for the holiday season...　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　ギ　便宜主義　べんぎしゅぎ(opportunism).
column12: Maison...étagère. Le mot-clé, formule de politesse, pourrait se dire « cela vous convient-il ? » Et c’est sans doute ce que dirait à sa cliente un installateur d’étagères après la livraison.  --

column11: Shelf . . . power. The reason why the shelf appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for add (Frame 932).  -    -  HELP! Someone´s pinned under this bookshelf and it´s gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!  -  Can you help me move this shelf? I don´t have the muscle to do it alone.
column12: Étagère...muscle. La raison pour laquelle l’étagère apparaît à gauche est que la droite est la position habituelle du muscle. De fait, l’unique exception à cette règle se trouve en 952. Quant au sens, pensez que l’installateur d’étagères est un peu maladroit, et qu’il faut lui donner un coup de main.  --

column11: Rice field . . . crown . . . shelf.  -    -  The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.  -  Making tatami mats from rice field waste was Japan´s crowning achievement, but for some reason other countries just shelved the idea.
column12: Rizière...couronne...étagère. Au sens de replier est directement associé celui de tatami, la natte japonaise sur laquelle chaque matin, la ménagère replie et empile les futons avant de les ranger l'étagère couronnée. La rizière fournit la paille de riz dont est constitué l'intérieur du tatami.  --

column6: equal to; side by side; also, what is more; both
column11: This character represents a slightly stylized duplication of the kanji for stand up. By lengthening the sixth and seventh strokes, you will see how this is done.  -  * The primitive meaning remains the same as that of the kanji, but special attention has to be given to the varieties of shape this element can undergo. It is the most difficult one you will meet in this book. When it appears BENEATH its relative primitive, the top three strokes are omitted, though the third horizontal stroke may be doubled up with the bottom horizontal stroke of the element above it. ATOP its relative primitive, it can keep its kanji shape. When it does not, the top three strokes are removed and all of them are replaced BELOW the primitive's bottom line. We shall acknowledge this latter transformation by changing its meaning to upside down in a row.  -  This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.  -  Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for "rowboat" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for "rowboat" has a generic meaning of "a small boat". In any case, the kanji for "rowboat" will not appear as a primitive in the book.
column12: Ce kanji représente une duplication à peine simplifiée du kanji debout. En allongeant les sixième et septième traits, vous verrez comment créer cette duplication.  --  * Le sens composant demeure le même, mais il conviendra d'être vigilant car cet élément subira plusieurs modifications. Quand il sera au-dessous d'un autre composant, les deux premiers traits seront omis, et le premier trait horizontal sera commun avec le trait inférieur de l'élément du dessus : . En position supérieure, il pourra garder sa forme normale mais il arrivera aussi que les trois premiers traits soient déplacés sous la ligne inférieure :  . Nous donnerons alors à cette forme le sens rangée à l'envers.

column11: Row . . . sun.  -    -  A row of suns is actually a normal, plain, and ordinary occurrence in an infinitely large and expanding universe. FUtsuu.  -  To me, row is way too close to file (#812), so I´m adopting Fab´s meaning of rowboat from the previous frame. Universal Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters UNIVERSAL orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man rowing himself in a boat around the sun.
column12: Rangée...soleil. Cette rangée de Soleils évoque l'unité de base de notre monde, la somme des étoiles, où toute la matière est créée par des réactions nucléaires, et ce phénomène a bien un caractère absolument universel.  --

column11: Words . . . universal.  -    -  Musical scores are in a universal language.  -  A musical score can be read, but not like ordinary words. Music is a universal language.
column12: Mots...universels. Pensez à une partition musicale, bien que le sens ne s’y limite pas strictement.  --

column11: Water . . . sun . . . row.  -    -  You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don´t wring them damp first they will take days to dry!  -  If your things are damp, lay them up in a row under the sun and let the water evaporate. (thx Raichu)...　RTK2:　シツ　湿気　しっけ(humidity).
column12: Eau...soleil...rangée. Revoyez 1576, car ce kanji en est une sorte de cousin, puis remplacez l'assiette par une rangée de légumes au jardin ou d'arbres dans une forêt. Le soleil en fera évaporer l'eau, mettant de l'humidité dans l'air.  --

column11: Sun . . . row . . . heads.  -    -  Somebody's head appears from behind the laundry in a row drying under the sun  -  Clouds were covering the sky for months now. Rows upon rows of people spent whole days with their heads turned upwards, waiting for sun to appear.
column12: Soleil...rangée...tête. La rangée des choses que nous observons, avec la tête, est bien exposée au soleil, donc parfaitement visible. Un sens associé est montrer.  --

column11: Thread . . . Thanksgiving . . . row.  -    -  At the end of Thanksgiving it's tradition for everyone to stand in a row and measure their waist with a strip of thread. Whoever is the most slender wins the leftovers.  -  At the time of Thanksgiving, there´s a row of all sorts of food on the table, which you mustn´t eat if you want to stay as slender as a thread.
column12: Fil...terre...hallebarde...rangée. Nous avons considéré en 387 que l'association terre...hallebarde est un atelier de coupe industrielle. Ici, ce sont des rangées de légumes qui sont traités et vont devenir complètement effilés, comme dans une julienne. Dans le domaine culinaire, ce kanji signifie julienne, et fibre de façon générale.  --

column11: Rain . . . two . . . row. This character will refer only to the inhabitants of the "spirit world," and not to moods or temperaments, for which we will learn another character in frame 2030.  -    -  After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006).  -  When it rains, two worlds come together and spirits can be seen in the forest, dancing in a row.
column12: Intempéries...deux...rangée. Il s’agit des habitants de l’autre monde dont les corps sont rangés en ligne et dont l’âme s’est dédoublée d’eux-mêmes, partant vers d’autres mondes à travers les intempéries.   --

column11: In a row upside down . . . not yet.  -    -  The oldest profession: prostitution. I was once in a brothel in Amsterdam where the working girls had a group of businessmen blindfolded and hanging upside down in a row, not yet spanked and whipped, but waiting eagerly.  -  A bunch of kids are hanging upside down in a row on the monkeybars. Naturally, they haven't chosen a profession, at least not yet.
column12: Le travail industrieux dont il est ici question est une activité industrielle, un travail consistant à remettre à l'endroit une « rangée encore à l'envers ». Ce kanji concerne les activités industrielles et commerciales de façon générale.  --

column11: Fingers . . . upside down in a row . . . husbands.  -    -  After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn´t get me banned…).  -  Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.
column12: Doigt...maris rangés à l'envers. D'une pitchenette du doigt, le lutteur professionnel remet à l'endroit tout un rang de maris l'envers.  --

column11: This key word is yet another synonym for "I," somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: person . . . husbands . . . in a row upside down.  -    -  Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.  -  Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it´s the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft; "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" -- but when he´s one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it´s ME!".
column12: Le mâle japonais dispose de plusieurs mots pour se qualifier, et dont l'usage est en principe réservé aux hommes. Voici l'un d'entre eux, qui s'écrit Tintin...maris rangés à l'envers, et dont le sens premier est humble serviteur.  --

column6: together with, all, total; to share
column11: Salad . . . animal legs.  -  * The primitive retains the meaning of together. Imagine things strung together like fish on a line, beads on a thread, or whatever. The main thing is to avoid putting them in a straight row, which would confound this element with the previous one. As we saw with bushel basket, this primitive can join its legs to the final horizontal stroke and stretch them to form an enclosure.  -  The character for deluge (#1799) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah´s Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.  -  The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.[Thanks fuaburisu!].
column12: Salade...pattes. Lorsque les salades mettent leurs pattes pour aller vers l'étal du légumier, elles y vont ensemble, apprend-on ici.  --   * Le composant garde le sens du kanji. Imaginons diverses choses attachées ensemble, comme des poissons dans un filet, ou des salades dans un panier. Ce composant pourra en héberger d'autres, et subira des déformations semblables à celles que connaît la malle d'osier.

column6: supply, provide for; offer in worship
column11: Submit here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. Its elements: person . . . strung together.  -    -  You have to SUBMIT all required documents together, in person!  -  When people are together and form a group, they suddenly submit their personal responsibility to the mob mentality.
column12: Tintin...attaché ensemble. Il s’agit d’un verbe signifiant offrir ou proposer, avec parfois une connotation religieuse. En corollaire, on trouve aussi le sens de pluriel cérémonieux.   --

column11: Brains . . . together.  -    -  Brains together with beauty is an uncommon combination.  -  It´s uncommon to find a pair of together twins who are connected at the brain! When such a set does turn up, they are inevitably showcased on TV.
column12: Rizière...ensemble. Pendant la courte période de la plantation du riz, la rizière prend un aspect inhabituel : couverte uniformément, elle devient provisoirement un grand ensemble, parfaitement plan.  --

column6: wings; fins on fish; shelter; 27th lunar mansion, determinative star α Crateris (Alkes)
column11: Feathers . . . uncommon.  -    -  The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon.  -  WINGS without any FEATHERS would be an UNCOMMON site. Well, unless you like to eat chicken WINGS alot.
column12: Plumes...inhabituel. Inhabituel veut sans doute traduire le caractère mobile des plumes des ailes.  --

column11: Thanksgiving . . . uncommon.  -    -  At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in.  -  You´re invited to a Thanksgiving party in Japan! Awesome! You´re so happy that your Japanese friends are trying to make you feel at home (you´ve been homesick recently). You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh...uncommon food. Really uncommon. Like just imagine the most uncommon Thanksgiving food ever, and that´s what you´re given (i don´t know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and accept humbly their food.
column12: Coupe industrielle...inhabituel. Vous pourrez revoir 97 et 387. Aujourd'hui est un jour inhabituel chez les coupeurs industriels car on célèbre le couronnement des meilleurs ouvriers.  --

column11: Water . . . strung together.  -    -  Lots of water coming together is called a deluge.  -  A real deluge of water, as if all water worked together, as if strung together haphazardly.
column12: Eau...ensemble. C'est la vigueur des eaux formant un ensemble unique, que nous devons retenir ici.   --

column11: Deluge . . . snakes.  -    -  During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour.  -  All throughout the deluge Noah had been kicking himself for forgetting to bring any snakes onto the Ark. It wasn´t until the deluge had finished, and Noah had brought the Ark safely back to the harbour that he realised that the snakes had been under the Ark all along.
column12: Eau...ensemble...serpents. On reconnaît un port à la présence d'eau et aux longs cordages serpentant d'un bateau à l'autre, les maintenant ensemble.  --

column11: Sun . . . strung together . . . rice grains.  -    -  If you think of it as of outburst of an atomic bomb (which will also prove useful in the next frame), then imagining thousands of suns blasting in one single outburst of rage and turning people into rice grains is not that hard.  -  Having spent all day stringing together grains of rice he suddenly had an outburst, "I can take it any longer!".
column12: Soleil...ensemble...irrigation. L'ensemble des systèmes d'irrigation est exposé aux rayons du soleil, afin d'assurer l'indépendance alimentaire du Japon ; et cela provoque le déchaînement du représentant commercial des États-Unis. Comme le suggère l'image, le sens d'exposer est inclus. En un sens, exposer revient à libérer, donc à déchaîner.  --

column11: Fire . . . outburst.  -    -  Actually means explosion, like an outburst of fire.  -  Bombs make fiery outbursts. It´s almost too logical, this one.
column12: Feu...déchaîner. Le feu est ici une petite étincelle qui déchaîne les éléments et provoque l’explosion.   --

column11: Strung together . . . valentine.  -    -  If you wanna stay together you have to show your valentine respect.  -  As I like Aretha Franklin's song "R-E-S-P-E-C-T", I cut out each of the letters from pieces of card, then string them all together and send it to her as a valentine.
column12: Par cette idée d'allégeance et de déférence, nous percevons l'unité de sentiment d'un groupe envers un individu. C'est ainsi que naît cette idée des sentiments ensemble.  --
