column11: Two snakes . . . strung together . . . road.  -    -  Isn't this how the US presedential election works? You are given a choice between two snakes. Their politics are actually strung together but you get to feel as though you chose which one you want to lead you down the political road for the next four years. So which snake are you going to elect?  -  You´re driving on the road and you see two snakes together. You can´t avoid both, so you have to elect which one gets run over.
column12: Deux entités sont attachées ensemble, chacune courant parallèlement à l'autre, chacune persuadée de suivre la route de la victoire.  --

column6: well, mine shaft, pit; surname; 22nd lunar mansion, determinative star μ Geminorum (Tejat); hexagram ䷯
column11: Recalling that there are no circular strokes, and that the shape of the square and the square within a square (Frame 630) have already been used, it should be relatively easy to see how this character can be consider a pictograph of a well.  -    -  I nearly died by falling in a well. Actually, on two separate occasions. I´m glad to see they´ve added these fence posts. Now the well will be much safer.  -  Have you ever seen an old fashioned japanese well? == http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well-at-Osaka-Castle.htm.
column12: Rappelant qu’il n’existe pas de forme circulaire, que le carré et le carré au milieu d’un autre carré sont déjà employés, il devrait être aisé de voir comment ce kanji peut être vu comme le pictogramme d’un puits.  --

column11: Well . . . pent in.  -    -  The village surrounded the well with a wall so kids wouldn´t fall in.  -  You get good surround sound when your pent-up in well.
column12: Entourage...puits. On entoure ici le puits pour éviter que les enfants ne s’en approchent trop.  --

column11: Christmas tree . . . well.  -    -  If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to till the soil.  -  A man was tilling a new plot to plant xmas trees but his tractor hit an old covered-up well and fell halfway in, he´s asking for a new tractor for xmas..
column12: Bêche...puits. Quand on laboure, il faut faire attention là où se trouve le puits pour éviter d'émousser la bêche sur la pierre.  --

column11: In this kanji, the abbreviation for Asia, you should be able to see the character for mouth behind the Roman numeral II.  -    -  In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.  -  A mouth barred up and not aloud to speak freely is the sign of asia (korea, China, pakistan etc).
column12: Vous reconnaîtrez dans ce kanji le caractère bouche derrière le nombre romain II, Ce qui établit une relation avec l’autre sens du caractère : sub- ou suivant.   --

column11: Asia . . . heart.  -    -  Because Asian people started to eat Western food, their hearts became bad and they started having heart attacks.  -  Asian hearts are bad and evil. They invented so much martial arts: karate, judo, kungfu, muay thai, silat, etc... just to hurt each other. They torture their own people (China, North Korea). They torture other people (Japan in China and Korea). And they are able to hide all this behind their nice facade of kindness. Bad, bad Asians. (did i shatter some people´s ideas on Asia? my bad).
column12: Sub-...sentiments.   --

column6: horn; angle, corner; point; Kangxi radical 148; 1st lunar mansion, determinative star Spica
column11: Bound up . . . glass canopy . . . walking stick . . . two. If you write the character once, you will see why we avoided using the element for soil, which would prompt you to write it in improper order.  -  * As a primitive, imagine the tool used by draftsmen and carpenters to draw right-angles.  -  A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle.  -  The gates have been bound up together leaving no angle to get through...　RTK2:　カク　兎に角　とにかく(anyhow)　"horns on a rabbit".
column12: Emballé...cloche de verre...bâton de marche...deux. En écrivant le kanji, notez combien il est préférable d’éviter l’utilisation de l’élément terre, sans quoi on risquerait des erreurs d’écriture.  --

column11: Angle . . . insect.  -    -  For insects to get in contact with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right angle.  -  Wow, he threw that BOOMERANG with such skill, it made CONTACT with that INSECT in mid flight.
column12: Angle...moustique. Il se trouve que la connaissance préalable et fortuite que j’avais du mot « araignée » (蜘蛛, insecte connu, insecte vermillon !) m’a aidé à retenir le kanji contact. Les angles dont on parle ici pourraient en effet être ceux que forment les fils de la toile, et l’insecte une fois entré en contact avec ces angles voit son compte réglé en un clin d’œil : insecte connu, insecte rouge.  --

column11: Angle . . . dagger . . . cow.  -    -  Did you know that you can unravel a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just unravel.  -  Unravel the mystery by determining at what ANGLE the SWORD went into the COW.
column12: D'un coup de poignard, il s'agit ici de délier une vache restée dans un angle peu éclairé de l'étable. Notez bien que le poignard est ici au-dessus de la vache, car il s'agit de la délier, non pas de l'égorger.  --

column11: Jewel . . . with a belt hung on it. Note how the belt is drawn right after the first stroke of jewel.  -    -  The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over?  -  This is a belt with a non-adjustable jeweled buckle. Everytime you go back to the leathersmith telling him to move the buckle because you´ve packed on a few pounds (but that this is the last time!), he says "Again?!? Weren´t you just here last month?".
column12: Bijou...avec une courroie. On peut aussi voir ce caractère comme l’écriture de un suivi par celle de deux, lequel étant caché par la courroie. C’est donc en un sens la succession de deux objets semblables, mais le second arrive par surprise. Attention à l’ordre des traits, décrit ci-dessous.  --

column11: Words . . . funnel.  -    -  I have a funnel attached to my laptop that takes my prof´s lecture and puts the words into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port.  -  Image: a professor walking around with a funnel and simply pouring his words into each students head instead of a lecture. (Primitive: FUNNEL, who got the celery stuck in the funnel again?! You know it´s not supposed to be used for that!).
column12: Mots...charpente. Le bon cours magistral doit contenir les bons mots, et la bonne structure, la bonne charpente.  --

column11: Shells . . . funnel. The key word is meant to suggest magazine subscriptions and the like.  -    -  Subscription is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country).  -  My subscription to Money magazine came with a free coin funnel.
column12: Monnaie...charpente. Pour acquérir un objet, nous nous présentons avec un projet financier bien charpenté, basé sur de solides espèces.  --

column11: Tree . . . funnel.  -    -  Ideal posture is standing tall like a tree and having a V shape like a funnel  -  I fell out of a tree and broke my neck. So they put one of those white funnels around my neck to correct my posture.
column12: Cette charpente est une structure solide construite en bois. Ce kanji porte aussi la connotation de préoccuper, comme si la préoccupation influençait notre structure mentale.  --

column11: Water . . . funnel.  -    -  A gutter funnels water.  -  A gutter takes the water that falls as rain and funnels it off to where it can be dealt with appropriately.
column12: Eau...charpente. Les fossés dessinent un réseau d'eau bien organisé, bien charpenté, pourrait-on ajouter.  --

column11: Words . . . meeting . . . scrapbook. The argument here is a process of academic reasoning, not a personal quarrel or spat.  -    -  Right part: academic conference (a meeting, some of the attendees making notes in scrapbooks during presentation). Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words.  -  It´s very difficult to present a good argument if you don´t bring along a scrapbook with some key words jotted down to the meeting.
column12: Mots...assemblée de cahiers. Certaines collections rassemblant la pensée d'un groupe portent le nom de cahiers, dans lesquels sont regroupés les mots contenant l'argumentation du groupe.  --

column11: Person . . . meeting . . . scrapbook.  -    -  Mr. T talks about ethics at the academic conference. "I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else´s stuff!".  -  Mr. T has no ethics at the scrapbooking convention. He´ll do whatever it takes to beat all those ladies.
column12: Tintin...assemblée de cahiers. L’éthique régissant les fait et actes de Tintin est reportée dans l’ensemble de la collection de ses albums.  --

column11: Car . . . meeting . . . scrapbook.  -    -  During a talk at the academic conference, speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of car, and then moves on to the more narrow topic of wheels.  -  Someone stole all the wheels off the ladies´ cars at the scrapbook convention.
column12: Voiture...assemblée de cahiers. Pour démonter la roue arrière d’une DS, il fallait d’abord démonter l’aile... Cela impliquait en pratique la possession des cahiers de documentation ad-hoc.  --

column11: Person . . . door . . . scrapbook. The sense of the key-word is that of having a bias or preference for someone or something.  -    -  Mr. T is partial to konbini hentai. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: KONBINI HENTAI, all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan).  -  Mr. T is very partial to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!
column12: Tintin...porte...cahier. Tintin, devenu un instituteur sévère et partial, est debout près de la porte, surveillant les élèves et leurs cahiers.   --

column11: Door . . . scrapbook . . . a road.  -    -  Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.  -  Go down any road in Japan and you´ll find konbini hentai everywhere.
column12: Dès que la porte s’ouvre, les élèves s’en vont sur la route, et leurs cahiers sont disséminés partout dans la campagne.  --

column11: Thread . . . door . . . scrapbook.  -    -  Raulir has a good idea. I prefer to think of the manga compilations as the individual comics (serials from the anthologies) bound together with a coarse thread down the spine, produced quickly and put on the market. Good way to recycle those pulpy manga, and since when has the consumer not gotten screwed in Japan? ;-).  -  A Japanese comic book is a compilation of the individual chapters (which have already appeared in weekly comic magazines) with a thread (story arc) going through it.
column12: Fil...porte...cahiers. Le responsable de la compilation est assis à sa porte, et dès qu’un nouveau contributeur se présente, il s’empare de son cahier et le tresse avec son fil aux travaux déjà reçus. Tresser est un sens associé.  --

column11: This key word is a counter for books. It differs from scrapbook both in the writing order and in the extension of the second horizontal stroke.  -    -  Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.  -  冊 さつ 1: counter for books A heavy scrapbook so full that flowers are sticking out. Only if a scrapbook is that full, it can be called a heavy book.
column12: Ce kanji diffère du cahier tant par l’ordre d’écriture que par l'allongement du trait horizontal.  --

column11: We introduce this character here because of its connection to the book-related kanji treated above. It is based on the character for bend (frame 1256), whose last stroke is lengthened to coincide with the first stroke of the element for tool.  -    -  Coding is a tool which you can use to bend the computer to your will.  -  Think "codex" (mnemonic help) or "code of laws", or even Leonardo Da Vinci´s code. Here I see a codex as a tool used to bend the masses into submission. Picture a huge codex book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you bend to the code without asking questions, you are a tool!
column12: Nous présentons ce kanji ici en raison de sa ressemblance avec les précédents. Basé sur le kanji courber, dont le dernier trait est allongé pour coïncider avec les pattes de l’établi du dessous, il apparaît sans doute sur la couverture de votre dictionnaire français-japonais : 仏和辞典[ふつわじてん].  --  Chapitre quarante-huit Gens et lieux  VOICI maintenant les derniers composants reliés aux groupes de gens, à leurs relations, leur classification, aux lieux qu'ils fréquentent.

column11: Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long drop . . . fishhook . . . a one . . . fishhook.  -    -  Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.  -  The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I´m keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.
column12: Attention à l’ordre des traits en apprenant le caractère. Les éléments sont une longue goutte...charrue...une autre longue goutte (également écrite de droite à gauche)...hameçon. Ce kanji est employé lorsqu’on mentionne un individu par écrit, détail dont la connaissance pourra être utile au prochain cadre. Nom de famille est un sens associé de ce kanji.  --

column11: Thread . . . family name.  -    -  All that threads you to your family name is a piece of paper. (birth certificate).  -  I imagine a ridiculously expensive, and rather pointless, Japanese type of paper for writing letters, with one´s family name woven in fine thread somewhere in a corner.
column12: Fil...monsieur (par écrit). Pensez que le papier est parfois fait à partir de vieux chiffons.  --

column11: Woman . . . family name . . . day.  -    -  Marriage is the day in this woman´s life where she gets a new family name.  -  Tip: Heisig later introduces the kanji 昏 dusk (#2451). Story: Never enter into marriage with a woman at dusk (wait until you see them in daylight). Note: This is an ancient proverb . . . (probably).
column12: Le jour du mariage, la femme peut, dans la loi française ou japonaise, changer de nom de famille.  --

column6: low; to lower, hang, bend, bow
column11: Person . . . calling card.  -    -  A person bows low when presenting his business card.  -  Mr. T travels to Japan and knows he must bow lower when presenting his business card.
column12: Tintín...carte de visite. Lorsque Tintín tend sa carte de visite, il se place le plus bas possible, comme le font les Japonais.  --

column11: Fingers . . . calling card.  -    -  Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don´t know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.  -  Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.
column12: Doigts...carte de visite. Un bon test de résistance au Japon pourrait être de savoir refuser, en la repoussant du doigt, chacune des innombrables cartes de visite que les Japonais s’échangent quotidiennement.  --

column11: Cave . . . calling card.  -    -  At the bottom of the cave you find a meishi: "LOST? DIAL 1-800-..."  -  In the deepest bottom of this cave complex, spelunkers leave their calling cards to prove they made it all the way.
column12: Appentis...carte de visite. Quelqu'un a rendu visite dans cet appentis, et y a laissé sa carte de visite, que nous voyons par terre.   --

column11: In place of the drop at the start of the character for family name, we have a mouth, which makes you think of the "vox populi."  -    -  All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.  -  How many of you know what "vox populi" means?
column12: Au lieu du premier trait du kanji monsieur - nom de famille, apparaît une bouche dans laquelle on peut imaginer la « vox populi », la voix des citoyens.   --

column11: Eyes . . . people.  -    -  In an Orwellian sense, the eye watching the people never sleeps.  -  The little boy from The Sixth Sense couldn´t sleep because before his very eyes he saw a dead crowd of people everywhere.
column12: Yeux...citoyens. Il est dix heures, citoyens, dormez.   --

column11: Fingers . . . dog tag.  -    -  I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.  -  Dog tag: This is a wild animal track device. It has an arrowhead and screwdriver-shaped radio beacon. It´s evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a dog tag, it´s easy to catch it: just take a dog tag in your fingers.
column12: Doigt...pépinière. Les doigts du pépiniériste sont maîtres dans l'art de capturer les minuscules pousses pour les faire grandir dans la pépinière.  --

column11: Water . . . dog tag.  -    -  The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle.  -  Otis Redding is sitting on the dock of the bay, looking over the water while clutching the dog tags of his fallen friend from Vietnam.
column12: L'eau qui entoure la pépinière est celle d'une baie, un endroit reculé, protégé des assauts des vagues de l'océan.  --

column11: Flowers . . . bay.  -    -  Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan´s coastline that is concretised... you´ll be surprised.  -  The bulrush is a flower that grows around bays. http://www.meltonrossnewbarnetby.co.uk/images/bulrush.jpg.
column12: La plante qui pousse dans la baie est un typha (on dit aussi quenouille ou massette).  --

column11: Cottage . . . dog tag. The key word refers to the noun, not the verb.  -    -  A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.  -  Normal cottages (舎 actually means a building) don´t have tags advertising their names, but shops do.
column12: La pépinière jouxte une chaumière dans laquelle les pépiniéristes ont installé une échoppe où vendre quelques articles de jardinage et des plantes.  --

column11: Cloak . . . dog tag.  -    -  I usually hear supplement in "dietry supplement". So you´re given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.  -  The name and number printed on a soldier´s cloak is a supplement to his main I.D. tag; his dog-tag, in helping identify the soldier.
column12: Dans la pépinière, on n'a pas besoin de vêtement particulier : ce n'est qu'un complément.  --

column11: Calling card . . . city walls.  -    -  The business card says his residence is just to the left of the city walls. Can you find it? Yep, got it.  -  So fed up am I, I´ve finally built city walls around my residence to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their business cards.
column12: Sur la carte de visite de cet habitant qui possède une belle résidence 8 résidence, il est simplement écrit « le bourg » .  --

column11: Receive . . . city walls.  -    -  The city finally received the enclosure that it desperately needed, city walls to protect it against attacks from the tall kids.  -  Even the tall kids can´t get out of the enclosure that is the city walls.
column12: La périphérie est la zone de terrain où l'on jouit encore des mêmes droits qu'à l'intérieur du bourg.   --

column11: Old boy . . . city walls.  -    -  The old boy had never been outside of his own county because he couldn't get over the city walls.  -  You can take the good old boy out of county (and into the city walls), but you can't take the county out of the good old boy. Is that how the saying goes?
column12: Jeune homme...bourg. En revoyant 1257, vous imaginerez ici le jeune homme garder un ensemble de bourgs, l'ensemble des villes et villages qui forment le comté.  --

column11: Mingle . . . city walls.  -    -  The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls.  -  The city walls mark the outskirts of the inner city, where it begins to mingle with the suburbs.
column12: Échanges...bourg. Cherchant à profiter des avantages de la ville, la banlieue propose d'échanger son espace avec celui du bourg, afin d'en faire aussi partie. La banlieue devient donc faubourg, puis quartier de la ville.  --

column11: Muzzle . . . city walls.  -    -  Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up.  -  The section within the city walls where dogs must be muzzled by law... RTK2:　へ　部屋　へや(room)...　　　　ブ　全部　ぜんぶ(all).
column12: Muselière...bourg. Il faut voir ici une partie d'un tout. Imaginez le bourgmestre en train de décider des nouveaux travaux, plaçant des sortes de muselières sur chaque partie du bourg pour délimiter les actions à mener.  --

column6: metropolis, capital; all, the whole; elegant, refined
column11: Someone . . . city walls.  -    -  In a metropolis people are just puppets inside city walls, there is no individuality if you live so close together.  -  A vision of a futuristic METROPOLIS: standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.
column12: Personne...bourg. Une personne qui passe son temps au sein du bourg vit dans la métropole.  --

column11: Droop . . . city walls.  -    -  The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials. Hint: think "hate mail" and you will remember this one. [thx CharleyGarrett].  -  The city walls droop down in one spot so that the mailtman can throw the mail over.
column12: Pendre...bourg. Le service postal pend les sacs de courrier à l'entrée du bourg.  --

column11: Bushes . . . city walls.  -    -  He reminisced about his home country: "Ah, back in my home country, the bushes grew so high that they covered the city walls!".  -  It's easier if you think of the USA as the HOME COUNTRY. To the northern border you have it protected by BUSHES, while to south you have it protected by CITY WALLS (or a 800 mile long fence).
column12: Buissons...bourg. Pensez à votre pays natal comme à un endroit dont vous connaissez tous les recoins, les moindres buissons de chaque bourg.  --

column11: Cocoon . . . silver . . . city walls.  -    -  Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.  -  Your home town is where you earned enough silver to enable you to break out of your giant cocoon (leave home) and explore outside the city walls.
column12: Cocon...fixer...bourg. Notre village natal est ce bourg où se trouve fixé le cocon qui toujours sait nous accueillir en cas de difficulté.  --

column11: Hometown . . . sound.  -    -  People´s voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they´re from by how they talk.  -  My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds echoes and echoes.
column12: Village natal...son. Le village natal résonne de sons familiers.   --

column11: Halo . . . city walls.  -    -  The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls.  -  A good son stays within the city walls so he can care for his parents…　RTK2:　ロウ　新郎　しんろう(bridegroom)…　Pure Group:　廊1852.
column12: Halo...saint...bourg. Voyez ce jeune qui parcourt le bourg en faisant l'important. Il se prend pour un saint mais tout le monde sait bien que c'est le fils Machin, rien de plus.  --

column11: Cave . . . son.  -    -  Your son plays in the corridor pretending he´s exploring a cave.  -  (ロウ) I think of the corridor found in the cave that Yoda made Luke Skywalker walk through as part of his Jedi training in Empire Strikes Back. It was in this corridor that Luke met Darth Vadar, cut off his head and found himself behind Darth Vadar´s mask. An early little hint that Luke was Darth Vadar´s son.
column12: Appentis...fils. Dans le couloir de la maison, le fils s'est inventé un monde imaginaire dans lequel il se réfugie, et il y a construit un petit appentis un peu mystérieux.   --  Chapitre quarante-neuf   La drague et le porte-manteaux   CONTINUONS d'épuiser le peu de kanjis restants, à l'aide de deux outils : une drague et un porte-manteaux.

column6: shield, shield-shaped object; currency sign for Dutch guilder
column11: Dragging . . . ten eyes.  -    -  You paint 10 huge eyes on your shield to scare the enemy, but consequently your shield is so big and heavy that you have to drag it.  -  From Wikipedia: "If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment." Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.
column12: Drague...dix yeux. Un soldat utilise son bouclier en guise de drague pour nettoyer la rivière après une inondation. Regardez bien son bouclier boueux : pas moins de dix rivets, formant autant d'yeux, sont employés pour y fixer la poignée.  --

column11: Line . . . shield.  -    -  This is mostly used in the word 循環, "circulation" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.  -  A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think "Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers" from Star Wars).
column12: Aller...boucliers. Il s'agit de suivre l'ordre établi. Le suiveur suit la ligne indiquée coûte que coûte, et se protège du bouclier pour faire face à toute éventualité.  --

column11: Water . . . drag . . . rag. Back in frame 1127 we indicated that this latter radical would come up once again, as it does in this and the following two frames.  -    -  Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies.  -  The radical faction is almost eliminated, sir. They´re living in the sewers dressed in rags and dragging their supplies.
column12: Eau...drague...Tintin...torchon. Nous annoncions en 1139 la réapparition de ce dernier composant. Voyez (idée à garder pour les deux kanjis suivants) cette faction comme un groupe suffisamment impulsif pour faire de nouvelles recrues. Tintin est ici en train de « draguer » près de l'eau pour faire de nouvelles recrues. Ses cheveux sont coiffés vers l'arrière, et il porte aussi une sorte de torchon, les deux derniers traits.  --  * Donnez à l'élément de droite le sens d'impulsion.

column11: Part of body . . . drag . . . rag.  -    -  The vein is the part of the body most lusted after by the flesh hungry zombies (drag & rag - see revenantkioku frame 1855).  -  To get blood drawn from a vein you present the part of the body to the nurse, and they drag an alcohol swab (rag) across the vein.
column12: Partie du corps...impulsion. La partie du corps où l'on prend le pouls – impulsion est un vaisseau sanguin.   --  La partie du corps où le globe terrestre prend son pouls – impulsion est une chaîne de montagne.

column11: Blood . . . drag . . . rag.  -    -  Masses of zombies, splattered with blood. (any zombie movie).  -  When the masses are hurt, say in a natural disaster like an earthquake, they can be seen everywhere dragging their bloody rags.
column12: Sang...deux gouttes...Tintin...torchon. Dès qu’apparaissent deux gouttes de sang quelque part, Tintin surgit de la foule, son torchon en main, pour soigner le blessé. Ici, ses cheveux ne sont plus coiffés en arrière.  --

column11: Drag . . . cornstalk . . . belt . . . road.  -    -  Picture a crude drag-sled - in this case, made from cornstalks that have been belted together - filled with parcels, that the postman drags along behind him down the road along his delivery route.  -  (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That´s because you´ve never looked at how they´re actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.
column12: Route...drague...tige de maïs...serviette. Si vous trouvez complexe l’écriture de ce kanji, je vous rassure : le caractère d’origine est 逓, cf. 2181. Voyons-y une sorte de relais postal. Sur la route, à intervalles réguliers, une sorte de drague collecte les paquets à distribuer jusqu'au prochain relais. On la repère à une tige de maïs plantée sur le bord du chemin, alors qu'une serviette permet aux postillons de s'éponger la sueur. Un peu tarabiscoté, mais tout y est !  --

column11: The kanji connoting rank or class shows us a new element on the left: the familiar primitive for staples with an additional stroke cutting through the vertical stroke. It is easiest in these cases to make a primitive related to what we already know. Hence, we call it a staple gun. To the right, missile.  -    -  This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.  -  1st grade: staple gun, 9th grade: missiles.
column12: Le kanji portant la connotation de rang nous montre à gauche une dé­formation de l’agrafe, nantie d’un trait supplémentaire. Le plus simple est alors de relier ce nouveau composant à ce qui nous est déjà connu : appelons Le kanji portant la connotation de rang nous montre à gauche une déformation de l'agrafe, avec un trait supplémentaire. Le plus simple est alors de relier ce nouveau composant à ce que nous connaissons déjà appelons-le une agrafeuse. Cette agrafeuse servira à fixer la médaille de son grade à qui parviendra à frapper fort lors d'un concours d'art martial. Une fois n'est pas coutume. donnons ici la prononciation, unique, de ce kanji, bien connue en France notamment par les judokas :ダン.  --

column11: Metal . . . grade.  -    -  As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles.  -  Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.
column12: Métal...grade. Le métal  forgé est d’un grade supérieur au métal coulé.  --

column6: queen, empress, sovereign; (simp. for 後) behind, rear, after
column11: Drag . . . one . . . mouth.  -    -  The empress is cruel. Normally she´ll violently pull her servants by the ear when they´ve failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he´s never been seen again.  -  The F word often comes out of the mouth of the empress.
column12: Revoyons ici un phénomène déjà vu (page 299). Il faut 2035 voir dans l'élément supérieur une déformation du composant fesses, à dire vrai des fesses entrouvertes. Dessous se trouve la bouche, et l'ensemble est à l'origine un des idéogrammes de l'anus, dont on retient le sens d'arrière. Puis le sens a évolué vers après, puis impératrice, sans doute callipyge.  --

column11: -    -  Big consternation in the court! A little bit of soil in the garden touched the empress' face and left a blemish there. Courtiers fainted left and right...  -  The empress gets a soil mask at the spa to treat a blemish.
column12: Terre...après - anus. Je présente ici ce kanji qui n’appartient pas à la liste des kanjis d’usage courant, mais permet de préciser le double sens du kanji précédent. Vous le lirez sans doute écrit sur votre tube de dentifrice.  --

column11: Cocoon . . . clothes hanger.  -    -  After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep.  -  You open your closet and find strange, glowing cocoons sitting on your clothes hangers... definitely a phantasm!
column12: Cocon...porte manteaux. Ce superbe veston en soie que l’on voit pendu au porte-manteaux n’est qu’une chimère: à minuit, il redeviendra un simple tas de cocons de soie.  --

column6: take charge of, control, manage; officer
column11: Clothes hanger . . . one . . . mouth.  -    -  The porn director has one big mouth. "Don´t bother putting your clothes on a hanger, just get started.".  -  The director sticks a clothes hanger in each actor´s mouth and hangs them from the ceiling until he needs them.
column12: Porte-manteaux...une...bouche - voix. Le directeur est la voix que l'on écoute, et il possède le privilège d'accrocher son manteau au porte-manteaux. Le kanji  vu ci-dessus est une sorte d'image miroir de 司.   --

column11: This honorific form of call on (Frame 534) is made up of: person . . . director.  -    -  That person, being the director, is someone you need to pay your respects to.  -  If Mr. T gets a role in a film, he doesnt pay respects to the director, the director pays respects to Mr. T.
column12: Dans chacune des affaires auxquelles il s’intéresse, Tintin va directement rendre une visite de courtoisie au directeur.   --

column11: The key word, parts of speech, refers to nouns, verbs, adjective, adverbs, and so on. The elements: words . . . directors.  -    -  Parts of speech act as word directors, giving it meaning and indicating its correct placement and usage in grammar.  -  The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, "More verbs! Less adjectives!" and such all the time.
column12: Le kanji désignant les verbes, noms, adjectifs, etc. s’écrit mots...directeur.   --

column11: Eat . . . director. The sense is of rearing of animals.  -    -  When you DOMESTICATE an animal, you are the DIRECTOR of it´s life and what it EATS.  -  After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead.
column12: Nourriture...directeur. Pour la vache, le vacher qui la domestique est une sorte de directeur de la nourriture.   --

column11: Mouth . . . scrapbook . . . director.  -    -  The lawyer called all the heirs into a meeting. Everybody else received cars, property, and the like. When it got to be my turn the lawyer informed me I would be receiving a scrapbook. My mouth dropped open. A scrapbook?! No Ferrari, no mansion, ...scrapbook?! Turns out the scrapbook was of my great uncle's company, and I had been named the new director of the multi-million dollar business. My mouth literally hit the scrapbook when I learned I'd be director.  -  My mouth hung open when I found out I was the heir to not only my father's scrapbooks, but he also left me as director of the company.
column12: Le sort de l’héritier, et le nombre de bouches qu’il pourra donc nourrir, est dicté - dirigé par ce que le défunt aura inscrit dans le cahier qui lui sert de testament.  --

column11: After the drop and the glass canopy, we come to a combination of three strokes that we met only once before, in the character for mama (frame 105). The pictographic meaning we gave it there has no etymological relationship to this character, but use it if it helps.  -    -  I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.  -  Cinnabar (丹) colored boat, the extra drop signifying that the paint hasn´t dried yet. The stick represents the oars.
column12: Après la goutte et la cloche de verre, nous retrouvons un élément employé une seule fois auparavant, en 104. La signification pictographique que nous donnions alors n’a pas de relation avec ce kanji, mais vous pouvez l’utiliser si bon vous semble. Sinon, imaginez la proue (la goutte), puis la carène (la cloche), le capitaine, son banc et son gouvernail dans les trois derniers traits.  --

column11: The type of boat connoted by this key word is a large oceangoing liner. The important thing here is to work with the elements boat and dove to make an image distinct from that of the former frame. Don't count on size alone to distinguish the boat from the liner.  -    -  The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.  -  A liner is to boat as an emperor (#261) is to a king (#255), or a chief (#967) is to a person (#951): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former.
column12: Bateau...blanc. Mettez le « Paquet² » pour retenir ce kanji.  --  ² Allusion aux croisières Paquet et à l'étymologie du mot paquebot.

column11: Boat . . . whirlwind.  -    -  To navigate a "boat" through a "whirlwind" takes a skilled navigator.  -  In Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, you can navigate your boat by summoning whirlwinds.
column12: Bateau...poltergeist. Imaginez un bateau dont un poltergeist a pris les commandes, pour imaginer les difficultés de la navigation.  --

column11: Boat . . . missile.  -    -  Carrier?! This means "general" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public.  -  In general, carrier boats have missiles.
column12: Bateau...frapper fort. Le global est lié au transport maritime depuis les origines, en ce qu'il permet de convoyer quantité de biens en tous points du globe. Ainsi, le bateau frappe fort à bien des égards.  --

column11: Carrier . . . dish.  -    -  What do you call a "CARRIER" of DISHes? A TRAY.  -  Imagine a restaurant set in Disney´s Fantasia or maybe in Harry Potter´s university, where dishes are magically landing and taking off of a carrier tray.
column12: Une assiette globale, contenant le repas de toute la tablée, est un plateau.   --

column11: Fingers . . . carrier.  -    -  Fingers take food from the sushi carrier, a conveyor belt.  -  During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).
column12: Doigt...global. Avec le progrès, le transposteur peut maintenant charger un camion entier (globalement) en pressant du doigt sur le bouton du transpalette.  --

column11: Boat . . . gully.  -    -  A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.  -  Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase "shape up or ship out!" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He´s riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).
column12: Bateau...plomb. Pour bien tenir la mer, un bon navire doit avoir une quille bien lourde, bien plombée.   --

column11: Boat . . . oversee.  -    -  The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port.  -  A warship is a boat that oversees the seas. Think of it as the patroller of the ocean.
column12: Un navire de guerre est un bateau qui surveille, rien d’autre !  --

column11: Boat . . . courts.  -    -  Rowboats are a classic way to court (go on a date with) someone...  -  Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... Yo ho, Yo ho....
column12: Bateau...tribunaux. Si l’on se fait « tailler des vestes » dans les tribunaux, on s’y fait aussi parfois « mener en barque ».   --

column11: The only thing that distinguishes this from the claw is the addition of the elbow, made by doubling up the third stroke and adding a fourth.  -    -  何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow.  -  Vegetarian vultures are fighting for a melon, each trying to elbow its way to it with claws.
column12: La seule chose permettant de distinguer le melon de la serre est l’addition du coude, tracé en trois traits au milieu. On pourra s’imaginer ramassant des melons pour relier ces deux éléments.  --

column11: Bow . . . melon.  -    -  When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are.  -  Joan of Arc ("arc" also means "bow" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field.
column12: Deux éléments montrant des arcs de cercle sont ici représentés : l’arc et le melon.   --

column11: Child . . . melon.  -    -  An orphan will never know the joys on sucking on his mother´s melons........  -  Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.
column12: Sans parents pour prendre soin de lui, ce pauvre enfant est contraint de se nourrir de melons chapardés au marché.  --  Chapitre cinquante Diversité  COMME annoncé au chapitre 27, nous quittons une fois de plus les sentiers battus, afin de rassembler quelques éléments laissés de côté car ils font exception aux règles et schémas créés.

column11: Though it's a good thing that the primitive for cocoon has been radically abbreviated from this, its full form as a kanji, the story it holds is a charming one. The silkworm (insect) eats the leaves of the mulberry bush (the flowers), digests them and transforms them into thread with which it spins about itself, in mystic wisdom, its own coffin (the hood). The dividing line that separates the two elements helps the picture of the little worm cutting itself off from contact with the outside world, but as a character stroke, it is a clear exception.  -    -  This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.  -  The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.
column12: Bien que ce soit une excellente chose que le composant cocon ait été radicalement abrégé de cette forme, l'histoire est vraiment charmante : l'insecte mange les feuilles du mûrier (les végétaux), les digère et en fabrique un fil à partir duquel il crée le cocon (le bonnet entourant l'ensemble). La ligne séparant les deux éléments aide à imaginer le petit ver se coupant entièrement du monde, mais en tant que trait de kanji, c'est clairement une exception. L'ordre des deux éléments intérieurs est aisément retenu car du fil et de l'insecte, c'est le fil que l'on voit en premier.  --

column11: Poised over the dish here is a pair of animal horns that are attached to a pair of animal legs by a single horizontal stroke.  -    -  The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.  -  The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).
column12: Ce qui est posé sur cette assiette est une paire de cornes liées à une paire de pattes par un simple trait : un bien maigre bénéfice.   --

column11: The element for day on the left is logical enough. Next to it we see staples being held in mouth (one stroke is doubled up), indicating working in one's hobby or handicrafts at home on one's spare time. The small box at the top right is facing backwards, or more properly "inside out." Finally, we have the crotch at the bottom.  -    -  Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video´s of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.  -  Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it "hobby". REF: shrimp (#2689), haze (#2779).
column12: L’élément jour vient naturellement. Ensuite, nous voyons des agrafes tenues en bouche par un individu bricolant durant son temps libre. La petite boîte est placée face à lui et au-dessous, sa main droite à la recherche d’autres agrafes sans doute.  --

column11: At the top we have the arrowhead whose vertical line joins it to the rice field (or brains) below it. Beneath it, the compass; and to the right, the taskmaster.  -    -  Instead of being glued to one specialty (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none.  -  Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.
column12: Imaginons le remplissage d’une rizière, qui d’une certaine manière revient à y étaler de l’eau. La flèchette indique par où faire couler l’eau dans la rizière, et dans les deux directions. Ensuite vient le chef de corvée, qui ordonne l’exécution des travaux d’étalement.   --

column11: This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for not yet into which a pair of animal horns has been inserted.  -    -  You horny bastard, don´t come, at least not yet!  -  Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not "poking through". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.
column12: Ce kanji étrange mais commun est formé du kanji pas encore au sein duquel sont insérées les cornes.   --

column11: The spirit in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one's personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other. Its elements are: reclining . . . floor . . . fishhook . . . sheaf. Do not confuse with spirits (Frame 1930).  -    -  You´re reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you´ve been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.  -  Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.
column12: Ce kanji définit les humeurs changeantes des êtres, ainsi les « humeurs de l’éther », les gaz, par opposition aux liquides et solides. Il s’écrit couché...sol...hameçon.. gerbe. Imaginez les humeurs d’un pêcheur à la ligne.  --

column11: Think of this character as a sibling of that for spirit. Simply replace sheaves with drops of water on the left in order to get vapor.  -    -  Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.  -  Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.
column12: On verra ici un jumeau du précédent. En remplaçant les gerbes par de l’eau, on obtient la vapeur.   --

column6: fly; go quickly; dart; high; Kangxi radical 183
column11: The two large hooks have little propellers (the two drops on each hook) attached to them for flying. Beneath is the measuring box, which serves as the body of this flying contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it.  -    -  Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?  -  Two hummingbirds flying into a measuring box serving as a bird feeder…　RTK2:　ヒ　飛行機　ひこうき(airplane).
column12: Les deux grands crochets ont deux petits propulseurs (les deux gouttes, répétées sur chacun des crochets) pour avancer. Puis se trouve la boîte-mesure, formant le corps de cette machine volante. L’ordre des traits est capricieux, faites-y donc très attention.  --

column11: The technique for sinking used in this kanji is unique. Rather than the biblical image of tying a millstone about the victim's neck, here we see a crown tied about one leg before the unfortunate party is tossed into the water.  -    -  (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn´t have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend´s schemes.  -  This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling "Eureka! Eureka!" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.
column12: La technique employée pour noyer est unique. Plutôt qu’attacher une pier­re au cou de la victime, on accroche ici une couronne à une jambe, avant de pousser le malheureux dans l’eau.   --

column11: Ten . . . rakes . . . woman.  -    -  Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.  -  (I´m really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. "Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!".
column12: Aiguille...rateaux...femme. La bonne épouse sait bien mener les travaux d’aiguille et soigne consciencieusement le jardin minéral décorant le devant de la maison d’un coup de râteau chaque fois que nécessaire.  --

column11: Let this key word connote the decline and fall of the Roman Empire. It shows a fellow in a top hat and scarf, trying hard to look happy by putting a walking stick in his mouth sideways to twist his face into a grotesque but semi permanent smile.  -    -  If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.  -  If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven´t seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!
column12: Imaginons ce kanji comme un symbole du déclin de l’empire romain. Vous devrez vous remémorer 438, afin de voir le bâton de marche placé dans la bouche de notre Romain déclinant.   --

column6: heart, from bottom of one's heart
column11: Between the top hat and the scarf you will see the character for in which is truncated at the bottom so as not to interfere with the scarf. You can think of this character forming as a pair with that of the former frame: there the in (the walking stick in the mouth) was set on its side; here it is set upright.  -    -  The guy from pathetic (#401) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.  -  Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!
column12: Chapeau haut de forme...dedans (coupé)...écharpe. Le bâton s'enfonce ici au plus profond de la bouche du clochard vu en 438 qui devient avaleur de sabre et en fait disparaître la partie du bas.  --

column6: face; surface; plane; side, dimension; Kangxi radical 176
column11: Imagine a mask over your head with eyes peeping out from all over the head, a hundred in all (the element for eye displacing the fifth stroke of that for hundred).  -    -  If you´re wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are.  -  When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head.
column12: Imaginons une face ayant des yeux placés en une centaine d'endroits sur la tête. Notez la distorsion du tracé : ici l'œil vertical remplace le trait horizontal de cent. Ce kanji signifie surface autant que face.  --

column6: leather, animal hides; Kangxi radical 177; hexagram ䷰
column11: After the flowers at the top (painted on the leather for decoration), we see the element for car with the middle stroke left out. Think of the seats having been taken out so that they can be reupholstered with this decorated leather.  -    -  I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order).  -  You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.
column12: Après les végétaux en haut, employés pour tanner le cuir, vient la voiture dont deux sièges ont disparu. On les a retirés pour les remettre à neuf avec ce cuir ; remettre à neuf, réforme sont des sens associés.  --

column11: Leather . . . change.  -    -  Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot.  -  Leather is often changed into shoes.
column12: L’industrie de la chaussure est une industrie de transformation du cuir.   --

column6: rule by might rather than right
column11: Old West . . . leather . . . moon.  -    -  In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us.  -  In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon.
column12: Ouest...cuir - réforme...mois. Avec une bonne « réforme », en un mois l’hégémonie de l’Ouest pourrait cesser.  --

column11: The samurai at the top is familiar enough. The combination beneath, which looks like a flag with a line running through it, is not. Try to devise some way to take note of it, and pay attention to the writing.  -    -  Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.  -  When an enemy´s flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.
column12: Le vieux professeur du haut est familier. Les « fesses fendues » du dessous le sont moins, mais commencez-vous à percevoir l’étrange voix du vieux professeur ?  --  Si cela ne vous convient pas ou si vous voulez en savoir plus, sachez que le caractère original est , dans lequel la partie supérieure représente un instrument de musique.

column11: The complex of strokes in this kanji is unusual and difficult, because of the fourth stroke, which is rare (see frames 33 and 34). The mouth and tool are already familiar.  -    -  Picture of a person facing you. 口 is the head. His right arm is raised (your left), to give you something from a tray 一. His legs ハ are below the tray. 呉れる、くれる, to give: 伯父がこの時計を呉れました, "My uncle gave me this watch." Following -て form of another verb, means "to do the favor of": 窓を開けて呉れませんか, "Won't you open the window [do the favor of opening/kindly open the window]?" Usu. written in hiragana.  -  I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!
column12: La bouche associée au trait tordu qui suit peut représenter la bouche tordue que fait le petit garçon demandant quelque chose à sa maman : « dis, tu me donnes un bonbon ? » Puis vient l’établi, pour signifier que ce kanji est en fait un outil de communication.  --

column11: Woman . . . give.  -    -  A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family.  -  Typical male fantasy of recreation: women "giving it up".
column12: Femme...tu me donnes. Nous pouvons imaginer une geisha, 芸者[げいしゃ] , divertissant ses spectateurs par ses chants et danses.  --

column11: Words . . . give.  -    -  You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.  -  It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says "You don´t have to give me anything for my birthday." Trust me, your sweetie wants something, something shiny, and if you disappoint, you will suffer.
column12: Mots...tu me donnes. La parole est d’argent, mais le silence est d’or.  --

column11: -    -  "If water completely covers the floor, you will need a helping hand to clean it up."  -  "Water is completely covering your floor, and no matter how fast you mop it up it makes no difference. In desperation you cry, ""Can someone give me a helping hand?""."
column12: Ce kanji qui ne fait pas partie de la liste standard nous aidera à retenir les deux caractères suivants, autrement peu aisés. Il met en scène un enfant dont les bras ont disparu en train de s'enfoncer dans l'eau. D'ailleurs, ses pieds touchent déjà le fond - plancher, et il hurle, attendant un improbable secours.  --

column11: The sense of passive acceptance or reception of information is contained in this key word. The form is based on the middle portion of the preceding character, with three additional strokes, best thought of as the kanji for three.  -    -  To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.  -  To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick´s).
column12: La situation s’est ici améliorée. Une corde (les trois traits autour de l’enfant) a été nouée, et le fond de l’eau a disparu, prouvant que l’enfant a déjà été hissé d’une bonne hauteur: une âme bienfaisante a accepté de secourir le malheureux.  --

column11: The flower at the top and the floor with the oven fire beneath are familiar. The problem is what comes in between. It is formed by the character for complete, whose vertical stroke doubles up as the first stroke of water.  -    -  Think of a picture of someone steaming vegetables. On top you see the flowers of cauliflower or something else that is being steamed. Underneath, the pan is completely full of water. Below the pan is a floor - that's the hotplate - and under that the oven fire. Caution: don't confuse with boil (#1257), or the steam radical in spirit (#1885).  -  When you want to steam some flowers/vegetation you don't cover them completely with water, rather you have just a little at the floor of the saucepan and then heat.
column12: Mais les sauveteurs avaient en réalité de bien sombres desseins, que l’on voit ici s’accomplir : le pauvre enfant a été installé dans un grand chaudron rempli d’eau et de plantes, alors qu'on est en train de l'étuver.  --

column11: This is the character from which the element for shovel derives. Within it comes the element for snare, with the sparkler surrounding it.  -    -  Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.  -  (thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I´ll show them. I´ll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.
column12: Ce coffre est fait d'une simple poubelle et on le ferme à l'aide d'un clou tordu. Dedans, une sarbacane (le tube), et c'est tout !  --

column11: The poles this key word refers to are the extremities of the earth or the terminals of an electric field. The elements are: tree . . . snare . . . mouth . . . crotch . . . floor.  -    -  Can simplify this using decay (#1243). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.  -  (modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using decay (#1243). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for decay (#1243)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.
column12: Il faut imaginer le point extrême d’un arbre, que nous cherchons à atteindre pour y cueillir un fruit. Le clou tordu nous permet, avec la main droite, tout en gardant les deux pieds sur le sol, d'attraper et de mettre en bouche le fruit convoité. Imaginez-vous bien sous l'arbre, la main droite tenant la branche du côté extérieur, pour bien retenir où tracer la bouche et la main droite.  --  Chapitre cinquante et un Des animaux   LE dernier groupe de kanjis que nous traiterons dans ce livre est centré autour d'éléments reliés au monde animal. Commençons par quelques éléments décrivant les parties du corps des animaux.

column11: If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a box-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the halberd, a convenient combination for the tusk protruding from the mouth of an animal.  -  * Since this kanji has 4 strokes, you would expect that as a primitive it would also have 4 - but in fact it has 5 in the following two frames (the second stroke between divided into 2 strokes) and reverts to 4 again in frame 2056.  -  The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant´s eye. The final stroke is the tusk.  -  He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.
column12: En jouant avec les formes de ce kanji, vous y découvrirez une forme semblable à une boîte, puis les deux derniers traits de la lance. Une heureuse combinaison pour définir le kanji croc. Selon les dictionnaires, ce kanji comporte 4 ou 5 traits, les second et troisième traits pouvant être tracés d‘une traite.  --

column11: Flowers . . . tusk.  -    -  Buds while they´re still small tend to be tusk-shaped.  -  Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant´s tusks keep budding into flowers.
column12: Les bourgeons forment des sortes de crocs qui deviendront végétaux, fleurs ou feuilles.   --

column6: wrong, evil, depraved, vicious, perverse, heterodox
column11: Tusk . . . city walls.  -    -  The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.  -  As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.
column12: Crocs...bourg. Les crocs dans le bourg évoqueront des loups sournois, faisant le mal dans le but de nuire.  --  Dépravé ou pervers rendent aussi le sens de ce kanji.

column11: Tusk . . . an old turkey.  -    -  Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk. This mnemonic is meant to join RtK´s keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used "elegant" here, which is not confounded so easily with graceful (#721), and accurately represents the character´s meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha´s Kanji Learner´s Dictionary).  -  To not confuse it with grace (#606) or graceful (#721), think of the phrase "Goodness gracious." Like: "Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!".
column12: C'est avec raffinement que nos crocs s'attaquent à la dinde de Noël. Comme ce caractère est une sorte de contraire de « vulgaire » (cf. 1054), imaginez un souper de Noël dans un magnifique palais, avec une table rassemblant de raffinés convives.  --

column11: Animal tracks . . . shakuhachi.  -    -  Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I´d purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They´re so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he´s playing.  -  An interpretive dance of some kind where somebody follows animal tracks, a shakuhachi providing the soundtrack, suggesting the tracker's thoughts and intentions.
column12: Rigole...30,303 cm. Cette rigole représente le cheminement intellectuel de celui qui justifie ses vues, afin que nous nous trouvions sur la même longueur d'onde, de 30,303 cm (début du domaine des ondes radio).  --

column6: to take turns; a turn, a time; to repeat
column10: Tour de rôle, charnière, couple d'oiseaux
column11: This key word has been chosen for its overlay of several meanings similar to those of the kanji: a turn of duty, a round, a number, and so forth. Its composite elements: animal tracks . . . rice field.  -  * As a primitive element, we choose the image of a pair of dice which it is your turn to throw.  -  The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.  -  They take turns alternating between wheat and rice in this field…　　RTK2:　バン　電話番号　でんわばんごう(telephone number).
column12: Il s'agit ici de monter la garde à tour de rôle. À chaque tour de garde, le vigile doit suivre la rigole qui contourne la rizière, son chemin de ronde.   --  Les sens secondaires sont charnière et couple d'oiseaux, mais nous emploierons parfois le sésame de courte paille, utilisée pour déterminer qui devra monter la garde.

column11: The hearing referred to in this character relates to trials in the courts. The elements: house . . . dice.  -    -  At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. ("I can´t believe what I´m hearing!" you say).  -  In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.
column12: Maison...courte paille. Ces auditions ont lieu au tribunal, et vous pouvez imaginer les jurés écoutant les témoins défilant à tour de rôle. Puis le verdict, décidé à la courte paille.   --

column11: Dice . . . feathers.  -    -  It's your turn to flip the chicken wings on the grill.  -  Don't play dice with birds. When you're not looking, they'll flip the dice with their feathers.
column12: Couple d'oiseaux, charnière...plumes. En voltigeant, l'oiseau fait bouger ses plumes, comme une charnière.  --

column11: Flowers . . . water . . . dice.  -    -  This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans´ location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.  -  In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.
column12: Végétaux...eau...tour. On percevra le clan comme l'ensemble du personnel protégeant le domaine. Il s'agit de monter la garde pour entretenir les plantes et les ruisseaux du clan.  --

column11: This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur. If you reverse your hand and put its palm down, you will have the side on which fur grows.  -    -  I´ve heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That´s not hair, that´s fur!  -  Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don´t like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.
column12: Ce kanji ne fait que retourner le dernier trait du kanji main pour créer la pilosité. Et en retournant votre main, vous verrez la face où croît la pilosité.  --

column11: Christmas tree . . . fur.  -    -  The amount of "fur" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn´t look all that good.  -  Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.
column12: Par l'action du temps qui fonctionne comme une sorte de bêche, notre pilosité décroît à mesure que les jours passent.  --

column6: tail, extremity; end, stern; 6th lunar mansion, determinative star μ¹ Scorpii (Xamidimura)
column11: Flag . . . fur.  -    -  A dog waves its furry tail like a flag.  -  A FLAG of FUR is a TAIL.
column12: Le kanji s’écrivant fesses...pilosité décrit la partie arrière de diverses choses, et en particulier celle des animaux.  --

column11: House . . . lock of hair.  -    -  This kanji is, of course, pronounced "taku", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn´t want to visit.  -  Home is where the hair is.
column12: C’est avec un soin tout particulier que nous retirons les touffes d’herbe qui poussent dans cette maison, car c’est notre domicile.   --

column11: Words . . . lock of hair.  -    -  When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don´t keep their word).  -  In "The Lord of the Rings", Galadriel consigned a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words.
column12: Mots...(é)touffe(és).    --

column11: This character rightly belongs to the previous lesson, but we held it until now because of the final element, the tail feathers. After the drop at the outset, the next three strokes are completely novel and should be given special attention.  -    -  In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: "So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?" "Only if you (ユ) do" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS.  -  Do me from behind, says the bird, as she shakes her tailfeathers.
column12: Après la goutte du début, les trois traits suivants sont entièrement nouveaux, mais peuvent être interprétés comme de lointains cousins du kanji vu en 756.  --

column11: Person . . . do.  -    -  A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood.  -  It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is, says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock.
column12: Associé à faire nous vient immédiatement contrefaire. Tintin ici est en train de faire quelque chose. Sans doute s'est-il embarqué dans une entreprise périlleuse de contrefaçon.  --

column6: long; length; excel in; leader; Kangxi radical 168
column11: In line with the story of the preceding frame, the hair that needs the hairpin is long.  -  * The primitive of this kanji has two more shapes in addition to that of the kanji itself. Above its relative primitive, it is abbreviated form will mean hair. Further abbreviated,  it will mean the long, mangy mane of an animal.  -  The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.  -  The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here´s my story: The girl´s hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.
column12: Gardant à l’esprit la forme précédente, le cheveu pour lequel la pince à cheveux est nécessaire est long.   --  * Deux formes supplémentaires existent en composant. La première sera obtenue par suppression du pénultième trait,  comme il en fut pour fixé : le sens sera alors cheveu. La seconde est obtenue en supprimant toute la partie inférieure, et représente alors la longue crinière d'un animal :

column6: stretch, extend, expand; sheet; 26th lunar mansion, determinative star υ¹ Hydrae
column11: Bow . . . long.  -    -  The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened.  -  Legolas recieves spam telling him that his can lengthen his "bow"...he smirks...he know´s it´s already long enough.
column12: Arc...long. Le jeu consiste ici à allonger encore plus un arc déjà long.   --

column11: Towel . . . long.  -    -  In ancient China books were rolled-up scrolls of paper. So notebooks were nothing more than long towels.  -  Students, for this class, your notebook will be a towel. Make sure it´s extra long though, we´ll have a lot of writing.
column12: Longue serviette. Pensez, comme nous l’avons déjà remarqué, que les écrits anciens étaient faits sur rouleaux, que l’on pourrait représenter par une longue serviette.   --

column11: Flesh . . . long.  -    -  Taking Viagra let´s your blood vessels dilate...resulting in a body part getting long.  -  Staying out in the dark moonlit sky for a long time, your pupils dilate.
column12: Chair longue. À voir après un bon repas.  --

column11: Hair . . . shape . . . friend.  -    -  Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends.  -  Friends influence the length and shape of each other´s hair.
column12: Ami des formes longues. Les Japonais portent aujourd’hui le cheveu court, mais il en fut autrement par le passé et dans l’ancienne Chine.  --

column11: Flag . . . salad . . . hairpin.  -    -  Unfold flag, take out the salad, pin the flag down with hairpins and have a picnic.  -  You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine unfolding it to open up the bounty you´ve fixed up for yourself.
column12: Drapeau...salade...pince à cheveux. Trois objets susceptibles de déve­loppement sont ici montrés : le drapeau que l’on déploie, la salade qui croît et, pourquoi pas, la pince à cheveux que l’on déplie. Le sens concerne aussi bien le développement économique que le « déploiement » d’objets pour les montrer à la vue de tout le monde.  --

column11: Soil . . . two mouths . . . hairpin. Hint: see spit (Frame 162). The key word carries the wide range of meanings readily associated with it: error, loss, absence, and so on.  -    -  I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. "Soil" is not drawn in its stroke order.  -  This kanji means miss as in "miss a (dearly departed) person", not as in "miss a target".　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths.
column12: Terre...deux bouches...pince à cheveux. Le deuil débute au moment où un être cher retourne en terre. De chaque côté se trouvent les bouches des amis venus se recueillir, et on dépose aussi en terre une pince à cheveux, bijou du défunt.   --  Chapitre cinquante-deux Petits animaux   CONTINUONS la série des animaux, en nous tournant cette fois vers les petits animaux. La chouette, l'oiseau, le pigeon, la poule, le corbeau sans lequel Tôkyô ne serait plus Tôkyô, la grue sans laquelle le Japon ne serait plus le Japon. Puis un singe savant, un chamois, un condor, un blaireau, un lapin, et pour finir un éléphant phénoménal.

column11: Owl . . . fruit.  -    -  The nest atop of a tree contains the fruit of the owl: its offspring.  -  The wise old OWL makes her nest out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it´s less work: no running back & forth to get food!
column12: Le nid préféré de la chouette est un bon grenier, plein de fruits.  --

column6: (same as 單) single, individual, only; lone
column11: Owl . . . brain . . . needle. The sense is "not complex."  -    -  Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine.  -  An owl´s brain is ten times smarter than other simple minded birds…　RTK2:　タン　簡単　かんたん(simple).
column12: Chouette...cerveau...aiguille. Voyez ici un contraire de « complexe », puis remarquez que l’ordre des traits n’est pas celui auquel vous étiez préparé à la lecture des éléments. Pour information, 單 est la forme ancienne de ce kanji.   --

column11: Simple . . . fiesta.  -    -  George W. Bush´s plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA.  -  So there´s this fiesta in downtown Compton. It´s a simple party, but someone invited people from the wrong gangs and the simple fiesta turns into an all-out turf war.
column12: Simple...hallebarde. On dit que la quatrième guerre mondiale se mènerait avec des pierres. Ce kanji est plus optimiste, qui propose des hallebardes, le plus simple moyen d'en finir avec l'ennemi.  --

column11: Altar . . . simple.  -    -  Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE.  -  Simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928) is very good at Zen, which isn´t surprising since she doesn´t think much. She has this bad habit of meditating perched on the main temple altar, which infuriates the Zen buddhists. When they get up to her and tell her rudely to step down the altar, she just smiles and teases them : "Not very zen are you ?". Who would have thought simple-minded blond girl would teach the Zen buddhists a lesson !
column12: Autel...simple. Un autel zen est le plus simple qui soit : une pierre, de la mousse.  --

column6: (variant of 彈) a pellet, bullet, shot, shell
column10: Boulet, rebond, phénomène vibratoire, phénomène sonore
column11: Bow . . . simple.  -    -  Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I´m switching to something simpler--using a bullet.  -  The bow was a weapon for simple times, but nowadays it has been replaced by bullets.
column12: Arc...simple. Ce boulet est probablement la chose la plus simple qu'on puisse lancer à l'aide d'un arc. Parvenu à sa cible, il subit un rebond, et par association la notion de phénomène vibratoire ou sonore, est aussi comprise dans le sens du kanji.  --

column11: Tree . . . owl . . . woman.  -    -  The tree in Japan that represents both wisdom (the owl) and femininity (the woman). This is a sakura (さくら), or cherry tree.  -  I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It´s really my favorite picture , just don´t tell her that.
column12: Arbre...chouette...femmes. Ne donnant pas de fruit, le cerisier du Japon est cependant classé dans la catégorie des « arbres-chouettes », peut-être parce qu'il permet chaque année à tout le monde de se retrouver sous les fleurs pour le hanami 花見 ; les femmes viennent aussi. La forme ancienne est 櫻, qui peut-être montre deux coquilles boucles d'oreilles ; sans doute les boucles d'oreilles qu'on arbore à la saison des cerises.   --

column11: Owl . . . rice field . . . one . . . mouth . . . chihuahua.  -    -  The owl looks for its prey in the rice field.
