column12: Lors de l'écrouissage, les fibres du métal s'orientent, et le kanji ne dit rien d'autre.  --

column11: Water . . . vulture . . . porter.  -    -  The vulture is on top of the porter and appears to be commiting a lewd act, so I throw water over the pair of them.  -  Claw marks across the porters back from engaging in lewd acts in the shower. He is tipped well for carrying the lady´s bags to her room.
column12: Lubrique et lubrifier ont même origine, et le « commerce de l'eau » au Japon concerne les relations tarifées. Liquide et débauche semblent donc liés, en Europe comme en Asie. Tout commence sous le prétexte de prendre un verre mais bientôt apparaît le souteneur - porteur surveillant les vautours qui encerclent le client.  --  Chapitre vingt Premiers animaux   SAUVAGES OU DOMESTIQUÉS, les animaux jouent un rôle considérable au sein des kanjis, comme ils interviennent en français dans de nombreux proverbes. Une véritable arche de Noé se cache dans les pages suivantes : nous y rencontrerons un scorpion, un serpent, un insecte, une tortue, une truie, une vache, un cheval, un mouton, une dinde, et pour finir un animal mythologique tout droit venu de l'ancienne Grèce : Pégase.

column6: must not, do not; without, never
column11: First take the primitive meaning of this character: knot. Think of it as the piglet minus its body (the horizontal stroke), that is, the curly tail that looks like a knot. As an exception, we will use the homonym to remember the abstract key word, not.  -    -  This kanji is NOT a piglett.  -  The butcher is standing over the piglet. "This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!".
column12: Pas, comme dans « ne marchez pas ! ». Cet élément est le dessin d'une banderole flottant au vent, employée jadis pour marquer une interdiction d'avancer : ne marchez pas ! La banderole flottant au vent est formée de plusieurs morceaux parallèles, qui sont dessinés dans ce caractère. Au sens de pas ou négation, nous ajouterons donc faisceau de lignes parallèles de formes diverses.  --

column11: Soil . . . turkey.  -    -  After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we piled high all the turkey corpses atop the soil of the farmyard.  -  During the Turkey Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don´t recall that it actually happens every single year), turkeys are killed en masse, and their bodies are piled high. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of dirt is piled high right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.
column12: Les squelettes d'oiseaux et autres animaux retrouvés dans les terrains sédimentaires nous permettent de comprendre l'histoire de notre planète.  --

column11: Tree . . . turkey.  -    -  Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.  -  Sweeter than Shiit~ake? Turkeys gobble Shiitake mushrooms椎茸 off the sweet oak tree. 　http://www.flickr.com/photos/tinyhare/13963627/.
column12: Le castanopis est une fagacée dont le bois en décomposition sert de substrat de culture des champignons nommés shiitake [ 椎茸 ] . Les sens secondaires sont frapper, maillet et colonne vertébrale. Imaginons une culture de shiitake que nous forçons au « fumier de dinde ». Nul ne sait si ça marche, si ce n'est pour retenir le kanji.  --

column11: Metal . . . harden.  -    -  You weld metal in the knowledge that it will harden again.  -  By welding metal and then subjecting it to refrigeration, it will become very hard by the process known as annealing.
column12: Un métal solide demeurera intraitable face aux plans d'évasion de qui est emprisonné ou confiné.  --

column11: Mouth . . . cause.  -    -  You can´t breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your mouth to find the cause. "Oh, I see the cause of your windpipe blockage. There´s a St Bernard penned up in there!".  -  Imagine a group of windpipes chatting: “That mouth is the cause of all my problems, you know, always breathing in germs, etc.”.
column12: Bouche...cause. La gorge, le pharynx, est bien une partie essentielle de la bouche.  --

column11: Flowers . . . heart.  -    -  My favorite are heart shaped candles that smell like sweet flowers. The trick is to find one with a thick wick, they give off the most flower scent (but burn the quickest).  -  Giving a girl flowers is like lighting the wick to her heart.
column12: Végétaux...cœur. Ce kanji se rapporte à diverses parties centrales ou essentielles, allant de la fleur à l'agrafe.  --

column11: Flesh . . . idea.  -    -  Cowardice is when you are not willing to sacrifice your flesh for your ideas.   -  Cowardice is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your flesh is a good idea.
column12: La chair sent une idée passer mais rien ne se produit. La timidité confine-t-elle au manque de motivation ?  --

column11: Second . . . heart.  -    -  A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own.  -  Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).
column12: À chaque fois que le distributeur de glace appelle « au suivant », l'égoïste se présente à nouveau, toujours au cœur du groupe, pour recevoir à nouveau sa part.  --

column11: State of mind . . . tool.  -    -  My mind found the tool disquieting.  -  Its disquieting to my state of mind when tools are arranged messily.
column12: L'état d'esprit est l'outil de l'appréhension. En comparaison, l'action nous la fait oublier. Notez que les barres latérales de l'outil rejoignent ici celle de l'établi. Cette déformation montre que certains tracés anciens peuvent parfois subsister.  --

column11: The sense of this key word is to pull or jerk, as in opening a door or making "ramen" noodles. Its elements: fingers . . . vase.  -    -  He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies...  -  He yanked his finger out of the vase upon discovering it had a venus fly trap in it.
column12: La victime d'un enlèvement veut rester debout, mais de son doigt, le ravisseur la tire vers ailleurs. Ce caractère signifie aussi écraser et, pour des raisons phonétiques, le latin.  --

column6: do, play or fiddle with; alley
column11: Jewel . . . two hands.  -    -  The king used both hands to tinker with himself in his spare time.  -  Picture the king holding a large pan in his two hands and tinkering with it, wishing he could lead the itinerant life of a tinker. As a rhyme: The king, he uses his two hands, To tinker with his pots and pans . . .
column12: Ce kanji signifie jouer autant que toucher. Il montre une boule tenue par les deux mains, évoquant un bébé à la découverte du monde.  --

column11: If, at some aboriginal level, Toys Я Us, then the archetypal ball must have been there at the beginning, before evolving into beach balls, ping-pong balls, rugby balls, and marbles.  -    -  The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen.  -  And so it was, the ball marked the beginning of all the toys that were to come.
column12: Des boules associées à l'origine, l'Origine du Monde peut-être, suggèrent une façon de jouer ou d'apprécier le temps qui passe.  --

column6: stem of flower, branch of plant
column11: This character refers originally to a deciduous, rough tree that grows on mountain plains. From this it gets the secondary sense of rugged or spiny. Its primitive elements: tree . . . grow late.  -    -  I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it grows late, trees change shape and become spiny creatures! Lesson: don´t go out at night.  -  With the safety of darkness as it grows late, spiny little insects start crawling out of the trees.
column12: Le pédoncule est la première partie de la feuille à se lignifier, formant ainsi du bois dur. D'autres sens sont essentiel et obstruction, notamment par durcissement des tissus vivants, comme si l'on assistait à une sorte de lignification des vaisseaux.  --

column11: There is a lot of money to be made of one's songs are "popular." This is depicted here as a stream of clams spewing out of the mouth of someone performing a pop song.  -    -  The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day.  -  A new way for sales to use their mouths to make alot of money.
column12: Bouche...coquille. Mettre en route le juke box, l'appareil à karaoké, télécharger une chanson sur un serveur ou payer les violons du bal : tout change et rien ne change, il faut toujours mettre une pièce pour écouter la chanson et c'est écrit dans ce kanji.  --

column11: Flesh . . . missile.  -    -  Where´s my flesh missile? Between my thighs, naturally...  -  My thigh is the part of the body that my missile smacks against.
column12: Partie du corps la plus forte, la cuisse permet à l'individu de frapper fort.  --

column11: Vulture . . . tree.  -    -  You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture grabs hold of a tree, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn´t shake him loose.  -  A common meaning for this kanji is ´DICE´. --- Ever wonder what vultures do up in the trees? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always grabbing the dice away from each other.
column12: Ce vautour en haut de cet arbre est en pleine partie de dés. Il les prend et les colorie avec les seules peintures qu'il connaisse, et qu'il extrait des entrailles des charognes. L'image est peu ragoûtante mais elle sert notre objectif de retenir les sens secondaires : prendre et colorier.  --

column11: Sun . . . love.  -    -  The sun´s love is equivocal: it warms yet burns us.  -  曖昧。 On a sunny day, a guy professes his love to a girl he admires. But she gives him the common equivocal response, "Let´s just be friends.".
column12: Ce kanji aimant le jour définit les choses floues et ambiguës.  --

column11: Bound up . . . elbow. Think of this key word in the sense of something that has been nabbed or cought.  -    -  Your elbow is bound up so that your biceps will stay flexed.  -  My elbow was bound up in a cast, making it impossible to keep it flexed.
column12: Emprisonner est un second sens de ce kanji.  représente les propriétés personnelles, et emprisonner revient à tout emballer, comme si l'on déformait l'espace afin que rien ne puisse plus jamais sortir, comme le fait la gravitation. Les notions de pente, pliage ou gradient découlent alors naturellement de cette idée.  --

column11: Ice . . . pedestal.  -    -  The secrets of metallurgy and smithing: get your redhot metal and bang it against the pedestal as an anvil. Then cool it quickly with lots of ice.  -  An ICE PEDESTAL is useless in METALLURGY since it will just melt.
column12: La fonderie est l'opération par laquelle le métal liquide versé dans un moule placé sur un piédestal se fige en un solide dur comme la glace.  --

column11: Mountain . . . cliff . . . ivy.  -    -  Standing at the base of the bluffs I announce, "I´m going to climb those ivy-covered cliffs, and then the mountain on top of them." My friends don´t believe me, "He bluffs!" they say.  -  The ivy-covered cliff we saw on the horizon (#157) ... the sheer beauty of the mountain that overlooks these bluffs is enough to make you want to swim for shore yourself!
column12: La montagne est suivie de la falaise, au bas de laquelle nous voyons le sable, plage née de la pierre rongée par la mer, et le tout nous donne le kanji falaise.  --

column6: legendary ruler, last of the Five Emperors
column12: Nids...pieds écartés. Les noms des plantes s'écrivent souvent en katakanas mais connaître leur écriture en kanjis est parfois utile. Ce cousin asiatique du liseron, calystegia japonica, est une plante grimpante qui pousse si vite que nous l'imaginerons grimper jusqu'au sommet de l'arbre, là où se trouvent les nids, ses deux pieds écartés allant de branche en branche.   --  Nous lui associerons la notion de court instant, eu égard à la rapidité de croissance de cette plante et à la brièveté de sa floraison.

column11: Slave . . . crotch . . . flesh.  -    -  When the sex slave misbehaves, threaten to sell his body parts starting with his kidney.  -  If you have a weak KIDNEY, you´ll become a SLAVE to your CROTCH´s need to pee. Oh well, it´s just a weakness of the FLESH.
column12: Notre esclave serviteur a mal aux reins, il y place la main droite pour contenir la douleur.  --

column11: Dig into your flesh and pull out a lymph gland. Now give it a squeeze and watch the spring of lymph spout out of it.  -    -  A body part that acts like a spring for hormones is a gland.  -  When adrenaline glands release hormones, the body springs into action.
column12: Partie du corps...source. Il y a une grande logique dans le tracé des kanjis définissant les organes. Imaginez des animalcules dans notre corps, ouvrant de grandes vannes, faisant que des sources abondantes se mettent soudain à sécréter l'insuline ou la bile, comme dans le film de Woody Allen.  --

column11: The spinal column has sprouted out of the flesh of your back into an umbrella that you always have with you, rain or shine. The pair of 2s on each side are the "ribs" of the umbrella. Take care to keep your image of the key word distinct from that for spine (Frame 24).  -    -  Look, says the teacher in biology class. "The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together".  -  A pictograph of a spinal column. The umbrella representing the shoulder blades, the I Ching as the shoulder muscles and the part of the body as the spine itself.
column12: Ce kanji est une variation de 背  que nous connaissons.  --

column11: If you think of the ten as a little "cross" sitting atop the root of a house where we are used to seeing the "chimney" (drop), then you have the image of a chapel. (This combination will appear once more in this book: Frame 1465.) To complete the picture for uprising, add: child . . . muscles.  -    -   An uprising of anger occured when it was found out the chapel had been molesting children and using the power of the Catholic Church to keep it secret.  -  An erection can shoot like a needle from its crown and has the power to make a child.
column12: La turgescence est commune aux règnes végétal et animal. Le débourrement soudain des bourgeons au printemps, durs et gonflés comme des muscles bandés, en est une manifestation, représentée ici par la couronne surmontée de la terre qui donne la vie, l'enfant du dessous.  --

column11: Tree . . . going.  -    -  Girders are support beams that are nowadays mostly made out of steel. But in the ancient houses that are placed at the boulevard the girders will be made out of wood.  -  When the wooden girders start to snap, the workmen shout "Run! Let´s go!".
column12: Pour fabriquer des colonnes nous plantons des arbres en ligne, à intervalle régulier. Ces arbres évoquent alors la succession des chiffres alignés en colonne dans un nombre, et cela nous donne la notion d'ordre de grandeur.  --

column11: The key word refers to kanji that are written in full, squared form, as opposed to cursive writing which is more flowing andabbreviates some of the strokes. Here block letters are pictured as tidy rows of trees that are all the same size and can be read easily by all, whatever calligraphic skills they possess.  -    -  Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.  -  all the hiragana are in "block letters" on wooden blocks, like children's toys.
column12: Alors que l'écriture manuscrite est difficile à déchiffrer, l'écriture en caractères d'imprimerie, espacés régulièrement comme des arbres dans une pépinière, est faite de sorte que tous puissent la lire.  --

column11: Flowers . . . committee.  -    -  Oh, the committee´s in for a surprise: I put some nightshades into their drinks. They´ll be numb for sure, probably worse.  -  The keyword numb makes no sense. I choose 萎む（しぼむ）"to fade away". A girl lies in a wheat field at the same time every day. A photo is taken every day showing this scene and a time lapse video shows the wheat growing through the year until the wheat is tall and the top sprouts to look like its flowers. At this point, the girl can no longer be seen in the photos and she fades away.
column12: Un comité de végétaux fraîchement fauchés est l'image que nous obtenons pour atrophier.  --

column11: Words . . . astray.  -    -  Words meant to lead you astray are those of a riddle.  -  I led Socrates astray with my riddle. He quit philosophizing and thought only about the riddle.
column12: Résoudre une énigme, c'est savoir ressortir d'un endroit où l'on s'est égaré parmi les mots.  --

column11: Person . . . spine.  -    -  Mr. T don´t take a partner, especially one with no spine. "I pity da foo got no spine", he says.  -  As a PARTNER, I want a PERSON with a strong SPINE.
column12: Tintin est associé à notre petite machine itérative vue en 24, pour nous donner l'idée de partenaire ou associé.  --

column11: Person . . . branch.  -    -  Mr T is dancing and singing and all that, but he´s doing it on a branch. All that talent and can still still keep his balance? That´s a real performing artist.  -  (note: this is the ´ki´ from kabuki).//The performing artist is a person doing Kabuki theater and dancing around with a branch in his hand.
column12: Tintin offre un support à une multitude de techniques au cours de ses aventures.  --

column11: Person . . . build.  -    -  Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, "I´m healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!".  -  Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy? I asked. "Simple, foo," he answered, "you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!".
column12: Voici la version japonaise de notre « esprit sain dans un corps 1061 santé sain », qui nous montre Tintin en bonne santé car il est bien construit.   --

column11: Person . . . soil . . . compass . . . taskmaster. You may, of course, take the character for emulate from the previous frame as the basis for this kanji, adding to it only the element for soil.  -    -  Mr T. showed his arrogance as he poured dirt on those foos who tried to emulate him.  -  Your arrogance has soiled your attempt to emulate such an honorable effort.
column12: Alors que tout semble perdu dans le naufrage du bateau, en 552, Tintin est parvenu sur la terre ferme avec la boussole, et il s'en montre fier comme tout, et même un brin arrogant.   --

column11: Fingers . . . assembly line . . . soil.  -    -  I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position).  -  I sprained in my finger doing a complicated mudra while sitting in meditation.
column12: Aux sens de foulure ou entorse s'ajoute celui de refréner l'enthousiasme. On verra ici deux Tintins accroupis, , en train de masser du doigt leur cheville foulée.  --

column11: Flesh . . . virtuous.  -    -  The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it.  -  Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh.
column12: Nous mettons le couvert pour nous préparer à faire du bien au corps. Ce kanji définit les ustensiles, bols et tablettes employés dans les repas traditionnels au Japon.  --

column11: Flower . . . shredder.  -    -  You cover over the shredder with flowers when the FBI comes a-knockin´.  -  The taskmaster arranges flowers to cover over the rags she makes us clean with.
column12: Un monceau de feuilles découpées en morceaux est employé pour recouvrir les nouvelles pousses de l'année.  --

column11: Flag . . . baseball team.  -    -  The baseball team stick flags in their buttocks and wave them at the opposing team to put them off.  -  I wonder if this story will be flagged for saying i give her buttocks a score of 9.
column12: Selon le contexte, ce kanji signifie indifféremment fesses, cul, popotin, arrière-train ou derrière de diverses choses.  --

column11: Cloak . . . reside.  -    -  Something is residing in the hem of your cloak. Maybe you should consider cleaning it? キョ コ すそ cuff; hem; foot of mountain.  -  If you reside in the slums, you start off as a small child with a very large cloak. As you grow it gets hemmed. The rich kids just get new cloaks.
column12: L'ourlet est l'endroit où le vêtement commence d'exister. Pareillement, le pied de la montagne est bordé par l'ourlet que forme la lisière de la forêt.  --

column11: Wooden leg . . . religion. The key word refers to a trail of footprints or tracks left behind.  -    -  A trail of destruction is left by pirates and religion invaders.  -  The followers of the crazy satanic religion are following the footprints of the escaped human sacrifices who fled from the altar.
column12: Pied...religion. Toutes ces traces de pieds autour du temple sont autant d'indices de la popularité de cette vieille religion.  --

column11: The key word refers to a very familiar way of referring to oneself, typically used by men. Its component elements: person . . . St. Bernard . . . eel.  -    -  I did it all by myself! Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He´s brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy.  -  As astridtops mentions, this is "Ore". In Japanese r = l, so could write it "Ole". So picture a bullfight with person as the matador and a dachshund replacing the bull. The crowd keep shouting "Ole! (Ore)".
column12: Il s'agit d'un pronom personnel de la première personne, à usage masculin, qui convoie l'idée de mâle protecteur ou un peu arrogant. La partie de droite apporte bien cette idée, car elle contient celle de re- couvrir. Très prosaïquement, elle nous montre Tintin sous la forme d'un homme de grande taille en train de « couvrir » un singe doté d'une longue queue.  --

column11: The top primitive of this character is actually an old form of broom. The remaining elements are: crown . . . fruit.  -    -  People who read the glossary are mutually exclusive (exclude the top line of mutually (#757) ) from those who eat crowned fruit イ はりねずみ same kind 語彙.  -  I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for "mutual difficulties" but found nothing. I guess we´re going to have to mutually end our relationship.
column12: La partie supérieure qui ressemble au kanji mutuel 互 (834) sans le premier trait représente un groin de cochon. Ensuite viennent la couronne et le fruit. Le sens figuré d'assemblage de divers éléments du même genre est plus usité. Les multiples épines du hérisson sont les diverses choses que nous avons à rassembler et ranger.  --  Chapitre trente Des outils   QUELQUES outils nous attendent : la hache, le peigne fin, la scie, le lave-pont, le balai, le râteau, le tamis et la poubelle. En route !

column11: Car . . . ax.  -    -  A "chop shop" is a place where stolen cars are taken, and parts chopped off with an axe, to be sold.  -  I wanted a convertible so I chopped off the top of my car with an axe.
column12: La décapitation est cette peine qui attendait jadis les condamnés conduits en voiture vers l'homme à la hache.  --

Balai...eau d'irrigation...sabre. Nous disposons ici de tout le nécessaire pour écorcer un morceau de bois. Le balai et l'eau pour nettoyer l'espace de travail, puis à droite le sabre pour arracher l'écorce. Notez que la partie de gauche est identique à celle de droite du caractère précédent.  --

column11: -    -  In an attempt to free them from being slaves to their desires, the samurai stands behind the altar likening a clear mind to a sieve that lets only the purest thoughts through.  -  Careful: retainer (#848). Think of slave in the virtual sense (a slave to your passions). The samurai is standing on the altar lecturing about goodwill (see goodwill (#1097)). He notices the boredom of most of the crowd. However some audience members are attentive about the message of goodwill. The samurai views his sermon as a sieve of character: those of good character pass through and see the merit; those of poor character - slaves to their passions - are blocked from understanding.
column12: Le vieux professeur juché sur l'autel regarde les esclaves armés de tamis. Revoyez 1186 款 et soyez vigilant car plusieurs sésames font intervenir des esclaves.  --

column11: The radiant, effulgent splendor of he sun makes it king of all the planets and other stars. Just to be sure you don't take this too abstractly, picture the sun seated on a throne, flourishing its scepter this way and that.  -    -  The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.  -  [+katsuo] This is the Sun King. Sayeth Wikipedia: "The Sun King (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the Sun, so too should France and the court revolve around [the king] ("http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France). And just like the sun, he was quite effulgent and actually emitted sunlight.
column12: Par l'effet de son rayonnement, le soleil est le roi qui garantit la vigueur à tout être vivant.  --

column11: The key word in this frame refers to the underworld, the world of the dead. By way of the classic Greek association, it is also used for the "dwarf planet" Pluto. Since no one knows precisely when this part of the cosmos was finished, we may imagine it as the crowning deed of day six of the creation.  -    -  The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.  -  In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that´s Japan.
column12: Pluton, dieu des enfers ici identifiable par sa couronne, est représenté par ce kanji qui signifie conjointement l'obscurité. Foin de controverse, qu'il soit ou non une planète, Pluton évolue à quelque six millliards de kilomètres du Soleil.  --

column11: Quarter . . . hand. Be careful to keep this key word distinct from the primitive element of the same meaning we met back in Frame 741.  -    -  1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.  -  Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch.
column12: Le poing fermé occupe environ un quart de la surface de la main ouverte.   --

column11: A nosegay of flowers make a nice gift, but if those flowers are poison oak, they can amount to bullying. Be sure to emphasize the word can when you repeat this little phrase to yourself.  -    -  How many flowers can I stuff in your nostrils? Well I´m just gonna have to go and see. Bullying at its worst!  -  Flowers, you ask if they can feel pain, do you? ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ They sure -can-!! ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^ ^stomp^!!
column12: La « possibilité d'un végétal » est l'image que nous donne le kanji portant l'idée de tyranniser ou bizuter. C'est le risque encouru par la victime de mauvais traitements : être attaqué au point de ne plus pouvoir rien faire que végéter. Il signifie aussi cruel, pénible et s'irriter.  --

column6: near, close by, next to, towards, against; to wait; to lean on
column11: Fingers . . . elbow . . . dart.  -    -  In the busy pub, one of the dart players shoved his dart into my elbow by accident when it nearly slipped out of his fingers.  -  Your fingers slip when someone´s elbow shoves you, causing you to drop the dart you were about to throw. But as you can see, their elbow is very small, so you decide they´re too weak to shove back.
column12: On pousse ici quelqu'un par derrière. On le pousse du doigt et du coude et il part comme une flèche.  --

column11: Fingers . . . flood . . . evening.  -    -  The old lady said that there was a flood imminent, because her fingers hurt in the evening.  -  The Dutch boy put his finger in the dam holding back imminent danger from flood waters until evening.
column12: Ce kanji n'est guère employé que dans le mot 挨拶 », « salutations ». Notre doigt fait quelques mouvements dans l'air du soir lors de notre discours de premier contact.  --

column11: Water . . . weak. Do not confuse the meaning of this key word with "Drown" (Frame 763), which is closer to "founder."  -    -  Weak people placed in the water start drowning. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim!  -  Weak swimmers drowning in the water.
column12: Le terme peut valoir au sens propre et au figuré. Au vu des éléments on perçoit une personne plus faible que le milieu aquatique qui l'entoure et qui va l'emporter.  --

column11: Bow . . . reclining . . . little.  -    -  The bow dug more and more into the small of his back as he reclined on it. Will someone please tell the idiot to get up?  -  If I recline back, I can pull my bow open a little more and more.
column12: Il s'agit d'aller de l'avant, ce qui est montré par le petit couché auquel est confié un arc grâce auquel il saura développer les meilleures aptitudes pour son avenir.  --

column11: Two mouths . . . ceiling . . . snare . . . head.  -    -  Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw.  -  Left side is crocodile primative. crocodile´s head´s most prominent feature is his jaw.
column12: Deux bouches...plafond...clou tordu...tête. Les deux bouches représenteront les narines ; puis vient le plafond représentant le palais, partie supérieure de la bouche, et le clou tordu, qui est la mandibule, l'os du menton. La tête ensuite nous précise dans quelle région du corps nous nous trouvons.  --

column11: Bamboo . . . puppet.  -    -  Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!).  -  I´ve always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do.
column12: Ces baguettes employées notamment pour manger sont les terminaisons en bambou de notre personne. Attention : Certains dictionnaires ou imprimantes ajoutent une goutte à la langue qui s'agite, ce qui donne un semblant de composant blanc dont le point serait déplacé. Le nombre de traits peut donc varier d'une unité.  --

column11: Scissors . . . head.  -    -  Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the "scissors of the head.". 頰  -  The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. Now the Joker isn´t right in the head.
column12: De chaque côté de la tête se trouve une joue. Les deux joues enserrent notre visage, comme une paire de ciseaux, et c'est l'idée que transmet le premier élément.  --

column11: Fingers . . . leg.  -    -  I felt a finger on my leg as someone tried to nab my wallet.  -  Fingers nabs Davy Jone´s wooden leg: Argh! Bring me back me leg, ya scurvy dog!
column12: On fait des mains et des pieds pour saisir l'objet. Le sens est général.  --

column11: Metal . . . jawbone.  -    -  A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a metal pot in the shape of a skull.  -  A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.
column12: Des morceaux de mâchoire dans du métal nous donnent une casserole, avec un ragoût en train de mijoter : objet de métal qui excite déjà nos mâchoires.  --

column6: mound; abundant, ample, numerous; Kangxi radical 170
column11: Maestro . . . needle.  -    -  The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.  -  Note to those who have not got this far in the book: This is the full kanji for the Pinnacle primitive (i.e. only the left-hand version of the primitive). The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is city walls (#2180). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer´s afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.
column12: Au sommet du monticule nous trouvons une croix, près de laquelle le maestro est venu se réfugier. Ce kanji est assez rarement employé mais il est extrêmement fréquent sous sa forme réduite.   --  * En composant, ce kanji est abrégé sous la forme , qui se rapportera au « plus haut point » d'un village, une colline où se célèbrent des événements festifs. Elle apparaîtra toujours à gauche, et notre sésame sera un tertre.

column11: Pinnacle . . . little . . . sun . . . little. Note that the form of the first element for little given here is the simpler form that has become standard in general-use characters (See Frame 110). For the time being, until typesetting fonts have made the adjustment, the official approved drawing has the drops similar to the bottom little.  -    -  There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun.  -  Man those little chinks can do anything! They were the first to build rockets, and by launching one off the top of the highest pinnacle in China, one little chink was the first to ride above the sun, and see all the little chinks below!
column12: Sur notre tertre se trouve une construction dans laquelle nous laissons passer un tout petit morceau d'un morceau de rayon de soleil par un interstice. Le soleil ne passe donc que par un tout petit trou et nous formons ainsi le kanji interstice.  --

column11: The key word should be taken to mean minute, detailed, or nuanced. Its primitive elements are: thread . . . doth.  -    -  THREAD, DOTH. fine THREADS DOTH make fine cloth. Think of a Shakespearean character stating this to someone else. Picture fine threads on one side of the picture and an aftershot of a fine cloth.  -  fine: If the thread doth fit through the eye of the needle, it is fine thread indeed.
column12: Les éléments fil et commettre évoquent un travail de dentelle, quelque chose de très minutieux.  --

column11: Thread . . . determine.  -    -  Even though his costume is coming apart at the seams as he chases the bad guys, Spiderman is still determined to catch them.  -  Spiderman´s costume has come apart at the seams and here he is, mending it in his house, determined to make it stronger than before.
column12: Dans un tissu déchiré, bientôt seul le fil existe encore, est encore fixé, mais la trame et la chaîne ont cessé d'exister. Ce kanji défini nombre de choses qui sont détruites par cassure ou déchirure.  --

column11: Two cocoons . . . field . . . fiesta.  -    -  People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs.  -  How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?
column12: Combien de rizières est un travail de dénombrement fait par les autorités de la province. Pensez bien à remplacer 人 par 田 dans 幾.  --

column11: Grandchild . . . road.  -    -  My parents aren´t at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends!  -  He wasn´t at all modest when telling us about his grandchildren - "They´re all on the road to success" he said.
column12: Route...petits-enfants. Cette personne réservée, tout à fait effacée, n'ose même pas accompagner ses petits-enfants jusqu'à la route lors des adieux.  --

column11: Water . . . courage.  -    -  The courageous man who went into the water to save a drowning victim couldn´t be seen, except by the air that bubbled up.  -  Bubble up the WATER and see who has the COURAGE to jump into it.
column12: La vigueur de l'eau la fait bouillonner.  --

column11: Water . . . fingerprint.  -    -  It´s a widespread belief that they cannot find fingerprints on a body that has been deposited in the water.  -  It´s a widespread belief that water takes away fingerprints.
column12: Quand elle déferle, l'eau est comme atteinte d'un gonflement pathologique donnant une idée de l'intensité des dégâts possibles.   --

column11: -    -  You know how missing childrens´ pictures often appear on milk cartons? Well here we have a missing hare. His concerned family is having his picture printed on the backs of receipts and even on stamps. So far, however, there has been no SIGN OF THE HARE.  -  rabbit ears.
column12: Le lièvre a mangé le tronc du saule ; il n'en reste que les branches.  --

column11: Jewel . . . detain.  -    -  “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.  -  The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck).
column12: Les rubis permettent de fixer et retenir les axes dans les mécanismes d'horlogerie, et ce sont aussi des bijoux.  --

column11: This kanji is used for thick, low-grade saké made from various kinds of grains. Its primitives are: whisky bottle . . . glue.  -    -  While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.  -  This thick, illicitly-made beverage is actually just whiskey mixed with glue!
column12: C'est un alcool qu'il faut servir avec mesure.  --

column11: -    -  You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil´s brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!  -  Even the most revered person must still abide by the rules of the road -- no exceptions are granted to anyone.
column12: Se conformer, c'est bien en un sens révérer le chemin tracé et qu'il faudra suivre.  --

column11: Flowers . . . oversee.  -    -  Indigo flowers have to be overseen because they are often picked for their beauty.  -  Traditionally, 青 blue (#1534) could be used to describe blue OR green. However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑. This kanji is the "blue" counterpart of green (#1371). Story: The overseer, master of the slaves, wore a cloak dyed with indigo, and flowers in his hair.
column12: L'indigo est une plante dont on extrait des colorants employés pour les estampes ; il faut surveiller attentivement l'opération d'extraction pour obtenir les couleurs désirées.  --

column11: Flowers . . . gone . . . dish.  -    -  The lid of this dish is gone! Now the whole room smells of the flowers that were used in the cooking.  -  When the magician lifted the LID, the flowers were gone from the dish.
column12: Végétaux...partir...assiette. Le bon couvercle est fait d'une tresse de végétaux, il protège le contenu de l'assiette et n'en laisse partir que la vapeur lors de la cuisson.  --

column11: Food . . . ear. The sense of the key word here is that of bait or feed for animals.  -    -  Food made of ears is animal feed.  -  Do you know Mike Tayson favorite feed? Ears! He eats ears!
column12: Nourriture mangée par les animaux, cette pâtée contient des bas-morceaux, ici de l'oreille. La partie de gauche apparaît parfois sous une forme non simplifiée : .  --

column11: Mochi is the glutinous rice the Japanese pound into cakes. Its primitives are: food . . . puzzle.  -    -  Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, mochi!" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come.  -  Mochi ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good.
column12: Le motchi est un aliment fabriqué en repliant une énorme masse de riz dans un grand mortier taillé dans un tronc alors qu'un comparse frappe simultanément à l'aide d'un gigantesque maillet.  --

column11: This kanji refers to one of the seven classical stones of China. Its elements: jewel . . . top hat . . . villain . . . belt . . . elbow.  -    -  Michael Jackson is the king of pop, wearing his crystal rhinestone glove (see detach (#1492).  -  In my story for detatch detach (#1492), the left side primitive was junkie. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the junkie is getting a fix of crystal meth: the jewel in the crown of today´s drugs.
column12: Ce bijou se trouve près des traces d'oiseaux au pied de la poubelle pleine et couverte. Les oiseaux consomment des pierres qui demeurent dans le gésier ; les pierres précieuses, les plus dures, y restent pour longtemps et servent à séparer les aliments que l'oiseau consomme.  --

column11: The sense of the key word is of something refreshing and invigorating. It is made up of the St. Bernard and a pair of sheaves on each side.  -    -  The St Bernard is bracing itself for an operation requiring four stitches.  -  St. Bernard dog had a refreshing bracing bath and now is shaking all the water out of his fur. The drops are thrown in all direction and that's why the have an x shape in the pictogram.
column12: Cette grande personne revigorée respire la forme et le bien-être. Nous le voyons à sa façon de brasser l'air en gesticulant de tous ses membres.  --

column11: The key word here is the noun meaning "a breif moment." Its elements: sheaf . . . tree . . . saber.  -    -  The kendo artist takes a brief moment to practice his skills: he throws sheafs over the tree and tries to cut them with his saber when they come down again.  -  Wtf moment? This kanji means temple. Wooden x-men statues with sabres guard the entrance to the Professor Xavier temple. Might help if you imagine the two x-men as Wolverine and Sabretooth.
column12: Certains temples au Japon sont périodiquement reconstruits. Le kanji montre les matériaux et outils nécessaires : une gerbe d'arbres et le sabre pour en débiter les troncs.  --

column11: -    -  The game characters from Worms sleep in their barracks at night.  -  Earthworm jim sleeps in a barracks because he is a soldier... apparently.
column12: Soc...poubelle...hameçon. Ce kanji convoie l'idée de grand rassemblement, et notamment de place militaire. Quand une garnison s'installe, un des premiers soucis sera de creuser des fossés, avec le soc, et de prévoir où ranger les déchets et comment s'alimenter.   --

column11: Earthworm . . . head.  -    -  Ever chopped the head off an earthworm? Notice how it will grow back immediately! Beware the killer earthworms...  -  When someone in the barracks tells you to come immediately, you´ll lose your head for sure トン トツ にわか.に とん.と つまず.く とみ.に ぬかずく suddenly; immediately; in a hurry.
column12: Dès que la tête de garnison prend une décision, l'exécution est efficace, soudaine.  --

column6: piece of jade with hole in it
column11: The holed gem to which this kanji refers is a flat, circular object of about a foot in length, made of stone or glass and having a large hole in the middle. It's elements: ketchup . . . ball.  -    -  Even more valuable and perfect (完璧) than a holed gem is a delicious meatball (ball = たま = 玉) with ketchup. Yum!  -  It's a little known fact that ketchup is highly corrosive and is used to cut holes into gemstones so they can be put onto chains. This kanji shows a piece of Jade with a blob of ketchup on the top eating a hole through it.
column12: Ici dans le kanji mur le joyau se substitue à la terre en donnant un « joyau de mur » de jade, parfait, second sens du kanji.  --

column11: Of the many and widely different meanings of this kanji, we select the verbal meaning of clasp, which fits in well with its primitive elements: tenacious . . . hand.  -    -  When you clasp something you tenaciously 執 hold on to it with your hand 手, te. 真摯、しんし, sincerity, earnestness.  -  This kanji shows Santa Claus (refer to frame tenacious (#1506)) clasping the reins of his deers with his hands, holding onto dear life as he almost falls off his carriage.
column12: Régisseur...main. Notre régisseur dirige tout de sa main, et convoie ainsi l'idée de franc, dans tous les sens du terme.  --

column11: Skeleton . . . acorn.  -    -  The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen.  -  Hint: The remains of a chipmunk.
column12: Tout est bon dans le cochon ! De ce cadavre de cochon tout a déjà été retiré et il ne reste plus que les os.  --

column6: stop up, block, seal, cork; pass, frontier; fortress
column11: House . . . celery . . . animal legs . . . soil.  -    -  The A/C wasn´t making the house cold because the filters had been blocked up with dirt.  -  It was so cold (#1526), the pipes blocked up with ice. After removing the ice, we insulated them with soil.
column12: Alors que les maisons au Japon sont traditionnellement construites sur de simples plots, ici une masse de terre s'est infiltrée et parvient à remplir ou bloquer tout l'espace sous la maison et sa carcasse.  --

column11: Grow up . . . oyster.  -    -  As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.  -  This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.
column12: Grandir...huître. L'obligation imposée aux huîtres quand elles ont grandi est d'être entassées dans une bourriche d'huîtres puis embarquées. C'est ainsi que notre sésame sera une bourriche d'huîtres.  --

column11: Thread . . . blame.  -    -  Spidey´s exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle´s pages blame him for every problem out there.  -  [Geek alert] A lot of modern software is full of exploits which can be abused by hackers. I blame multi-threading.
column12: Fil...obligation. Quand on organise un exploit, le spectacle est préparé dans ses moindres détails et il n'y a pas de droit à l'erreur. Le fil doit donc être pris au sens symbolique le plus fort, et l'obligation de résultat est impérative.  --

column11: Whisky bottle . . . star.  -    -  On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”.  -  You´ll need an awakening after the whiskey bottle makes you see stars.
column12: Bouteille de whisky...étoile. Après s'être mis pompette, on finit la nuit à la belle étoile pour dégriser.  --

column11: Insect . . . walking legs . . . bushes.  -    -  A bee is an insect with a pointy (see summit (#1562)) stinger.  -  The insect that interrupted our tryst (#2417) was a bee!
column12: Cet insecte se meut avec précision, contrôlant parfaitement ses jambes qui marchent sur le buisson formé par la fleur qu'il butine.  --

column11: Person . . . cabbage.  -    -  People may consider themselves important but in the cosmic scheme of things, they are merely a trifle of no more worth than a cabbage.  -  To MR.T swallowing a whole CABBAGE is no more than a TRIFLE.
column12: Tintin...chou. Tintin mange à peine un peu de chou, nous dit-on, mais cela le mènera loin.  --

column11: Mouth . . . droop.  -    -  When some people are sleeping, their mouths droop open, and saliva drips out.  -  Saliva drools from a mouth that droops. つば.
column12: Bouche...pendre. Quand on « en bave », on ressent la salive  qui nous pend de la bouche, ce que nous voyons ici.  --

column11: Clock . . . shellfish.  -    -  Whatever you covet at the moment (now), can be bought with money. Well, _almost_ anything....  -  One begins one's life coveting money. One ends one's life coveting time -- those precious seconds ticking away on the clock. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).
column12: « Maintenant la monnaie » est le slogan que semble dicter le caractère portant les sens de dévorer et d'avidité.  --

column6: to twist or nip with the fingers
column11: This kanji does not refer to the tool but to the act of twisting. Its elements: fingers . . . wish.  -    -  Ever try WRENCHING a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you´ll WISH you had a wrench for WRENCHING to save your FINGERS.  -  I have an unfortunate habit of wrenching off other people’s fingers when I pull a wishbone with them.
column12: Ici notre doigt suit le désir d'un tiers. Ouille !  --

column11: State of mind . . . chestnut.  -    -  Shudder. If chestnut trees were sentient, shudder would be their state of mind as the tree shaker approaches. Note: Tree shakers are used commercially to harvest nuts and cider apples. A tree shaker makes a tree shudder causing all the ripe chestnuts to fall.  -  Data, chestnut: Some pranksters were throwing chestnuts at Data who was passing by. However, they started to shudder in fear when suddenly Data turned around and his eyes turned red in anger!
column12: Trembler de crainte de « prendre une châtaigne » sera notre état d'esprit.  --

column11: Gates . . . sound.  -    -  I like to think of a horror movie where the protagonists enter a graveyard when suddenly their flashlights go out and it becomes pitch dark, whereupon they hear the sound of the gate creaking shut behind them.  -  Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark.
column12: Il faut faire du bruit devant ce portail obscur pour que les occupants nous remarquent. Le kanji concerne aussi certaines activités illégales.  --

column11: Mouth . . . marquis.  -    -  I think of "clearing your throat". Some stuffy guy opens his mouth to clear his throat so the marquis can speak.  -  The Marquis de Sade was kinda gay. He used to mouth down a lot of deep-throat action.
column12: Ce kanji est synonyme de 咽 vu en 646. Il nous montre un marquis d'âge avancé dont le gosier commence à faiblir. Ce kanji est aussi un compteur des poissons.  --

column11: Spicy . . . bundle.  -    -  bitter, spicy, bundle: In a desperate attempt of creating a new drink, they decided to mix a bitter drink with a spicy one -- now bundled together for the same price of one! However, bitterness didn't go well with the spicy, as seen in the misshape to the left.  -  I'm rather bitter that someone stole my spice bundle.
column12: Les éléments 辛 et 束 nous dictent « un fagot de choses pimentées », et nous écrivons le kanji piment. Comme toujours le premier élément se gauchit un peu pour faire la place au second.  --

column11: Flesh . . . heavy.  -    -  A tumor is a useless body part that is nothing but heavy.  -  When flesh clumps together and gets heavy, it forms a tumor.
column12: Partie du corps...lourd. L'abcès se forme par un gonflement des chairs qui deviennent lourdes.  --

column11: Sickness . . . silver.  -    -  I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar.  -  I got sick and needed surgery, but the silver lining is that now I have these awesome scars I can show off!
column12: Une marque laissée par un mal forme une sorte d'image fixe qui survit à la maladie.  --

column11: Sickness . . . monkey . . . crotch.  -    -  The most horrific way to lose weight is from that devastating sickness that came from a monkey's crotch.  -  The poor monkey obviously had a sickness. He was scratching his crotch the whole time and when he started to lose weight heavily, the caretakers knew they couldn´t save him anymore.
column12: Quelqu'un mince à en être malade tient dans la main droite un mortier et un pilon pour préparer des potions amincissantes.  --

column11: Sickness . . . piggy bank.  -    -  His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank.  -  The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!
column12: Une petite contrariété nous ulcère. Ce kanji propose maladie...lumière solaire. L'ulcère donne une sensation de chaleur, comme le soleil s'il est perçu en excès.  --

column11: -    -  (Think rpg!) We were in dire need of healing. Our party was fighting the cavemen, but we didn't fare too well. It was more like a butcher's meeting than a fight... just as they were about to pierce my heart, luckily a priest came along and used his healing spell in the nick of time (#2433).  -  Note: meeting of butchers + heart are later combined into 愈 in the nick of time (#2433). Story: For healing to take place, you must catch the sickness in the nick of time.
column12: On entend parfois des témoignages parlant d'animaux visitant les patients dans des hôpitaux en guise de thérapie. C'est bien encourageant mais attention car c'est ici le rassemblement des bouchers qui met son cœur au service des malades ! On pourrait craindre le pire mais en tous cas, cela nous permet de retenir le kanji guérison.  --

column11: Woman . . . rapidly.  -    -  If you go through women rapidly you will be the object of envy.  -  Ah, puberty ... the girl that starts her journey towards womanhood the most rapidly will become the subject of envy from all her classmates.
column12: Femme...rapidement. Des relations matrimoniales conflictuelles sont parfois à l'origine de réactions rapides. Nous voyons ici encore que l'homme est bien rarement mis en scène dans les kanjis.  --

column11: It should not be hard to leep from the key word to the image of a woman who is jealous of the rock that another woman is sporting on the third finger of her left hand.  -    -  The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone.  -  Every woman wants a huge stone on her finger to make her friends jealous.
column12: « Ne jetez pas la pierre à la femme adultère, je suis derrière ... » nous chante Brassens. La pierre est ici déjà parvenue derrière la femme, Brassens arrive trop tard.  --

column11: -    -  "The SICKNESS called cancer works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more & more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you-- that's the tumor, the awful sign of cancer."  -  "You may have a mountain of goods, but cancer is a sickness that strikes the rich and poor with equal contempt."
column12: La multiplication désordonnée des cellules est le propre du cancer. Une « montagne de multitude » est jointe à la maladie pour transmettre cette idée.  --

column11: Eye . . . pup tent.  -    -  Open your eyes, it's obvious that not all of us can fit into that small puptent!  -  It´s obvious that the pup tent with a huge eye on the side belongs to the dark lord Sauron.
column12: Les meilleurs téléscopes sont ceux dont le miroir principal est le plus grand, afin de capter avec la meilleure netteté la clarté des étoiles. Les appareils photo de meilleure netteté sont aussi ceux dont les pixels sont assez grands ; démesurément grands ! C'est ainsi que d'un œil démesuré dérive naturellement le kanji net.   --  Chapitre quarante-quatre Formes et couleurs   COMPOSONS un tableau à partir de formes, couleurs, étincelles, et mosaïque. Les kanjis obtenus nous mèneront bien loin, allant jusqu'au chic parisien.

column11: Ball . . . plaid . . . ball.  -    -  Speckled is a pattern, like plaid, but with lots of little balls all over the place.  -  The sentences exchanged between the two kings got more and more heated, finally leading to a fight which left the whole area speckled with blood.
column12: Deux rois se disputent les motifs de leurs blasons respectifs, , mais de loin nous ne voyons que de simples taches. Revoyez 1329 au besoin.  --

column6: take in, absorb; act as deputy
column11: Fingers . . . ear . . . sparkler. Do not confuse with substitute (Frame 1080).  -    -  Now that I´m a responsible adult, I have to get my vicarious thrills from watching stupid people put sparklers up to their ears and burn their fingers.  -  I put my fingers in my ears to avoid going deaf while getting a vicarious thrill from watching kids light off sparklers and fireworks on Chinese New Year.
column12: Doigt...oreilles...étincelles. Le délégué obéit « au doigt et à l'œil » au patron qu'il écoute tout ouïe. Puis il « passe un coup de tube » aux exécutants pour leur transmettre les ordres.  --

column11: -    -  Tip: Heisig later names 赫 "red + red" as incandescent (#2908). Story: "So the boss upbraided you, huh?". "Yep, his mouth was incandescent.  -  To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red).
column12: Un individu rouge de colère, la bouche en sang, marquée doublement de rouge, est le signe d'une menace certaine.   --

Ce kanji se rapporte à ce qui concerne un interlocuteur, s'opposant à « ici » de 491. Nous y verrons un grand contenant, comme le suggèrent les deux pattes du bas et leur barre de renfort. Imaginons-y une grande malle rangée dans le grenier, et en y trouvant des tas de bricoles, nous nous demandons ce que tout « cela » peut bien être.  --  Notre sésame sera parfois une grande malle ou un interlocuteur, en accord avec notre description.

column11: Water . . . precious.  -    -  Man continues to defile precious water and it may prove to be his downfall (Think of Exxon, BP, etc.).  -  ...Faramir and Frodo watched the tiny creature far below. "Shall we shoot him?" Faramir asked. "This Gollum has defiled the waters of the Forbidden pond, looking for his Precious, and for that the penalty is death"...
column12: Il s'agit de la disparition d'un système établi de longue date. Les richesses partent à vau-l'eau.  --

column6: mortar; bone joint socket; Kangzi radical 134
column11: The image here is of back-to-back staples. The mortar referred to in this key word is a stone or wooden basin used for grinding with a pestle.  -    -  I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust.  -  The mortar bomb exploded, ripping the sun in half.
column12: On constate souvent que cet élément est substitué par , les anciens temps, ceux du vieillard de 59 qui retombe en enfance. Ces deux kanjis représentent en effet la même chose : la fontanelle d'un nouveau-né, qui évoque une sorte de mortier.  --

column6: land impregnated with salt from the tide
column11: -    -  Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron.  -  I stapled both sides of some tail feathers to a waterfall towering over the lagoon to give it a more tropical feel…　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　RTK2:　On list of rare or no official Chinese reading.
column12: Ce lagon est une sorte d'énorme mortier bordé par l'eau de l'océan ; les plumes de queue désignent les oiseaux migrateurs qui y transitent.  --

column11: Mortar . . . soil . . . missile.  -    -  To "break the soil" is to make a symbolic gesture that indicates the beginning of construction. Like when a politician in a hardhat gets a shovel and lifts a piece of dirt. This particular project is behind schedule, so to speed things up, they blow it up with mortar and an air-to-ground missile.  -  Place your mortar on solid ground before firing missiles from it, otherwise it will break.
column12: Ce mortier placé sur la terre est prêt à frapper fort, et convoie le sens de destruction.   --  Chapitre quarante-six  Position  LES composants que nous abordons concernent la position et la disposition des choses. La classification devient arbitraire, car nous approchons de la fin de notre réserve de composants et nous disposons de moins en moins de kanjis à classer mais l'usage de ces composants vous les fera aisément retenir, tout comme les précédents.

column6: moreover, also (post-subject); about to, will soon (pre-verb)
column11: -    -  Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later.  -  Same as darg_sama. Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think "Whew! It´s over." ... but the person says "... and wait, there´s "moreover" !", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf.
column12: La représentation pictographique d'une étagère paraît claire. Elle ne diffère de l'œil que par le dernier trait, allongé pour le rendre plus stable. De plus suggère un rajout à ce qui existe déjà, comme l'étagère rajoute de la surface à celle existante.   --  * En accord avec cette construction, notre sésame sera une étagère.

column11: Flags . . . strung together . . . missile.  -    -  Mr. President in his palace, ordering missiles to be fired at a harmless enemy in order to unite us together under the flag.  -  Mr. President! We all stand here together under a national flag. One thing is certain: we´ll never give in. We are launching nuclear missiles now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.
column12: Fesses...attachés...frapper fort. Ce kanji se rapporte au palace où vit sa majesté et à la majesté elle-même. Les deux finissent par former une seule entité possédant assez de force de frappe pour réussir ses entreprises, et pour laquelle les fesses...ensemble représentent l'abondant personnel au service de sa majesté.  --  Chapitre quarante-sept  Lignes  LE groupe que nous abordons est composé de caractères dont les composants sont regroupés en raison de leur forme plutôt que leur signification. Chacun d'entre eux est formé de carrés et de lignes croisées. Alors même que cela aurait pu porter à confusion auparavant, nous connaissons désormais suffisamment de composants pour apprendre ces nouveaux éléments sans risque.

column11: Donburi is a bowl of rice with eel or meat on it. The character is a pictograph, perhaps designed by someone who felt that the portion of meat he was served with his bowl of rice looked to be no more than a tiny drop in the well.  -    -  A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!  -  I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.
column12: Le donburi est un bol de riz surmonté d'un tout petit bout de viande ou de poisson, que l'on place en dernier sur le dessus, et c'est ce que raconte le kanji, y compris pour ce qui concerne l'écriture : la goutte est tracée en dernier.   --

column11: Tree . . . tome.  -    -  A palisade is a "fence of stakes especially for defense," usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.  -  An army of scholars build a wooden palisade to protect their precious tome of literature.
column12: Derrière sa clôture en bois, le gardien compte les livres qui passent, et il finit par s'endormir.  --

column11: Mouth . . . dog tag.  -    -  The scaredy-cat soldier puts his dog tags in his mouth and suckles them nervously. It sounds like he's a suckling infant.  -  suckle: this mother had heptuplets. Wow! But she had to put dog tags on the mouths of her babies to keep track of which ones had been suckled.
column12: Les jeunes mammifères doivent être allaités ; ils passent un temps dans une sorte de pépinière, ce que nous appelons un jardin d'enfants en français.  --

column6: area; district; city; state; Kangxi radical 163
column11: -    -  "The city walls are beautifully built. High above you, shows you the famous mouths of former city mayors, all smiling down at you, integrated into a total mosaic making the city walls a unified beautiful work of art."  -  "I stand outside the city walls, requesting permission to enter. The guard hands me a Rubik's cube and tells me ill only be allowed in after I fit the whole thing in my mouth..."
column12: Sur la carte, le bourg montre un certain nombre de quartiers juxtaposés, formant une sorte de mosaïque. Dans la réalité, le bourg contient de nombreux habitants, représentés par la bouche qui symbolise les âmes, la population.  --  *  Inclus dans d'autres kanjis, ce kanji prendra la forme , toujours placée à droite. Placée à gauche, la même forme porte le sens du plus haut point d'un village, notre tertre, mais à droite, elle représentera notre bourg.

column11: Sword . . . two . . . city walls. Used classically to indicate an interrogative part of speech, this character is used chiefly now for its sound.  -    -  If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they´ll let you in.  -  Interrogation at the city walls: "Any weapons, question mark." "Just a blade." "Why the two scratches on the blade, question mark." "To remind me that I cut off my other ear too, exclamation mark (exclamation (#2680)).".
column12: Sabre...deux...bourg. Dans le bourg, chaque patron de maisonnée possède deux sabres : le sien, propre, et un second, celui de la maisonnée.  --

column6: the sides of a boat, bulwarks; a gunwale
column11: Boat . . . mysterious.  -    -  The gunwale is perhaps the most mysterious part of a boat for it is neither a gun nor a whale.  -  Gunwale (rhymes with "tunnel") is the top edge of the side of a boat, for example the widened lip on the sides of a canoe. The mysterious origin of this part of a boat comes from the strengthened sides of warships that used artillery (it means "gun ridge").
column12: De chaque bord du bateau on voit le sombre de la mer, ou les mystères qu'elle recèle.  --

column12: Notre bateau a perdu sa proue et son gouvernail ; abandonné dans un lieu perdu, il a pris la couleur de la rouille. Tout cela nous explique le tracé basé sur les éléments qui nous sont connus mais si vous retournez le dessin, vous reconnaîtrez un creuset au fond duquel se trouve un reste de cinabre.  --

column11: Tree . . . crown tied around leg of person.  -    -  The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. "If I´m gonna be sleeping with the fishes," he said, "can I at least have a pillow? I´m real sensitive." The mafia bosses laughed. "Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow.  -  WOODEN PILLOWS do not sink (#1888) in water.
column12: Nous sombrons dans le sommeil en écrasant l'oreiller, et c'est ce que nous dit ce kanji.   --

column11: Ice . . . wife.  -    -  His wife has a nifty way of making all types of ice cream in her home freezer.  -  Sugoi! Sugoi! Ice Wife Sugoi!
column12: Cette épouse, terrible, nous glace d'effroi. Le sens figuré existe en japonais comme en français, et cela adoucit le sens du mot.  --

column11: Barley . . . mask.  -    -  There is a certain restaurant in West-Shinjuku that serves its noodles made of BARLEY in a MASK instead of a plate. I love these theme-restaurants!  -  I always eat barley noodles with a mask on - it stops them splashing in your face.
column12: La technique de préparation des pâtes alimentaires permet de créer une grande surface à partir d'une pâte faite de céréales.  --

column11: The flag here has an extra vertical stroke in it. Think of it as an eyebrow pencil stuck in the eye.  -    -  The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.  -  Pictograph: opera glasses over eyes ビ ミ まゆ.
column12: Au-dessus de l'œil se dessine une sorte de petit drapeau double, le sourcil.  --

column11: Field . . . hairpin.  -    -  I was a little apprehensive before brain surgery, and when the surgeon took my brain out and stuck it atop a hairpin, my apprehensions were confirmed! Put my brain back right away, I bellowed. 畏まりました！ said the surgeon. (thanks Meconium).  -  I ran out of Q-tips...then I noticed a hairpin lying on the counter that was about the same size as a Q-tip. I was apprehensive at first, but I thought "what the hell". Unfortunately I ended up stabbing my brain!
column12: Cette cordialité représente l'aptitude à vivre en bonne intelligence. Notre pince à cheveux est un symbole de bonne présentation, et au-dessus le cerveau représente la tête bien faite.  --

column6: first day of lunar month; the north
column11: -    -  "On the first day of the month a mountain goat lets out a ""Baah"" as it jumps over the moon."  -  The female mountain goat can only give milk on one day of the month: on the first day of the month. Her milk cycles are controlled by the moon.
column12: Le premier jour du mois, la lune change de forme, passant du dernier au premier quartier, on la voit donc se retourner comme un chamois dans le ciel.  --

column11: Mountain goat . . . moon . . . road.  -    -   On the first day of the month, all the salmon go upstream, up the road, to the mating grounds.   -  In this kanji we see a mountain goat that decided to go upstream along a road, but for some reason it will only go upstream when the full moon is up. It's actually stubborn like a mountain goat about not going upstream along the road at any other period of time. The road itself is also very confused about this.
column12: Le premier du mois nous remontons au début sur le chemin de la numération. Il s'agit de remonter la pente, le fil du temps ou du courant.  --

column11: Learning this character will take a little doing. Before we start, it is a good idea to keep the key word distinct from melancholy (Frame 663), with which it combines to create the psychological condition of depression (a metaphor based on the hollow or sinking of the material depression we met in Frame 1421). The picture of gloom begins with a small grove of trees, under which we see a crown made out of used tin cans. Next (the lower half of the kanji) we find a combination that appears only a few times in modern characters and only once in those treated in the volumes of Remembering the Kanji. It is composed of a shovel with a sheaf dotted with small drops on all sides. Think of it as a large scoop shovel attached to the front of a bulldozer, whose driver is singing: ♪ "Bulldozing in the sheaves, bulldozing in the sheaves..." ♪ The drops represent the chaff flying about as the sheaves are tossed about by the heavy machinery. There is someone sitting on the ground alongside, watching as the machinery makes its way around the neighboring farmland - and it's you, wearing your tin-can crown. You feel overwhelmed by the impending doom as the invasion of agro-business draws closer and closer to the grove, the only patch of woods that remains of what once was a vast forest. The whole scene represents a re-shaping of the natural environment that brings the heavy weight of gloom down upon you. A bit much, perhaps, but there are enough elements to allow for any number of other combinations.  -    -  The pixie, wearing a tin can crown, watches from the middle of the grove, the sparkling villain approach. She sits down in gloom wondering if she belongs amongst the trees, for she has never seen such a beautiful shape.  -  The context of gloom here refers to an environmental disaster that humans make. The story begins at a GROVE with TIN CANS shaped like CROWNS which are really soda cans. They belonged to workers who bulldozes (or SHOVELS) lots and lots of SHEAVES with DROPS of its pieces. Afar, a boy is SITTING while watching the workers reSHAPING the environment. His face now has a very gloomy expression.
column12: Nous voyons d'abord un bosquet où traîne une boîte de conserve, résumé des problèmes environnementaux qui nous dépriment, pour ainsi dire. Mais au-dessous, surmontée de la couronne, nous vient la recette miracle qui va nous sauver de cette déprime :  représente des herbes infusant dans un grand récipient placé au-dessus de la louche, et nous voilà ainsi remis en forme. Si vous vous rappelez bien tous les éléments, ce caractère ne vous résistera pas.  --

column11: -    -  A chihuahua with one human leg is understandably not as fast as other chihuahuas.  -  That one-human-legged chihuahua that appeared before the capital in concerning (#1969) is understandably traumatized by the abuse he suffered at the hands of the scientists.
column12: Le sens du caractère a évolué au cours du temps. De nos jours, il signifie raisonnable. Nous voyons une grande personne un peu difforme, avec une jambe tordue et une excroissance, la petite goutte. La société cherche à lui donner une place raisonnable.  --  * Originellement, ce caractère définit une excroissance, une sorte de verrue. Voyons quelqu'un souffrant à la jambe parce qu'une excroissance l'empêche de bien marcher. Cela nous conduit au sésame verrue, excroissance, morceau accolé au reste.

column11: Wooden leg . . . concerning.  -    -  The soccer player was concerned that his peg leg would affect his ability to kick.  -  I kick with my FEET in the CAPITAL of all the ONE LEGGED CHIHUAHUAS. It is such a great fun, since they cannot kick me back! lol.
column12: Le pied est attaché en position de tir. Imaginez un tir de penalty ou la transformation d'un essai pour bien retenir l'aspect presque professionnel de ce coup de pied.  --

column11: Wheat . . . chihuahua with one human leg . . . delicious.  -    -  After a hard day of training, wheat is understandably delicious.  -  After training hard and eating Wheaties for months, you are understandably thrilled to sink your spoon into a delicious hot fudge sundae.
column12: Blé...verrue...quintessence. Il s'agit de nous imprégner de l'essence d'une relation ou de la connaissance, en allant au plus profond. Le blé est un symbole de richesse, et ici c'est la richesse de la connaissance qui nous importe. Nous voyons donc la quintessence des connaissances auxquelles nous consacrons de longues heures jusqu'à ce qu'elles adhèrent comme des verrues à notre esprit.  --

column11: Skunk . . . white . . . human legs.  -    -  Anyone who watched a looney tunes cartoon know those kind of scene : pepe embraces a poor kitty mistaken for a SKUNK and the smell of pepe make the unfortunate girl loose all countenance : she turns WHITE then runs as fast as her LEGS can carry her . So much for cat s dignity and countenance.  -  The shocked countenance on girl's face when Pepe started to hump her white legs.
column12: Nous voyons un masque blanc et des jambes dessous, mais il est recouvert par une tête de blaireau.  --

column11: Eyeball . . . team of horses.  -    -  In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival´s horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death.  -  In Japan, is is considered insulting to look at someone from atop your horse. You have to step down and face people properly.
column12: Plutôt qu'entendre son maître jurer « comme un charretier », le cheval se protège d'une mousseline pour ne rien voir ni entendre.  --

column11: Grove . . . deer.  -    -  Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.  -  Deer are well known for frolicking in groves of trees. However, they are not well known for actually watching where the heck they are bounding about. Here we have a bunch of dead deer bodies that you find at the foot of a mountain. You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. Looks like they hopped through some leaves to their doom.
column12: Cette base d'une montagne nous présente un tableau bucolique où quelques cervidés gambadent dans un bois.  --

column11: -    -  The queen is not happy. "We (majestic plural) are not amused that the hunger for the flesh of the wooly mammoth has caused it's extinction. Poor Charles is particularly upset.  -  The king says "Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf.".
column12: Le lien entre la plèbe, toute cette chair humaine, et les divinités est représenté par une danseuse gracieuse. Il s'agit du pronom de la première personne du singulier, à usage exclusif de l'Empereur.  --

column11: -    -  Pictograph of a stanchion, which includes two vertical posts to restrain cows so they can be milked, with a horizontal stroke showing the number of cows per stanchion: one. A stanchion is a great symbol for the SIGN OF THE COW, since modern, domesticated cows are often stanchioned in barns.  -  77 cows behind a fence.
column12: Le signe du buffle commence par un gros coutelas dont la pointe n'est pas arrondie, puis un plan de travail et enfin le sol. Cela pourrait représenter une cérémonie sacrificielle, mais aussi nous permet de retenir aisément l'ordre d'écriture.  --

column11: Wool . . sign of the cow.  -    -  The sheep had his coat shaven in the winter and a sign of th cow branded on him. column12: Pris d'un accès de pudeur, notre buffle du zodiaque se cache en se recouvrant d'une peau de mouton.  --

(Note: The Japanese dragon has three toes, unlike other Asian dragons. Asian dragons generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a dragon!)."  -  "(insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese Dragon, now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. column11: -    -  My friend's new dangly earrings are interesting--cacti strung together with butterfly cocoons.  -  The criminal refused to be taken along 連 by the police．He just put his hands on his ears and shouted: "I can't hear you!" over and over. column6: even, uniform, of equal length; Kangxi radical 210

column11: -    -  "This is the kanji for the classical form of ""is"". I think Heisig's keyword ""est"" is the old english or latin word for ""is"". The Scorpion this est!"  -  """Est"" is the latin third person singular of the verb ""esse"" (to be) in Latin. So, this word has been chosen to point out that this character is found chiefly in Classical Japanese (also names). I imagine an incredibly haughty Latin Scorpion, looking down at his vast estate and saying ""Mihi est"". This literally mean ""It is to me"" and means ""It's mine"" ... this is gramatically similar to how Japanese express possession too, incidentally."

Being the shogun, the most powerful military leader in all of Japan, it is only fitting that he also have a very large bow to go along with his office. So large in fact, that it was given to him by the god of good luck, Ebisu."
